famovse cronicle oure time called sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common wealth raigne emperour charles fift argumentes ſet euery booke conteyninge ſumme effecte booke following tranſlated latin engliſhe ihon daus ¶ vnto added alſo apology authoure ✚ che sarà sarà ❧ blazon coat arm ✚ right honorable ſingular good lord fraunces earle bedford lord ruſſel one quenes highnes moſt honorable priuy counſel ihon daus daily oratour wiſheth helth peace cō ſolatiō chriſt ieſu thincrele honor digntiy amonges wryters compile bookes knowledge inſtruction others right honorable ſingular good lord thei opinion deſerue beſt common welth commit wrytinge ſtories wherby men maye learne thexamples others ſet eies guide gouern theyr life thinges embrace eſchue iudge matter paſt ſhalbe conſequent end thing come cauſe moſt eloquent orator cicero calleth hiſtory myſtres māners guid light life ſercher vertues driuer away vice many ſuch like goodly title attributeth ſame certenly ther wer euer ſtory written whereof men might reape frute commodity worthy hand practiſed common vſe man life ether worthines ofihargumente concerning ſtate religion common wealth report thing done lately freſh memorye thys ſame work sleidane treateth thenterpriſes men caſuall chaunces thing happen climing higher auauncing minde man vp vnto heauen conſtraineth ſame maruel wō derful prouidence liuing god touching gouernement churche induceth men wonder vnſearchable counſel god almighty hath preſerued ſame ſomany troubleſome ſtormes tempeſtes ful pearil daunger concerninge author dilligence fidelity hath vſed deſerueth doutles highly commēded men ſo much hauing reſpect common wealth regard priuate commodity hath wholy imploid ſelf conſecrate beſt moſt excellent matter maye euerlaſting memory ſaid thucidides ſo deſyrous verity ſo doubtfull ſcrupulous wryting ſtory gaue great ſome monye euen ennemies haue truth matter know thinges went aſſuredly ſame may ſay alſo sleidan ſelfe confeſſeth content go heare ſay common report people hathe fiſhed certenty story common recordes leaſt report men worthy credit herein hath ſpared nether coſt paine although hath wrytten many thinges ſelf hath ſene germany fraunce italy place yet muſte neceſſitye holpen herein eies eares many compact hiſtory ſo many ſeuerall nation place ſo far diſtante one seing therefore thys ſtory ihon sleidane compiled matter ſo ſinguler excellent perfection worthy perpetuall memory j haue thought expediēt ſondry cauſes preſent honoure ſame wel great good wil zeale good lordſhip beareth towards lerninge chriſten religion common wealth natiue country alſo place dignity iudgement al mē moſt worthely called cōſidering ſhalbe neither vnprofitable vnnedeful honor vnderſtand ſtate realmes cōmon welthes tormoils church ſame thing aboundantly ſufficiently appear thend may eaſely knowen place euery matter may found haue ſet beginnyng euery boke ſome argumēt conteining moſt matter compriſed ſame moſt humbly beſeching honour accept ſimple tranſlatiō dedicated good lord ſhip wrytten vtility common coūtry honorable tuition throughe good lordſhips authority tonges euil ſpeakers repreſſed put ſilence others diſpoſed may receiue commodity profit readinge ſame doutleſſe profitable boke hath ben ſetforth thengliſh tong many yeres thus liuing god preſerue increaſe honor ſo repleniſh noble mind light grace holy ſprite perſwade treat quenes highnes moſte honorable ſuch wiſe thinges ther condeſcended agreed vpon may wholy redownd glory god holy name kalendes auguſt anno 1560 ❧ tranſlator boke go forth painful boke thou art longer mine eche man may loke ſhame praiſe thine ſeke thou praiſe thanke yet reward eche man pleaſe haue thou great regard labor hath bene mine trauell paine reproches ſhalbe thine beare muſt fain yet hath ſtudy bene profit others mo men thereby win truſt ſhalbe ſo pleaſure many haue bene euer glad right ſo diſpleaſe wold loth ſad thou pleaſe beſt ſuch ſkill paſſe reaſt good men accept good thou mightſt remaine ſo eſchue blame ſince thou wouldſt ſo faine gon goe god name ¶ moſt excellent prince auguſtus prince electour duke saxon lantzgraue turing marque meiſſen high mareſchall thempire ſinguler good lord ihon sleidane wiſheth health diuers author moſt excelleut prince haue ſetforth vnto v many ſondrye alteration kingdomes god ſelf wold ſhuld taught theſe thinges mouth long ſhoulde come paſſe thoſe foure greate monarchyes worlde theyr greate aulteration ſucceſſion taughte v prophette daniell whoſe prophecy mooſte parte alreadye made euidente manifeſt vnto v wyth certaine knowledge moſt pleaſaunt ful conſolation alteration contention ſhoulde relygion doctrine ſame prophet hathe ſpoken paule comminge prophecieth alſo manifeſtlye ſorte ſame ſhalbe ſetforth declared mo one two howe alteration hath chaunced time moſt notable others romain empire whyche ſhould laſt alſo much greater reſt prophet ſaid ſhuld deuided brought huge vnmeaſurable great quantity right ſmall thing manifeſt whiche conſiſteth within limites germany hathe bene manye time great haſard daunger partly reaſon domeſticall euils partly throughe faction forain enemy length god hath geuen v ſuch emperour mighty hath bene theſe many hondreth yeres vnto haue deſcended mooſte ample realmes prouinces moſt ritch welthy ſo alſo mooſte commodious thinges ſondrye place bothe ſea lande like ſelf excelleth power emperor germanye haue bene ſence tyme charles great ſo alſo reaſon thinges haue chaunced time gouernment moſt famous notable amonges thinges alteration religion hath chiefeſt place whiche beginninge raigne toke originall time whan emperour maximilian departed preſent life matter ben hand aboue xiiii monthes time prince electours choſe manne emperour manner ſelf ſame time luther beinge prouoked came forthe reaſon matter diſputed openly eckius lipſia fell men theyr ſtudy ether ſide wherefore thempire man ought conſidered dilligentlye waied memory former time god hath euery time ſtirred vp certain great prince table thā reſt whē ether ſtate religion comon welth ſhuld altred ſort cirus alexander macedonie iulius caeſar conſtantine charlemaigne alſo ottous saxonie ſpeake charles fift certenly alteratiō ſuch ſort wherof make mention man knoweth thing perfectly thinck theof without great maruel wonder beginning ful ſmall manner contemned one man alone ſuſteined malice violence world yet might ſelf haue ben appeaſed quieted caſe aduerſaries would haue taken condition beginning offred promiſed kepe ſilence ſo would like refuſed preſcribed recantation herein perſeuered ſaid vnleſſe could firſt ſhewe erroure coulde chaung opinion diſſention increaſed matter brought counſell thempire come ſuch great maner ſe meanes came ſo pa thing biſhops rome vniuerſities king prince haue tempted ſelf hath pleaded cauſe themperour counſell prince diuers men excellent learning haue ioyned ſelues howe matter hath ben debated thaſſembles thempire howe meanes reconcilement haue bene aſſaid oftentimes biſhops rome haue bene hand emperour kinges oft haue put hope reformation counſel perſecution burning ther hath ben league conſpiracies haue hen made ſame religiō hath ben ſetforth germany place alſo diuers haue reuolted others remained conſtant tumultes warres battels haue riſen occaſion theſe ſay ſo great ſondry thing leaue vnſpoken commit memory wryting think ther man would iudge blame worthy moreouer paſſed ouer ſilence ſtate common wealthe man empire ſpace ſix thyrty yeres war hath kept commotion tumultes haue ben meane ſeaſon thing haue chaunced realmes prouinces neuertheleſſe thordre argumente ſhalbe obſerued hereafter ſhalbe declared like emperor raigneth ouer moſte large ample dominion ſo hath alſo moſt ſtrong puiſſant enemy wherfore matter haue ben wonderful great haue chaunced memorye duringe raigne thys emperor therfore certen yeres paſt diuers worthy wel lerned men chanced talke ſuch matter began perſwade whoſoeuer chanced theſe dais eſpecially touching cauſe religion ſhuld put wrytinge vnto dyd exhort could beſt ther wer others much mete purpoſe becauſe ſaw delite much ſame kinde exerciſe therefore ſuppoſed acerten natural inclination thing ſhould beſtow time labor amiſſe ſelf doubtleſſe knew wel enough daungerous ſea muſte enter caſe required maner man endued greater wit eloquence albeit almoſt deſpair could bring thing paſſe yet vanquiſhed theyr auchority opinion determined aſſay thing beginning time luther began inuey againſt ſelling pardon brynging matter ſtill vnto diſputation lipſia appoynted duke george ſame hadde ſo compoſed ſente vnto ſetters woormes time counſel thempire ten yeres paſt read peruſe ouer afterward letter mouth alſo importune ſhould procede longe ther chaunced ſorowfull time germany whan aroſe warre great let hindraunce ſtudy learning ſo alſo diſturbe let purpoſe doings nether could procede deſired many time muſt tarye make delay ſo ſone relieued thoſe euils eſpecially thoſe iii yeares paſte imploide ſtudy trauel herein neuer reaſted till came thend wiſhed ſurely worke made chiefly principally concerning religion neuertheleſſe obſeruynge order thought good alſo put polliticke matter touching whole narration ſort euery man reading ſhall eaſely perceiue nothing becommeth history better truth ſidelity doubtleſſe leaſt man ſhould finde lacke behalf haue traueled diligently haue written nothinge lighte reportes hear ſay haue compiled worke publick record haue gathred vp dilligently verity wherof man nodeth dout alſo aid helpe worthye noble man lame sturmie hath ben occupied publicke waighty affaire theſe xxx yeres mo commendation gentlenes ſhewinge frendſhip whan ſomtime doubted ſticked faſt rockes ſhelues expert ſailer many time brought right courſe void dāgers moſt part work red ouer requeſt ſickneſſe wherof died admoniſhed diligently ſuche thing wer nedeful alſo much mention made forein matter eſpecially french engliſhe therein haue alſo folowed ſame ordre haue put nothing tried certenly knowne french matter moſt part ſelf haue ſene theſe ix yeres dwelt ther diuers execution burning whereof mention made many decree made action commenced diuines paris againſte certen miniſters church ſhortly article religion ſetforth faction court chaunced ſame time whan thoſe party warlike matter ſuche like affaire omit mighte wiſe yet haue profeſſed treat expreſly ſaid little laboure purpoſed chiefly cauſe religion therfore wold haue reader warned whan ſhal come vnto ſuch place loke long diſcourſe thoſe affaire nether mine intent may read men work haue taken hand wryte part ſo much herein ſhalbe wanting thing ſaid obſerued hiſtory fidelity vprightnes wit nothing told affection although ſome harde becauſe performed albeit perauenture ſhall perſwade men haue ben dilligently ware ſame yet require inſtantly burthened ſuſpition cauſe worke mine wholy compiled ſayde publick recordes collected great dilligence wherof alſo great part ſetforth print partly latin partly vulgare ſome italian ſome alſo french hath many oration demaunds anſwers diuers accuſations conſutations alſo theſe thinges recite plainly ſimply truely euerye thinge done neither adde thing mine ſpeak mine iudgement leaue reader free neither vſe alſo collour rhethorick wryte thing hatred fauor man frame ſtile vſe mine word ſpeache may alwaies like equal beſtow eche thing place followed ordre thoſe firſt yeres biſhop leo adrian ſpake many thinges bitterly againſte luther whoſe wrytinges take away nothing ſo likewiſe adde nothing vnto luther anſwers neyther make complainct worſſe yet defence better biſhops ſucceded thē clement paule man eſpecially whan luther dostrine ſpred abroade farre neare making digreſſion perſon haue inueyed moſt ſpitefully againſt prince alſo city follow ſame ordre throughout whole volumne kepe ſelf ſame trade wherfore beſeche reader lay part diſliking know firſte matter ſelf tender laboure hath ſurely bene great theyr good wil fauor certenly vnleſſe ſame cauſes moued write firſt eftſones allured procede deuour tediouſnes long ſince forſaken enterpriſe ther appeared ſo great variety much ſtomack ſtrength came firſt becauſe ſuppoſed ſame ſhuld concern glory god opened time omnipotency wonderful counſel comon vtility moued euen germany remember thing paſt forain nation know certenty many mennes mindes diſpoſed diſlikinges thinck farre otherwiſe many matter ought furthermore reſpect posterity leaſte wiſe wrytinges may abide light continuaunce beſides alſo many thing like fort others put wryting nether truely modeſtly ther one natiō ſetforth boke vi yeres ſince mentz moſte full lie ſlaunders triſling rayling wordes theſe laſt yeares paſt came forth two tome florence authour wherof handleth dede moſt larg ample wiſe history time wherſo euer ſpeaketh germain matter eſpecially concerning relegion bewraieth diſeaſe mind thing vntrue falſe ſclaunderous ſo euer wryteth may euidently proued omit ſo manye oration epistle preface whiche ſetforthe • rinte whan touch theſe matter handle thing hatred mallice ſwarue alſo moſt far truth theſe cauſes ſay thought good proceade permit ordre actes done ſhould vntruely ſet ether preſent age el time come kind thing vile le ſuffred thā ſame thing ſhuld make reader expert ſhuld wyth falſe tale lie depraued aſſuredly magiſtrate ought foreſee nothyng done herein licentiouſly thys faulte vſed oure dayes verye manye thoſe wryters ſeke pike thanke whileſt ind • uour pleaſe gratifye one man deſerue euil many induce mo errour doutleſſe part whiche yet would ſhuld ſpoken without ostentation ſo affected herein knew ther wer anye thing work vntruely wrytien ſelf wold ſcrape ſame frankly warn reader ſhould geue credit truſt aſſuredly vntruthe obiected ſtudy paine dilligence haue taken theſe certen yeres might know eche thing exactly manye good men witneſſe trust alſo thing ſelf ſhall declare notwithstanding although compriſe thoſe thinges haue chaunced thys emperor gouernement al yet aliue hath gouernment although many thynges mo yet may fortune day yet forſomuch theſe former actes chalenge firſt chiefest greateſt part vnto wold ſame ſhould longer wanting ſo many learned men germany alſo foreine nation inſtantly requiringe wold gratify herein comming doubtleſſe moſte greuous commotion wonderful alteration thing alſo holy scripture dothe nether doubtfullye daroklye prognoſticate preſent state thinges doth plainly ſignify ſo ſuch applye theyr minde vnto ſhall want matter wryte ſame cauſe moued wryte publicke vtility ſelf ſame perſwadeth nowe alſo ſome thinges haue written compriſed theſe xxvi bookes ſhoulde ſuffer come abrode others men handes labor pain taken wil dedicate whole vnto mooſie excelient prince whiche deſcended noble houſe familie whiche fyrſto gaue harborow refuge thys religion whoſe father earneſtly imbrace ſame whoſe brother education youth true religion learning imploied wonderful ſubstaunce whoſe father law ſelf ſame cauſe hath famous name among kinges ſo much alſo walke theſe theyr foteſteps great commendation worke hope wil profite many truſt alſo vnpleaſaunt liuing god preſerue highnes ſafe healthful geuen x kalends april yeare lord 1555 firſt boke ❧ firſte booke sleidans commentary concerning ſtate religion common wale reigne emperour charles fyfte argument fyrſt booke pardon graunted byſhop leo luther reproueth preachyng wryting propoſicions letter ſent tharchbiſhoppe ments fyrſt unpugned frete tckell eckins silueſter prier hogeſtrate upō pope ſendeth cardinal caietane taduertiſe thēperour maximilian cite luther rome fridericke duke saxon founde meanes luther aunſwered caietane auſpurge cardinal threatenynges thalligations decree mainteyneth thauthoritie ſupremacie pope luther depertynge thence ſet appellation caietane ſolliciteth letter duke saxon vaine whiche pope perceyuing publiſheth new remiſſion ſynnes pardon wynne duke fridericke ſendeth goldē roſe meane tyme dieth maximilian great ſuite meane made taſpire vnto thempire whiche fine charles auſtriche atchieued word ſent spaine golden bulle lawes thempire recited eraſmus commendeth luther ſame time diſputacion lipſia zwinglius preached zuricke luther reſiſteth perdoner one samſon agraye frere biſhoppe rome leo tenth name florentine borne vſurped auethoritie predeceſſours pretēded haue ouer church ſent forth al realmes vnder bulles lead indulgēces pardōs wherein promyſed cleane remiſſyon ſynnes euerlaſtynge ſaluation ſuche would gyue money ſame leuiyng wherof ſent collectours prouinces gathered together heaped vp great treaſures place ſpeciallye germanie affirmed doynges good bothe wordes writyng pardon papiſtes call olde accuſtomed terme indulgence grauntyng moreouer money licence eate whitmeat fleſhe day prohibited ſame time martin luther auguſtine frere profeſſed diuinitie uniuerſitie wittemberge beynge little tickled preachinges fonde bokes theſe collectours ſawe howe ſimple people beleued thinges true bragged began admoniſhe men ware circumſpecte bie marchaundiſe ſo dere ſame beſtowed vpon ſuch trifle might much better emploied yeare lorde thouſande fiue hondreth ſeuentene thintent might woorke thynge effect wrote alſo archebyſhop mentz firſte nouembre ſignifying taught alſo lamenting ignoraunt luther letter b mentz people ſhould ſo far abuſed put whole truſt ſaluation pardon thinke wickednes ſo euer committed ſhould forgeuen ſoules tormented purgatory ſo ſoone mony caſt boxe ſhould ſtraight wayes flie vp heauen fele payne ſheweth chriſt cōmaunded goſpell ſhould taught propre office byſhop ſee people rightly inſtructed wherfore putteth remē braunce dutie prayeth authoritie whiche beareth would eyther put thoſe prattelinge pardoner ſilence el preſcribe better order teachinge leſt inconuenience might growe vpon ſame doubtles wil doo vnleſſe inhibited cauſe wrote vnto ſo muche alſo byſhop maydenburg care al ſuch matter b maydē burg charge belonged vnto theſe letter ſent certen queſtiōs whiche lately ſet vp wittenberg diſputed nombre foure ſcore fiftene whiche reaſoneth muche purgatory true penaunce dutie charitie indulgence luther 95 queſtions wittenberge pardōs large inueigheth againſt rageouſe preachinges certen deſyre boulte trie truth prouoked men come diſputation hadde anye thinge ſaye ſuch could preſent deſyred ſend myndes wrytinge proteſting would affirme nothing ſubmitte ſelfe whole matter iudgement holy churche neuertheleſſe ſayd woulde admitte thomas aquine ſuche lyke writer ſo farre foorth luther exception conſonaunt holy scripture decree auncient father byſhop aunſwered woords ſhortly iohn b mentz clence tecela frere dominick ſet vp concluſions franckford quite contrary thoſe luther wherin extolleth ſupremacie ihon tecell ft concl frankford byſhop rome frute pardōs lyke thinges ſo muche compareth peter apoſtle croſſe whiche commaundeth ſet vp church croſſe chriſt ſuffered vpon man cōtrary parte wold repeare diſputacion wittenberge queſtions ſuche many deſtrous reade luther wrote longe expoſition ſame ſent firſt hierome byſhop braundenburge one stupice prouinciall auſten freres deſiring hym cauſe ſent byſhop rome ſelf moneth iune wrote vnto leo tēth partly complayning pardoner whiche owne auarice abuſed auethoritie partly purging ſelfe knowing ſuertie complayned luters letter pope leo ſame matter affirmyng hym wrong inforced reaſon fonde sermōs bokes collectours ſet vp certain queſtiōs ye matter diſputation whiche woulde playnly declare beſeching geue credit ſclaunderous reportes alledging duke fredericke duke frederick wiſdom prince electour saronie man ſuche wiſdome honour caſe ſuche thinges true aduerſaries reported would haue ſuffered countrey beare ſuch infamie vniuerſitie wittenberge lyke conſideration ſo ſubmitted vnto workes lyfe alſo refuſing death ſhould ſeme good vnto whatſoeuer ſhould procede would take oracle flowed chriſte ſelfe amonges others luther aduerſaries iohn eckius wroote echins booke againſt luth little booke againſt ſame tyme whiche luther aunſwereth neyther bringeth scripture hym thinge auncient doctours certein dreames owne receiued ſcoolemen vnallowable euill cuſtome eckius one silueſter prierias freer dominicke maſter silueſter priers dialogue holy palace terme wrote againſt dialoge preface leo tenth right ſtoutelye ſaying woulde proue whether luther ſo inuincible confuted vanquiſhed anſwer thē wil ſet forth greater thinges moſte exacte diligence ſpeaketh vnto luther exhorting amende commeth diſputation propoundeth certain theme byſhop rome head whole silue priers theme churche churche rome firſte chiefeſt others erre matter faythe religion neyther generall counſell erre byſhop roome preſent moreouer holy scripture taketh force authoritie churche byſhop rome moſte certain rule beleueth wyſe heretike foundation one layd beginneth debate matter afterward doth luther luth anſwer sil priers make anſwer ye ſame boke preface silueſter ſaith wōdreth queſtions rather vnderſtādeth ſame takyng example defence cauſe putteth forth alſo certen theme ſuche taken holy ſcripture wherin ſheweth ought geue credit euerye doctrine man way euery thing exactely embrace thing whiche conſonaunt goddes worde none doctrine receiued left v prophetes apoſtles scriptur choldewriters alſo wed although haue neuer ſo goodly apparence neuertheleſſe thautoritie thoſe writer whiche next allowed reſt well ware wryte concerning indulgence lawfull collectours inuente anye newedeuiſe herein followe ſame order canon iudulgences vſed canon lawe law obiecteth alledgeth teſtimony ſcriptur reciteth opinion thomas aquyne treated maner al thing pleaſure without thauthoritie ſcripture wherfore reiecteth affirming doth ſame onely commanndement ſaint paule auſten alſo emōgs ciuilians commonly ſayd lawfull pronounce ciuiliās vſe citing thyng preſcript lawe much leſſe diuine matter ought thing ſuffered ſpokē without teſtimony ſcripture paules precept ſuche appointed inſtruct people ſhould furniſhed syllogiſmes ſondry decree men holſome ſounde doctrine lefte v godly inſpiration ſo muche many haue contemned precepte great blyndnes hath induced innumerable ſorte vnprofitable queſtions hath flowed ouer worlde tyme hath thus made waye commeth confutacion aboute thende therof ſayth howe nothinge affrayed manaſinge wordes ſet forth brauery albeit ſhuld dye therfore yet chriſte liueth immortall vnto whome honoure dewe therfore liſt come trial matter muſt fight ſtronger weapōs el authour thomas lyke goo woorſe againe sylueſter writeth luther aunſwer ſaythe deliteth muche ſubmitteth hym silut prier ſeconde aunſwer luth ſelfe iudgemēt byſhop rome wyſhing alſo ſpake harte vnfainedly luther charged ambition fllatterie purgeth ſelf therof muche may defendeth right ſtoutly doctrine thomas affirming ſuche ſorte receiued approued churche rome ought preferred aboue writinges blameth ſore hath ſpoken ſo worthy man ſo vnreuerently accomptyng honour ſelfe called thomiſte notwithſtanding ſayeth howe hath red men woorkes alſo whiche ſhall hereafter appere preface ſetteth forth little booke wherin cōmendeth exceadinly aucthoritie byſhop rome ſo much clerely preferreth counſelles decree affirminge ſtrength scripture dependeth vpon authoritie thomas comming noble houſe gaue ſelf wholy learning leauing italy went firſt collyn paris proued beſt learned al men time wryting diuers workes whiche treated matter diuinitie philoſophie blacke frere diſciple albertus magnus whan thomas aquine albertus magnus ſcollar dead iohn byſhop rome xxii yt name made ſainct fifty yeāres lefte lyfe great mainteiner byſhop rome authoritie attributed vnto ſupremacie ouer byſhops kynges church vniuerſall thomas aquine ſalt iuriſdictions aſwell ſacred ciuile affirming neceſſary thyng vnto ſaluation men ſubiect vnto hath full authoritie churche appertaineth call thomas aquin geueth authoritie pope counſell confirme decree made moreouer ſayeth howe men may iuſtlyappeale generall counſell finallye aſcribeth vnto thinges onely excepted make newe article faith neither aboliſhe thoſe whiche left v handes apoſtles auncient father iudulgēces pardon wrote muche alſo graunting ſame maketh byſhop rome great prince died ſaide 1274 thom aq died yeare lorde athouſand two hundreth thre ſcore fortene cōmonly called thangelical doctor ſubtiltie witte booke sylueſters luther aunſwereth onlye epiſtle luth ſeconde anſwer silueſter prier reader ſaying ſo compacte altogether lye terrible blaſphemies god holy name ſhould appeare deuyl himſelfe aucthour therof wherfore byſhops cardinalles ſame opinion ſuche doctrine taughte rome ſeat antechriſt rome longer doubted rome ſeate antechriſt happy grece happie lande grece bohemes happines boheme yea fortunate thoſe haue made diuorcement wt miſerable haue doe ſame wherfore vnleſſe biſhop ſee puniſhed compell recante lut forſakīg rome proteſteth wil diſſente frō forſake church rome alſo take henceforth moſt filthy ſynke puddell wickednes daylye inuented newe prayſes byſhop rome ſuche lyke haue heard ſubtile ende craftie polycie lawful counſell ſhould take place therfore flatterer preferre aboue al counſels affirme vnderſtanding scripture muſt fetched cauſ wh • ye rome extold hande mooſte certen iudge wherefore holde madnes iuggelinge caſtes mocke worlde ſorte remedy noone ciuile magiſtrate muſt ſe puniſhed theues murtherers ſuch malefactours puniſhed death great deale prince neceſſitie muſt reforme ro right theſe whiche muche hurthfull enemy common wealth ſhould common aſſent trauell men ſupſuppreſſed biſhop rome ſame ſtate al mē biſhop rome bounde god commaundement leſſe bounden obſeruation goddes commaundementes pooreſt man liuing ſuch teache otherwyſe greateſt iniury may diuine maieſtie ſame tyme alſo iames hogeſtrate blackfreer wrote againſt luther full bitterly exhorting byſhop rome fyre iames hogeſtrate wrote againſt luther ſworde whome luther aunſwering fewe wordes reproueth cruell bloudy mynde ſcoffing merely man ignoraunce admoniſhing ſo procede chiefeſt way wyn true fame tyme man blamed vnlearned euil men byſhop leo handes ſaith looketh better thinges whileſt theſe matter thus handled either parte maner ſcolemē themperour maximiliā calleth aſſemblie auſputg thaſſembly auſputge maximilian whether alſo leo tenthe ſendeth afterwarde ambaſſadour thomas caietane cardinall aſſemblie preſent ſeuen prince electours ſo called bycauſe haue authoritie electe create themperour treated warre againſte turke solyman emperour turkes hauing lately ſubdwed sultane conquered syria egipte wherfore cardinall made exhortacion promyſing maiſters name treaty warre againſt turke treaſures churthe employde vpon warre required herein ayde aſſiſtaunce maximilian defendoure churche ſelfe ſame tyme leo tenth created albart archebyſhop mentz cardinall aſſemblie cōmaundeth caietane cōſecrate ceremony rytes accuſtomed albert archb mentz mabe cardinall whiche thing doone accordingly themperour leadeath home newe cardinall churche ſendeth preſentes ſaye princelyke horſelitter wythe horſes manye ryche coſtly hangynges byſhop rome gaue alſo hat ſet golde pearle precious iwels ſwoorde gylt ſkabarde moſte part al biſhoppes germany wel ciuile eccleſiaſticall magiſtrates howbeit thoughte cauſe cardinalſhip leo preferred dignitie theude church rome myght haue defendour germany ſuche oue nobilitie birth authoritie alſo right famous lyke vnto man could founde beſydes noble houſe brandenburg archebyſhop mentz chiefeſt prince electours conſull euer albeit byſhops bondē byſhop rome yet ſuch made cardinalles muche bonden maximilian aduertiſed controuerſie luther maximilians lettre pope leo cōcerning luther moneth auguſt writeth letter byſhop roome ſignifiyng hath heard ſorte luther hath reaſoned many matter preached alſo ſome thinges ſeme hereticall ſory defendeth doctrine ſtyfly hath many fauorers opinion emonges whiche diuers hygh eſtate exhorteth hym therfore hyghe authoritie beareth would abolyſhe ſuche idle vnprofitable queſtions inhibite ſophiſticall contencions wordes ſo much applie ſtudy way little hurt chriſtē cōmon weale intent thing whiche haue learned ſhould bee prayſed receyued men alledging tyme paſt great diligence ſhewed appoyntinge ayt preacher intent ye al sophiſticall contention myght eſchewed howbeit order lyttle lyttle felle cōtempt ſo maruell ſuche ſhould haue taught others haue oftentimes erred thē ſelues cauſe therof ſomuch auncient writer interpretours holy ſcripture haue long tyme layde ſyde filled full lye maye bee imputed alſo ſo muche contention reyſed theſe oure day matter learnyng laſte daungerouſe controuerſie pardon certeinly weightines thinge requireth remedie betyme leſt diſeaſe runne farre delaye daunger ſo euer ſhall determine therin ſame wyll allowe ſee ſhall take place throughout partes thempire mencion made howe luther sylueſter wroote one againſt nowe office rome ſo aggrauated luther matter leo cited tappeare rome luther cited rome vnder great penaltie afterwardes xxiij day auguſt wryteth letter caietane ambaſſadour germany ſignifiyng howe aduertyſed luther holdeth certein opinion wycked againſt iudgement churche roome whiche maiſtres faith religion fatherly loue deſyrous repreſſe raſhenes hath geuen commaundement hierome byſhop aſcula vnto whome thing properly apperteyneth ſomone hym rome might aunſwere matter charged might alſo make declaraciō fayth byſhop aſcula executed commaundemēt comme amendement ſtubbernly perſiſtinge hereſy ſet forth muche peſtilent workes great grief vexation mynde wherfore let fynde meanes may brought auſpurge herein requiring ayde emperour prince germany whā brought thither apprehēded ſent rome wherfore repent owne accorde deſyre remiſſion offence let hym pardoned reſtored churche whiche neuer wont exclude true penitent let excommunicated commaundeth moreouer men ſhall obeye theſe letter ſhall otherwyſe eccleſiaſticall perſones confiſcateth goodes promotion therwith taketh awaye hope poſſibilitie obtaine hereafter others ciuile office depriued al honour office commodity finally want chriſten buriall vnto thoſe ſhall dooe faithfull ſeruice herein pleaſure ſhall haue eyther common ful remiſſion ſinnes haue alſo ſome rewarde geuen thē precept byndeth men emperour excepted wyſe wylleth mās fredome priuilege ſhuld force herein ſame day alſo writeth frederick duke pope letter duke saxō saxon ſame tyme auſpurg howe emonge ornamentes houſe sarony euer propre vnto greatly fauour religion wherfore ſayeth lyke noble familie ſhould ſo farre degenerate elder mayntayne man would impugne ſame notwithſtanding harde dayly greuous cōplaintes martin luther bearyng ſelfe highly prince fauour forgetting ordre profeſſion doth many thinges wickedly againſt churche regarding authoritie mā albeit doubteth braggeth prince fauoure falſelye yet thought good wryte vnto herein admoniſhe euer myndefull owne honour dignitie aunceſtours myght eſchewe crime ſelfe alſo leſt ſuſpicion ſame ſayeth well aſſured teacheth manye wicked peſtilent hereſies whiche maiſter palace haue dylygently noted ſame verely cauſe hath cited hym appere rome written cardinall caietane ambaſſadour would haue furthermore donne matter ſo muche matter religion doeth appertaine properlye churche rome examine euerye man faythe requyreth hym neuertheleſſe chargeth commaundeth hym beynge requeſted vnto ambaſſadour doe endeuoure brynge paſſe luther maye bee delyuered cuſtodye wherein ſhall bothe dooe god hygh ſeruice alſo thynge ſhall hym ſelfe hys familie ryght honourable caſe ſhall bee founde faulte hym whan ſhall examined roome maye retourne home ſafe ſounde caſe bee founde crime worthie puniſhemēt ſhal duke whiche wold longer ſuffer ſuch peſtilēt fellow clere al blame part ſuch clemēcie yt neither wold oppres innococent exclude fauour one willyng amende thus ſought meanes poſſible oppreſſe luther pope letter gabriel veneius ſame yeare moreouer wrote vnto gabriel prouinciall thauſtine fryer ſhould ſpedely ſeke redreſſe martin luther frier vnder iuriſdiction ſoweth newe opinion germany quickly quenche flamme newly kyndled leſt proces tyme takyng force ſtrengthe paſte remedy ſo ſet fyre diſeaſe increaſeth dayly neyther thynge ſo much feared delaye therfore muſt applye thynge ſtudy labour deuiſe diligence ſo muche hathe authoritie ouer hym whan luther perceiued ſelfe cited rome laboured muche haue matter heard germany ſome indifferent iudges place ſubiect iniury coulde meanes bryng paſſe vniuerſitie wittenberge letter vniuerſitie wittenberg writeth luther byſhop rome written xxv septembre gaue hym maruelouſe good reporte lyfe learnyng ſaye howe cited rome certain queſtions howbeit reaſon ſickenes daunger lyfe notable beſeche hym haue none opinion good man propownded certen thinges diſpute determine whiche aduerſaries haue interpreted woorſe parte haue exaſperated ye matter proteſte howe wyll admitte nothinge againſt churche requeſted luther coulde geue hym teſtimony whiche beſeche geue credit theſe letter ſende others alſo charles meltice germaine chamberlaine byſhop leo vnto whome declare luther without deſertes brought great hatred byſhop ſo muche cited rome could yet fynde ſo muche fauour cauſe might herde germany ſaye howe ſo affected toward religion alſo towardes holy churche rome caſe cryme wicked errour luther would beare man ſuche learnyng honeſtie lyfe hath ſo well deſerued whole vniuerſitie faile caſe neyther would duke frederick ſo faithful wittie prince vnleſſe iudged honeſt mā ſuffer ſo long vnpunyſhed wherfore require fauour eſtimacion yt hath byſhop would bryng paſſe ſome indifferēt iudges might appointed rome germany doubte declare ſelfe lyke chriſten man good diuine hath raſhely without cauſe ſought occaſion ſtrife require earneſtly ſo muche haue conceiued greater hope whiche germain ſelfe wil naturally coūtrie ſake ſo honeſt matter helpfull germaine maner oppreſſed daunger lyfe beſydes interceſſion frendes duke fredericke deuiſed ſo cardinall auſpurge luther ſhould nede trauayle rome ſhould come pleed luther called auſpurg cauſe caietane comming thether begynnyng october remayned thre dayes ſpake cardinall duke friderick gone homewarde aduiſed frendes come cardinalles fyght emperour maximilian graunted ſaufe conduicte whiche obtayned gently receyued cardinal ſayd would contende diſputacion frendly appeaſe controuerſy according byſhops roomes commaundemente propoundeth two thinges firſt ſhould come amē dement reuoke ſuche errours publiſhed ſecondlye henceforth abſtayne ſuche wrytinges diſturbe trā quillitie churche hereunto doeth luther make aunſwer priuie errour hath erred thyng deſyreth conferens cardinal caietane maye ſhewed wherein cardinall chargeth hym affirmeth queſtions howe merites oure ſauioure chriſte conſiſte treaſures pardon whiche ſentence ſaith againſt decree clemēt ſyxte moreouer vnto thoſe come receiue sacramēt faith ſhould neceſſary wherby myght aſſured ſynnes forgeuen neyther true ſayeth cardinall luther aunſwered read decree byſhop ſhewed mynde touching ſame mention made thomas aquine affirmeth authoritie scripture preferred farre aboue hym cardinall extolling byſhop rome authoritie preferreth aboue scripture counſelles recityng howe coū ſell whiche determined contrary abrogated condemneth alſo gerſon paris fauourers opinion contrariwyſe luther denieth authoritie byſhop aboue coū ſell alledging emonges others diuines paris opiniō long diſputacion could agree luther aſketh ſome deliberation next day retourneth preſence secretary certain witneſſes foure alſo emperours counſell proteſteth beareth dew reuerence holy churche rome haue ſpoken thyng againſt ſame wyll haue ratified howbeit much admoniſhed commaundeth forſake errours abſtayne henceforth ſuppoſeth hath ſpoken nothing ſwarueth either holy scripture opinion auncient father decree byſhoppes alſo ryght reaſon yet denye may erre diſceiued ſo may euery man therfore committeth hearing lawfull holy churche referryng whole matter iudgement ſame wil alſo rendre reaſon doctrine place may ſuffiſe wil make aunſwere wryting ſuch argumentes may brought againſt refuſe ſtande iudgement herein vniuerſities germany paris cardinal charged againe done daye decree clement though made muche fine permitteth hym deliuer vp wryting theffect wherof time ſet vp queſtions wrote expoſition ſame 〈…〉 red decree clement mynde therewith ſatiſfied although eſtabliſhed decree byſhop rome ſhould aſwell receiued voyce peter apoſtle yet ought ſo taken muche thei conſonaunt holy ſcripture agreable decree auncient father doubt voyce peter ſacred holy yet ſoore rebuked paule neyther coulde doctrine receiued tofore conſente churche whiche hieruſalem hadde eſtablyſhed wordes men may hearde thinges muſt referred wordes chriſt diſceaued decree againſt ſondrye place scripture cauſe whiche tyme brought ſame queſtion afterwarde affraied make expoſition ſame euer ſynce tyme fully reſolued ſtire vp diſputation concernyng matter rather heare opinion others albeit leuer inſtructed others eſpecially byſhop roome yet muche conſtrained neceſſitie defende owne wyl proue beſt make ſame decree queſtions accorde whan made preface goeth matter ſelfe certain expoſitiō made ſheweth howe decree maketh purpoſe yet ſo would neither biſhoppes authoritie owne eſtimation ſhould therby infringed commeth ſeconde parte hys accuſation alledging purpoſe many place scripture declareth playnly howe faith maketh v iuſt god wherfore deſyreth deale fauourably ſhewe hym errour force thinges whiche alledged ſcriptures ſo muche beleueth ſufficiently groū ded vpon owne truthe whiche forſake ſo much ought rather obey god mē therfore requireth may releaſed harde burthen recantynge came contencion vpon arrogancie deſyre vayn glorie yea would wyſhe nothing truthe might opened man el myght bryng moore learned godly beſeched yt may cōpelled hurt conſcience cardinall receiued wryting offered vnto luther whan red eſtemed lyghtly yet promyſed ſende byſhop rome vrged muche recant vnleſſe ſo doe threateneth puniſhment appointed already byſhop alſo commaundeth ſight vnleſſe amende maners come preſence threatening whiche xvij day octobre luther wrote vnto gentle letter ful good wil dutie caietane thus chidden luther ſent away wrought ſecretly iohn stupice prouincial auguſtine freers ſhuld induce recant accorde wherfore luther ſame letter maketh mention stupice verely omitting nothing becōmeth faithfull frendly man dooe geueth thankes beneuolence towardes whiche perceiueth well talke stupicious wherby doubtles much comforted ſo nowe would gratifie man rather hym graunteth ouer quicke little regarde byſhop rome authoritie howe ſame imputed importunitie collectours deſyreth forgeuen fault promyſeth modeſte hereafter affirmeth alſo wyll ſermons ſatiſfie byſhops requeſt cōcerning indulgence wil ſpeake therof ſo aduerſaries may lykewyſe commaunded ſilence reuoke ſentence already taught defended ſafe conſeience tyll ſuche tyme teſtimonies holy ſcripture cōdemned errour therfore requyreth hearing matter may referred byſhop rome nothing ran dooe hym pleaſure heare voyce churche whan cardinall would make none aunſwere theſe letter manaſed wordes counſell frendes departed thence two dayes leauing behind appellation openlye ſet luther appeleth vp tyme departure euer went wrote agayne cardinall hath done able howe came foote ſickly longe iournaye auſpurg intent might declare dutie towardes byſhop rome nowe hauing litle monye left lothe longer chargeable houſe white freres hoſt dryuen retourne rather abyde ſight hath forboden preſens wherefore freindes maner counſailed appeale biſhoppe ſelfe whiche woulde haue done aduiſe freindes chifely becauſe ſuppoſeth duke friderick alſo rather ſome appellatiō made thinge ſhould raſhely vnaduiſedly reuoked appellation made muche ſort ſame queſtion touching indulgence hath bene diuerſely handled many neuer throughly determined ſuche doubtefull queſtions hath bene alwayes lawfull namely diuines reaſon thing alſo ſelfe ſame time whan certein clamorous pardoner onely write teache raſhely vncircumſpectlye alſo polled people exceadingly yet affirme anye thinge trie trueth committed alſo whole controuerſie iudgemente learned men euen biſhoppe rome pardonars haue inuented ſuch ſclaunders againſt haue complayned ſo ſore byſhoppe brought matter ſuche paſſe laſt matter committed biſhop aſcula sylueſter prierias whō cited rome ſo much theſe wer ſuſpected one thē alſo vnfit iudge ſuch matter moreouer ſhold haue gone rome mā douted ſhold haue ben great daūger lif laſt cōmaūded prince remain home theſe cauſes alſo ſuch feare may come vpō moſt cōſtant mā liuing deſyred duke friderick bring paſſe yt hearyng matter might referred ſome ſkilful fitte men germany place ſuſpected ſubiect iniurie wherfore biſhop rome hath committed ye whole matter ambaſſador cardinal caietane whiche doubtles done inſtaunce aduerſaries whiche knewe alreadye mynde wyll cardinall thoughe myghte wythoute iuſte cauſe ſuſpected yet dyd obey cardinall fyrſte metynge commaunded reuoke workes whereunto aunſwered woulde iuſtifye done eyther preſent diſputation writinge yet would ſubmit whole matter onely vniuerſities alſo iudgement churche rome al theſe thynges beynge nothing ſatiſfied commaunded ſtyll recante coulde bringe ſame threatened greuous puniſhment bothe others alſo opinion therfore findeth ſelfe ſore greued ſuche preiudices doeth appeale byſhoppe rome well infourmed matter biſhop yt ſhal better inſtructed ſame proteſteth openlye furthermore ſame decree clement founde parte cannon lawe called extrauagaunte clemente appoynteth yere iubile boniface eight ordained euery hundreth yeare nowe euerye fiftithe yeare ſpeakinge benefite ſauioure chriſte welſpring pardon ſayeth howe one droppe chriſtes bloud bene ſufficient haue redemed man kynde wherefore ouerplus hathe left treaſure wyth peter ſucceſſours dyſpoſe diſtribute vpon penitente perſonnes confeſſe theyr ſynnes lyke good stewardes ſo releue temporall puniſſhemente dewe vnto theyr ſynnes moreouer beſyde merittes uirgin marie sainctes belonge vnto thys place ſaieth ſo matter power remyttynge ſynnes vnmeaſurable wherefore vpon decree caietaine groundeth authoritie pardon luther ſayth howe nothyng committed peter hys ſucceſſours beſydes keyes miniſtration worde wherein chriſt commaundeth truſt remiſſiō ſinnes ſhold ſhewed beleuers true ſence meanyng scripture decree clement meane thus content otherwiſe alow ſame whiche ſpoken moreouer merites saintes wholy agaynſt holy scripture men ſoeuer onely oughte alſo ſo muche bounden neither ſaued owne merites ſole mere mercy god men muſt pray dayly god father forgeue v offence ſtand iudgement agaynſt v leſt damned touchynge whiche cardinall inferreth authoritie byſhoppe rome thus ſtandeth caſe enacted fourth fifte ſyttyng coū ſell conſtaunce biſhop rome ſelfe ſhould obey decree synode ſame afterwarde eſtabliſhed repeted pope vnder coun ſeuententh eyghtenth ſyttting counſel baſil wheras eugenius fourth would come counſell baſill although oftentimes warned cited thither pronounced ſame fruſtrate called farrare whither came iohn paleologe laſt emperour grece ſaue one ioſippe patriarche conſtantinople numbre biſhoppes yeare lord mccccxxxvij farrare remoued florence conſent grekes decreed amonges thinges church rome ſhould haue ſupremacie yt biſhop rome ſucceſſor peter prince thapoſtels trew vicar chriſt head ye whole church ye father doctor al chriſtiās cōmitted chriſt ful power fede gouerne church vniuerſal decree whereby caietanus woulde preferre biſhoppe rome aboue generall counſels ſyxe yeares whan yet cardinall maiſter blacke frieres made oration ſeconde ſyttynge counſell laterane wherof ſhall ſpeake hereafter inueiyng muche agaynſte certeyne cardinalles forſaken biſhop rome taunteth waie counſelles coſtauntz baſil father ſame tune toke ſelues aucthoritie ouer byſhoppes wherefore ſaieth wel done eugenius ſuppreſſed factiō ſuffered aucthoritie diminiſhed oration iulius ſeconde whoſe fauoure theſe thynges ſpoken commaunde recorded caietane made cardinall leo gerſon paris tenth gerſon ſpake diuine paris right famouſe wrote diuers worckes preſente counſell conſtans bookes written commendeth hyghely decree whereby agreed byſhoppe rome ſhould ſubiecte counſell ſayeth thing worthie written church publike place perpetuall memorye ſaieth peſtilent flatterer whiche brynge thys tyrranny churche thoughe biſhoppe rome ought neither obey counſel iudged ſame though counſell ſhould take force aucthoritie thoughe coulde called pleaſure though bounden obſeruation lawes none accompt myght taken doynges certeinly theſe monſtruous ſayinges muſte vtterly reiected againſt lawes equitie reaſon aucthoritie churche dependeth generall counſell lawefull appeale pope vnto thoſe inquire whether byſhop rome churche greater make wiſe queſtion ſhould aſke whether part whole aperteineth coūſel conſtitute iudge depoſe byſhop rome lately declared conſtaunce ſome ſemed doubte pope iohn depoſed matter attributed ouermuche byſhoppe queſtion determined iohn three twentith depoſed seate theſe many thinges writeth gerſon ſame effecte therefore nowe reiected caietane died yere oure lorde mccccxxix vniuerſitie paris holdeth ſame opiniō includeth vnmeſurable vſurpation romiſhe byſhoppes wyth theſe boundes fewe monthes luther wrote indulgence ſame uniuerſite appealed leo tenthe abolyſhyng law whych profitable ſtudentes fraunce opened waye promotion luther departure aſpurge cardinall writeth letter ye duke saxonie fiue twentye daye october ſignifiynge luther dede came auſpurge ſpake caietan writeth ye duke saxonie till obteined themperours ſafeconduit marueileth greatlye ſo little credit geuen much treaty aboute matter certaine fatherly loue admoniſhed luther amende albeit waxed ſtubberue yet deuiſe stupice others waye reconcilemente ſuche forte neyther churche rome ſhoulde loſe dignitie eſtimation wheras good foundation thing already laid went preuely away firſt stupice luther whiche chaunced muche contrary expectation luther pretendeth treateth theſe matter onlye waye reaſonynge diſputation ſermons people affirmeth thynges whiche maye wiſe bee permitted ſo muche hys doctrine bothe ſwarueth churche rome alſo verye parnicious certainlye proued wherefore dothe admoniſhe regarde owne honour conſcience either ſēd luther rome el baniſhe countrye ſo peſtilent thinge ſhoulde longe continue neyther anye doubt wil procede iudgement againſte rome hath accordinge duetie ſignified biſhop whole matter clokynge ſame prayeth hym therefore geue credit vnto ſuche commended luther doinges neither ſuffer ſo greate euill ſpot blemiſhe noble houſe saxonie like oftentimes promiſed whiche epiſtle exhibited duke letter cardinall ninetene daye nouembre duke fredericke maketh aunſwere eighte daye decembre promiſed ſende luther auſpurge whiche beinge perfourmed require promiſed likewiſe let frendly departe nowe woulde dryue hym recante hys matter hearde lyttle maruell dyuerſe well learned men aſwell partes countrye whyche dyd condemyne doctrine ſuche hys aduerſaries blyneded wyth auarice corrupted wyth filthye lucre caſe hys erroure hadde bene detected woulde whiche ſeeketh bothe glorye god ſafetye hys owne conſcience haue done readye herein duetye chriſten prynce therefore wryteth proceſſe ſhall paſſe againſte ſayde luther rome beyonde hys expectation deſyreth moreouer eyther ſhoulde ſente rome elles exile lawfull hym ſo firſte becauſe yet detected hereſye secondely becauſe ſame ſhoulde greate loſſe uniuerſitie wittemberge whiche lately founded whereof luther certeine lyghte ornament unto whome ſent letter myght reade offereth ſelfe readye diſpute matter anye indifferente place iudged anye indifferente hearer elles aunſwere matter wrytynge whiche requeſt becauſe reaſonable ſo muche wyll defende none errour wyllyngly thynketh meete graunted length maye appeare wherefore ſhoulde accompted heretike ſelfe myghte chieflye folowe lyke wyll maynteine errour willyngly woulde verye lothe ſwarue church rome euen ſo condemne heretike tofore detected errour nowe luther ſene cardinales letter ſayed wrote againe hys prince immediatlye wente caietaine obtayned emperours ſaufeconduit done aduiſe freindes cardinall would haue recante ſuche thynges wrytten touchynge pardon faythe neceſſarye sacramentes fyrſte dyd muche paſſe denye wherein conſiſteth effecte ſaluatiō might wiſe cōſēt declareth place ſcripture papiſtes depraue wraſte wronge ſenſe reciteth alſo done euery day howe length cardinall began threaten vndoubtedly wiſheth nothing might ſhewed wherein erreth caſe rome ſhall refuſe take ſo muche paine ſo poore man leaſt wiſe let write hereof duke ſelfe themperor ſome great biſhoppe germanye elles appoynt ſomwhere free diſputation whiche thinges haue denyed hitherto thus perſeuer eaſye iudged whether faulte exhorte crueltie oughte perſwaded woordes ſeme note errours might muche eaſely ſende writyng germany thā great charge preſent daunger life trauaile rome vnderſtande errours finally wheras boaſteth iudgement ſhall paſſe againſte rome vnleſſe eyther come thither exiled refuſeth exile although knoweth full well place ſafe hauynge ſo many aduerſaries liynge waite hym moreouer ſhould great griefe vnto man ſhoulde ſake incurre daunger wherefore leſt ſhould attempte thing departe limittes whole countrey whither ſoeuer ſhall pleaſe god leade wherfore geueth thankes prayeth proſperous health reioyſeth ſelf hath pleaſed god ſhould ſuffer ſome thinge glorie chriſtes name thē dyd uniuerſitie wittenberge moneth nouembre uniuerſitie wittenberge writeth lut write vnto duke theyr fauourable letter luther behalfe nowe vnderſtode luther cardinall caietanes letter bothe requeſt alſo offer luther made auſpurge luther therefore requireth errour maye ſhewed ſubmitteth ſelfe holy churche rome beſeche ſee open wronge ſhewe erroure way oute holye scripture ſelfe hopeth well gentleneſſe biſhop leo feareth leſt aduerſaries ſo flatter abuſe name churche albeit duke accompliſhe papiſtes requeſtes ſemed rather defende luther tofore maye appeare yet neuer read hys woorkes yet hearde preache ſelfe witneſſeth letter written auſpurge raphell riare cardinall olde acquaintaunce frindely admoniſhed ſhold take vpon defence luther whileſt theſe thinges doinge leo fearinge ſome alteration eſtabliſſheth indulgence newe decree new pardōn ſayinge doctrine romaine churche maiſtres others biſhoppe rome succeſſour peter chriſtes uicare hath authoritie graunte ſo great benefite ſuche ſorte ſhall profit onely quicke alſo deade purgatorie doctrine muſte men receyue beleue vnleſſe ſequeſtred felowſhippe holy churche decree ſent caietane mighte publiſhed vnto men folowyng commaundement publiſſhed thinge lintz towne auſtriche riuer danubye tonoware decembre ſendeth copy byſhoppes germany commaunding leo name vnder great penaltie ſhould immediatly ſet foorth euery man dioces commaunded reuerently kept obſerued luther perceiuing cardinal letter ſentence ſhoulde geuen againſt luther appealeth pope counſell rome putteth vp newe appellation xxviij day nouembre wherin conteined would diminiſhe thauthoritie biſhoppes rome thinking rightly muche leſſe diſſent churche notwithſtandyng ſo muche byſhoppe ſame ſtate mortall men maye maye erre offende neither ought attributed vnto alone cannot erre diſceiued proueth exemple peter erred ſounde doctrine ſharpely openlye rebuked paule aucthoritie rich biſhoppe rome ſo great may commaunde liſte careth man ſuche thinke haue wronge hande haue onely one remedie lefte appeale reciteth howe inforſed throughe ouer muche aſperitie cardinall caietane appeale biſhop rome whoſe humanitie thought haue founde ſome fauoure aſmuch offered moſt reaſonable cōditions promiſed al thinges errour beyng taken away nowe ſins appellation condemned offer diſpiſed lookynge helpe health biſhoppes hande might learne cardinalles letter written duke saxonie beynge broughte thorow extreme neceſſitie appealeth biſhoppe rome nexte general coūſell al meanes ought preferred biſhop rome ſendeth charles meltice chamberlaine pope ſendeth golden roſe duke saxonie germanye preſente duke fridericke golden rooſe biſhoppe yearely wonte conſecrate many ceremony great pompe ſolemnitie token ſingular freindſhip geue vnto ſome mā wrot alſo degenart pheſfinger noble man duke counſell praiyng alſo woulde ſuite duke maiſter luther childe sathan might puniſhed noble houſe saxonie might thorowe blemiſhed ſame effecte alſo wrote george spalatine better perſwade ſaid wholy geuen plucke vp euillwedes chriſtes felde ſame ſorte wrote vice chauncelour alſo degenart deſyring moue duke fridericke imitation aunceſtors commit nothing vnworthy famouſe memory whā meltice come saxonie exhibited roſe folowed ſuite right ſtoutly whiche thynge knowen luther thirde day marche writeth biſhop rome letter full ſubmiſſion wherin declareth howe greuouſly complained vpon vnto duke whoſe diſpleaſure ſmal grief vnto beſydes ſtil called vpon recāte might honoure dignitie churche rome refuſe ſince germany therbe many wittie wel lerned men hable iudge controuerſie ſhould rather blotte hinderaunce churche rome anye furtheraunce dignitie hath done iniurie therunto thoſe collectours pardoner couetouſnes vttered ſhamefull thynges people haue complained accuſed without deſerte beareth ſuch affection towardes churche rome attempt nothinge againſte power thereof ſo great chriſt onely excepted nothinge worlde excellent beſecheth credite enemy pardon wyll make mention ſo hys aduerſaries maye lykewyſe commaunded kepe ſilence wyll alſo admoniſhe people sermon thinke well churche rome aſcribe vnto auarice others yet folowe example thorowe impudencie aduerſaries enforced treate vnreuerently briefely thinges quietnes ſo errour falſe parſwaſion remayne mindes men meltitius came germany themperour maximilian death maximilian departed life auſtriche vij daye januarye time wer prince electours albert mentz herman collon rycharde treuers archebyſhoppes lewes palſegraue fridericke duke saxonie joachin marque brandenburge kingdome boheme lewes kinge hungry theſe beynge called aſſemblie archebyſhop mentz cuſtome empire month june mette franckefourt towne ryuer moene except kinge boheme ſent thither depute ladiſlaus sterneberge archebyſhop mentz beginneth oratiō ſpeakyng much weightie importaunce thing exhorteth vnto concord declaryng many exāples heape euilles diſſention prince electours brought germany within father memorye ſhould nowe one mynde conſent ſo muche requiſite greater daunger hāgeth ouer turke others ſeke ſpoyle germanye two aſpire dignitie thempire charles archeduke auſtriche three yeres ſucceded ferdinando kinge spaine graundfather mother ſide fraunces frenche kynge whiche foure yeares paſt vanquiſſhed heluetians marignane poſſeſſed dukedome millan kynge spaines ambaſſadoures comen alreadye mentz whiche fyue mile franckefurt frenche ambaſſadours ſtaied confluence towne archebiſhoppes treuers rhine moſelle mete whence either partie letter meſſagers commended eche prince electours beſte reaſons perſwade eſpecially frenche mē perceiued cauſe leſſe fauoured differed frō german lāguage lawes maners ſente therefore heluetians praiynge matter prince notwithſtandyng dyd cleane contrarye exhortyng choſe ſome one prince germany swiſes alſo wrote leo tenthe praiynge aſmuche hys parte inueſte confirme emperour beyng choſen woulde ſe ſhould geuen foreine prince aunſwered heard ſay one laboured might haue lawe kynges naples tributary biſhoppe rome haue promyſed faith couet empire content one hath admoniſhed prince hereof alreadye ment tale charles auſtriche fauoured frenche kynge euer ſyns ſubdewed heluetians led awaye maximilian sfortia duke millan captife fraunce whiche yere lorde mdxv aboute ides septembre ſwiſſes banquiſhed whome decembre folowinge mette bonony made perfecte league amitie touching kingdome naples thus ſtandeth time manfredus baſtarde ſonne emperour fridericke ſeconde made warre agaynſte churche rome clement fourthe byſhoppe name yeare oure lorde mcccccxv thentent repreſſe hym whiche predeceſſor urban fourth aboute doo ſent charles erle gaunte prouince fraunce kinges naples paye tribute rome italy made kynge sicilie naples yet vnder condition fyrſt ſuche benefite receiued ſhould pay yerely churche rome fortie thouſand ducates moreouer ſhoulde time ſewe emperour yet take vpon beynge offered freely prince comen conſulte archebiſhoppe talked ſeuerally fridericke duke oration archebyſhop mēiz saxonie whoſe authoritie verye greate begynneth matter whiche ſaieth diuided three queſtions whether fraunces frenche kyng charles king spaine el ſome germane choſen emperour touchinge french kynge ſaieth ſuppoſe prohibited lawes othe alſo wherby prouided dignitie empire ſhould alienated ſtraungers thinke man doubteth foreine prince albeit let yet commune weale ſeketh meanes enlarge kingdome hath ioyned millan attempte ſame germany warre vpon charles whome hateth yea hathe proclamed already germanye ſhall tormoiled vprores ought foreſe ſtyrre vp ciuill warres inuade auſtriche ſuerly ſhall leaue breres hath themperour maxilimilian deſerued thus v empire thoſe countreis ouer runne howe longe thinke ſhall libertie continewe maye truſte fayre promiſes oftentimes couetouſneſſes ambition cary awaye men headlonge doyng theyr dewtie time paſte many noble houſes fraunce nowe fewe nombre kinge maner hathe owne handes ſay ſtouce prince like brynge monarchie ſeke maintaine preſent ſtate nobilitie promiſeth great aide agaīſt turke dede thinge wiſhed germany mighte ioyne wyth fraunce italy firſt wil bend power againſte houſe burgundy warre vppon flaunders naples ſhall aide theſe enterpriſes leaſt mā ſhould ſay prophecied dreames doubtfull matter leuying armye foraſmuche therfore letted oure lawes othe loue natiue country proteſt iudge vnmete elected nowe reſt party ſuppoſe ſome thyncke vnmete charles ſhoulde choſen becauſe spaine ſo farre abſence ſhould go well germany either turkiſhe warre ciuile diſſentions thinges onlye graunte true alſo conſider depelye ſo moued maner quake feare waye alſo emperour time come germany diſpleſure bring spaniardes ſhalbe daunger loſe liberty conſider moreouer may spaniard wil hardly time reſtore vnto v dignitie thempire force power recouer millan kepe hereafter ſelues almoſt ſemeth better create one owne nation fit example elder whiche paſſinge ouer foreine prince haue choſen inhabiter contrie wil deny ſtate tyme thē farre otherwiſe worlde great deale better nowe emperour ſmall power thinke auſtriche country obey frenche kinge warre vpon charles without doubte wyll eyther lowe countrey italie ſhall geue lokyng ſhal new emperour ſuffer ſtraunge nation ſpoile great parte empire yea world goeth day thought prince germany contemnynge theyr emperour ioyne ſelues ſome houſe auſtriche ſome frenchemen fridericke third emperour charles duke burgundie warred germany philip maria duke millan italy mā repreſſe ſame diſhonour moreouer greater ſhame whan emperour beſeged auſtriche yea driuen oute owne countrey hungarian yet ſame time dyd lande boheme take parte ſo alſo graundefather albert marque brādēburge duke saxonie ſame name chaunce ſo thē ſee like enſew theſe day ſome prince addicted others ſtipendes leaue ſpeake howe many incidente cauſes maye chaunce whiche prince city maye refuſe ſhewe obeidience moreouer like haue great tumultes trouble religiō ther ſpronge vp diſputations indulgence authoritie byſhoppe rome eccleſiaſticall lawes whiche ſeme yet curable euer longe cauſe great ruine alteration churche manye ſubcribe myghtye nation maynteine cauſe saxon heluetians neither miſchief holpen generall counſell howe ſhall emperour ſmall power eyther call counſell defende ſame eſpecially kinges agaynſt remayneth turkiſh warre muſt onely defende make alſo recouer loſt reſtore grece vnto libertie doynge whereof haue nede aide many ſundry nation emperour haue ſmall power litle authoritie howe ſhall gather greate army mē cauſes iudge mete choſe ſome mightie prince charles auſtriche preferred prince germanie incommoditie ſhould put feare ſo thinke great deale leſſe ſhall enſew caſe gouernement committed anye bothe germayne borne hath many country holdynge empire ſee owne countrey brought bondage beſydes ſhall ſweare neither alienate diminiſh thempire break infringe liberty albeit theſe great cauſes haue mentioned yet ſhould moue one whit vnleſſe towardnes wel knowen loueth religion juſtice chaſtitie hateth crueltie hath good witte vertues ſhall euer admoniſhe mainteine comonwealth know throughly muche commende conſyder well hys father philippe graundfather maximilian doubt great age yet fitte ripe gouerne ſhall haue graundefathers counſellours certeine prince germany choſen purpoſe whereas ſaid worſt ſhoulde longe oute germany ſhall condition matter aſmuche hathe greate poſſeſſions germany ſome time come ſee ſhall turke driuen hungary frenchemen oute italy church ſhal refourmed eſtabliſhed many others holpen thynges cōſyder care leſſe abſens owne naturall courage loue countrey verye neceſſitie thinges ſhall prouoke come ofte amonge v oration archbi treuers archebyſhop ended oration exhorted reſt ſpeake myndes others talked litle together deſired archebiſhoppe treuers ſuccede ſyngular witte experience muche eſtimation began tale prophete ſayd maximilian ſhould laſt germaine emperour nowe ſaieth thinketh almoſt comen paſſe foraſmuche lorde mentz hath ſpoken many thinges wittely hath gon aboute perſwade v commit gouernement empire ſtraunger maruell muche preferreth spaniarde frencheman certes lament ſtate germany folowe ſteppes oure elder ſhoulde nede forayne helpe nowe ſeyng ſeke vpon ſtraungers thinge procure owne bondage leauynge complainte folowe ſame order lorde mentz hath done ſpeake fyrſt lawe oure othe chiefe cauſe ground law ſuppoſe leſt foreine prince ſhould choſen certen habitation germany dignitie thempire ſhoulde litle litle alieuated ſtraungers meaning lawe spaniarde choſen frencheman charles may created becauſe hathe landes lyinge within empire neceſſitie ſame muſt force alſo fraunces hath millan membres common weath wherefore two thinges propounded let fraunce germani wer 〈…〉 ted v ſee whether better certaynly whā fraunce vnited germany empire moſt floriſhe ſo muche remembraunce time doth litle delite chance reade ſtories therof like occaſion offered v whiche certainly would let ſlippe foreyne nation alſo opinion biſhop rome venetian prince city italie frenchman come ſame ofſpringe vſe almoſt ſame lawes maners ſhewyng loue gentleneſſe men vicinitie therof neceſſary italiās v tumult ſhall ariſe ſtraight way ſhall armye ready fraunce ſhall paye wage turke ſhall inuade either hungary italye verelye thincke wil ſhal goodly matter haue ſo nere ſo floriſhing emperoure fourniſhed ſtrength either nation spaniard though accompted warlicke notable thing euer italye without healpe germanes furthermore becauſe ſo farre v loke helpe handes time though would neuer ſo faine yet healpe v greatlye spaine ſo waſted continual ſayling ſend forth great nombre men moreouer ſhall haue frenchman fellow ſouldiours companion trauell paine spaniardes thing wel done haue al praiſe ſelues enioye boaties rule country ſhal bewaile bondage late leaue compariſon come election choſe kynge fraunce ſhalbe none occaſion warre italy hathe millan nowe poſſeſſion ſhall perſwade ſhall attempte nothinge againſt naples nether againſt baſe countreis flaūders artois ſo yt wil quiet yet ſee ſhoulde thincke theſe countreis ought defended v dede oure neigbours haue league wt neither obſerue lawes thempire geue thing towardes cōmon charge thē doth englād scotlāde seing yt frēch kīges power greateſt hath lūbardy quiet poſſeſſiō furniſhed wt al thinges neceſſary wil attempt greater enterpriſes honorable moue warre namely againſt turke bend al power thither wardes yt cruel enemie expulſed hūgary italy germany maye liue reſt caſe preferre charles liuing god tumultes ſhall raiſe vp italy wil recouer millan wilbe long warre whileſt goodly coū trey ſhalbe thus tourmoyled turkes inuade hungary theyr whole power praye ſhall reſiſte able bringe ſufficient armie agaynſt theſe thinges would conſydered diligently paſſed ouer lightly nowe end italyan warre ſhalbe vncerten frenche kynge conquere couet naples maye byſhoppe rome throughe impulſon vndo oure election trouble ariſe thereby euerye manne perceyueth righte well agayne charles get better hande let v loke haue italy reſtored againe spaniardes kepe ſelues foreuer onely wyll hardely let theyr handes empyre kepyng naples poſſeſſion wherof wel knowen came miſery haue ſuffered may therfore brought italy ſpeake ſome thinges either king doubt king charles milde gentle diſpoſition ſo reported many yonge man howe men diſcerne ſuch vertues required mightye prynce common welth nede ſuche one beſides thinges could eſtabliſh reforme ſtate church lord mentz wittely admoniſhe verely king fraunces performe beſt men hath good wit good iudgemente hath oftentimes conferens lerned men religion readeth muche ſelfe moreouer ſtate preſente time requyreth prince captaine ſkilfull warres payneful lucky ſhall behalf take price away fraunces vertue rightwell tried knowen king charles haue noue experiment towardnes promiſeth ſome thinge prowes dedes armes doeth farre excell aunceſtours hath latly ouercome battaill swiſers mighty nation neuer ſubdued ſyns iulius ceſars time yonge man therefore oughte wyſe preferred ſo worthye capitayne lorde mentz doeth accompte diſcommoditie thēperour ſhold longe germanye yet biddeth v take thoughte matter thinke matter full greate daunger haue emperour abſente farre withoute border empire ſhall reſiſte inuaſions turkes ſhall repreſſe ſodayne inſurrections ciuile vprours ariſe tempeſt ſhall ſaue shyppe wanteth maſter ſhal know certentie oure affayres beynge abſent many thynges ſhalbe told vntruely ſhall haue germaines counſell spaniardes onely wyll make many decree ſend vnto v farre tyme ſeaſon afterwardes beynge tyckled wyth falſe complaintes ſklaunders ſhould come germany anyetyme armye foreine ſouldiours ſtate thinke ſhall wyth empire wherfore thinke good oure deſtinie foreine prince ſhall time weare oure crowne vpon heade certenly thinke mete preferre frenche kynge spaniſhe lawe prohibite v choſe frenchekinge letthe ſame take place spaniſhe kinge let v throughe ſubtill interpretation accompt king charles germanie let v eſpie amonges prince one whiche hath manſion germany germanie birthe language maners diſpotition lorde mentz ſuppoſeth ſuche emperour ſhoulde ſmall abilitie diſpiſed choſe mete man germanie riche ſtronge enough beare vp burthen raffe xj themperour raffe emperour maximilian man small power excelled vertue reſtored thēpire ful weak ſore afflicted great warres ſuch ſorte kinges feare good opinion alſo foreine prince amonges others lewes xij king fraunce themperor maxilian onely wit vertue ſuppoſe knowe righte well doubtles prince germany haue bene euer muche eſtimation yet noble fame extinguiſhed floriſheth ſtil amōges others day thre principal houſes germani houſe bauar saxonie brādenburge theſe houſes alſo diuers worthy mē wherfore choſe one thē aſſiſt aide ſurely boūden ſhal nede feare ſtraūgers ſo one minde althinge ſhalbe ſaftie therfore ſetting part ſtraungers let v create ſome one owne coū treymen ſhal proue right wel many domeſtical example vertue wherof ſhall recite one matthias kinge hūgary ſtout warriour fortunate proclaimed warre vpon time againſte father lord saronie whē perceiued ſufficient armie prepared againſte anger ſone pacified mighte alſo meanes founde emperor owne nation elected might mainteinehis eſtate authoritie home broad thirdly ſpake ye duke saxonie proued frenche king excluded lawe king charles germayne prince haue habitation germany ſaid common weale nede ſome mightie prince knew noue compared charles therfore contented ſhould declared emperor yet vpon certen condition germany ſhall reteike libertie thoſe daungers mentioned ſhould eſchewed finallye reſt approued ſentence archbyſhoppe treuers ſayde • ſee fatall deſtenye germany alteration euen nowe hande withſtandynge aſmuche ſemeth ſo good confourme wyll vnto iudgemente xxviij daie iune darke night wherfore departed mette agayne next daye began treate condition ſhould propounded emperour matter debating certein day lengthe agreed vpon written ſent ambaſſadours mentz whan receiued theyr voice committed writinge maner ſealed daye thempire offered friderick duke duke saxo refuſeth emperour saxonie ſtout courage refuſed gaue voice vnto king charles whoſe ambaſſadours ſo doynge offered hym great ſūme money vtterly refuſed would ſuffer mē alſo take one farthing tharchbiſhop mentz calling nobilitie comon people church saint bartholomew ſermō declareth charles archduke auſtrich king ſpaine charles declared emperour king romanes ye ſtede maximiliā departed yt choſen wt ſuch cōſent ſaieth ought geue god thankes exhorting thē ſhew fidelitie obeyſaūce ſpeaking much praiſe declareth choſe others thambaſſours comen myle ſent thoſe matthew ye cardinall saliſburge erarde biſhop liege barnard biſhoppe trent fridericke countie palatine caſimire marque brādēburge henry erle naſſo maximiliā sibebouge certē others coūſel whē comē cōſulted howe common wealth gouerned vntill ſuche tyme came ſelfe germany howe caſimire paulſgraue ſhould leuie force men place gariſons foreſee ſtate take harme afterwardes prince electours ſente ambaſſadours letter king charles declare whole matter chief thē fridericke paulſgraue howbeit ye meane time friderick paulſgraue ſent spaine diuerſe meſſengers went spaine amonges one went frō franckefurth barcelona nine dayes countie palatine arriued ende nouembre deliuereth prince letter content wherof would receiue thempire offered delaye ſette parte repaire germany ſo ſoone mighte aunſwereth ryght curteſiye mouthe mercurine cattinar beit muche trouble towardes turkes frenche men yet withſtondyng ſayd neither coulde woulde faile common countrie chiefly ſyns ſo noble prince ſuch opinion required ſo wherfore receiueth honour offered right thankefully ſo ſhortly may imbarke ſelf come border thempire maner ſame wordes writeth prince electours ſendeth home fridericke honourably rewarded thus made emperor fift yt name xxj yeres age frenche kyng toke repulſe greuouſlie perceiued greater daūger hang ouer ſtate ſeing power enemie ſuſpected herby muche increaſed rather man el bene choſen geuen great ſommes money haue bene cōſydered ſo flaūders like caſe reported herein affirme nothing certenly declare petiegre kinge charles charles fift ſurnamed wiſe king fraūce gaue dukedō burgūdy fel vnto philip yongeſt brother philip maried afterwards ye lady margaret thonly daughter lewes erle flaūders ſonne called iohn ſonne named philip father charles ſtoute warriour ſlaine nancey leauing daughter called mari inheritour many great coūtreis maried maximiliā ſonne thēperor friderick iij brought forth ſon called philip maried ye lady iane ye daughter ferdinādo kig spaine ij ſons charles ferdinādo whan lady wt child ſhe went flaūders brought abed charles gaūt yeare lorde md xxiiij day february ſome thynge ſayd ferdinādo thēperours graūdfather mother ſide 1500 byrth emperor king aragonie sicilie wife elizabeth daughter heyre iohn ſeconde kyng spaine fine alſo kingdome naples begotte fyue child iohn iſabel iane mary katherine iohn iſabell deynge without iſſewe inheritaunce lawes realme came vnto iane next ſyſter meanes yt duke burgūdie exceding much whatſoeuer ferdinando king spaine came wholy charles ſonne lady iane landes houſe auſtriche diuiſiō thinheritaūce went ferdinā brother wherfore long time germany emperour greater power father died whā ſixe yere olde graūdefather ferdinādo whan ſixtene whiche tyme wēt spaine remained til elected emperour came germany ſhalbe declared herafter forſomuch arecome place ſhal much purpoſe ſpeak ſome thing creatiō themperor charles kinge boheme ye iiij emperor name made law herofin yeare 1356 called comenly golden bull wherof one thing yt thēperour dead tharchbiſhop mentz ſo ſoone knoweth therof ſhal immediatly ſignifie ſame reſidew price elector mane choſing • emperour appoint thē day within iij monthes mete frāckfourt either owne parſons ſende deputy wt ful authoritie elect new emperor king romanes fortune yt ſaide archbiſhop neglect yt yet neuertheles reſt ſhall aſſembe within time preſcribed accōpanied euery mā ij c horſe aboue whā enter towne 50 thē armure neither cōmeth himſelfe yet ſendeth ambaſſ depute tofore buſines ended ſhall loſe right electiō yt time officer frākefurth ſhal ſhew al fidelitie thelectours duringe time thelectiō ſuffer nomāto enter beſides prince family yt cōmen together ſhal haue meſſe holy ghoſt church ſ bartholomew thē euery mā ſweare yt ſhal nothing yt matter bargain bribe reward promiſe afterward come electiō depart thēce thēperor choſē thing differred aboue xxx day thē haue nothing geuē thē bread water whō part ſhall choſe muche effect choſen wt cōmen aſſent almē themperor thus elected ſhal firſt cōfirme al priueleges whatſoeuer apperteineth honor dignitie libertie fredō moreouer prouided ordeined one ſhall ſuffer another paſſe coūtrey place eche thē ſhal haue conſiſtory ſort ſhall giue voice office euery thē ſhall haue time thēperor either dineth abroade doth thig opēly furthermore yt durig ye vacatiō thēpire coūtye palatine ſhal haue gouernemēt sueuelāde frākeconie rhine duke saxo ſuch place vſe lawes saxnie prince elector departed eldeſt ſonne ſhal ſucced brother germayne electour vnder xviij yeares age next kinſman ſhall ſupplie rowme til come age electours mete euery yere conſult comē wealth frankefurth place election agnon baſe contrey towne ſhalbe inueſted ſpake condition preſcribed prince ratified emperours ambaſſadours puttyng caution maner writinges made ſame name whiche theſe ſhall defend chriſten comen wealth biſhoppe churche rome whereof aduocate ſhall miniſter law vprightly ſeeke maynteine peace ſhall confyrme eſtabliſh al lawes thempire chiefely called golden bulle alſo theyr aduiſe time ſhall require encreaſe ſame appointe cenate counſell within empire choſen germaines onely ſhall miniſter comon wealth ſhall breake diminiſhe lawes priueledges dignitie prynces ſtates thempire ſhalbe lawful electoures nede ſhall requyre aſſemble conſult common welth ſhall let hereunto take euill parte ſhall aboliſhe confederacy conſpiracies nobilitie commōs againſt prince prohibite law ſuch made hereafter make league compacte ſtrangers touching matter thempire without aſſent vii prince neither alienate lay pledge anye parte thempire deminiſhe ſame ſuch goodes landes empire nation haue plucked away occupy ſeeke forthwith recouer yet ſo infringe lawes priueleges alſo ſelfe houſe poſſeſſe parte thempire vnlawfullye gotten reſtore ſame beinge required vii prince kepe peace amitie withall chriſten prince attempte warre affaire empire without conſent al ye ſtates chiefly prince electours either within empire wythout bring ſtraunge ſouldiours germany without aſſent man moue warre againſt thempire ſhalbe lawfull vſe aide cal none aſſē bly empire commaunde taſke tribute conſent electours ſame alſo within limittes empire publike affaire appointe foreyners germaines nobilitie writinges made latin duche tonge man ſommoned appere court bondes thempire foraſmuch many thinges done rome contrary couenaūtes made time paſt biſhoppes therof deuiſe biſhop fraude vſed towardes preuileges liberty thempire impoſe cuſtome droicte ye aſſent thelectours neither letter diminiſh cuſtome thelectors dwell rhine haue action agaynſt man ſhall trye lawe vſe force ſuche aunſwere lawe ſtande ordre lawe goodes empire whiche ſhall chaunce vacant ſhall geue away man lotte publicke patrimonye ſhall wynne foreine countrey throughe aide ſtates germany ſhal annexe thempire ſhal recouer publike thinge owne force power ſhall reſtore ſame common welth ſhall ratifie done vacation thempire countie palatine duke saronie take counſel vnite thempire houſe poſteritie propre inheritaunce leaue ſeuen prince fre election according vnto lawe charles fourth preſcript canon lawe thinge otherwiſe fruſtrate none effect ſo ſhortly may repaire germany inueſted time ambaſſadours approued theſe thinges othe name deliuered vnto eche elector writinges therof ſealed whiche ſpoken cannon lawe conteined epiſtle decretall innocentius thyrde teſtifieth ſeuen prince electours haue fre authoritye create themperor thempire goeth ſucceſſion election innocētius liued yere lord miic nowe let v retourne luther ſame time eraſmus eraſmus iudgement luther roterdam wrote letter andwarp frederick duke saxonie wherein amonges thinges maketh mention luther ſaying bokes ioyfullye receiued red good well learned men moreouer life man reprehended farre ſuſpicion auarice ambition deuines louain hearinge greatly oppreſſed thaucthoritie cardinall caietan nowe triumphe theyr ſermons bankettes raile vpon callynge heretike antichriſt declaringe mo wordes ſame much contrary theyr profeſſion ſo ſlaunder man comiicte hereſye wryteth alſo maner ſame woordes archebiſhop mentz cardinall campegius tauntyng theſe ſophiſticall diuines monkes whiche abide ſtudye tonges eloquens good learnynge writeth alſo luther frendly louain ſayth howe hath receyued receiued epiſtle whiche declareth excellencie witte alſo chriſtian hert ſhewinge tragedie bokes haue ſtyrred vp hatred ſuſpicion ronneth diuines preuaile nothinge excuſynge matter howe many englande great eſtimation whiche thinke rightwell workes himſelfe hath taſted cōmentaries vpō pſalmes truſteth ſhall profit many like well one thing would admoniſhe man ſhall preuaile certeine ciuile modeſtie vehement muſte rather thunder againſt abuſe biſhop rome authoritie againſt biſhoppes themſelues certeine good counſels whiche gaue exhorting procede hath begonne luther hauing thus manye aduerſaries diſputation appoynted lypſia towne miſnia belonging george duke saxonie diſputatis lypſia uncle duke friderike thither came luther melanthon read greeke lecture wittenberge thither came alſo iohn eccius diuine bothe ſtoute bolde fourth day iulye began diſputation luther touching ſupremacie biſhop rome affirming ſaid church rome fyrſt chiefeſt others euen time cilueſter erre hathe seate faith peter euer taken ſucceſſour chriſtes uicar earthe luther ſetforth one contrary ſame ſuche dyd attribute ſupremacie churche rome ground themſelues onely vpō biſhoppes decree whiche made foure hundreth yeres ſyns decree cōtrary hiſtories written thouſande yeres paſt contrary holy ſcripture counſell nice moſt famous others eccius mainteyneth ſupremacie biſhoppe rome called luther diſſented ſame bohemer becauſe iohn huſſe time paſt ſame opinion luther aunſwereth churche chriſte ſpreade abroade farre nere twentie yeres peter came rome eſtabliſhe churche therfore fyrſt chiefeſt law god ſaieth diſputed purgatory indulgēces penaunce remiſſion ſynne authoritie prieſtes ended diſputation fourteneth day iuly whiche appointed luther andrewe caroloſtadius eccius luther comming onely company caroloſtadius drawen forth eccius got ſaufe cōduict duke george ſo muſte nedes diſpute eccius luſtie courage reaſon matter ſelfe wherein thoughte ſelfe aſſured victorye whiche diſputation luther ſet forth afterwardes wordes wrytinges aduerſaries throughe wittye obſeruation collected diuerſe article doctrine altogether termeth hereticall thintent mighte playnely declare howe whileſt ſpeake write thinges fauor biſhop rome deſyre maynteine theyr cauſe ſtraiynge farre broade confounde moſt thinges beynge nerer looked conteyne ofte tymes great errours wickednes ſame tyme ulrichus zwinglius taught zuricke ſhortly byſhop rome ſent thither pardoner one sampſon graye frere millan gather vp money zwinglius ſtoutly reſiſteth declarynge diſceyuour people ¶ ſeconde
