booke sleidans commentary ❧ argument ſeconde booke motion charles miltice luther wryteth pope dedicateth vnto boke chriſtian libertie themperour hauynge paſſed throughe englande came lowe countreyes luther writeth boke fouretene image conſolation confeſſion uowes prouyng lordes supper ought permitted mē vnder kyndes obiected counſell laterane vnder iuly ii wherevpon way ſpoken iuly actes ſayd counſell meane diuines louayne condemne luther bokes defence article picus erle mirandula queſtions ockam controuerſie rewcline ſame diuines recited seyng ſelfe aſſayled ſo many enemy writeth themperour ſhortely tharchbiſhoppes mentz marſeburge duke fridericke beyng aduertiſed cuill rome reaſon luther maketh purgation letter luther lyke caſe yet notwithſtanding pope extreme bulle doeth excommunicate luther contrary decree mantua waye recited maketh appellation hauinge ſet forthe print boke captuitie babilon emperour ſame tune goeth crowned acon ſolemnities maner whereof recited pope beginneth agayne ſollicite duke fridericke agaynſt luther nothing preuailyng cauſeth luther workes burnt likewiſe luther burneth pope decretals ſheweth cauſe afterwarde aunſwereth ambroſe catarine written agaynſt charles meltice ſent leo tenthe vnto duke fredericke golden roſe perceiued howe luther doctryne ſo farre ſpreade abroade ſo highly eſtemed many ſhoulde hearde almoſt vnpoſſible quench ſought meanes poſſible heale wounde plaſter reconciliation wherfore longe conferens luther frendes laſt meanes foūde luther ſhould write letter biſhop reportyng hym muche honour ſo requeſt frendes aboute 1520 luters letter pope ſyxte day aprill tenure letter albeit appealed counſel yet neuertheleſſe ceaſed make prayer vnto god healthe much ſore blamed haue hurt offended name dignitie hartely ſorye ſo charged cauſe writinge preſent ſignifiynge dede hathe bene earneſt rebukyng vice errours hath euermore written right honorablie ſene bokes doth ſo frankely taunte falſe doctrine doeth example chriſte prophetes apoſtles ſuch reprehenſions holſome admoniſhementes yet take place long naughtie flatterer tickle men eares regardeth god glory court rome vnturable ſeeketh onely truth might appere may obtaine willinge ynough giue place matter leaue profeſſyng god veritie meanes commeth court rome call ſayeth corrupt wicked euer sodome babilon cā miſchiefe wrought antichriſt ſelfe wherefore ſory lambe amonges manye wolues rome worthy haue ſo good man gouerne muche better content meane benefice liue owne landes reuenewes farre ſuche peſtiferous ſlatterers whiche ſerue owne luſt ambition depraue name dignitie addeth barnarde bewailed ſtate eugenius rome better preſent aſmuche moſt filthy ſinke al place uniuerſall worlde rakehell heaped miſchief ought much lamented cauſe inueighed ſo ſoore agaynſt whiche appertayneth nothing reproche rather ſaluation would wiſhe learned men woulde ſet touch nayle ouercome monſtre touching thing ſelfe whan ſet forth certeine litle bokes ſawe attempt vayne willyng haue left enterpriſe imployed frudye profite bretherne ſame houſe roſe vp eccius diſturbed theſe quiet cogitation deſyred leaſure wherin nothing el aptely diſcloſe ſhame wickednes rome toucheth fewe wordes howe vſed cardinal caietane ſaieth might haue appeaſed matter pleaſed vnto faulte imputed thinge miſſe afterwarde came charles meltice quieted kinge bene importune diſputation eccius whiche prouoked reaſon matter agaynſt dede enemie fyrſt men kindled fyre nowe aſmuch requeſted condition propounded luther melticius others better write waye ſubmiſſion would refuſe nothing appertained reconcilement firſt therfore required aduerſaries might kepe ſilence raile vpon ſecondarely driuen recante bounden interprete ſcriptures preſcript mā doctrine goſpell bringeth libertie myndes men bounden within certen limites theſe thynges may graunted content thinge ſo lyeth nowe ende ſtrife vnderſtande matter commaunde either partie ſilence herein muſt chiefely beware flatterats muſt eſchewed flatterer deafe eare ſayle beſydes theyr ſonges enticementes daungerous rockes sirenes aſcribe vnto godlines affirme head world preferring aboue generall counſelles nothing peſtiferous kynde paraſites credite rather admoniſhe dewtie put remēbraunce part true frende man dewtie frende finally dedicateth booke lately written chriſten libertie commendinge ſame fewe wordes conteyned ſumme trew doctrine begynning ſpringe time themperour taketh ſhippinge spaine ſayle englande royally receiued kynge henry eight maried hys aunte katherine amonges kyndes princelike liberalite builded goodlye lodginge purpoſely vpon riuer themſe called bridewell then ſayled flaunders ioyefully receyued almen ſame time duke fridericke fell ſore ſicke wherfore luther compiled boke cōforte letter ſaith cōmaundemēt chriſt luth boke duke saronie amonges workes charitie whiche oughte one another ſhoulde alſo comforte ſicke therfore ſo many cauſes ſo greatly boūden vnto ſake gathered litle boke beyng otherwiſe able comfort ſignifiyng like man body head ake greueth reſt membres taking ſame apperteine priuatly euery ſo nowe lieth ſicke people oute iuſte cauſe teares mournyng greateſt part germany doth depēde vpon reuerence chiefe ornament refuge afterwarde maketh booke confeſſion teacheth confeſſion ſynnes ought leane truſt confeſſiō promiſe god whiche forgeueth oure ſinnes firſte muſte confeſſe v vnto god ſo confeſſeth muſte hate ſinne couet amend life thereherſall euery ſinne particularly neceſſary poſſible performed wt diuers thing laſt vowes wherof wrote ſeueral work afterwardes certaine boke ſaid thought expedient authority counſel might permitted men ſhuld receiue ſupper vnder bothe kindes whole ſupper vſe ſpeke vnder kindes ſaying contrary decree laſt counſel laterane offend many among others ihonbiſhop miſene cō maunded taught throughoute dioces whole ſupper compriſed vnder one kinde condemned luther boke whiche thing vnderſtanding maketh anſwer ſuch ſort layeth fault thereof biſhop certaine vnlearned troubleſome perſons vnto whome ſaith wiſhe ſuch decre might made counſell deſerued iuſt reprehenſion wiſſhed decree counſell wiſhe pope pius might lawfull priſtes haue wiues whiche pius ſeconde biſhoppe rome ſaide wiſhed wherefore oughte blamed wiſhyng ſame graunteth decree counſell laterane yet neuertheles ſame contrarye fyrſt eldeſt counſelles aunciente maner churche agayne diſpraiſe men boheme becauſe receaue vnder bothe kyndes wheras kepe v one halfe onely yet haue make inſtitution chriſte maner obſerued churche apoſtels time til late day haue nothing aledge againſt counſels laterane whiche lighte verye weake reaſon maner coūſel yt wel knowen euen laughed romanes thē ſelues thoughe neuer ſo greate aucthoritie yet counſell latherane muche proue thinge reaſon antiquitie mockery concernyng counſell laterane thus iulius ſeconde elected byſhoppe promyſed ſolemne othe two yeares ſpace holde generall counſell yere lorde thouſande fyue hundreth three whileſt made warre one againſt frenche kynge another againſt uenetians nowe duke farrare nowe others troubled italy nine cardinalles departed came millan called general counſel piſa counſell citie piſa xix day may yere lorde thouſande fiue hundreth eleuen begynne kalendes september folowyng chiefeſt theſe bernardinus cruceius william preneſte fraunces coſſentine wyth whome annexed ambaſſadours emperor maximilian lewes frenche king intended ſame counſell depoſe biſhopprike got briberye nowe muche broken othe bene biſhoppe ſo many yeres called counſel pourpoſed could ſuffer chriſtian common weale lenger deluded becauſe theſe letter coulde ſaufly conueighed vnto ſet vp townes italy admoniſhinge appeare parſon daye appoynted iulius vnderſtandynge matter maketh anſwere fyrſt auguſt time cardinall deſyred nothing generall counſell whiche well knowen kinges prince whole college cardinal euen cauſe alexāder ſyxt ſore offended ſtill ſame minde alſo howe ſtate italy hath late yeres bene ſo troubleſome ſo lefte byſhoppe alexander coulde counſell called ſuche aduerſitie time cōfuteth appoyntment ſhortneſſe time diſcommoditie place piſe towne torne defaced warres former yeres countrie aboute layde waſte neyther men ſafely repayre thither reaſon warres betwixte florentine seue moreouer howe haue none authoritie call theyr cauſes alledged moſt vntrewe wherefore commaundeth vnder paine excommunicatynge man obeye called counſell agaynſte nexte yeare begynne rome vpon ninetenth daye aprill churche laterane pope shifie vnto ſubſcribed one twentie cardynalles ſaye euer byſhoppes policie afrayde counſell appoyncte ſome place mete theyr purpoſe warneth cardinalles agaynſte hym leaue theyr enterpriſe come rome offerynge pardon would come banniſhed xxiiij octobre namely thoſe thre ſpake heretykes ſciſinatykes traitours ſendynge copie theyr preſcription maximilian alother kinges becauſe many byſhoppes fraunce ioyned ſelues theſe cardinalles banniſheth alſo vnleſſe forſake within certeine tyme make p •• gation againe cardinal diuerſe time riſed counſell vaine ſytten eyght tymes ſuſpends al well ciuill eccleſtaſticall iuriſdiction commaunding mē ingenerall hereafter obey hym thys yeare lorde thouſande fyue hundred twelue one twentye aprill ſame tyme pauie philippe decius euntian excellently well learned ſet forthe booke defence cardinalles cauſe againſte byſhoppe rome afterwardes maximilian forſakyng cardinal made league iulius fardinando kinge spaine ſent counſell rome mathew lang byſhoppe gurce ſametime made cardinal lewes kynge fraunce perſiſted ſtyll purpoſe lately ouerthrowen biſhops armye bauenna ſtriken thonderbolte curſing hys realme gyuen ouer ſpoyled ſytten counſell fyue tymes died xxi daye february yeare fraunce offered ſpoile lorde thouſande fyue hundred thyrtene leo tenth dyd ſuccede continewed counſel reſtored cardinal theyr former dignitie counſell ended xvi daye marche yeare lord mdxvij counſell debated rome doubt immortalitie soule turkiſhe warre reformation churche immortalitie soule doubted rome howe boheme ſhoulde reduced theyr errours whiche thynge luther ſpeaketh receyued vnder bothe kyndes whileſt theſe thinges done saxonie diuines louain collen condemne luther workes written sylueſter prierias alſo penaunce excommunication indulgence preparation luth bookes condemned louaine vnto death prophane wicked worthy brente aucthor compelled recante whiche thynge beyng knowen luther aunſwereth euerye article doctrine preface lamenteth theyr ſtate condition time capnio rewcline condemned capnio yet ſome hope nowe ſeyng endeuour extinguiſhe clere lyght doctrine ghoſpell growe euery day wourſe god doubtles muſt nedes greuouſly offended caſe ſhoulde thus procede man ſhould bridle lybertie would ſhortely condemne bokes scripture decree liſte theyr owne pleaſure thinge conſidereth thinke leſſe eyther antichriſt doth reigne el come ſhortly theyr doctrine conteyneth ſounde certen thynge waueringe diuers opinion ſaieth moreouer williā ockam time paſte alſo condemned uniuerſitie paris ockam receiued ſet bye lykewyſe picus mirandula lawrens ualla whyche picus mirandula lawrence ualla nowe eſtimation moreouer ſayeth iewes tymes paſte peculiare people god fledde lyghte ghoſpell refuſed benefyte chriſt forſaken ſo gaue place gentyles lykewyſe nowe dayes ſuch byſhoppes diuines chalenge take vpon greateſt authoritie churche haue dede thinge elles vayne title others farre lyke oſtentation ryghtely maye chalenge name brieflye howe haue thus vexed tymes good well learned men yet dyd neuer contende wyth ſame wyth anye ſounde trewe reaſons rather diſceipte crafte tyranye dyd iohn huſſe hierome prage memory wherof ſhal endure euer marueleth raſhenes ware ſo many example blemiſhe thē ſelues uniuerſities euer althoughe neuer ſo ſure grounde alledged neuer ſo ſtronge reaſons agaynſt thoſe famouſe men yet touching matter haue dealt bothe wickedly maliciouſly ought offended might haue conſidered parte man haue vſed certen leuitie iudginge hys doctrine moued fury cō demne althinges without reſpecte herein bewrey theyr maliciouſe myndes ſpitte oute poyſon theyr hatred make great accompt ariſtotle defende ſoeuer ſayeth neuer ſo contrary religion make ariſtotle excuſe glo • e depraue worckes agaynſte charitie conſonant trweth declare malicious cankred hertes oughte fyrſte haue ſhewed faulte admoniſhynge gently haue reformed ſame might haue proceded chriſt hath gyuen commaundement nowe ſmall iuiurie byſhoppe rome condempne boke dedicated vnto certeine preiudice reproue negligence newes maruell committee ſuche faulte agaynſte biſhoppe ſeynge moſte malapartely contemne lawes god wylliam ockam ſpeaketh flouriſhed tyme emperour lewes fourth aboute yeare oure lorde williā ockā thouſande three hundred twentie amonges thinges wrote power biſhoppe rome ſame boke handleth eight queſtions diuerſlye whether office highe biſhoppe emperor may executed one ſame parſon whether themperor hath authoritie god alſo biſhop rome whether chriſt gaue aucthoritie biſhop church rome ſhould cō mit themperor prince iuriſdiction whether yt emperor beyng choſen hathe thereby full aucthoritie gouerne common wealth whether kynges beſydes emperour kynge romanes ſo much crowned prieſtes receyue anye aucthoritie wherfore ſame kinges ſubiection ſuche inueſte whether vſed newe ceremony crowned themſelues ſhould loſe regall power whether election ſeuen prince geue muche authoritie emperour doth lawfull ſucceſſion kynges debatyng manye reaſons partes determineth cōmonly ciuile maieſtrate vpon occaſion mentionynge iohn two twenteth byſhoppe name lyuynge made lawes extrauagauntes terme placed wyth canon lawe whiche ſaieth ockam reprehended many altogether falſe full hereſyes recyteth errours maruelynge men witte geue credit howe beit tyme ſaieth paule wrote timothe moſte parte men nowe day ſeke doctrine chriſte apoſtles auncient father hearken byſhoppe rome willeth commaundeth concernyng capnio rewcline thus ſtandeth matter iohn phefercorne iewe profeſſed chriſtianitie ſued long emperour maximilian bookes iewes myghte aboliſhed wicked full ſuperſtition hynderaunce conuerted chriſtianitie therefore ſhoulde ſuffered kepe none bible maximilian length commaundeth uriel archebyſhoppe mentz ſhoulde appointe certeyne uniuerſities iames hogoſtrate inquiſitour iohn reucline ſearche conſult ſtory reuchliue whether mete expedient oure religion excepte bybles bookes ſhoulde burned yere lorde thouſande fiue hundred ten reuchline lawier right ſkilful hebrewe tongue receiued archbiſhoppes letter wrote againe mynde ſaid hebrewes bokes three ſortes hiſtories hebrew bokes thre ſortes bookes phiſicke prophecy theſe laſte alſo dyuers ſortes whiche albeit many fonde ſuperſticiouſe thinges yet purpoſe profytable ſerue well confute errours dotage opinion ſente archebyſhoppe ſealed phefercorne knewe made lytell doe ſet oute booke agaynſte callinge hym fautoure defendour iewes reuchline defence eſtimation aunſwereth another offended certein vniuerſities eſpecially collen moſte reputation iames hogoſtrate arnolde tōgre wrot inuectiue againſt like caſe phefercorne done dedicating ye ſame thēperor maximiliā wente lawe archebyſhoppe mentz hogoſtrate plaintife whome reuchline ennemy reſuſed firſt aunſwered vlatter attourney fine came ſelf mentz accompanied diuers gentleman learned men whiche ulriche duke wirtemberge ſent ſoughte meanes haue quieted matter coulde appealeth vnto rome byſſhoppe rome committeth hearyng therof george palatine biſhop spire commaunding mā el ſhoulde medle notwithſtandyng colon condēned reuchlines boke burned moneth february yere mdxiiij biſhoppe spire take maruelous euil part becauſe plaintife beynge called ſeuerall tymes maner appered geueth ſentence reucline approuynge booke good condemneth hogoſtrate coſtes domage intent make ſentence fruſtrate trauayleth rome meane time fellowes home labored wrot paris lewis frenche kinge mediation erarde marchiaue byſhoppe liege ſame tyme greate lewis twelfeth wherofore uniuerſitie paris longe debatynge matter condempned booke alſo worthye burnte author dryuen recant thoſe hebrew bokes brent like maner haue bene time paſt auguſte followynge duke wirtemberge intreated letter reucline ſelfe wrote vnto gentely bene ſtudiēt ſent copie sentence pronounced biſhoppe spire vaine hogoſtrate ſued rome three yeres could preuaile retourneth home againe wente diuers cardinalles vnto whome leo committed hearynge matter loued reuchline intierlye hys excellente learnynge amonges others adrianus wrote booke latin tounge alſo commended vnto eraſmus roterodame whoſe epiſtles hys behalfe yet remaine menne louaine hadde publyſhed theyr ſentence luther tooke theyr aduiſe adriane cardinall derthuſe spayne hollander borne brought vp amonges louaine whome boldned wherefore luther ſo manye ſo greate ennomyes luther letter emperor wrote epiſtle newlye created emperoure charles fifte fyrſte crauynge pardone beinge manne ſo lowe degree ſhoulde attempt write ſo highe prince ſaithe matter weightye cauſeth doe altogether ſuche appertaineth glory chriſt ſignifying written certaine bokes whiche procured diſpleaſure manye deſert broughte contention aduerſaries agaiuſt wikhe muche rather haue ſetten ſtill hath bene chief ſtudye pure doctrine go ſpell might appere againſt falſe tradition men many good excellent learned men beare witnes ſame cauſe hatred diſdaine reproches pearils diſpleſures hath bene theſe thre yeres done much lay matter might taken vp oftner ſought quietnes aduerſaries offended hath oftentimes required ſhew wherin erred teach better thinges hitherto haue aunſwered maner nothing railing wordes cruell iniuries ſekinge quench doctrine goſpell cauſes conſtrained vſe laſt remedy enſamples athanaſius flie vnto ſuccour beſechynge take vpon tuition chriſtian doctrine defende againſte violence iniurie till matter knowen deſyre defence caſe proued maynteyne euill cauſe deſyreth onely thing may tried knowen nothing determined apperteineth office cauſe hath highe power geuen god miniſter iuſtice mainteine right equitie defende pore weake agaynſt iniuries ſtronger like effect writeth ſtates empire reciting fewe wordes howe vnwillynge fall contention howe deſyrous hathe bene haue taken vp condition hath offered yet doeth ſame longe writeth luth letter archbiſhop mētz archebiſhop mentz cardinall greate ſubmiſſion beynge ſory ſaieth complained vpon ſuche wont praiſe doinges admoniſheth gyue credit talebearer beware flatterer example kynge dauid diſceaued flatteter siba would ſet part ſiniſtrall ſuſpicion workes vntill ſuche time leaſure reade ſelfe two kindes men condemned writinge one neuer red another ſuche read dede malicious minde theſe depraue doynges wherin man coulde fynde errour teache better woulde glad folowe hathe oftentymes ſo proteſted aſmuche truſted well great humanitie borne brought vp ſame prouince hath cure coulde write thus vnto hym cardinall aunſwered againe pleaſed well aſmuch promiſed defende doynges obſtinatelye annſwere luther would willyngly gyue place vnto ſuche coulde reache better thinges albeit delighted muche religion yet leaſure hitherto reade workes therfore would • iot iudge leaue vnto others taken thinge hande neuertheleſſe would wiſhe bothe expoſitours ſcripture ſhould handle euery thing reuerently modeſtly without ſcripture muſt hadled reproche enuie ſory heare men diſpute openly ſupremacie byſhoppe rome frewill supper lorde ſuche queſtions full daunger part could contente learned men ſhould conferre theſe matter frendly amonges ſelues would blame teaching truth ſo done without bitterneſſe contempte eccleſiaſticall power profeſſe trueth good zeale continewe preſumpſion malice permanent longe endure abuſeth god giftes heapeth vp doubtleſſe ſore vengeaunce vpon ſelfe luther wrote alſo biſhoppe merſebourge ſame thing luth letter biſh oy merſeburge effecte touching doctrine clere conſcience taught none thinge chriſt apoſtles becauſe maners lyfe aunſwere profeſſyon wiſheth remoued office preaching ſeketh lucre deſyreth vaine glory thing onely euerlaſtyng veritie myght knowen men condemne workes moued maruelous hatred abuſe byſhop rome name fulfyll owne affection whereas many learned men foren nation haue writtin letter reioyſyng writinges geuing thankes ſame whervpon beleueth rather hath taught ſounde doctrine wherfore requireth deale fatherly ſhewe faulte way hitherto coulde obteyne ſo muche matter might hearde notwithſtandyng hath aunſwers luther erneſt prayer required alſo man ſhould greater pleaſure take errour whereunto biſhop aunſwereth hath bene oftentimes carefull litell ſory hath written amonges others boke lordes supper wherwith many ſore offended people vnder cure greatly inflamed doctrine chiefly ſory reprehendeth ſharpenes writing ſaith albeit ſtraungers like yet allow ſame wiſheth woulde bringe chriſtian minde voide affection handlinge matter furthermore chargeth haue ſpoken vnreuerently biſhop rome • thing neither becometh mete ſuffered wherefore admoniſheth applye dexteritie wit dthirthynges may profit common wealth leaue thys bitter contention laſt al requireth error may ſhewed promiſeth tractable ſaith anſwer therto wryting au time ſhal mete wil talk large duke fridericke ſame time certaine • rtes rome commended ualentine ditleb germane ſent worde matter well hearde rome reaſon raſhnes leud demener luther written many thinges bitterly ſpitefully againſte biſhop church rome college cardinal fellow nouriſhed maintained moſte men affirmed whan duke receiued theſe letter aunſwereth neuer intent defende luther doctrine maintenaunce neither dothe take vppon iudgement thinges luther teacheth heareth dede doctriue well allowed learned men iudge therof hath long ſince made offer may haue ſure ſauf conduicte rendre reaſon doctrine biſhoppes legate ſo euer hys error ſhewed moſte ready forſake hys opinion thus hathe proteſted openlye althoughe thys myghte appeare ſufficient yet admoniſhed hym long ſence wold haue forſaken country charles meltice aduiſed contrary thought better ſhould remaine ſtil go place perauenture hauing libertye mighte ſetforth worſe thinges hitherto hath done wherfore iuſt cauſe alledged ſuſpect euil truſteth fare neuer worſe biſhops handes therfore wold right hartely ſory erroure ſpronge vp time ſhoulde ſaid defended eſtabliſhed deuiſeth wt familiarely howe contention began reaſon eckius others excellent wittes good learning knowledge tōges floriſhe nowe germanye deſire common people haue read ſcriptures luther doctrine infixed many men mindes ſo vſed otherwiſe well like ſtyrre vp ſuche tumultes germany turne nother biſhop mā el profit duke thus written kalends aprill receiued vi day iuly letter biſhop rome wherin reioyſed little wold haue nothing wyth luther wicked man affirming euer good opinion foraſmuch graue mē haue aduouched true good wil bare hereby little encreaſed thing doth rightwel become hys houſe hath euermore done great honor church rome ſingulare wiſdome doth alſo herein appeare perceiueth ſente chriſte sathan ennemye almankinde whiche mad kinde ambition reyſeth vp agayne hereſyes wiclife huſſe condemned whiche ſeeketh fauoure people vayne glorye whichs falſe enterpretatiō scripture giueth ſimple occaſion ſinne diſpiſeth chaſtitie ſpeaketh againſte confeſſion penaunce beareth fauoure turkes raileth againſt diſcipline church lamentech puniſhemente heretikes briefe turneth thinges vpſide growen ſuch pride arrogancie contemning aucthoritie counſelles biſhoppes rome woulde haue hys owne oppinion take place againſt iudgement mē wherfore wittely done haue familiarytie ſo peſtilent fellowe alowe hys errour whiche thinge graue wiſe men muche commende vertue chieflye giueth god hertie thankes hath giuen ſuche mynde affirming moreouer hath ſuffered borne raſhenes ſee woulde amende aſmuche hathe nothinge preuailed gentle admoniſhmentes compelled vſe extreme remedy fearyng leſt throughe contagion ſhoulde infecte many wherfore callyng counſel cardinalles learned men debate matter hath made decree inſtinction holy ſpirite whiche neuer faileth churche rome copie wherof hath ſent vnto intent might ſee monſtrouſe errours miniſter sathan pope curſeth luther defendeth wilieth therfore vnleſſe openly ſolemnely recant daye preſcribed ſhould commit toward ſo ſhall put away ſhame houſe germany wynne muche honor god highe ſeruice decree ouerlonge ſumme fyrſt byſhoppe leo callynge vpon chriſte peter paule ſainctes tourne awaye daunger hangynge ouer bulle leo church moſt lamentably complayneth ſhould ſpring vp doctrine conteinyng bothe hereſies already condemned alſo newe errours great wickednes germany wont ſo muche churche rome bothe longe ſins late dayes concernyng huſſe thē boheme becauſe numbre chriſtians throughout vniuerſall worlde committed vnto charge chriſt lenger wyncke ſo great matter reciting luther opinion ſaieth againſt chriſtian charitie reuerens men owe duetie churche rome agaynſte counſell aunciente father wherfore conſent cardinalles condemneth work brought forth burned aucthoritie whiche ſaieth hath commaundeth mageſtrates namelye germany ſe thing executed accordingely commeth luther ſhewyng howe fatherly loue ſought refourme howe cited rome promiſed beare charge howe contempte therof appealed coū ſell contrary decree pius iulius decree pius iuliꝰ hereby deſerued puniſhement condigne heretikes yet clementie gyue longer time happely prodigal child amended owne miſery would retourne boſome churche yet alſo minde yea moſte hertely beſecheth adherentes trouble church promyſing great good wyll ceaſe theyr errours notwithſtandynge commaundeth luther teache preſcribynge lx dayes wythin whiche time ſhoulde amende burne owne bokes recante doctrine openlye condemneth heritike ſuffer accordynge yt lawes ſuſpendeth church commaunding al men eſchew talke company vnder lyke penaltie decree red church aſſemblies people certen dayes appointed touching pius iulius thus ſtandeth pius hilde counſell mantua yeare lord mcccclix chiefely becauſe turkiſſhe warre amonges made decree man ſhould appeale byſhoppe counſell vnder coope heauen ſaid coulde nothinge founde better chriſtes uicar longe ſuſpended sigiſmunde duke auſtriche takinge cardinall cuſane priſoner duke appealed counſell wherfore byſhoppe excommunicate george heimburge worker herof commaunding senate norinburge baniſhe citie ſpoile goodes whiche decree renewed iuly maynteyne ſelfe agaynſt cardinalles ſwarued agaynſt kynges prince vniuerſitie paris whiche vſed ofte ſuche refuge biſhop pius called aeneas siluius counſell baſill wrot aeneas siluius euery thing prayſing decree made exceadyngly auaunced highe degree dignitie chaū ged opinion would haue counſell ſubiecte byſhop honor chāge maners luther hearde condemned rome goeth former appellation wherin appealed biſhoppe counſell nowe forſomuche byſhoppe perſeuerynge hys luth impugneth pope cenſure wicked tyrrannye hath proceded ſo farre condemne nether called heard yet conuicte hereſye ſaieth howe appealeth againe counſel chiefly foure cauſes hath condemned pleaſure hearyng controuerſie cōmaundeth denie faith ſacramentes neceſſary preferreth owne decree dotage men scripture leaueth place anye counſell wherefore calleth tyrran proude contemner churche fynallye antichriſte affirmynge ſhewe proue al theſe thinges whenſoeuer ſhall pleaſe ſuperiours therfore prayeth themperour magiſtrates accepte appellation defence god glory libertie counſell would bridell tyrranny thynke decree made concerned nothynge would ſtyrre nothinge tyll cauſe lawfully decided thus appealed xvij day nouembre written boke captiuitie babilon preface luth booke captiuitie babilou wherof ſaieth howe profiteth dayely knowledge holy scripture howe fewe yeares paſte ſet forth booke byſhoppes pardon tyme wrote renerently becauſe ſtoode great feare romiſſhe tyrranny great eſtimation iudgement farre otherwiſe beynge ſtyrred vp prouocation aduerſaries hath lerned see rome nothynge el kyngdome babilon power ſtronge hunter niutroth afterwardes diſputeth sacramentes churche holdeth three onelye baptiſme penaunce lordes thre sacraſes supper treateth alſo foure confirmation order matrimonye unction theſe calleth sacramentes becauſe haue ſygnes annexed promeſſe ſacramentes properly called sacrament haue promiſe thē ioyned ſaith vare ſignes therfore thinketh penaunce coūted numbre thē wil properly exactly ſpeake accordyng difinition word becauſe wāteth viſible ſigne heauēly inſtitutiō yt hard biſhops decre beſides appellation mentioned ſetforth thā another work wherin confirmed mayteyned opinion whiche leo condemned meane time emperor flaunders hauinge ſet thinges ordre appointeth prince electours mete acon ſixte daye octobre inueſted priuces arritſing collen ten mile acon heard ſore plage wherevpon wrote emperour beynge tyme louaam woulde chouſe ſome place townes melt whiche beſtowed great coſte preparyng theyr houſes victualles wordes extenuate force plage encouraginge come wherfore emperour perceuereth ſtyll ſame mynde ſaying ſo lightly alter breake law charles forth thus ordeined wherefore xxi daye octobre come thirther three archebyſhoppes menty collen treuers ambaſſadours duke saxonie marque brā denburge duke saxonie lay ſicke collen next daye rode forthe mete emperour lyghting theyr horſes receiued honorably mouthe lorde mentz anſwereth gently cardinal saliſburge thus ioynynge together marched towardes towne gate mete paulſograue prince elector thouſande ſyre hundred horſes ſome demy launce ſome archer emperour two thouſand al gorgeous apparell iohn duke cleaue foure hundred horſemen fayre armed contended muche saxon whether ſhould go ſo muche preaſe beyng great company fayre many ſuche lyke hath bene ſeldome ſene germany night came vpon thē could entre towne eyther ſyde emperour rode archebiſhoppe collen mentz next folowed ambaſſadour kynge boheme alſo cardinal sedune saliſburge croye ambaſſadours kynges prynces ambaſſadour byſhoppe rome kinge englande onely abſent whiche thought done ſet porpoſe leſt goinge prince germany ſhould ſeme diminiſhe dignitie ſent emperour broughte oure lady churche made hys prayer talked thelectors part ſo went lodgyng next daye met againe church ſuche preaſe people harueſed men muche kepe backe middes churche hangeth large crowne floore vnderneth covered clothe arras vpon themperour maner coronatiō laye downe gruflynge whileſt lorde collen ſaid ouer hym certaine prayer whiche ended archeby ſhoppes mentz treuers toke vp led ladyes anltar falleth downe agayne ſayd praiers led ſeate fayre gilted tharchebiſhoppe collen goeth maſſe litle proceded demaūdeth latin whether wil kepe catholicke faith defende church miniſtre iuſtice reſtore empire defende widowes fatherles ſuch others diſtreſſe whether gyue dewe reuerence biſhop rome hath aſſented led vnto aultar taketh othe vpon ſame ſo retourneth ſeate againe archebiſhoppe collen aſketh prince whether perfourme gyue theyr faythe allegeaunce whiche thing promiſed againe certein praiers finiſhed annointeth breſt head boughtes armes palmes hādes done archebiſhoppes mentz treuers lead reuſtry apparelled like deacon bring agayne chayre prayer ſayde collen accompanied wyth two delyuereth hym sworde drawen commendeth vnto common wealth againe puttinge vp sworde ſkabarde putteth alſo rynge fynger aboute roobe royalle moreouer reacheth hym scepre appell golde repreſentynge ſhape rounde worlde three archebiſhoppes together ſet diademe vpon hys head ſo led aultare ſweareth agayne wil dewtye good prince afterwardes followe conueing vp higher place ſet ſeate ſtone tharchebiſhoppe mentz ſpeakyng vulgare tounge wiſheth great proſperitie commendynge vnto moſte diligently ſelfe peres ſtates empire likewiſe prebendes churche choſen f •• lowe colledge olde cuſtome done organes trompetes blow vp myrthe melody theſe thynges behelde lady margarate aunte yt • egent flaunders whan maſſe done themperour receiued lordes ſupper dubbed many knyghtes willyng honor time paſt wont gyuen onely ſuche foughten manfully agaynſt theyr enemy rewarde valeauntnes nowe maner kynges ſwordes drawen ſhall ſtrike ſoftely ſhoulders deſyre ordre whether nobilitie marchauntes couet honour churche came palace moſt ſumptuouſly hanged arayed emperoure dined electours alſo euery man ſelfe ſame hall diuers table ſet eche ſyde emperours table archebiſhoppe treuers placed right ouer againſt themperor accordyng lawe charles fourth day auncient cuſtome rooſted whole oxe farſed wyth beaſtes piece whereof ſerued emperours table reſt haue common people moreouer day runne two conduictes wyth wyne free men diuer thēperor retornyng lodging deliuereth tharchbiſhop mentz ye ſeales thempire next day maketh ſupper prince electours daye folowed reparynge churche hearde maſſe worſhipped reliques sainctes amonges others ſay cloth sauioure lapped ſwaddlynge cloutes archbyſhop mentz pronounceth biſhop rome approuynge creation doeth commaunde hereafter vſe name ceſar electours beyng departed contagious place ceſar taketh alſo iourney arriueth collen aboute fyrſte nouembre whence ſendyng letter throughe germany calleth aſſemblie empire wormes agaynſte ſyxte daye ianuarye themperor calleth coū ſel imperial concernyng archebiſhop mentz ſpake howe biſhoppe rome confyrmed emperours creation thus haue tourned totnam frenche late yeres tymes paſt biſhoppes rome wonte approued themperours pore encreaſed wealth onely begyn rule theyr pleaſure alſo length brought vnto paſſe muche ſtrife contention dede pope ſubiecte themperor permitted ſeuen prince germany might electe hym ſaye lyeth theyr power onely cōfirme ratifie ſame authoritie haue vſed many tymes maner throughe realmes chiefly italy fraunce germany tyme haue put downe kynges ſubſtituted others theyr place beſides place canon lawe thepiſtles decretall gregory ix innocentius iij affirmeth aucthoritie choſyng themperor benefit biſhoppes churche rome conueighed grekes germanes tyme great charlemaigne howe theyr partes know iudge whether perſon mete yet cōtēted haue alſo extorted faithe othe higheſt magiſtrate whole vniuerſall worlde whiche thynge hathe bene often tymes cauſe great warres muche miſchief fyne clemēt lawe clement fift bounde lawe lyued yere lorde thouſande thre hundred wheras henry ſeuenth emperour name houſe lucemburge woulde thys ſort bounden ſaid matter newly inuented neyther vſed former time clemēt ſhould come openeth matter large declarynge ſame othe conteyned ſay themperour ſhoulde defende church rome baniſh heretikes haue company wicked mē al meanes poſſible mayneteine dignitie biſhoppes rome yt defend kepeal priuiledges graūted church rome tyme eſpecially ſuch geuen cōſtantine charlemaigne henry otto fourth fridericke ſecōd rodulphe chalenge parte landes poſſeſſions church rome maner title pretence theſe thinges ſaith emperour bounden henry alſo meſſengers promiſed hym leſſe howe ſoeuer diſſembled afterwarde thys decree came forth death emperour henrye ſame clement firſt called forth cardinal frō rome lyon kept court fraunce syns whiche time courte rome fraunce authoritie power emperours hathe decreaſed italy daylye power dignitie biſhoppes bene augmented ſo much theſe dayes lytle time emperours haue ſuppoſed owe faithe obediens euen bounden dewtie chiefe biſhoppes yt haue moleſted oure emperours theſe gregory ſeuenth ix alexandre thyrde innotentius thyrde fourth nicolaus thyrde boniſace eyght clement fyſte nowe let v retourne pourpoſe meane tyme cefar yet collen byſhoppe rome ſent marinus carracciolus hierome aleander encenſe duke saro incenſed againſte luther duke saxonie againſte luther ſpeakynge fyrſte praiſe familie tellynge daunger hāged ouer germany deuiliſhe workes luther demaunded fine two thinges firſte would commaunde bokes caſte fyre ſecondarelye woulde eyther ſee hym executed ſend bounde rome peter bonhomme tergeſte barnarde trent biſhoppes alſo commiſſion ceſar prince germany beyng required ayde ſhould accompliſhe byſhoppes requeſt committed ſayde aleander doctor eckius herynge matter duke fridericke becauſe matter importaunce axynge tyme deliberation fourth daye nouembre anſwer duke friderike maketh aunſwere hys counſell hym ſelfe otherwiſe occupied preſence biſhoppe trent howe farre beyonde expectation biſhoppe rome ſhoulde demaunde anye ſuche thynge hathe alwayes indeuoured ſelfe nothing vnworthy vertue dignitie aunceſtours faithfull ſeruice empire dewe obſeruaunce churche howe hath heard whileſt hath bene frō home eckius hath gone bring trouble onely luther others alſo dominion cōtrary order maner canon lawe whiche thinge righte taketh euil part priuate mā ſhould take vpō medle ſo muche māsiuriſdictiō luther others haue done abſence ſins byſhoppes decre brought knoweth neuer thinge matter neyther nowe haue howebeit teache rightly ſory two yere paſt labour meanes broughte cardinall caietaine auſpurge ſpoken together coulde agree ſo muche cardinall caietane wrote vnto hym letter complaint ſo anſwered ſame time thought ſatiſfied yea take awaye ſuſpicion would haue put luther miltitius letted matter moreouer howe oftener archbiſhop treuers appointed heare matter howe luther wyll appere place ſo euer commaunded ſo may aſſured maketh ſo large great offer required opinion good well learned men hathe thus farre proceded owne accorde pricked forwarde aduerſaries yet hath neyther bene ſo heard emperor others workes ſhould ſo conuicte hercſye ought burnt el would already haue done duetye good prince requireth therefore woulde deale ſorte rather fynde meanes ſome godlye learned menne maye choſen ſhall frendely quietlye heare whole matter luther maye haue good ſafeconduicte bookes burned hathe pleaded cauſe teſtimonies scripture ſownde argumentes conuicted holde hys doynges although bothe cauſe ſhoulde take foile yet woulde truſt byſhoppe would requyre nothyng might ſtande honoure thynges throughe god helpe would ſhoulde become prince empire obdient childe church tyme anſwere geuen ſome deliberation began recite howe many thynges byſhoppe rome done ſuffered luther mighte length retourne right way hath kepte parte promyſe lyeth nowe archbiſhoppe treuers matter ſo muche biſhoppe rome hathe taken ſelfe ſame onely apperteineth iudge ſuche cauſes concluſion theyr talke yt ſaid muſt procede according biſhoppes decree ſo longe burned luther workes luther bokes br •• aleander italian borne right ſkilful hebrew tonge ſometyme reader paris commynge rome grewe eſtimation firſt made archebiſtoppe brunduſe cardinal ſame degre dignitie came alſo carracciolus luther vnderſtoode calleth forthe ſtudentes wittenberge preſens many learned men burneth luther burneth canon law byſhop rome law decree lately publiſhed openly tēth day decembre next day lecture admoniſheth al men regarde theyr ſaluation beware biſhoppes kyngdom afterwarde ſet forth boke wherin ſheweth cauſes burned canon lawe firſt hath bene olde cuſtome obſerued time naughtie peſtilent bokes ſhould burned teſtimony wherof yet actes apoſtles moreouer concerneth dewtie baptiſed chriſte whiche profeſſour open teacher holye scripture impugne wycked doctrine teache men holeſome plucke mēs mindes falſe erronious opinion ſame apperteineth alſo many others although yt bryng letted eyther ignoraunce feare perill oughte yet none excuſe vnleſſe dewtie moreouer biſhoppe rome rable ſo obſtiuate ſhameleſſe onely wyll heare good admonition alſo condempne doctrine chriſt apoſtles compell men committe open idolatry furthermore ſuppoſeth howe theſe booke burner booke burner haue commiſſion burne bookes diuines collen louain emperour finally muche workes beyng burnt brute therof ſpread abroade ouer countreis many growe weaker doubtfull ſuppoſynge caſte fyre withoute cauſe therefore dyd ſeynge aduerſaries paſt remedy burne theyr bookes alſo might therby erecte confyrme mindes men wherfore beſecheth men laying ſyde thambitiouſe proude title aduerſaries would looke nerer thinge howe wicked peſtilent opinion conteyned thoſe bokes law thinge maye better perceyued innumerable hath gathered fewe thynges whiche belonge reproche almightie god iniurie ciuill magiſtrate eſtabliſſhing owne tyranny numbre thyrtie place whereby ſheweth iuſte cauſe burne prouoketh ſhewe reaſons wherfore burnt workes cauſe fewe none haue diuerſe age paſt attempted anithing agaynſte tyrannye antichriſt ſaieth hathe bene scripture hath prophecied howe ſhoulde deſtroy aduerſaries haue kynges aſſiſt seyng therfore prophetes apoſtles haue tolde v ſuche tyrrible thynges come eaſye conſydre howe greate behoueth hys crueltye ſo commeth paſſe ordenarily worldly matter beſt begynnynge thinges procedeth worſte ende whiche hathe proued diuerſe example inuergeth agaynſte citie rome whiche beyng indewed god many benefites ornamentes vtterly gone kynde contagion hathe infected great part world byſhoppes ordinaūce agaynſt lawes agaynſt good cuſtomes nether ſuffered fleeth lawful iudgement affirmeth ſelfe aboue lawes iudgementes tolde fyrſte boke sylueſter prierias wrote agaynſt luther whan anſwered ſharpely ambroſius catarinus italian toke defende ſetting forthe booke dignitie biſhoppe catarinus writeth againſt lut rome whiche luther aunſwereth large interpretynge certen place daniell teacheth byſhoppes tyrrannye paynted proueth ſuche thinges hathe prophecied kyngdome antichriſte altogether concerne see rome catarinus made archbyſhoppe coſſent thirde booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale empire charles fyfte ❧ argument thirde booke duke fridericke obteyneth letter ſafeconduict luther come wormes defende opinion writinges themperor ſtates perſeuereth conſtantly although themperor threateneth wyth baniſhment pope curſed hym bulle lordes ſupper prynces ſeuerally ſoughte peruerté counſell conſtaunce ſet eye vpon occaſion mention made wycleſe iohn huſſc ʒ iſcha bohemer sorboniſtes condempne luther bokes whileſt pope frenche kynge made league swiſſes ʒ wmglius diſwadeth thē takyng penſions thē luter beyng exiled letter patentes auoydeth kynge englande writcth agaynſt pope leo dyeth adrian ſuccedeth solyman greate turke hathe luckie ſucceſſe hongary commotion spaynè themperor couetyng appeaſe treated wyth englande goeth thyther byſhoppe conſtance perſecuteth ʒ wynglius trouble wittenberge annabaptiſtes aryſe aſſemble norinberge pope ſendeth thyther letter ambaſſadours turke taketh rhodes ʒ winglius hauyng ſet forth hys doctrine certeyne article aſſayled papiſtes fyne ghoſpell receyued ʒ uricke duke fridericke accompaniynge emperour emperour ſent luther wormes aſſemblie wormes obteyned ceſar ſayde would call luther heare matter whiche luther vnderſtanding duke letter wrote agayne aboute latter ende ianuary exceadyng glad emperor would vouche ſaufe heare matter dede common cauſe ſhalbe content thing may ſaufe conſciēce wherfore beſecheth prouide ſo may daunger good well learned men may choſen diſpute condemned conuicte hereſie meane time aduerſaries may refraine theyr wonted rayling ceaſe burnynge bookes caſe ſhall nede hereafter enterpriſe anye thinges el god glorye trouthes ſake emperor impeched herin promiſyng fayle come wormes whan ſhall haue receyued themperors ſauffeconduit truſteth ſuch ſorte demeane ſelfe cauſe indifferent iudges worlde may vnderſtande hath done nothing rebellion common wealth chieflye germany haue taken al trauell reduce men many groſſe errours ſownde pure doctrine deſyreth moreouer emperor woulde haue regarde horrible bondage miſerable eſtate chriſtientie oppreſſed throughe mere papiſtrie wherfore ceſar collicted empe writeth luther duke wrote vnto luther ſyxte day marche ſo muche ſetforth certeine bookes determined heare matter ſelfe prince wherfore theſe ſignifie vnto hath free libertie paſſe repaſſe ſafely without daunger plainely doeth appere ſaufe conduict ſent commaundeth therfore take iorney ſpedely fayle within one twentie dayes byſhoppes rome haue accuſtomed thurſedaye paſſion weeke ſolemnely curſe banne certeine kyndes men bul curſyng fyrſt heretikes ſecondarely pirate ſuche eyther reyſe vp new cuſtomes extorte forboden alſo ſuche coūtrefeit bulles iuſtrumentes courte rome moreouer ſell armure turkes saraſyns ſuche vnlawfull ware let hinder corne brought rome hurt man ſuyng belongynge courte rome furthermore ſuche worke damage violence poſſeſſyons neighbour dominion churche rome namely citie rome sicilie naples cardinie corf hetruria spolete sabine ancona flaminie campanie bononie farrare beneuent peruſie auenion former biſhoppes haue named heretikes garaſians pateronians pore menne lion arnoldiſtes speroniſtes wicleuiſtes huſſites fratricelles leo tēth put alſo lutherians curſeth full blacke curſe commonly called bull lordes supper luther got afterwardes tranſlated duche without much myrthe paſtime luther receued emperours letter went wormes ſame heralt came almooſte diuerſe diſwaded hym puttynge mynde howe bokes brent certen preiudice condemnation howe ſame might chaunce ded iohn huſſe ſtoute courage contemned perill ſayinge plainely deuyll woulde put thus feare ſeynge conſtā cie luth kingdome ſhould quayle confeſſion trewth ſo notable place ſo came wormes ſyxt day april next day brought emperour whole counſell lut cōmeth wormes prince emperours commaundement eckius lawyer ſpake vnto wiſe two cauſes martin eckius luther luther whiche emperor conſent prince ſtates hath ſent forth commaundyng enquire thee ſame firſt wherther thou wilt acknowledge theſe bookes thine made thee againe whether thou wilt reuoke thing ſtande defence written therin luther brought wt lawies wittenberge one hierome schurffe lu pleadeth cauſe themperour whole empire title bokes ſhould read ſhewed done luther briefly repeting queſtions propoūded concerning bookes ſaieth confeſſe acknowledge myne whether defende haue written intente make trewe aunſwere nothyng raſhely forſomuch thinge weightie importaunce require time take deliberation thing debated albeit ſaieth thou myghteſt eaſely haue knowen emperours letter thou waſte ſent therfore nowſhouldeſt ſeke delay anſwere yet ceſar clemencie graunteth thee one dayto take aduiſement commaunding thee time declare thou wilte herein mouthe writynge made delay many ſuppoſed would conſtant came next daye eckius ſayde vnto yeſterday thou wouldeſt aunſwere ſeconde demaunde required time whiche myghte ryght well haue bene denied euery man ought ſo certen fayth ſhould aunſwere therto al time much leſſe ſhould great diuine doubt premeditate anſwere ſo euer matter ſayeſt thou nowe wilt thou defend thine owne writinges luther addreſſyng aunſwer emperor counſell prince beſought heare paciently ſhould ought offende eyther wordes maners geſtures vnſemely ſuche preſens beare pardō kinde lyfes ſake hath bene brought vp ſelfe ſaith witneſſe nothinge el haue taughte ſyncerly hitherto thoſe thinges whiche beleue concerne glorye god ſaluation men concernyng bookes anſwered yeſterday made written hath added thyng take mine ſecōde queſtion bokes haue wrytten ſundrie argumentes ſome apperteine onely doctrine fayth vertue whiche myne aduerſaries ſelues commēde ſhould abiure ſhould play parte honeſt man others wherein reprehended byſhoppe rome hys doctrine whereby hath ſore afflicted chriſtian common wealth ſeeth pitifully men conſciens vexed lawes decree deny howe craftely diſceiptfully robbeth countreis chieflye germany maketh yet ende hys rauenynge ſhould aboliſhe theſe bokes ſhoulde confyrme tyrrannye ſhoulde greater preiudice done nowe authoritie emperour prince thirde kynde written agaynſte certeine priuate men whiche woulde defende romiſhe wickednes ſeke euery trap confeſſe haue bene vehement became aſcribe ſelfe holines profeſſion life maners trewe doctrine yet wyll retracte nothynge theſe ſame ſo doyng ſhould ſet open windowe arrogancie manye yet would ſo taken thoughe toke vpon could erre ſo muche propertie man erre diſceaued take defence cauſe ſaying ſauior ſpeakynge doctrine time ſtriken ſeruāt ſayeth haue ſpoken euyll beare wytneſſe euyll wherefore chriſt perfection refuſed witnes moſt vile ſeruaunt iohn xviii againſt howe muche ſynner nature ſhould come whan called man teſtifie bring forth thing againſt doctrine wherfore deſyre honour god haue thynge obiecte agaynſte doctrine profeſſe would hide come forth ſhew errour teſtimony scripture whiche thinge done ſo lytell obſtinate fyrſt men ſhall caſte myne owne bokes fyre hereby maye man iudge led raſhely like one rauiſhed wittes haue waied diligently weightines thinge trouble ingendred doctrine reioyſe greatly whā perceyue doctrine cauſe ſo great offence chriſt ſelfe ſaith nature goſpell ſtyrre vp ſtrife contention euen amonges ſuche ioyned moſt nere bloud nowe therfore noble men ye ought grauely greate deliberation conſyder foreſee leſte condemnynge doctrine throughe ſyngular beuefyte god offred ye cauſe muche incōuenience may therby chaunce vnto germany muſte haue reſpecte alſo newe empire yonge emperor preſent made vnlucky vnfortunate ſome vngodly vnprofitable example poſteriti proued diuerſe place scripture haue empire fallen greate peril tyme common wealth hath bene gouerned onely counſel man wiſedome notwithſtandyng moſt wyſe honourable prince myne intent ſhewe haue ſpeake zeale beare germany natife coū trie ought derer vnto v oure owne lyues reſt beſethe receyue tuition protection agaynſt forſe myne enemyes tyme made ende eckius ſtowning comutenaunce ſayd vnto thou anſwereſt nothing purpoſe noyther thy part call agayne queſtion ſuch thinges haue bene determined intimes paſt aucthoritie counſels thou ſhouldeſt make playne directe anſwere whether thou wilte abide thy writynges ſayd luther aſmuche commaud dement moſt mightie ceſar moſt noble prince ſhall anſwere directly obey therfore myne aunſwere vnleſſe conuinced teſtimonies holy scripture manifeſt reaſon reuoke parte whiche haue written taught neuer thynge ſhould hurte myne owne conſcience biſhoppe rome counſels onely beleue admitte authoritie haue erred pope coſt ſell may erre often tymes ſet forthe thinges contrary one another may erre diſceaued prince layde theyr heades together touchyng aunſwere ſayd eckius thou aunſwereſt luther vnreuerently becommeth thee ſufficientlye matter thy bookes thou makeſt difference caſe thou woulde retract thoſe conteyne greater part thyne errours ceſar woulde ſuffer iniurie done vnto ſuche well written thou diſpiſeſt counſell conſtaunce wheras manye noble well learned men germany reneweſt errours therein condemned wilt conuinced holy scripture herein thou doeſt well art farre abuſed loke thinges church hath condemned ſame maye come newe diſputation euery man ſeke reaſon eche thinge ſpeaketh againſt counſell muſt reproued scripture ſhall nothyng certeinly determined whiche cauſe emperour wyll haue thee pronounce openly thou determineſt thy bookes beſeche ſaieth luther gyue leaue kepe conſcience ſafe ſounde haue anſwered playnely haue none thinge ſay vnleſſe myne aduerſaries ſhew trew argumentes taken scripture take away errour quiet minde able ſhew haue oftentimes ſhamefully erred ſwarue scripture whiche manifeſt cannot erre wicked dede ſayd could proued euer generall counſel erred luther ſayd could would ſo departed time next day emperour ſent letter prince ſyttyng counſell ſignifiyng progenitours profeſſed chriſtian religion euermore obeied church rome ſeing luther doth impugne perſeueryng obſtinately opinion hys dutie requireth folowynge ſteppes hys aunceſtours defende chriſtian religion ſuccor church rome wherfore wyll baniſhe luther adherentes vſe fitte remedy quenche fyre touching promiſe kepe may retorne home agayne ſafe ſound epiſtle muche debated ſkanned amonges prince ſome ſaide promiſe kept according decree made counſel conſtance againſt manye others namely lewes countie palatyne prince elector affyrminge would redounde perpetuall ſhame germany wherupon diuerſe thought mete kepe theyr promiſe alſo condempne raſſhelye weightie matter conſyderyng themperor theſe yeares ſoone moued exaſperated agaynſt luther byſhoppe rome miniſters fewe dayes biſhoppe treuers appoynteth luther come xxiiij daye aprill preſent joachin treuers prince threateneth luther marque brandenburge electour george duke saxonie byſhop auſpurge noble whan luther brought archebiſhoppes chapplaine emperours heraulte ueus lawyer badon ſayde vnto theſe noble prince haue ſent thee martin luther enter diſputation thee treate frēdly thee priuatly admoniſhe thee touching thine owne profyt emperour hath geuen leaue ſo fyrſt may counſels haue taught dyuerſe thinges contrary albeit haue erred yet theyr authoritie ſo decaied herby euery man may treade vnder foote thy bokes well loked wyll ſtyrre vp greate trouble many interprete ſame thou haſt written chriſten libertie theyr owne affection entent maye lyſte worlde nowe corrupte hath bene tofore therfore men muſt worke warely ſome thy workes reproued feared leſt deuill meane tyme petſwade thee ſet forth others agaynſte religion godlines ſo thy bokes may altogether condemned thoſe thou haſt ſet forth laſt declare ryght well tree knowen fruites bloſome thou art ignoraunt diligently scripture warneth v beware noone deuill fliynge arrowe enemye mankynde ceaſeth lye waite v many time vnder godly pretence intrappeth leadeth v awaye errour therefore thou oughteſt conſider bothe thine owne ſaluation men would become thee foreſee leſt ſuche chriſt hath hys death redemed death euerlaſtynge beyng thy faulte bokes prechinges ſeduced churche periſhe againe dignitie church men ought acknowledge reuerently world nothing better thā obſeruation lawes lyke cōmō weale conſiſteth wtout lawes euen ſo vnleſſe moſte holy decree forefather reuerently kept ſhall nothing troubleſome ſtate church ſhould moſt quiet ſtable theſe noble vertuouſe prince preſent ſingular zeale beare commō weale thy cauſe wealth alſo thoughte good admoniſſhe thee theſe thinges doubtles thou wylte perſeuer thus obſtinatlye thine opinion relent emperour wyll banniſhe thee empire wyll forbyd thee haue anye reſtynge place germany ende thou maieſt better conſyder thine owne ſtate wherunto luther replied great good gentlenes luther anſwer prince moſt noble prince ſhewed vnto gyue moſt hertye thankes certenlye man baſer ſorte ſhoulde beſeme ſo noble men take ſuche paine concernynge counſels reprehende chiefly conſtaunce haue iuſte cauſe ſo huſſe defyned churche fellowſhippe god electe bothe ſaying beleued holy churche condemned alſo worthy ſelues condemned ſpake bothe truely like chriſten man therfore ſuffer puniſhement yea ſpend life ſooner ſwarue manifeſt worde god muſte rather obey god men touching offence connneth bookes neyther ought eſchewe offence charitie offenca faith maners faythe differ much wherof conſiſteth life maners muſt anye wyſe auoyded thother whiche cleaueth godes worde regarded trewth commaundemēt heauenly father muſt accompliſhed though whole world ſhould offended scripture calleth chriſt himſelfe ſtone offence ſame appertayneth alſo likewiſe ſuche preach goſpell knowe ought obey lawes magiſtrates ſo haue euermore taught people alſo writinges ſufficiently beare witnes howe muche aſcribe dignitie lawes touchyng decree churche conſideration god word taught ſincerely biſhops paſtours church dewtie like chriſt apoſtles haue ordeined nede impoſe vnto mēs mindes conſciēces yt heauie intollerable burthē men traditiōs moreouer ignorāt ye ſcripture admoniſheth v refrain affectiōs thīg truely ſpoken wilbe glad perfourme neither thinge obſtinately ſo may onely profeſſe doctrine goſpel whan ſayd thus cōmaunded depart whan conſulted matter ueus amonges thinges began perſwade ſubmitte writynges knowledge emperour prince content ſaith wil neuer ſeme refuſe iudgemēt ceſar ſtates thempire ſo maye done scripture god worde whiche maketh ſo much vnleſſe ſame reproue errour forſake mine opinion paule commaundeth beleue aungel comming heauen bringe doctrine wherfore beſecheth prince might kepe ſaufe conſcience theyr mediation emperour mighte obtayne content thing ſaid marque brādenburge wilt thou geue place except thou conuict scripture dede ſaieth luther el manyfeſt reaſons wherfore counſell broken vp archbiſhoppe treuers toke parte began admoniſhe againe might preuaile next day alſo moued commit iudgement vnto ceſar ſenate prince without conditiō vaine noone biſhoppe certeine others required leſt ſubmitte workes nexte generall counſell agreeth therunto ſo matter handled aucthoritie scripture archbiſhop priuate talke alone demaunded remedy would helpe greuous diſeaſe ſayde beſt counſell gamaliel tymes paſt gaue scribe phariſeis contende god fyne coulde preuaile actes v letteth depart gently ſayd would deuiſe ſhould retourne home ſaufeconduicte longe commeth eckius lawier ſaieth vnto aſmuche thou haſt refuſed admoniſhmentes ceſar prince emperour hence forth office apperteineth commaūdeth thee depart hence immediatly graunting thee one twentie dayes thy retourne looke promiſe made thee ſame wil kepe vnbroken charginge thee moreouer yt thy retourne home thou ſtyrre vp people way neither word writing wiſe beyng ſuffered depart luth ſent awaye ſcom wormes gaue glory vnto god way wrote thēperour reſidew prince ſtates repeting whole actiō word requiring thē ſo much hath euer wil ſeke quiet agrement deſireth nothing el yt matter maye indifferently heard iudged scripture wold defende frō force enemy yt priuate cauſe cōmō al world namely germany whoſe weale eſtemeth thā life muche oftentimes mention hath bene made huſſe counſell conſtaunce bohemers ſhall brieflye declare matter iohn wickliffe liued englande yere iohn wicl • ffe engliſhe man lord ccc xciij wrote many thinges agaynſt see rome brought afterwardes lāde boheme prage thē noble uniuerſitie flouriſhed iohn huſſe doctor diuinitie lecture ſermons ſet forthe iohn huſſe bohemer taught wicliffes doctrine holeſome godly beyngt accuſed ſame byſhoppe rome alexander fyfte cited procurer ſheweth cauſes coulde come wencelaus alſo king entreateth requireth would ſend legate boheme vnderſtand matter yt vaine wherefore huſſe condemned rome heritike ſetteth forthe writing wherin appealeth biſhoppe iudge chriſt church rome yt time full trouble cardinal huſſe appealeth pope beyng deuyded choſen three byſhoppes gregory xij benedicte xiij iohn xxiij thinge themperor sigiſmſide kynges right ſory cauſed biſhop iohn ſommon counſell conſtance sigiſinunge brother kynge wencelaus called thither iohn huſſe ſendyng ſafe conduicte coūſel cōſtaūce moneth octobre yere mccccxiiij whereupon huſſe accompanied diuerſe gentleman come vnto conſtance thirde day nouembre three weekes came priuate talke biſhop cardinalles deteined priſoner thēperour abſent beyng certified thing came thyther greate diſpleaſure borne hande promiſe kept heretikes onely content albeit bohemers made oftentimes greate ſute kepe promiſe alſo fyrſt ſpak bitterly againſt finally ſyxt day iuly yere followynge synnode condemned heretike ſedicious parſon workes alſo burſit thus beyng condemned deliuered iohn huſſe hierome praga burned thēperour burned aſhes caſt riuer rhine leſt reliques ſhold remayne hierome prage scolar lyke maner executed counſell beſydes themperour ambaſſadours ſondry kynges thre prince electours lewes countie palatine raffe duke saxonie fridericke marque brandenburge greate numbre prince three patriarch aquileia antioche cōſtantinople xxviij cardinalles civ byſhops diuines lawiers many italian germaines frēchmen engliſhmē hūgariās polonians doctrine wicliffe condemned decree made body englande ſhould taken vp brent furthermore decreed prieſtes onely ſhould receiue hole ſupper lord al others content one kind thinge huſſe impugned alſo lawe made ſhould promiſe kepte heretikes ſuſpected hereſye albeit came counſell examined emperours ſaufeconduicte fynally three byſhoppes depoſed cō mon thre pope depoſed aſſent choſen martin fyfte name whan reported boheme death huſſe hierome aroſe tumulte alſo verye bloudy crewell warre conduicte iohn ziſcha ſo muche sigyſmunde conſtrayned require aide empire moſte crueltie wrought againſt priſtes hatred biſhop rome whoſe tirranny ſhaken receiued doctrine huſſe time diuines paris condemned luther bokes gatheryng ſame certein title theſe sacramentes diuines paris condempne luth bokes theccleſiaſtical lawes vowes contrition abſolution ſatiſfaction purgatory frewyll ſuche like admoniſhyng men profeſſe chriſt beware ſuche heretykes vnder flattering wordes exhibite preſent poyſon wiclyffe huſſe luther thoughe like could ſee others thoughte chriſte woulde haue ſuffered onelye ſpouſe haue wandered ſo longe darkenes errours ſo recytyng bokes ſhew opinion heretikes luther foloweth wherfore ſay ſeyng apperteyneth chiefly profeſſiō ſuppreſſe errours ſpring vp finding doctrine pernicious cōdēne bokes brent ſelf forſed recāt decree theyrs aunſwereth philip melanchthon thauthoritie diuines paris luther ſelfe ſkoffyngly notwithſtandyng diuines paris take vpon herin chiefe europe haue two principall colledges sorbone nauare bachelars diuinitie exerciſed diſputations ſomer time ſpace xij houres muſt anſwere mēs argumētes maruelous cōtentions moſt part either trifle thinges farre exceadyng man capacitie clamorous aboue meaſure ſtrife cōmonly ended hiſſyng clapping theyr auditor time one diſputers either fōde tedious doctor diuinitie ſtāde lateſſe windowes hearkē called magiſtri noſtri cēſours iudges doctrine plainely poſſeſſe kingdō man dare publiſhe thing touching diuinitie permiſſion leo x swyſſes make league wyth frenche kynge already made league wt swyſes yt nede time ſhold haue theyr aide kīg fraūce like caſe cōcluded peace thē laboured thē aide wt mē mony zwinglius ſermons diſwaded ſame declaringe vnto howe vile howe wicked thing ſerue foreine prince money exhorted therfore folow frugalitie elder whiche kepte cattel occupied huſbandry yet done many goodly exploictes vaine chiefe corrupted wyth bribe perſwaded reſte make league alſo kinge aide men saue onely zuricke perſwaded zuinglius refuſed made othe would neuer take wage ſtypende anye prince ſerue warres borne kynges ſonne charles whome thirtene townes swyſſes swyces ſendynge theyr deputy chriſtened fonteſtone heluetians swiceſſe conſiſte thirtene townes zuricke berne lucerna ura swite unterualde tugie glarea baſille solodure friburge schafuſiane apecelle theſe ioyned moſt ſtraite leage othe vſynge one ſame law gouerne common theyr common weale fyrſt made leage uranites swyces unterualdians tyme expulſynge nobilitie libertie swyſſes vnder whome oppreſſed procured owne libertie yere lorde mcccxv came vnto thē lucerne next tugians ſyxte place men zuricke laſt berne baſille ioyned wyth ſocietie ſame lawes ſo great frendſhippe rhetians lepontians sedunites ueragrites sangallians mulluſians rotuuille emperour beyng paſt one twenty yeres age baniſheth luther common decree eyght day may takyng begynning therof owne parſon part office luib ontlawed emperour onely eſtabliſhe augment empire alſo foreſe blemiſhe hereſye ſhould ſpringe vp within limittes ſame progenitours dede haue bene diligent men herin wherfore mete vnto whō god hath giuen ſo large ample dominiōs ſhould folow ſteppes vnleſſe ſhould puniſhe nowe hereſyes lately ſpronge vp germany ſhoulde bothe hurte owne conſcience beginning reigne ſore blemiſſhe name dignitie well knowen vnto men wicked doctrine luther hathe ſpread abroade nowe theſe three foure yeres agaynſte byſhoppe churche rome againſt decree auncient father namely againſt coū ſel conſtance great reproche thēperor sigiſmūde prince germany yt preſent wherfore ſyns hys bokes nothing el conteined ſedition diſcorde warre murther miſchief ſo yt appereth man wrote thē rather deuil man likenes zeale beareth common wealth dignitie biſhoppe rome doth condemne proſcribe aucthor sciſmes manyfeſt obſtinate heretike commaundynge men vnder great penaltie ſo accepte thre weekes wherin gaue leaue retourne apprehende bringe vnto al ſuch ſhall fauour aide doynges baniſheth like caſe commaundeth alſo bokes ſhould brent appoyntynge greate penaltie herafter stationer commaunding decree ſayeth made common conſent aſſent prince well obſerued men ſay decree made fewe diuerſe electours confeſſed made priuie ſhall declared hereafter archebyſhoppe collē archbiſhoppe mentz beyng chauncelour empire maye muche ſuch matter ſo euer came paſſe emperour hereby wanne muche fauoure ſo muche biſhoppe rome cleane forſakynge frenche kynge made league ſhall declared hereafter tyme publication duke fridericke appointed certein nobilitie eſpecially truſted conueighe luther luth conuetghed daunger way ſome ſecrete place might eſchewe daū ger whiche thinge done bothe diligently cloſelye carefulnes luther wrote diuerſe epiſtles frendes alſo bokes concernyng abrogating priuate maſſe whiche dedicateth sunday bokes luth brother auſten freres religious uowes father iohn luther booke agaynſt iames latomus doctor louaine auſten freres beganne nowe fyrſte men leaue maſſyng cauſe luther compiled booke might encourage weake confyrme ſkylfull exhortinge muche perſeuer ſame purpoſe whiche thinge knowen duke friderick fearing ſome great trouble commotion ſhould arriſe therof commaunded opinion whole uniuerſitie herein ſhould knowen brought vnto uniuerſitie choſe iiij ſame purpoſe iuſtus ionas themaſſe aboliſſhed philip melanchthon nyclas amſtorfe iohn dulce conferryng auſten freres brought worde theyr intēt furthermore declared iniury done lordes supper wherfore beſeche prince would aboliſh ſo great wickednes one churche onely alſo place ſet vp trew vſe lordes supper accordyng chriſtes commaundement maner apoſtles ſtoutly contemnyng al reproches aduerſaries hath euerbene ſene ſo taketh hande maynteine trew doctrine goſpel muſt ſuffre many thinges ought greatly foreſee accept reuerently preſent gifte god wherwith chiefly adorned reaſon lyght ghoſpell ſpronge vp amonges people wherunto duke anſwered would leaue nothing vnattempted might god glory ſo muche thing ful difficultie thinketh good beto haſtie litel ſo fewe bringe effect caſe matter grownded scripture ſhall doubtles haue mo take theyr part thē ſhall alteration ſhall ſeme godly neceſſary conueniently brought paſſe ſelfe ignoraunt scripture cā tel time accuſtomed vſe maſſe reproue came vp yt maner apoſtles vſed lefte taketh moſt part colledges church fownded maſſes whiche ſhould put downe landes taken awaye geuen ſame purpoſe euery man might well conſyder hurly burly would follow vpon ſame wherfore aduiſe ſhalbe go conſult matter reſt good well learned men vniuerſitie theyr heades leyde together ſuche meanes may foūde maye kepe godly quiet theſe men deliberation make anſwer admoſhing put downe thē maſſe thinge maye done without tumult thoughe coulde yet whiche righte godlye woulde therfore lefte vndone fewer numbre newes euer ſyns worlde began greater part men haue reſiſted trewe doctrine moreouer yt thoſe beſt thiges pleaſe feweſt men onely ſhall receiue ryght vſe lordes supper vnto whome ſhall gyuen aboue furthermore colledges fyrſt inſtituted maſſes youth myght vertuouſely brought vp learnynge landes gyuen fynde ſome teach ſome learne reſte vſe pore vſe haue continewed maner time barnarde aboute foure hundreth yeares ſyns marchaundiſe maſſes began whiche vtterly taken awaye albeit originall thereof yet auncient yet ſo great wickednes ſuffered caſe buſynes ſhold come therof ſame ought aſcribed doctrine wickednes owne lucre impugne truthe againſt conſcience ought regard ſuch inconueniences procede conſtantlye trouble ſo euer ſhall come therof theſe thinges ſhewed chriſt thys yeare themperours brother farnando archduke auſtriche marieth lady anne ſiſter lewes kinge hongary emonges ſo many aduerſaries luther henry eyghte kynge englande wrote ſoore agaynſt fyrſt confuteth iudgement henry kyng englande writeth againſt luth touching indulgence defendeth biſhops authoritie reproueth diſputations concerning sacramentes churche taking occaſion writing boke intitiled captiuitie babylon whan luther knewe therof anſwered moſt vehemently ſhewynge defence cauſe one whit reſpecte highnes dignitie parſon cauſe biſhop leo gaue kynge honorable title callyng defendour faith howe kynge charles choſen emperour fore declared wheras euer ſyns certen priuate dyſpleaſures growe themperor hath warre fraūce betwixte hym frenche kynge brake warres fyrſt border spaine flaunders ſame tyme frenchman kept parma placence italy biſhoppe leo right ſory alſo late attēpted rhegium vtterly forſoke entred league emperour wherof chief condicions theſe dignitie churche rome ſhould defended ſuche townes frenchemen late taken ſhould recouered france sfortia time baniſhed man ſhould reſtored father ſeat dukedome millan thus ioyning power together recouered frenchman parma placence force toke citye millan droue french king lumbardy kept quiet poſſeſſion fullye vi yeares afterwardes reſtored sfortia conduit proſper columne fernando daualle marque piſcare lōg theſe newes wer brought leo departed without ſuſpicion poyſening ſōne vnto laurens medices death leo x great grandfather coſmus yt great honor houſe leo made cardinall xiii yeares old liued paſt ſeuen forty ſucceſſor adriane ſixt hollāder bene tutor emperour ſame time soliman adrian ſuccedeth leo lately created emperour turkes moued warre vpon lewes king boheme hungary maried lady marye themperours ſiſter beſides many townes caſtels tooke turke taketh belgrade belgrade chief fortreſſe hungary placed therin garriſon whileſt ceſar maketh abode flaunders germany greate ſeditions aroſe spaine wherfore intent might remedye thing time hauing firſt appoynted coūſel miniſter law commotfôs spaine ſee affaire thempire ſaileth againe spaine toke iorney ſtates thempire readye aſſembled norinberge concerninge diuers matter chieflye turkyſhe warre ceſar ſending forth proclamation later ende marche warneth chiefly eccleſiaſticall parſons pray make theyr ſupplications vnto god afterwardes fyrſte maye aide graunted kynge lewes themperour retourne goeth agayne ſee kynge englande haue aſſured frende agaynſt frenche kynge promyſeth geue hym yerely hundreth three thyrtie thouſande duckates ſo muche frenchkynge paye yearely kynge englande ſyſter mary french quene wherfore vnleſſe mighte ſaued harmeles would attempt nothing againſt treatie made thirtene day iune caſtell wyndſore xx myles lōdon entiere loue frendſhip agreed emperour ſhoulde take wyfe lady mary kynges daughter aunte quene kataryne marry whē lady mart aſſured thēperor time ſhould ſerue ſhe ſeuen yeares age whetherſoeuer brake pay foure hundred thouſande crownes frenche kynge bendeth force towardes italy recouer loſt haue heard zuinglius hugh byſhoppe conſtance within whoſe prouince zuricke aduertiſed senate complaintes heard zuinglius kynde newe doctrine broughte defendeth hys cauſe senate whome ſatiſfied byſhoppe wrote letter college canon wherof zuinglius one ſpeakyng muche new doctours troubled churche exhorteth take hede beware ſo muche leo biſhop rome emperour alſo haue moſt ſtreigth proclamation condemned thys doctrine warneth obey ſame neyther alter chaunge thinge till haue authoritie ſhould decree ſome thinge generall counſell moneth maye epiſtle read colledge zuinglius whome concerned wryteth agayne byſhop vnderſtondeth right well whoſe motiou doeth admoniſheth folow theyr counſell trueth inuincible reſyſted afterwardes longer letter anſwereth thoſe whiche ſtyrred vp biſhoppe write zuinglius certein others intreate biſhop letter would hynder doctrine goſpell ſuffer longer filthy ſklaunderous life priſtes permitte marrye ſame effecte writeth heluetians admoniſhyng thē ſtop courſe trewe doctrine worke diſpleaſure agaynſte maryed author ſingle life prieſtes ſingle life deuill ſelfe author many theyr townes maner whan receyue newe miniſter churche bidde take leman leſt attempt defyle honeſt woman whiche cuſtome althoughe laughed many yet wittelye diuiſed tyme ſerued ſo greate darkenes doctrine depraued ſame touchinge theyr concubine ought nowe euery receiued lawfull wine meane tyme luther kepte ſelfe cloſſe cercertein monethes retorneth wittenberge fearinge leſt duke lut rotaurneth wittenberge ſhould take euyll part writeth vnto marche ſignifiyng retourned without commaundement dyd ſo euill wyll contempte knoweth ſome beare hande ſame ſhall daungerous grace aſmuche condemned bothe biſhoppe rome themperour whoſe power bothe great conſyder longe ofte three cauſes retourne fyrſt oftentimes requeſted ſundrye letter churche wittenberge retourne whoſe deſyre coulde accompliſhe ſame people properly committed charge god ought neglected albeit ſome muche offended refourmation doctrine reporte euill therof yet knoweth moſte certenly profeſſion vnto god moſt acceptable secondarely tyme hys abſence throughe crafte deuill abyde lyght ghoſpell ſtyrred vp trouble churche whiche vnleſſe ſelfe preſent coulde well appeaſed matter ſo great weightie might wiſe neglected thinge might haue bene diſpatched letter coulde righte eaſelye haue forborne wittenberge thyrdely ſayeth feareth doth maner foreſee wō derfull great tempeſt germany ſo rackleſly doeth contemne luther foreſeeth teni peſt cōmyng preſent benefite god many dede embrace trewe doctrine liuyng ſklaunder abuſynge libertie ſpirit theyr carnall appetit others wholy gyuen quēch oppreſſe worde rare howe whiche contempte word god muſt nedes punniſhe one plage time paſt iewes theyr citie hieruſalem wherefore part ſuche others admoniſhe men hereof whole force diligēce albeit ſhould trauaile vaine laughed yet may therfore leaue theyr office vndone ſeyng pleaſeth god hathe committed vnto cure ſoules wherefore prayeth offended thus retourned beyng neither called commaunded ſythe altogether chriſtes cauſe truſt ſhall ſuſtayne diſpleaſure perill retourne trouble whiche abſence ſayde churche andreas caraloſtadius meane tyme luther abſente preached contrary doctrine diſorderlye ſtyrred vp people caſte image oute churche cauſe luther beyng called againe frendes diſpraiſeth raſhenes caroloſtadius ſhewyng fyrſte image ſhould haue bene remoued people hart inſtructed god pleaſed image faith onely ſhould taken away ſame done magiſtrates tumulte rage common people ſame tyme began ſecte ſaide talke god commaunded ſleyng wicked men ſhould begin new world wherin onely holy innocent people ſhould lyue beare rule theſe kepte ſelues priuelye parte saronie lyeth riuer sala whoſe opinion ſaith luther caroloſtadius alſo fauoured could bringe hys matter paſſe wittenberge beynge defaced luther aucthoritie went then vnto ſorte men thomas muncer whiche ſtyrred vp people againſt theyr magiſtrates thuringe franconie ſhall recyted place luther hearyng yt lande boheme ſome whiche common aſſemblies counſeiled receiue agayne biſhop rome luther writeth bohemers aucthoritie elles ſhoulde neuer ende contention controuerſies wryteth vnto moneth auguſte name time paſt odioſe hated ſuch tyme knewe biſhop rome antichriſte nowe ſyns god hath reſtored worlde lyght goſpell iudgeth farre otherwiſe ſo hath profeſſed workes ſo muche nowe byſhoppe clientes much offended thē aduerſaries haue many tymes ſaied howe fledde boheme dede hath ofte wiſſhed go thyther leſt ſhoulde call iourney runnynge awaye hath altered purpoſe nowe matter brought ſuche paſſe good hoope howe germaynes bohemers ſhall profeſſe goſpell ſame religion together many ſory deuided ſectes greued without iuſte cauſe reuolte vnto papiſtrie ſhall onely take awaye theyr ſectes increaſe ſwarme many ſectes popiſh kingdome ſame mo ſectes romiſhe kyngdō ſene graye freres differ much amonges themſelues yet ſuche thinges done mainteined byſhop rome whoſe kyngdome throughe men diſcorde nouriſhed eſtablſſhed verye cauſe whye ſetteth prince together eares ſeketh alwaies ſtyrre vp matter grudge diſpleaſure wherfore let thē take goodhede leſt whileſt go aboliſh thoſe leſſer ſectes fal pernicious al thoſe romiſh vtterly vncurable frō thorow god benefit germanye latelye delyuered howe better medicine take awaye euill paſtours churche woulde ſetforth doctrine goſpell purely ſyncerely caſe reteyne weake people theyr dewtie wyll reuolte leſt wyſe let indeuour kepe ſtyl lordes supper wholy memoriall huſſe hierome prage vndetiled may biſhop attempt take theſe two thinges chiefly wherfore relent graunr tyrant bothe ſhall well done howe though 〈◊〉 boheme reuolte yet ſet forth commende doctrine huſſe vnto poſteritie wherfore praieth exhorteth 〈◊〉 perſeuer ſtate religion whiche haue defended 〈◊〉 muche bloud valeauntnes neither 〈…〉 yng blemiſhe goſpell nowe floriſheth beit al thinges wel eſtabliſhed amonges yet god fayle whan ſeeth time ſtyrre vp ſome faythfull miniſter reforme religion ſo wyll conſtant vtterly refuſe fylthines wickednes romiſſhe biſhoppe concernyng bohemers thus ſtandeth death iohn huſſe people boheme wer deuided three ſectes bohemers three ſectes oue part toke biſhoppe rome head churche uicar chriſt another ſorte receyued lordes suppes kyndes maſſes certeine thynges reherſed vulgare tounge differing nothing el papiſtes thyrde ſort called picardes call biſhop rome antichriſte whore babilon deſcribed reuelation admitte nothynge bible choſe theyr owne prieſtes biſhoppes forbid man mary pray dead holy dayes ceremony haue fewe luther compiled boke againſte falſe named order lu writeth againſte biſhoppes biſhops preface wherof ſaith great ſhame ſo many great liuinges honourable title proſeſſyng maiſters whole scripture yt dare come diſpute onelye indifferent iudges beyng ſo ofte prouoked therunto wherfore ſaieth hence forth ſubmitte writynges vnto dyd wormes doctrine chriſtes lyueth reigneth euer reſtraine theyr madnes bluddye enterpriſes decree biſhop rome thēperor name marke great beaſt taken thāketh god highly hath deliuered ſtiking dōgeon moſt filthy error wicked doctrine lightened trewe knowledge worde wherof ſo certein yt herafter ſubmit doctrine iudgement angell teſtimony therof iudge ſelfe angel alſo wherfore warneth thē put truſt theyr tyrany ſwell theyr malice enuie againſt hym boldely proceds purpoſe chriſt liueth reygneth confounde cruell bloddy enterpriſes would wiſhe dede theyr amendment yt wil wil haue ſuch continual warre thē ſhall neuer recōciled charge franke rebuking thē ſhuld ſtyrre vp people againſt muche wronge proued scripture yt ſuch reprehēſions neceſſary paſtors church bevnlearned wicked obſtinate neither doynge dutie thēſelues permitting others yt would right well coūſel norinberge lewis king hūgary ſent ambaſſadors lamētably cōplaining turkes great crueltie deſyred ſtrōge cōtinual aide thither ſent alſo adriā biſhop adrian writeth duke sa rome hierome rorare one chāberlaines letter duke friderike ſignifiyng yt right glad heare thaſſēbly norinberge truſting yt ſhalbe ſome thing done yt ſhall cōcerne cō mon weale cauſe hath alſo determined cōſent cardinal toſēd ambaſſador thither yt meane thought good ſēde mā ſignifie vnto whō hath euermore loued derely good affectiō towardes common wealth ſhall better know ambaſſador yt foloweth exhorteth praieth hi yt price thēpire tuition empire church rome cōſiſteth wold trauaile cōſult diligētly thing yt cōcerne dignitie thapoſtolical church trāquilitie cōmon weale folow herein ſteppes noble progenitor deſyringe giue credite ierome ſuche thynges hath wylled debate wt farnādo archduke auſtriche ſtraight executer ſentēce giuen yere againſt luther dukedome wittenberge helde ſame time ſet forth ſore proclamation xxvj day nouēbre promiſyng rewardes promotors prouinces puniſhed extremely thoſe yt obeied pope lawes reucline dieth yere departed reucline pure aged man whō eraſmus roterodame commended goodly dialoge attributyng vnto hym immortalitie excellencie knowledge three tonges latter ende nouembre adrian biſhop rome ſendeth letter whole aſſemblie norinberge ſins time pope writeth letter prince germany firſt choſen thoffice apoſtleſhip neuer wiſhed thinge yt might euery cōdition accompliſh
