dewtie good paſtour ſuffring one ſhepe flocke go farre ſtray asmuch might done vigilant eye carefulnes herof taketh god witnes hath auaunced vnworthy dignitie neuer loked intent might eaſely atteine purpoſe hath greatly exhorted kynges prince abſteine frō ciuil warres nedes make warre bende theyr forſe power againſte enemy chriſtian faith ſame yt aſſaied perſwade others hathe performed ſelf hauing ſent great ſum money knight rhodes preſent great daunger thēperor turkes afterwardes calling home remēbraūce forein periles loking narrowly vpō domeſtical euils heareth great diſcōfort yt martin luther hath oftētimes bene gently fatherly admoniſhed length whan none remedy cō demned baniſſhed certein uniuerſities leo predeceſſor alſo themperor cōmon cōſent yet put ſilēce ſtyll libertie ſetting forth dayly new bokes chriſtiā religiō al honeſt liuing ſore decaied thing greueth hi ſo much heareth ſaye howe diuerſe nobilitie fauoure hym matter ſo farre gone eccleſiaſticall parſons daūger loſe lādes dignitie germany touching ye thing certein haue already ſtyrred vp ciuil war 1 corin 〈◊〉 trewly ſpokē paule yt iiedes muſt hereſies thinges ſtād chaūſeth moſt ceaſon deuill diſpoſed wrap v ſondry calamity one time inſtigation fury turkes hereſie luth oppreſſe v although v poſſible diſcōfite foreine enemie yet ſo lōg domeſtical aduerſarie vnuāquiſhed ſhould litel preuaile time yet spaine hearde muche luther falſe opinion albeit greued yt ſuch euyl ſhold ſpring countrey borne yet comfort ſelf wt ij thing fyrſt truſte ſo trifelynge wicked doctrine ſhould haue bene diſpiſed men secondely ſuche peſtilente plante broughte place ſhould lightly take roote countrie whiche alwayes ingendred roters hereſyes hath chaū ſed otherwiſe whether iuſt iudgement god throughe certeine negligence rackleſnes ſuche ſhoulde haue redreſſed tyme uerelye nede looke leſt whileſt worke ſlowlye herin appere eyther haue forgotten olde vertue el approue wickednes alledgyng amonges thynges ſhame ſo ſtronge ſo conſtaunt nation ſwarue religion whiche chriſt apoſtles haue lefte v whiche ſo many martyr notable perſons alſo forefather haue kept obſerued motion ſory frere hathe folowed profeſſed ſame ſelfe many yeres thoughe erred luther frere ſo many hundreth yeres though chriſt hath promiſed euer amonges v woulde haue ſuffered churche remayne ſo lōg errours thoughe onely wiſe ſtyrred vp god intent open errour whole worlde thinges doubtles wiſe mockerye laughed haue deuiliſh purpoſe vnder pretence chriſtiā libertie may contemne lawe rule aucthoritie work outrage lyſt ſeyng haue already cōmitted ſacrilege vnreuerently handled lawes holy biſhoppes counſels yea caſt fyre thinke wyll knowe obey ciuill magiſtrate haue begon ſley prieſtes enter vpon poſſeſſions ſo wil fine ende theyr miſcheuous enterpriſes prince themſelues theyr wiues childrē family wherfore praieth exhorteth aucthoritie office beareth ſucceſſour peter chriſtes vicar alſo chargeth commaundeth layinge diſpleaſure part newe reconciled mindes come wholye together quenche cōmon domeſtical flāme puniſhing luther amende according new decre made thēperor folowyng herin thexample theyr elder coūſell cōſtance burned iohn huſſe hierome prage wel deſerued whoſe vertu caſe nowe would imitate god ſhould faile thē might alſo hope giue repulſe turke violence wil beſtowe treaſures yea hys lyfe alſo flocke committed charge reſt concernynge luther ſhall knowe hys legate fraunces cheregate byſhoppe aprutia vnto whome prayeth gyue credite ciuill warre ſpake betwyxte rycharde warre treuers archebyſhoppe treuers fraunces sickynge noble man fauoured luther muche notwithſtandynge cauſe warre religion bicauſe biſhop would ſuffer two men wythin hys iuriſdiction whome became ſuertie aunſwere law ſo mentioneth writyng wherin fraunces ſente hym defiaunce aboute latter ende auguſte byſhop adrian wrote letter ſame effect certein others alſo greatlye deteſted doctrine luther required senate straſbourge ſhould ſuffer bookes pope letter straſburge adherentes printed ſuche ſet forthe already ſhoulde onely ſuppreſſe burne alſo heareth ſay howe ſuche maner bookes put print theyr men contrary workes refuſed whereunto vnleſſe obey threateneth wrath vengeaunce god although perſeuer neuer ſo much olde religion yet vnleſſe take others libertie offende occaſyon errour let loke ſcape vnpuniſhed ſaieth whileſt spaine hearde luther thus ſtandeth ſtocke aorian adrian poore man ſonne utrecht egge hollande learninge whiche gote uniuerſitie louain called scolemaſter charles nowe emperour afterwardes beyng ſent ambaſſadoure spaine obteyned biſhopricke derthuſe kyng ferdinando whoſe death gouernement came vnto kyng charles remayned chiefe counſel ſame time biſhoppe leo diſſention betwixt leo cardinal fell variaunce cardinal conſpired death ſo muche diſpatched ſo many exile impriſonnement made one thirtie newe cardinal one tyme partly owne defence partly get money amonges adriane one afterwardes whileſt emperour wēt crowned germany gouernemēt spaine abſens whan leo tenth died wheras iulius medices alexander farneſius laboured excendyngly adriane beyng abſent vnknowen choſen biſhoppe ix daye ianuary yeare lorde thouſande fyue hundred twenty two hearinge thereof wrote letter thanckes colledge cardinalles good opinion whereas iii cardinal appointed ſent ambaſſadours spaine willeth ſpare theyr paynes ſo ſhortly may come rome ſelfe writeth moreouer senate people rome litel diſpleaſed ſtraunger ſhoulde haue dignitie promiſinge ſoeuer pleaſure could ſhew fewe monethes chaunſynge fayre wynde taketh ſhyppynge italy arryueth rome monthe auguſt beit ſame tyme ceſar commynge flaunders appeaſe rebellyon arryued spaine yet departed neuer bad hym fare well wrote vnto hym gentell letter ſignifiyng great haſt time soliman emperor turkes beſieged rhodes three monethes ſeuenth moneth knightes ſame defended ſelues moſt valeauntly beyng deſtitute aide ſuccor toke cōpoſition xxv decē ber onely oure great loſſe ſhame alſo ſelf ſame time cheregate biſhop rome ambaſſador came norinberg vpon new yeres day ſent frō then senate straſbourgh biſhoppes letter offering ſeruice caſe would writ anſwere whileſt many bare grudge towardes zuinglius diuerſe well within citie without preched againſt doctrine wicked ſwaruing faith eſpecially black freres againe affirmed agreable scripture able proue ſenate zuricke called cōuocation prieſtes diſputatiō zuricke within juriſdiction xxix january controuerſie religiō time men ſhalbe heard ſo much ſhalbe requiſite require alſo louingly theyr letter biſhop conſtance yt either would come ſelfe ſende deputie thefore came many dai appointed amōges others iohn faber biſhoppes deputie borowmaſter ſpeaketh theſe wordes foraſmuche great diſſention ryſen religion therfore aſſemblie called intēt mā hath ought ſay againſt yt doctrine zuinglius may ſpeake ſame frely zuinglius compriſed doctrine certein common place theme nūbre lxvij publiſhed queſtions zuinglius ſame place intent men might come diſputation fourniſhed prepared time borowmaſter done ſpeakyng propoūded ſame againe deſyring ioyne hym diſputation whan faber ſhewed cauſe hys commyng goeth perſwade place mere decide matter religion ſame apperteineth generall counſell whiche truſted ſhould ſhortely zuinglius required diſpute thinge ſaye diſſemble matter ſaid would confute doctrine writyng many wordes betwixt neither would come forth diſpute senate breakynge vp aſſemblie commaundeth throughe dominion tradition men layde ſyde ghoſpell ſhould taught ſyncerely bokes olde new teſtament ❧ fourth booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale empire charles fyfte ❧ argument fourth booke pope adriane ambaſſadoure vttereth manye thinges confeſſeth wickednes rome prince germany anſwere propounde conditiond counſell alteration denmarke chriſtierne kyng ſleeth ſpeaketh impoſtes ouer germany fyrſt fruictes tenthes dere mantel archbiſhops burning two auſten freres decree norinberge expounded luther certeine bokes written complaint made kyng englād adriane dieth clement ſuccedeth trouble swyſſerlande ʒ uinglius doctrine straſbourgh mariage prieſtes aſſemblie norinberge cardinall campegius came ambaſſadour clemente prayeth duke friderike hauinge ſpoken counſell prince make aunſwere replie trouble arriſe swiſerlande againſte ʒ uricke rendre reaſon theyr doctrine ambaſſadours ſent cā ton byſhop conſtance defendeth image yet wythſtandyng wrytyng image beaten downe al dominion ʒ uricke foreſaid aſſemblie • orinberge themperor ſent ambaſſade straſburgh byſhop vtter theyr controuerſie campegius ſayde aſſemblie kynge ferdinando others make league agaynſt goſpell warre bowres beſides former letter biſhop adrian requeſt adrian diſpatch lu preſcribed ambaſſadour ſhould furthermore ſaye expreſſed ſame writing fyrſt ſhould accompt prince grief luther ſhoulde ſtyrre vp trouble ſedition thing concerned loſſe ſoules deſtruction flocke committed hym chriſt kepe ſecondly hath chaſiſed ſame cuntreye hymſelfe borne nation euer furtheſt ſuſpecion hereſye wherfore deſyreth greatly would helpe remedye matter ſo ſoone might leſt longer delaye ſame thinge happen vnto germany dyd lande boheme affyrmyng wyll neyther ſpare coſt labour herin beſeching euerye man power lyke beynge many weightye cauſes whie ſo oughte fyrſte glory god holy name throughe hereſye chiefly obſcured rite ceremony churche defaced maner quite aboliſhed loue oure neighboure vnto charitie bindeth v ſhewe right waye germany wont haue chiefe prayſe religion reaſon reuolting theyr fame eſtimation groweth contempt ignomie might eaſely haue diſpatched luther alſo quenched hereſies would degenerating herin aunceſtours left notable example theyr vertu cōſtance moſt open wronge doeth alſo theyr elder folowed religion catholick churche rome nowe iudgement condemneth ſame religion damned let wey conſyder ſelues theſe fellowes purpoſe intende uerely vnder pretence libertie goſpel ſubuerte take away al lawes magiſtrates albeityt luther ſemed begynning impugne onely eccleſiaſtical power tyrranical wicked yet intent hath perſwaded chriſtians lawes bounden obeye magiſtrate maye open waye vnto men worke miſchief liſte therfore greate daunger hangeth ouer alſo hitherto craftely traiterouſlye hyde theyr purpoſe flatter magiſtrate intent may frely vtter theyr malice vpon clergie oppreſſed wyll doubtles attēpt may ſee already experience grudge hatred tumultes offence hereſie hath alreadi brought common wealth whiche euyles vnleſſe ſuppreſſed time feared leſt god hathe gyuen power ſworde wyll plage theyr ſo great negligence bothe owne priuate alſo common deſtruction germany luth compared bahomet luther differeth muche ſecte mahomet permitteth men mary many wiues forſake ſame whiche policie miſchieuous man bewitched allured greateſt part worlde whiche thing thoughe luther permitteth yet doth aduiſe mary haue vowed chaſtitie gyuing reignes lybertie man luſt concupiſcens maye haue mo confyderacie vtter deſtruction common wealthe namely germany ſayd therfore theyr partes put execution decree leo ceſar intent may auenge god glorye auoyde ſklaunder countrey eſchewe preſent daunger yt hangeth ouer owne heades furthermore yt ſay howe luther condemned matter heard reaſon thing ſhold debated executed thinke well chriſt hath taught v rule faith religion whoſe authoritie muſt folowe reaſon article faith inquire cauſe precept dede hearde examined whether ſpake thinge hys ſermon whether ſetforth boke touching faith sacramentes may permit reaſon defend thoſe thinges whiche hathe written thereof muſte folowe vſe cuſtome church wiſe ſwarue ſame againe ſith hys doctrine ſuche hath bene heretofore condemned generall counſels none accompt made therof moreouer ſhould ende cōtention might lawfull euery priuate man call queſtion thoſe thinges wittie great learned men haue muche deliberation eſtabliſhed whereſoeuer aſſēblie felowſhip mē certein lawes bounden obſerue howe muche oughte ſame done time anye thynge openlye eſtabliſſhed churche ſeyng theſe men onely contempne lawes decree counſels auncient father alſo burne ought ſuerly puniſhed breaker common peace quietnes neuertheles confeſſeth howe god reuenger wronge doeth thus plage churche ſynnes miniſters therof scripture ſaieth iniquitie people procedeth iniquitie procedeth frō prieſtes prieſtes elder certenlye ſaieth haue ſynned rome theſe many yeres full greuouſly ſundry wayes euen highe biſhoppe loweſt eccleſtaſticall parſon one excuſed cauſe callynge mekely god ſynne rome ſpred ouer al worlde pardon wyll endeuour redreſſe thing ſee court rome perchaunce hath bene occaſion miſchief fyrſt ſharpely refourmed hathe bene example vice ſo may begynning amendement patron vertu ſaieth muſt lytell litell al ſodayne mutation daungerous common prouerbe bloweth noſe ouermuche ſhall wringe bloude writing dyd luther tranſlate vulgare toungue ſet note lut expoundeth pope ſaiynge margente ſayeth lytell lytell luther affyrmeth ſpace many men liues ſo frankely bewrayed vicious lyuyng court rome gote great loue cardinal reported neuertheles ſay euer biſhop rome policie wil deferre coūſel delay hearynge matter promiſe largely whileſt men truſt meane let coūſels vpon promyſe maye fynde meanes fauoure prince force armes mainteine hys power dignitie like fall ſome daunger fyre generall counſels whileſt byſhoppes ambaſſador declared thus prince complained league made time paſt byſhoppes rome broken diuerſe wayes whereof byſhoppe beyng certifyed letter ambaſſadour anſwereth ſame ſuche thynges predeceſſours dyd lieth helpe miſliked handelyng matter rome priuate man purpoſed leſſe refourme ſame thoughe man ſpoken therin ſuffer man ſuſteine wronge muche leſſe common countrey ſake coueteth chiefly gratifie deſyre action commenced might retourned germany ſo ſoone iudges aduocates whiche fled oute rome plage ſhall retourne inquire caſe therin ſhall ſeme reſonable commaunded moreouer ambaſſadour require aunſwere prince theyr opinion beſt way deſtroy peſtiferous ſecte maye vnderſtande time ſhall part therin theſe thinges beyng declared counſel prince anſwer price ſtates make aunſwere fyrſte recityng briefly demaundes ſay ryght glad hath pleaſed god place gouernement church perilous time nede ſuch paſtour beareth ſuche zeale common wealthe taketh ſuche paynes ſet kynges quietnes emploieth hys treaſure repreſſing turkes violence whiche thynges reioyſe heare theſe ciuill warres thempire decaied turkes power increaſed man prepareth armye reſiſt ambaſſadours kyng prince hungary without great lamentation haue recited cruell thinges haue ſuffered daunger ſtande dayely wherfore deſyre father paſtour others perſeuer moſt holy purpoſe trauaile yt eyther ſuer peace el long treuce may taken yt meane time may make preparation withſtande turkes violence recouer countreis empire loſte whereunto promiſe aide bothe men money concernyng luther diſpleaſure growen germany meanes doctrine right hartely ſory therefore becommeth leſſe deſyre alſo remedy euyll knowyng theyr duetie obey themperour nother wil luth puniſhed degenerat progenitours herein complaineth already puniſhed according emperours decree vpon lyght conſyderation omitted degree complayne moſt heinouſly courte rome maner al men ſo wel inſtructed preachinges bokes luther caſe decree ſhould put execution would doubtles ſtyre vp great ſedition many would ſo couſtre done intent trueth ſhould oppreſſed lyght ghoſpell extinguiſſhed mayntenaunce ſuche open crymes borne withall perſwaſion moſt certeinly would ſtyrre vp rebellion people againſt magiſtrates tan denied himſelfe graunteth alſo lyue diſſolutely vitiouſly rome great decay religion wherefore dyſſembleth nothing clooketh diſorder court rome promyſeth reformation deſeruith muche praiſe eſpecially performe dede thing hathe promiſed wordes writynge whiche earneſtly require would otherwiſe certein longe quietnes loked germany muche impoueriſhed warres charge tribute extraordinarie ſo hardely hable ſuſteyne neceſſary charge common wealth gyue aide hungarian others againſt turke nowe ſorte germanes certein yeres paſt permitte biſhops others clergie ſhould certein time tributary biſhop rome ſuppoſe ignoraunt cōditioned ſame tyme al money tyme ſerued ſhould employed vpon warre againſt turke nowe bothe tyme expired predeceſſors biſhoppes rome haue put money ſame vſe ought haue done whiche cauſe nowe ſubſidie gathered countreis empyre turkiſhe warre men grudge mutine think thoſe great ſummes money haue bene leuied many yeres kepte ſame purpoſes ſhould ſerue tourne charged deſyre therfore hence forth demaunde anye ſuche tribute permitte ſame broughte common treaſure houſe empire thus ſhall many men quieted germany nede ſhall require ſhall want money ayde foreine nation agaynſt force violence turkes areth counſell alteration religion conſydering matter conſiſteth onely luther doctrine alſo many abuſes errours crepte churche mayntened longe cuſtome men corrupte life iudgemente ſelf cōfeſſeth cā ſee better way redres al theſe thing free generall counſell whiche emperour beyng maner free coū ſell chiefe magiſtrates chriſtendome may ſommon ſome citie germany mentz straſeboroughe metz collen whiche thynke alſo good cōmon wealth begyn ſhortly mighte furtheſt within ayere yet vnder condition many ſhal preſent eſtate degree ſo euer ſhall take othe ſpeake frely hyde ſo euer ſhall ſeme make glory god profit cōmen wealet el ſhalbe ſuſpected harme good may rather done accordynglye ſee luther meane time ſhall write mo bookes doubtinge fridericke noble duke saxonie wyll aſſiſte herein preacher ſhall teache goſpell ſyncerely reuerently interpretation approued churche printer ſhall print nothinge ſame ſhall fyrſte peruſed aucthoriſed certeine learned men appointed byſhoppes matter controuerſie reſerued counſelles amonges thinges ambaſſador ſpake prieſtes maried wiues forſomuch puniſhment appointed ciuill lawe thinke miſſe ſuche haue offended ſhoulde puniſhed canon lawe finally beſeche take good part theyr opinion touching euery thyng doeth procede ſyncere minde tendereth common weale fauoureth alſo dignitie ſame tyme chaunſed great alteration denmarke thus befel caſe chriſtierne fyrſt name king dēmarke alteratiû denmark norweye suecia two ſonnes iohn fridericke iohn ſuccede father warre suecians whiche rebelled notwithſtandynge compoſition matter appeaſed iohn ſonne named chriſtierne whan ſyxe yeres age proclamed kynge father yet lyuing ſyxe twentie yeres whē father dead crowned yeare oure lorde mdxiiij durynge whoſe reigne suecians rebelled againe ſet vp steno stura haue gouernement chriſtierne made power agaynſte many battels ſondry ſieges ſubdueth commaūdyng steno ſlayne battell buried ſhoulde taken vp brent yeare mdxx suecians beynge thus vanquiſhed guſtauus erixonius noble man hauing aide thought lubeckes ſtirred vp new rebellion good fortune pretēded fyrſt haue done steno child aſſuraunce maried daughter king loſt prouince euill beloued home gouerned common welth eruelly offended men alſo vncle fridericke lubecke moued warre againſt fearynge leſt broile length would tourne vtter deſtruction fled king denmarke flecth away child wife iſabell ſyſter charles themperour whan reigned ix yeares fyrſte aryued selande themperours prouince immediatly ſtates realme callynge counſell create vncle fridericke duke holſe aged man kynge beyng aided herin thē lubecke ſending abroad theyr letter emperor byſhoppe rome prince empire rendre reaſon dyd ſo accuſe moſt greuous crime ſay howe baniſſhed hys iuſte deſeruinges ſame thinge alſo doeth fridericke citie lubecke moſt aucthoritie power al thoſe party chriſtierne fyndynge good wryter cornelles scepper flemmyng well learned aunſwereth theſe crymes deſyreth cornelles scepper ſtates empire aſſembled norinberge aide ſuccour one ſonne emperour toke vnto two doughters dorothie christine ſame yere frendes attēpted warre haue reſtored vaine emperour beyng intangled frenche warres ambaſſodor rome complained preacher norinberge ſhould teach euill doctrine required might layde faſte feete prince ſuppoſed miſſe infourmed preacher ſaye greate eſtimation people ought ſhould done men would take done ſet purpoſe oppreſſe trueth whiche thinge myght cauſe rebellion notwithſtandyng wyll appoint certein men ſhall make inquiſition whole matter therin ſhall reaſonable tyme prince anſwered biſhoppe rome demaundes gather certeine article ſuche thynges would haue done biſhops germany ſuch infringed liberty made germany bare money keptmen great bondage ſaid plainely would longer ſuffer caſe reformed ſpede wold ſeke redreſſe thē ſelues concernyng tribute clergie thus amonges meanes gather vp money one byſhoppes ſpirituall parſons ſhoulde paye byſhoppe rome rate benefice certeine ſumme beginnyng firſt fruictes tenthes money commonly called fyrſte fruites tentes aſcribe deuice iohn xxij others vnto boniface ix pretēſe fayre goodly ther might treaſure ready time againſt turkes saracenes much time aucthoritie biſhoppes rome growen great eſtemed holy eaſely graunted englishman refuſed pay namely theyr ſmal benefice continued till counſel baſil put downe brought vp againe eugenius fourth made counſell fruſtrate ſo hath continued euer ſyns yet much repining yere lorde thouſande fine hundred time emperor maximilian held counſell auſ •• rge turkiſhe warre decreed ambaſſadors ſhould ſent alexander ſixt ſhould aide common wealth geue thoſe yerely reuenewes vnto vſe graunted ſame purpoſe tharchebiſhops metropolitanes receane certein ſigne honor dignitie made flaxe wolle call palle muſt paye great piece money byſhoppe romiſhe palle rome ſhort ſpace maye admit none byſhoppe till haue receiued palle whiche weareth alwayes maſſe deliuered muſt take othe owne faith obeidience ſixte day marche prince norinberge ſet forthe writinge thinges mentioned charging men obſerue ſame vnder great penaltie whiche decree publiſhed emperours name eſtabliſſhed senate iudgement retorned spaine fridericke countie palatine deputie aſſemblie two freres brent bruſels tyme taken bruxels two monckes auſtens order iohn henry hogoſtrate frere dominicke thē examination aſked beleued made anſwere howe beleued bokes olde new teſtament crede apoſtles conteined article faith againe whether beleued decree counſels aū cient father agreable scripture whether thinke deadly ſynne man breake decree father biſhoppe rome aſcribed god commaundementes condemne ſaue whē perſeuered herin condemned dye gaue thankes god yt ſhould ſuffer glorie name brought forth ſuffer ceremony diſgratyng men marueyled beholde theyr conſtancie ſo burnt fyrſt day iuly wer executed diſgraded thing done vnto prieſtes onely beynge condemned hereſye eccleſiaſticall iudge hath put vpon albe ueſtement deliuered handes chalice wine water alſo gilt patent ſinging cake ſo knelyng vpon knee biſhoppes deputie taketh thynges named commaundynge hym ſhall ſaye maſſe quick dead piece glaſſe ſkrapeth finger ioyninge neuer herafter halowe thing taketh reſt thinges certein curſes ioyned therunto whan exempted thus numbre prieſtes alſo put ye reſt ordres came vnto prieſthod torned naked decked againe layman apparell ſo deliuered magiſtrate biſhoppes chaunceloure entreateth yt wold determine harme againſt life body vſe ceremony leſt beynge holy men ſhoulde ſeme aucthors death bloudſhed whan decree empire made norinb many taken diuerſely ſome alſo cōtemned luth writinge letter luth interpreteth 〈◊〉 prince prince doth aduertiſe yt hath read reuerently great pleaſure firſt cōmaunde goſpell taught interpretatiōs approued church ſome dede vnderſtād ye accuſtomed maner thomas aquine dūſe ſuche others biſhops rome haue allowed taketh mont aūcient writer hilary cypriā auſtē ſuch others yet ſo much credit giuē vnto thē nothing like ſcripture bible preferred others thus doubteth mēt ſo doth take cauſe yt certen chiefeſt nobilitie wold ſubſcribe ſuffer proclamed theyr coūtreis secondly biſhops ſhould appoint mete mē preſent ſermōs ſhould geue gentle admonition thing miſſe ſaith decre good biſhops though wold obſerue ſame yt wāt learned men haue ſuche haue learned nothinge elles ſophiſtrie prohibite yt bookes printed learned mē appointed therunto haue firſt peruſed thē wil againſt ſo yt cōcerue bokes ſcripture wiſe oughte inhibited finally haue decreed yt prieſtes mary wiues forſake order ſhalbe puniſhed according canon law yt ouer hard thig cōfeſſe goſpel preached ſincerely thā muſt canō law much qualified afterwarde bewalleth miſerie frowardnes time yt ſo clere light goſpel yt extreme law prohibiteth mariage aboliſhed hath geuen thoccaſion ſo many great euils yet much praiſed content wt puniſhmēt preſcribed canon law ſuch wold kill prieſtes yt marie leaue ordre haue priſon kind punniſhement tormented thē greatly abhorred wherfore beſecheth prince ſo muche theyr aduerſaries obeie decre mighte ought obſerue pore prieſtes might pardoned yt thinge • ech power performe euery man hath gift chaſtitie vowes made fooliſhe ſet forth boke ordeining miniſters senate lut wrot senate prage prage ioyneth writynge wherein declareth howe church hath power authoritie iudge euery doctrine appoint miniſters fyrſte defyneth churche ſo euer ghoſpell ſyncerely taught byſhoppes calleth image heades without braynes wherof one yt doth duetie place namely germany longe wrote eſchewynge men doctrine luther wrot eſchewing doctrine men wherin ſaieth holdeth dede contēne lawes tradition men yet nothynge belongeth dwetie trewe chriſtian preſcribeth maſſe communion ſhould vſed churche wittenberge ſaieth howe hath hitherto wrought ſlouthfullye reaſon men infirmitie haue care one lye howe myghte plucke wicked opinion men myndes nowe many confyrmed time ſuffer vngodlines churche longer cloking ſimulation ſet parte ſincere workyng maye enſewe vpon pure doctrine addeth wrytyng holy ceremony obſerued churche againe abhomination priuate maſſe call canon wherin exhorteth ye people flee frō accuſtomed ſacrifices maſſe woulde deuyll hym ſelfe demonſtration wherof reciteth order canon maſſe declaryng howe full blaſphemies againſte god amonges learned men germany fauoured luther ulriche hutten noble man borne death workes hutten one died yere farre zurick certein workes remaining declare excellent witte iij boke ſhewed luther made anſwere henry king englande whiche kynge read writeth letter king englande writeth prince saxonie prince saxonie fridericke john brother vncle george greuouſly cōplaining luther ſheweth daunger hangeth ouer germany reaſon doctrine thinge contemned neglected great crueltie turkes nowe ſpred ſo farre broad beginning naughtie man two boheme hard may warning ſee thing reformed time admoniſheth thē alſo ſuffer luther tranſlate newe teſtament uulgare tong wel knowē ſuch practiſioner doubt ſuche thinges well written euill tranſlation wil corrupt depraue unto theſe letter anſwer duke george duke george anſwereth frendly blaming alſo luther excedingly whoſe bokes ſaith hath baniſhed al dominiōs moſt hurtfull enemy moreouer howe righte ſory hath written ſo extremely againſt hath giuen cō maundement throughe countrey man reade ſell howe hath puniſhed printer brought fyrſte copie thyther aſſemblie norinberge beſydes matter religion prince entreated peace lawes punniſſhement thoſe obeyde lawes empire continuall aide againſte turke two laſt agreed vpon al city thempire becauſe certein thinges enacted ſowe ſhould preiudiciall ſent theyr ambaſſadours sp • ine emperour ariuynge ualolet ſixt day auguſt thyrde day declared theyr meſſage unto emperor aunſwered gently frankely notwithſtandynge ſayde byſhoppe rome complained letter strauſeborough norinberge auſpurge fauorers luther doctrine truſted trewe yet woulde hyde thentent might obſerue byſhoppes decree thinketh theſe ambaſſadors pourge ſelues faiyng accompliſhe pleaſure meane time dieth byſhoppe adrian ides septembre adrian pope dyeth clement ſuccedeth place choſen clement vii houſe medices zuricke onely folowed zuinglius doctrine reſt suices hated ſame wherfore cōmon aſſemblie fal • e purpoſe berne ſome accuſed zuinglius preached openly howe ſuche made league nation dyd ſell zuinglius broughtin hatred bloud eate men fleſhe zuinglius heringe therof wrote ſpake ſo ſaid generall howe ſome abhorred wicked thing eate fleſhe beyng forbidden biſhoppe eatyng fleſhe rome lawe thinke none offence ſell men fleſhe gold deſtroy weapon herin named nation ſeyng vice doeth nowe ſo muche abound dewtie rebuke ſame doeth nothing concerne good innocent parſons zuinglius amonges thing taught image ſhuld church maſſe put wicked thing cauſe senate called new aſſemblie new diſputatiō zu citie whither came great reſorte moneth october diſoutation cōtinued thre day time ſundry place namely strauſburgh prieſtes maried wiues thinge made prieſtes maried wiues muche contention accuſed ſo doyng anſwered done nothinge agaynſte god lawe permittinge men marie indifferently senate strauſburghe muche biſhoppe caſe called xx day ianuary appeare hym towne sabernes heare ſentence ſhoulde gyuen agaynſt contractyng matrimonye wherein ſaieth haue broken lawes churche holy father byſhoppes rome emperoure alſo empire haue done great iniurie order offē ded diuine maieſtie prieſtes receiued citation make ſuite senate haue theyr cauſe hearde refuſe ſuffer death founde haue done thing againſte cōmaundement god ſenate intreateth biſhoppe much refuſe come theyr aunſwere ſhould puniſh like brede much trouble cō ſyderinge reſide •• kepe harlot openly nothynge ſaied would leſt defferre thende imperial counſell norinberge doubtles ſuche like caſes ſhould decided later coūſel holden yere norinberge clement biſhop rome ſent legate cardinal campegius pope clemēt ſendeth campegius duke fri letter moreouer friderike duke saxonie written friendly ianuary signifiynge howe reioyſed heare aſſemblye ſhoulde preſente ſelfe truſtynge ſome thynge ſhoulde enacted mighte helpe common 〈◊〉 cauſe hathe ſent thither cardinall campegius 〈◊〉 man excellent vertue enfourme prince carefulneſſe 〈◊〉 towardes common weale deuiſe priuately meanes peace quietneſſe whereunto exhorteth 〈◊〉 gyue mynde ſame thyng concerneth proſperitie dignitie al magiſtrats beareth great good vnto germany hauynge good hope wyll fall auncient vertue helpe eſchewe publike daungers wherfore requireth ſhewe good fauoure hys legate whome ſhall heare thinges large ſixe twentie day ianuary heluetiās called conuocation decree suyſes lucerne decree made man ſhoulde mocke contemne god worde whiche bene taught theſe thouſande foure hundred yeares maſſe wherein bodye chriſt conſecrated honor comfort quicke dead ſuche lawfull age receyue lordes ſupper cōfeſſe ſelues prieſtwiſe lent ſeaſon al men abſteine fleſhe day forbidden lent alſo egges cheſe nothing luther newe doctrine taught priuely openly ſuche cary reliques holy goſt virgin reliques holy goſt mary anthony laughed yt obſerue olde cuſtomes offende herein preſented magiſtrates puniſhed whē cāpegius cōmen norinberge cardinall writeth duke saronis duke friderike departed thence wherefore wrote vnto hym laſte daye february ſendinge alſo biſhoppes letter lamenteth vnhappye chaunce ſpeake wyth preſently hauyng many thynges talke biſhop rome whiche ſo well done letter meſſengers ſuche ſorte maye abyde delaye ſeynge better muche gretyng made biſhops name ſaieth albeit reporte great ſhould fauorer theſe newe ſpronge vp hereſyes yet biſhoppe hitherto ſo perſwaded manyfold excellent vertues perceiue eſpecially hath bene euer great fauourer religion apoſtolicall churche whereupon truſte iudgementes others nother leaue good opinion hath ſhall ſee cauſe know ſelf germany hath bene wonderfully altered theſe fewe yeres cō cernyng religion vnderſtandeth howe muche commō people differ nobilitie prince ruler lawes amonges principal aſwel alſo deſerte aūceſters haue euermore done great honor church rome wherfore biſhop requireth theſe daūgerous dayes woulde example elder declare vertue ſtoutenes onely miſlyking lybertie people alſo extremely puniſhing ſame vnleſſe theyr licentious boldnes malapertenes reſtrained bring lyke miſerie confuſion germany tyme boheme hongary yet quieted ſtubberuely contemne ſacred lawes eccleſiaſticall magiſtrate alſo vndoubtedly worke violence againſt ciuil magiſtrates loue manye nowe glad ſee paſtours church courte rome thus troubled diſpiſed whiche perceaue ful litel daunger ſelues ſtande byſhoppe whiche maſter ſhyppe ſitteth watching healme doeth foreſee ſtorme approching hath ſent hym warne prince eſpecially beware tempeſt like diſtroy onely citie rome alſo germany ſelfe ſame cauſe alſo hath ſent letter willed treate diligently theſe matter intente tranquilitie quietnes germany might recouered purpoſely ſent lifte vp fallen receiue vnto grace ſuch penitēt whereunto albeit fit yet truſtynge vpon gentlenes wil attempt al diligence wherfore ſeing hath taken wery painefull iorney praieth maye want helpe fauor herein woulde write agayne ſhortly thinketh beſt done againe worlde counſell prince fyrſte declareth howe man willyng rome take voiage germany campegius oratiō prince norinberge laſt appointed one may thanke germanes promotion hauing two thinges treate religion turkiſhe warre fyrſt marueleth muche ſo manye greate worthy prince beare alteration ſuffer ſame religion rite ceremony wherin borne brought vp theyr father alſo progenitours dead thus defared ſet naught thing ſpedely reformed wil ſtyre vp doubtles great commotion rebellion people agaynſte theyr magiſtrates hyghe biſhoppe fearing conſyderyng hath ſent hym deuiſe way howe remedie matter whoſe diligens herein refuſed good father paſtour wiſſheth well child ſhepe cauſe hereafter laye blame touchynge turkes denieth money gathered ſame purpoſe brought rome albeit employed wayes yet may cōmon welth therfore calamitie time neglected hurt cruell enemie hathe done vnknowen negligens cowardiſe owne men hathe taken rhodes chiefeſt foretreſſe hongary rhodes endured harde ſiege many monethes laſte wantynge thynges neceſſarye whan ſaw aide would come yelded like chaūce hongary ſhould ſubdew wholly bringe vnder ſubiection feared leſt wyll become enemy muche worſe turkes vnleſſe contention procedynge new doctrine fyrſt taken away part common wealth opinion well holpen hereunto prince anſwere wheras beareth good prince aunſwere vnto germany glad came thither amonges wyll choſe certeine conferre ſuppoſing hath ſome order preſcribed biſhoppe cardinal haue willed folow knowyng matter ſo wel laſte yere tyme another ambaſſador wrote vnto theyr mindes howe daunger alteration ſhould foreſeen remedied alſo required done parte wherof haue brought aunſwer deſyre vtter intent may better procede cauſe touching turkiſhe matter confeſſe hath ſayd notwithſtandyng great warre doth concerne empire together kynges prince chriſtendome like maner vnleſſe peace amonges ſelfes giue aide ther nothing done continew aſmuch turke nowe maketh great preparation vnto warres ſea lande would alſo knowe opinion herin legate ſaid againe whether ſuch way deuiſed appeaſe ſtrife aboute religion whether deliuered biſhoppe cardinalles certeinly tell biſhoppes good wyll muche hathe gyuen full aucthoritie ſuche matter whiche knowe men maner cuſtome countrey muſt fynd way may lead ende wiſhed counſell wormes emperor theyr common aſſent decre wormes repeted made decree haue bene executed thorowout germany ſome obeied ſome wherefore great diuerſitie ſhould empire knoweth thinketh good thynge determined conſulte howe maye executed comen thither ſtyrre vp fyre diſſention ſome reporte deſyre biſhoppes like caſe make peace concorde thentent ſuche haue erred ſtraied may reduced waie decree counſels themperors prince proclamation might obſerued concernynge requeſtes whether made ſent rome knoweth three copy brought thither priuate men whetof one byſhoppe colledge cardinalles coulde perſwaded ſhould made prince thought rather ſome priuate men deuiſed hatred malice bare citie rome wherin diuerſe thinges deny byſhoppes authoritie ſmell hereſye ſuche meddle withall others againſt biſhop ſuch grounded vpon equitie reaſon refuſe treate howe ſemeth vnto demaundes ſhould haue bene propounded wt modeſtie ought ſay highe biſhop ſo dyd lately spaniardes ſendyng ambaſſade rome declared gē tely theyr requeſt wheras printed publiſſhed abrode thinketh ouer muche yet doubte biſhoppe rome wyll germany moreouer power turke hath preparatiō maketh biſhop hath good intelligence hath alredy great treaſure pope wel monied readines haue ſo muche concorde chriſten prince requiſite hath done emperor frenche kynge king england hauyng peace together might ſet vpon turke handes employ therupon treaſure doeth biſhoppe good ſheperde foreſee care peace quietnes caſe ſhepe wyll folowe voyce sheperde take paciently commit whole matter vnto god amonges suyces encreaſed dayly cōtention religion suiſes offended zuricke reſt townes ſendynge theyr ambaſſadors zurycke ſhewed theyr grief tymes paſt thinges godly quiet contention doctrine nowe meanes luther fyrſt began zuinglins leo iude preached amonges interpretinge godes worde theyr owne iuſte appetite godly peace quietues churche common weale nowe tourned trouble diſſention beſydes theſe incommodities enſew vpon faſtyng dayes eate bothe egges fleſſhe religious folkes aſwell men woman forſaking theyr profeſſion order marrie god ſeruice laide downe ſinge churche neglect confeſſion penaunce maſſe railed lady ſainctes diſhonoured theyr image pulled downe broken ſacramentes contepte ſo muche nowe day ſacred holy hoſt yeare hoſte repreſenteth chriſtes body ſkarſely ſafe prieſtes haides theſe thinges lamēted auenged alſo loſſe life good wherfore deſyre leaue newe doctrine perſeuer olde religion father beare gere longer caſe thinge wherin fynde ſelues offended biſhop rome cardinal byſhoppes marchaundiſe clergie ſuche others whan entre benefice choppe chaunge gather vp money countrey vſurping taking ouer muche vpon theſe ſuche like thing moleſt greue refuſe helpe reforme ſame miſlyke muche ſelues senate zuricke aunſwered xxi daye marche anſwer zuricke miniſters church preached fyue yeares whoſe doctrine begynnynge ſemed vnto newe becauſe heard like vnderſtode ende therof ſhewe ieſus chriſt aucthor ſaluation dyed ye ſinnes world loue deliuered v wretch frō death euerlaſting onely aduocate mankinde god father could wyth feruent deſyre embrace ſo ioyful newes great agrement concorde time paſt betwixt apoſtles thoſe theyr time embraced chriſtes doctrine ſame truſt ſhall nowe alſo amonges ſuch giue mind hereunto luther ſo teache well done neyther ought god word called doctrine although honor chriſt yet iniurie therfore virgin marye ſaints al earth loked eternall ſaluatiō onely name chriſt nowe ſuch light giuen maner men within citie reade ye bible diligently ſo miniſters wraſt wrye ſo continuallye men handes wherefore ſecte obiected vnto name accordeth mainteine lucre dignitie wraſte god worde whither liſt ſaid error man ſhewe haue often time required herin biſhoppe conſtaunce baſill courtes certeine uniuerſities alſo vnto day ther nothing done therfore miniſters gyue none occaſion diffention commō wealth author sciſmes biſhoppes ſuche owne profit teache contrary godes worde deceiue people offende god greuouſly feare loſe theyr commodity wer loth forſake theyr pride auarice touchyng eatyng egges fleſhe albeit free forbidden chriſt yet haue made lawe auoide offence raſhenes god aucthour matrimonie lawfull men matrimony hath ordeined almen paule alſo commaū deth miniſter church ſhould huſband one wife ſins biſhoppes permit prieſtes money kepe concubine harlot filthy example neither wyll without woman thinke good reſiſt god ordeyned holy wedlocke ſufferyng haue gifte chaſtitie marrie rather ſinglenes lyue fylthy lyfe colledges ſuch place fyrſt founded pore moſt part poſſeſſe haue enough beſides often time ſene one hath much wold find many wherfore think reaſonable ſuche good againe conuerted vſe poore wherin notwithſtandyng vſe moderation ſuche poſſeſſion already permitted enioye rente theyr liues leſte man ſhoulde haue cauſe complaine iewels churche apperteine trewe nedeth gold churche worſhipping god acceptable vnto god time pore nedye releued order prieſthode diſpiſed muche ſet caſe dewtie teach ſyncerely reſt rabble yt doeth good harme litell litel diminiſhed without offence theyr poſſeſſions put ſome godly vſe doubte ſame woulde vnto god moſt acceptable whether god accept ſinging ſeruice latin muche doubted many vnderſtande ſay yet hired ſame order monkes inuention man ordinaunce god howe muche auricular confeſſion valewe numbreth ſinnes wil leaue vndiſcuſſed wherby trewe penitentes true cōfeſſiō haue acceſſe vnto chriſte theyr mediator iudge onely profitable alſo neceſſary conſciences troubled preſſed burthen ſinne trewly repent mā doeth amende life sacrament inſtituted god contemned great reuerence notwithſtandyng muſt vſed accordyng vnto god worde lordes ſupper ſo applied oblation ſacrifice clergie thus complaineth fynde error amonges thē prone hindred empeched thē make amendes reaſon ſhould commaunded theyr dewtie teache treuth abſtaine ſklaū dering others deſyre deliuered pillage vſurped howe yoke papiſtes ſhaken aucthoritie biſhoppe rome clientes exceadyng glad heare whiche thinge done meanes better godes worde may throughly receiued ſo longe theyr lawes decree ſhall take place let v looke deliueraūce onely preaching god word ſhaketh theyr power dignitie force goſpell veritie ſuche diſtruſting theyr owne ſtrength ſeeke forthe aide kynges wherefore ſhould caſe vſe helpe scripture requiſite ſame done lyke wiſe thinges god offended may aboliſhed reformation whereof wyll glad beſtowe onely theyr trauaile counſel good alſo would haue bene done longe ſyns wherefore deſyre accept good part weighe diligently conet nothing peace quiotneſſe nothing contrary theyr league caſe concerneth theyr euerlaſtyng ſaluation otherwiſe vnleſſe theyr errour detected deſyre therfore thinke theyr doctrine againſt scripture maye ſhewed ende maye ſo longe tary anſwere frō byſhoppes alſo univerſitie baſill meane biſhoppe conſtaunce calling conuotion biſhop cōſtance maketh booke defence image made boke anſwere zuricke ende wherof declare scripture ſpeaketh againſte image vnderſtand onely idoles amonges iewes gentile image receyued churche kept ſtyll treateth maſſe proueth many teſtimonies biſhoppes rome theyr coūſels oblation ſacrifice boke ſendeth zuricke fyrſt daye iune exhortynge senate many weightie wordes neither take downe theyr image abrogate maſſe ſuffer people taught otherwiſe senate make anſwere eighteneth day auguſte howe glad hathe ſetforth booke ſhall appere whether partie defendeth iuſter quarell declared mindes theyr learned menne teaching contrary scripture wrote aunſwer senate commaunded throughout theyr inciſdiction image betaken downe brent image brēt zuricke yet without trouble moneth iune within fewe monethes canon zuricke make compact senate order taken landes good colledge ſhould imploied emperor ſent counſel norinberge iohn hawnart complainyng decree made worines common aſſent counſell broken great loſſe germany commaunded hence forth ſhould diligentlye obſerued prince anſwer wyll herein finally xviij aprill decreed aſſent decre norinberge emperour biſhop rome ſo ſhortly might ſhoulde free counſel germanye ſome place conueniente eſtates empire aſſemble spire xi nouember conſult ſhall folowe vntill begynninge counſell prince ſhall aſſigne certeine good well learned men euery prouince gather luther bookes others queſtions diſputable exhibite prince next aſſemblie maye procede ſpedely ſhall come counſell meane diligens magiſtrate goſpel may purely taught ſoberly according interpretatiōs approued churche moreouer herafter therebe ſet forthe mo famous libelles picture finally ſuche thinges prince haue charge court rome clergie treated diſcuſſed next aſſemblie spire counſel campegius dyd vndertake promyſed prince declare byſhop diligently prince aſſemblie lewes countie palatine wylliam lewes duke bauare friderike palatine caſimire markes brandenburge byſhoppes treuers bamberge wirciburge trent brixine albert brandenburge maſter pruſelande tolde howe senate straſebrough intreated biſhoppe therof maried prieſtes whome cited appeare suite betwixt biſhop ſenate strauſo sabernes came theyr day appointed wherfore biſhop writeth legate campegius complaynyng senate ſaith letted ſo execute office puniſſhe haue maried contrarie byſhoppe rome lawes thomas murner graie frere meſſager complained greuouſly senate cardinall ambaſſadours thomas murner ſame towne beynge preſent norinberge came made purgatiō neither would let biſhoppe ſignified vnto letter yt looke actiō againſt maried prieſtes agreable god law might come execute would aſſiſte called liberty contrary ordre takē betwixt whereas claimed theyr liberty condemned theyr cauſe neyther hearde knowen ſayde moreouer moſt part clergie strauſb liued viciouſly kepīg ſtrōptes home thē lewd example yet biſhop doth puniſh one thē wherfore senate ſhould permit handle theſe extremely obſeruing biſhop rome law let cōmon whoremonges breake lawc god eſcape vnpuniſhed doubtles people would grudge ſtyre thereat cāpegius anſwered yt cōpaet bargaine betwixt thē knew ſurely theyr act manifeſt neded greate triall law wer ſequeſtred frō felowſhip church dede doyng bycauſe others kept harlot lyued diſhoneſtly yt doeth excuſe theyr cryme knoweth maner biſhops germany permit theyr prieſtes money kepe lemans euil done dede ſhal yeld accōpt one day neuertheleſſe greater offence prieſtes mary campcgſus raileth agai •• holye matrimony kepe home many harlot perſwaded yt well theſe acknowledge theyr ſynne men ſo chaſte iohn baptiſt yet neuer ſene myght lawefully refuſe ſole life amonges grekes theyr rite cuſtomes differ much frō v wherfore praieth giue theyr aide theyr biſhoppe matter ambaſſadors ſay would fyrſt puniſhe whoremonger might senate aſſiſte better correcting theſe others hand againe firſt aſſiſt theyr biſhop woulde puniſhe whoredome would come thither ſelfe ſee puniſhed accordingely aſſemblie norinberge fernando campegius cardinall saliſburge duke bauare yt biſhops decree papiſtes againſt goſpellers trent regenſpurge alſo thambaſſadors biſhops bāberge spire strauſ auſpurge cōſtance baſil friſinge paſſame brixine mette ratiſbone agreed vpon opiniō ſixt day iuly muche themperor folowing herin iudgement requeſt leo tenth cōdemned wormes publik decree doctrine luther wicked likewyſe decreed aſſemblie norinberge aſwell fyrſt laſt al men ſhould obey ſame much lieth therfore requeſt cardinall campegins hath ful auethoritie biſhop rome concernynge matter commande foreſayde decree decree made laſte aſſemblies obſerued kepte wythin theyr iuriſdictions ghoſpell others scripture taught church interpretation aūetent father puritie life excelled theyr great vertu confyrmed theyr doctrine martyrdome teach hereſtes already cōdemned thing el reproch chriſt lady ſaints may occaſion ſedition let puniſhed according tenure therof man admitted preach without haue biſhoppes licenſe eccieſiaſtical lawes cardinal cāpegius hath writtē cōmō aſſēt take away vice reforme maners whē ons publiſhed ſhalbe obſerued touching maſſe sacramēts al thing let nothing altered done hath bene accuſtomed oure forefather receyue lordes ſupper wtout confeſſion abſolutiō eate fleſhe dayes forbiddē alſo mōcks none yt ron ordre prieſtes deacōs subdeacōs yt marrye ſhalbe puniſhed let nothing put print cōſent magiſtrate namely luther cōpanions let nothing ſet forth ſold ſuch theyr iuriſdiction ſtudying wittēberge wtin thre monethes ſhall heare decree made retourne home go ſome el wheras luth poiſon taketh place ſhall otherwiſe ſhalbe depraued theyr benefice loſe theyr inheritāce thoſe ſhall cōtinew uniuerſitie wittēberge ſhal neyther enioy benefice haue charge brynge vp youthe certeine fit men choſen euery place ſee theſe thinges executed offender ſo many taken committed warde reſt yt ſhall baniſſhed haue place refuge ſo farre theyr rule dominiōs rtretche cōmotiō ſedition ſhould fortune arriſe reaſon decree wtin theyr limittes reſt ſhall come aide eccleſiaſticall lawes whiche campegius deuiſed theſe let prieſtes liue honeſtly go comely appareled nother ſell marchantes haūt tauernes let thē couetous theyr miniſtration extorte money gredelye let ſuch kepe cōcubines diſplaced let nūbre holye dayes meaſure theſe woulde campegius haue enacted counſell empire could bring paſſe held aſſembly part whan luther vnderſtode emperoure diuerſe prince woulde practiſe decree wormes bewaileth ſtate lamentatiō lut germanye whiche beynge ſo ofte admoniſſhed neglecteth wealthe calleth vpon prince ſelues beynge ſo openly wickedly diſceaued romiſhe byſhoppes maynteyne neuertheles theyr dignitie ſeke diſtructiō wiſſheth beſt vnto wherfore ſaith great ingratitud frowardeneſſe inexcuſable hangeth moſt terrible plage ouer germany warneth alſo attempte raſſhelye warre vpon turke counſell moderation doeth farre excell prince liuing may hope victorye furthermore calleth mockery thēperour kynge englande lengthen theyr lyues one momēt ſhould cai ſelues defendors church faith beſecheth god ſende ſuche magiſtrates ſeke tendre god glory golden roſe pope lately conſecrated atcuſtomed golden roſe ſent kynge englande eraſmus boke free three weekes eaſter ſendeth heury eyghte kynge englande notable token ſingular good wyll beneuolens aboute tyme came forth eraſmus boke freewill wherunto luther aunſwered contrary tytell bondewyll kynge englande cardinal yorke cauſed eraſmus write booke ſelfe confeſſeth certeine epiſtle cardinall printe time alſo anthony duke decree duke loraine loraine made decree ſo muche luther doctrine condemned biſhop rome emperor famous uniuerſities commaundeth none preache ſuch doctrine ſuche haue bokes ſet forthe luther exhibite ſame within certeine day appointynge penaltie ſuche dyd diſobey yere henry zutphā put death exceadinge henry zutphan paine torment doctrine goſpel thē dietmary marces germany beyng called went thither taught two yeres amonges bremers tolde coūſell ſhould haue bene spire emperor biameth prince ſame altered themperor knewe writing letter spaine ſtates thēpire ides iuly doth blame exceadinly decree made wheras certeine yeres paſte counſell wormes common aſſente ſtates moſte weygtie wordes condemned luther doctrine hereticall peſtilent alſo byſhoppe rome dewe examination condemned bokes commaundyng brēt marueyleth greatly ſory alſo ſhoulde forbed onely ſclaunderous bookes ſkornefull picture ſold though decree wormes ryghtly orderly made moreouer lytell moued woulde haue counſell holden germany haue ſpoken legate campegius would write byſhop herin thoughe ſame concerned biſhoppe doeth thought ſo expedient germany haue counſel made preuie yt might haue obteyned thing byſhop nowe albeit perceiueth rightwell howe muche biſhoppes authoritie alſo decree diminiſhed yet conſyderynge waye ſhal vnprofitable cōmon wealth approueth counſell alſo yet ſo may done biſhoppes authoritie tyme place conueniente ſo maye preſente ſelfe fully determined whereas haue appoynted aſſemblie agaynſte xi day nouembre eſtabliſſhe religion till begynnyng counſell haue alſo choſen certeine learned men gather ſumme doctrine neyther wyll conſent therto wyſe accordynge hys office ſo muche defendor protectour byſhop rome churche doth meanes prohibite decrre leſt themperor defendour romiſhe churche ſhould procure ſelfe diſpleaſure god biſhop alſo greater cōtumelie cā wrought againſt chriſtiā church thā reuerēs dew higheſt power ſhould thus ſhakē germany hath bene euer moſt cōmended vertu obeidiēce ſhould lone alter yt religiō prince biſhop rome ſelf euer durſt neuer man forſoke hitherto felt god vengeaunce wickednes ſhould forſake aboliſh hath bene ſo long cōtinewaūce chriſtendō craftye perſwaſion luther endeuoureth wt painted word diſceaue lut cōpared mahomet abuſe mē time paſt mahomet plage god might loke beſecheth god loke mercifully vpon germany ſuffer ſo great miſchiefeſt take place ther ſo lōg liueth wherfore let thē obey decre wormes vnleſſe ſmart defer matter religiō till general coūſell may biſhop rome appointmēt theyr chief magiſtrats ſelfe ſame ſorte writeth alſo priuatly certein ſtates amōges others ſenate strauſo thus decre next aſſēblie aboliſhed themperor hauing hand full frenche warres ſought winne biſhop rome meanes duke bourbō beſieged marfelles poſſible ſommer charles duke bourbon cōſtable fraūce yere partly owne accorde partely laboured themperor fell frō french king beſeged marſelles vain departing thence italy kyng foloweth great expedition taking many holdes lūbardy citie millan ſelfe towardes wynter beſegeth pauie towne riuer ticine moneth nouembre countrey people suelande began ryſe againſt theyr lord countie lupſe charge wherwith begynnynge ruſtical war complayned ouer muche burthened lykewiſe others place nere vnto ſame rebelled againſt theyr magiſtrats ſo much yt counſel thēpire gouerneth cōmon welth themperors abſence beyng eſlinge ſent theyr ambaſſadors appeaſed certeine cōtrouerſies broile ceaſed ſhalbe told herafter yt begining greateſt moſt daūgerous cōmotion yt pearſed afterwards throughout great part germany tyme luther doctrine ſet forth place ye clergie reſiſt forſe fearyng loſe theyr goodes benefice papiſtes fight bely certein straceborugh complained ſenate empire townes men infringe theyr liberty priueleges diuerſe way howe appointed maryed prieſtes monkes capito bucer others haue gouernement church receiued lordes ſupper vnder kindes yt raſſhely caſt image theyr church cauſe two chiefeſt counſelors thempire friderick coū tie palatine philip marque baden letter written frō eſling moneth ianuary admoniſhing ſenate leaue theyr chaūge reſtore eche thing place diuers swices namely schafuſians baſill oecolampadius taught begā litel litel giue ouer theyr diſpleaſure towards zuricke maner al reſt could meanes pacified whā captaine turege wherunto zurick belongeth taken prieſt night cariyng awaye makinge outcry calling helpe neighbour reiſed vp ſodē tumult euery man gote weapon whan zuricke ſuffered many iniuries fourth day ianuary wrote theyr letter al theyr confederate felowes complaining wiſe chriſt ſay cōmaundeth yt ſtryketh thee cōplaīte zuricke one cheeke thou ſhalte offer folowinge doctrine haue ſuffered many thinges patiētly ſith ther ende meaſure iniuries inforced flie yt ſame chriſt ſelf vſed haue done euill deſyre yt ſame may taught ſhewed v undoubtedly much ſuſteine ſuche hatred malice euery euill reported men thynge ſelfe requireth conſtreineth v make anſwere wherfore wil declare cauſe al malice cauſe theyr hatred confute ſclaunders ſhewe howe affected towards common countrey fyrſte dede wheras fraunces frenche kyng made great long ſuite enter league v conſent therto notwithſtandynge ofte hande v vtterly refuſe ſame diuerſes cauſes chiefly maner liked v witte ſhold ſerue foreine prince vile ſende ſtrength ſouldiours vnto ſtraungers money ſhould hired warre neuer harme bring vp ſuche euill example maineteine idlenes whiche ſhould die warres theyr wiues childrē ſhould come extreme miſerie iudged vuſittynge thynge oure owne great loſſe hynderaunce ſerue kynges torne brynge countrey men ſuche bondage therefore haue iudged beſt retaine kepe ſame libertie bodie good elder great valeaūtnes blouddy handes haue gotten v wyth like vertue conſtauncie al matter cauſe wer welſpringe begynnyng diſpleaſure woulde haue ratified league thinke ſhould haue ryſen diſpleaſure often tymes hande v ſhould forſake league ſhewed mynde kepe amitie kynge accordynge compoſition peacetions olde league made wealth preſeruaalready eſtabliſhed moreouer would obſerue condition common countrey becauſe perſeuer herein haue gotten diſpleaſure abroade ſyns lyghte ghoſpell ſprange vp haue ſhaken ſhoulders moſte weigtie burthen whiche biſhoppe rome adherentes laide vpon v aboliſhed manifeſt errours occaſion haue ſome taken late ambaſſadors ſent haue intreated v ſhould conuerte amende aunſwere thereunto worke preſcripte goddes worde man ſhewe v errour alter purpoſe ſurely reaſon obey god men ſtode vp egly captein lucerne threatenyng v vuleſſe forſake doctrine luther zuinglius lucernates uranites switenſians unterualdians tugiaus friburge ſit counſel v henceforth longe confyrmed thing amonges ſelues law captaine turege taken night ſeaſon iohn oxeline preacher ghoſpell hys owne houſe caried away priſoner vnto vsis double iniurie owne man taken owne liberty whereas many ran oute ſame night al part outcry many thinges wickedly blame layde vpon v men happened amonges nowe ſeconde matter charge v procedeth aſſemblie whiche ferdinando archeduke auſtriche helde laſt yere regenſpurge ruler countrie alſo biſhoppes ſuche others hate doctrine ghoſpell era • papiſtes endeuor go vnknowen verely make diſſention amonges v plucke v ſonder thinge greueth v credite ſuche time paſt haue knowen leaſte ſome lewde wycked parſous whome alſo vnderſtandyng theyr craft treaſon haue baniſhed limittes euen nowe ſo muche woulde gyue eare fled vnto accuſe v nowe though brokē league made houſe auſtrich ſay ſent aide walſute againſt theyr prince ferdinando vntrew whers walſutenſiās daū ger theyr religion could ſuffered ſpeake ſelues fewe men againſt knowledge ran thither ſaue harmeles men iniurie violence ſo ſone knew therof called backe againe therefore grounde theyr accuſation vntrewe ferdinando haue thing ſhewe league ſhould brokē let bring forth ſhall aunſwered ſuche ſort al men may plainly ſee whether parte hath kept couenauntes therefore haue ſecret talke ferdinando ambaſſadours part oures litell maruel treated tholde league ought mē haue bene made priuie ſame religion whye deale wt v ſame condition haue many time offered report góth haue conſpired deſtroy ſecte luther whiche althoughe trew yet ſo much ioyned league aſwel moreouer becauſe folow ſteppes luther holy scripture ought accompted numbre muche knowe done amonges complained malicious parſons though ſpoken aide certeine city proteſt falſe ſclaunder like ſort ſay howe wil ſodainly ſo ſide dromme cauſe men take armure ſo ſurpriſe baden certeine place lie deuiſed entente purpoſe might take thoſe townes laye garuiſous againſt v thing done doubt ſome greater tumult would therby arriſe might kindle amonges v domeſticall ciuile warre beſydes theſe go manye ſclaunderouſe reportes v one howe ſhoulde teache mary mother chriſte mo ſounes yonger iames apoſtle died v chriſt ſelfe theſe ſuche like thinges would haue cōfuted lucerne wold ſuffer men ſpeake vnto people tyme alſo eckins promiſed come ſhewe zuinglius errours right glad therof ſent onely eckſuc thē pope champion alſo others safecouduict exhorting earueſtly come promiſyng ſhewe fauour finally heare ſay plucking downe image hath procured v finale diſpleaſure hereof haue declared cauſe reaſon wherfore ſeyng haue doné nothing againſt condition league ſeyng refuſe perill ſafgarde oure common countrey beare lyke loue haue done alwayes caſe permitte v ſuffer diuiſyon pouertie boundage swices made amonges v knowen ſtate condition ſome aunceſters content poore liuinge gote ſore labor houſeholde oppreſſed nobilitie extreme bondage god looked mercyfully vpon expulſed tyrrauntes gote libertie inriched ſubſtaunce ſuche rich libertie ſame driuen oute fortified ſelues league force wherof able defende theyr coūtrey inuaſions forein power many time victory ouer theyr enemy many ye ſought ſeauer break ſocietie yet vaine aide power oure elder prepared ſame time doubte haue remembraunce theſe fewe wordes may ſuffice touching begynnyng league faith indeuor diligence hath bene ſhewed v euer ſins amplifiyng dignitie common countrey nede recited doubtles ſame mynde good haue ſhewed euer hitherto remaineth ſtyll v ſeynge thus greueth v exceadingly ſhould perſwaſiō others ſeke theyr owne commoditie therby ſo incenſed againſt v call rather remembraūce amitie hath bene alwaies betwene v time ſundry place aſwel home broad haue abiden like chaunce warre done many thinges ryght worthely aſſuredly memoriall hereof ought onely bynd v alſo poſteritie moſt ſtreight bonde amitie ye cauſe religion facte oures offende reaſon matter quietly frendly amonges ſelues becommeth felowes frendes knitte together brotherlye league wyll neyther frowarde obſtinate vntractable haue alwayes ſaide wilbe content glad reformed ſuche teache v better thinges ſo muche profeſſion ghoſpell ſakynge frenche league moreouer many ſclaunders inuented againſt v haue torned good willes v altered former mindes muſt write theſe thinges neceſſitie defence oure owne eſtimation haue often ſaied vnleſſe errour canne ſhewed conſtā cie zurieke v scripture may forſake religiō force ſo euer bent againſt v ſame aboute middes february senate strauſburge aunſwered letter ſente chamber imperiall confuted thynges thoſe three accuſers mo ſay founde charged reporte troubleſome parſons fled citie ſtyrre vp ſtrife contenſion therefore require gyue credyte haue ſame opiniō senate mete thē example theyr elder ſeke concorde wealth empire alſo preacher thēſelues wrote ſame time vnto thoſe counſelers longe oration declare reaſons theyr doyng ſo muche haue committed nothyng againſte goddes lawe require moſte humbly geue credite theyr aduerſaries determine thing agaynſt matter knowen time warre italy waxed hote betwixt emperor frēche kyng taken priſoner frenche kynge beſeged pauie winter aboute later ende february taken battell caryed emperour spaine warre biſhoppe rome clement ſecretly vnconſtācie clement frenche parte chaunge fortune gaue vnto themperors captaines greate ſumme money paye theyr ſouldiours anthony lena kept pauie garniſons germanes spaniardes kyng wonderfull great armye ſo much imperialles beyng diſpaire lumbardie conſulted howe conueigh armye kepe naples encouraged throughe oration fernando daualle marque piſcare gate battell wanne felde takyng moſt mightie kinge victor themper • alles obteined noble victorie riche ſpoiles chirſtaine charles de lanoy bourgonion pretendyng fyrſt would haue led kyng naples takyng ſhypping chaūged courſe ſayled spaine matter might ſooner pacified battel foughten ſame day emperor borne foure twenteth february begynnyng ſpring time began newe commotion cōmotion bulgare people sueuelande parte germany yt lyeth riuer thonawe bulgare people againſt prelate churche pretendyng cauſe thoughe would defende goſpell brynge ſelues bondage magiſtrates promiſed heare theyr complaintes reforme miſſe perſeuered ſtill encreaſed dayly ſet forth certeine demaundes numbre theyr demaundes xii wherin would ſatiſfied commynge handes others ſtyrred vp newe commotion ſundry place whyleſt theſe thinges brewing ulriche duke wirtemberge duke wirtemberge attēpte •• warrs certeine yeres confederacie suelād driuen coūtrey got armie swices thinking recouer dukedome beyng reſiſted fernandoes captain kept townes therof others foreſaid confederacy laſt wantyng money gaue ouer enterpriſe meane tyme hoſte bowres much increaſed power prince giuen repulſe duke wirtēberge recouered townes taken went againſt thē ulmes gathered three army whereof one pitched nere vnto biberake algouia thyrde lake cō ſtaunce muche intreatye peace betwixte raueſbourge campodune alſo senate thempire carefull ſtate common welth ſent ulmes simon piſtor duke george saxonie iames sturmnus noble man senate strauſburge treate peace wt counſellours prince confederated commaundyng eyther partie emperours name withdraw theyr warre vnder greate penaltie neyther peace trewce could taken certeine bandes horſemen wente ulines elchinge whiche riuer danubius ſlewe great numbre bowres fyrſte ſlaughter bowres brought many priſoners backe citie george truckeſe chiefe capitaine sueuical league marching forward army came lippene little towne danubius two mile beneth ulmes great numbre peſauntes neyther taryinge footemen munition gaue charge horſemen ſlewe mooſte parte reſt toke riuer another ſlaughter drowned towne beyng gyuen vp taken ſpoyled many therin beheaded truckeſſe victorie would haue gone agaynſt reſydew fotemen whiche lead wylliam furſtemberge would forward wer paid though fought battell captaine ſaide battell enemy diſcomfited euer came yet longe could pacified new entreatie peace nothing could concluded armie marched againſt wer algouia would haue men lyke tyme ſhould ioyne battel ſome ran away reſt yelded ſelues ides aprill meane another parte sueuia aſſembled great numbre hala franckonie vpon great crueltie bowres eaſterday beyng xvi aprill toke towne winſperge ſlewe diuerſe noble men therin amonges others lewes erle helfeſtene moſt cruell ſorte runnyng ſpeares ſo muche cruelly ſight wife baſtarde daughter themperour maximilian cariyng yonge childe armes fell downe theyr feete lamenting wepyng moſt miſerably beholde axing pardon huſbande father ſame childe ſpurned vtterly reiected capitaine truckeſſe diſcoinfited three army mentioned marched ſtreight vpon alſo ſlew two three thouſande putting reſt flighte puniſhynge greuouſly pryſoners namelye thoſe whiche fleyne countie moſt cruel maner burnynge helfeſtene one tyed ſtake longe chaine might ronne vp downe fyre made rounde burnt others nobilitie like fyreth towne winſperge cōmaunded ſhould neuer builded againe another troupe went franckonie burned two hundreth caſtels aboue beſydes abbeis noble men houſes taking citie wirciburge beſeged caſtell truckeſſe commynge vpon throughe countrey wittemberge vanquiſhed alſo put flight recouereth wirciburge reſkeweth caſtel beſeged beyng aided lewes coū tie palatine owne parſon germany broile went loraine ſo much warre bowres loraine anthony duke therof accompanied brother claude duke guiſe gathered vp remenaunt frenche armye diſperſed battel pauie kyng taken went sabernes wheras muche people aſſembled well lorayne alſate wheras bowres reſorted aide ye others made certeine horſemen fotemen againſt village called lupfſteine ſlew nūbre thouſand fyue hūdred reſidew eſcaped flyght nexte daye made great ſlaughter thoſe sabernes notwithſtandyng kept promiſe commaundyng laye downe theyr weapon promiſyng pardon done accordyngly goyng home wardes without weapon ſlayne horſe men fotemen moſt part towne biſhoppes ſlaughter bowres caſtell ſpoiled lewde foldiours citizen alſo ſlayne without reſpecte mercie duke retourned home ſlaughter armye bowres encamped valley willers kepinge ſtreightes ſhoulde paſſe ioyned battel ſlaine aboue iiii thouſande ſame conflicte loſt erle iſerburge thus retourned home much ſpoile many priſoners ſlaine thoughte theſe three place aboute eghtene thouſande monthe may like ſucceſſe others place peterſheme beſydes wormes great numbre murthered ſoldiours time rēdred thē ſelues layde parte weapon ſlaughter preſent countie palatine tharchbiſhop treuers countie beſt power ſtay pacifie ſoldiors crueltie archebiſhop treuers allow theyr doynges alſo killed many hand crediblie reported notwithſtādyng ſundry place policie magiſtrates thing appeaſed quietlye friburge briſgoye whither senate strauſ requeſt gneſt marque baden great land ſent iames sturmius conrade iohame ambaſſadors whoſe perſwaſiō ambaſſadors baſill together thoſe yt encamped lara foure mile strauſ appeaſed xxv day iuly yet fidelitie fayled many came home executed likewyſe heluetians appeaſed rebellion sontgauia prouince belongyng kinge fernando houſe auſtriche declaringe vnto dewtie magiſtrate people alſo theyr requeſtes wer euery like beginning suelāde paſſing ſo vnto others reaching thuringe border saxonie vnto toppe alpes coū trey saliſburge whither rebellion appeaſed frāckonie came alſo armye prince confederated diſtroied geiſmer captaine bower baniſhed many amōges theyr captein geiſmer paſſed alpes ſtreyght paſſages part hoſte uenetians yerely ſtipende dwelled padwey wheras ſlaine treaſon thend bowres warre whiche ſlaine one ſommer leaſt fiftie thouſande league swelane prince confederacie league swelād ſo oft mentioned weretheſe ceſar prince auſtriche brother fernando tharchbiſhop mentz palſegraue biſhoppe saliſburge bamberge wirciburge aiſtet auſpurge wylliam lewes brother duke bauar otho henricke philip brother county palatine george marque brandēburge albert nephewe philip lantzgraue haſſe diuers others nobilitie clergie moreouer moſt part city sweuia amōges norinberge eight day aprill maſſe put downe zuricke commaundement maſſe aboliſſhed zuricke senate aſwell within citie without ſtead inſtituted lordes supper lykewiſe ceremony aboliſhed doctrine godes worde taketh place lawe made againſte fornication adulterie iudges appointed heare cauſes matrimony ✚ fyfthe booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common ale empire charles fyfte ❧ argument fyfth booke muncer newe doctrine teaching goodes common inflamed rage people hauinge phifer companion duke fredericke departeth prince aſſemble againſt muncer perſwading people reſiſt diſcomſited executed luther written againſt toye ſenate miſſhuſe requeſtes wurs made ye beginning recited wherunto luther anſwereth ſheweth diſordre exhorting ye magiſtrate deſtroy ſuch wicked men themperor vnderſtanding theſe trouble appoynteth counſel auſpurge caroloſtadius exiled wittenberg goeth make purgation luther marieth nonne ʒ winglius meete marſeburge conferre theyr controuerſie lordes ſupper whileſt french king priſoner pope clement receiuing letter kynges mother ſolliciteth parlamente paris make perſecuſion faber conſtrained flee wherof king wing aduertiſed cauſeth ſuch ſuites action againſt learned men ſurceaſe common welth pruſe altered knightes germany duke donie receiueth goſpell agreat occaſion terrible warre muncer great anabaptiſts came raſhe lewd preacher wherof thomas muncer principall leauing preaching goſpell ſet forth new kind doctrine alſtet atowne duke saxonye thuringe taughte againſt byſhop rome againſt luther alſo contendinge bothe doctrine vyle naught byſhop byndeth men conſciences ſtraight ouer harde lawes whiche bondes ſaide luther deede hath lowſed offended contrary parte geuing ouermuche libertie teaching thoſe thinges ſpirite biſhops decree maye fafely contemne helpe nothynge vnto ſaluation whiche obtayne ſaith muſt firſt eſchewe open crymes murther adultery blaſpheming god name body muſt chaſtened made leane faſting ſimple apparel coūtenaunce muſt framed vnto grauitie ſpeake ſeldome weare long beard theſe ſuch like thigs called croſſe ye mortifiēg ye fleſh diſcipline wherwt yt furniſhed ſaid muſt get cōpany thike oft god whether hath care ouer whether chriſt died ſakes whether religion better thā turkes moreouer axe god ſygne wherby maye teſtifie careth v true religion albeit ſhew token yet muſt neuertheles procede praie ſtill yea expoſtulate braule god dealeth well wt v ſeyng scripture promiſeth graunt ſuch thinges demaunded righte doeth exhibite muncer haue token ared god ſigne man ſeketh true knowledge expoſtulation anger ſaieth god well accepted perceiueth herby earneſt minde zeale doubt thus inſtantly ſollicited declare ſelfe ſome notable ſigne quenche thirſte minde dealinge v intymes paſte tholde father taughte moreouer god opened hys minde dreames wherin builded foundation intēt loke whoſe dreame could interprete would praiſe openly ſermon meanes allured many began take ſtipulation wrot theyr name promiſed othe ayde pretenſed miſchiefe ſaid commaunded god diſtroy wicked prince ſubſiſtute new theyr place taughte moreouer thinges ſhould cōmon al mē like fredom dignitie wherupon ye cōmon teacheth thinges ſhould common people leauīg theyr daily labor toke ſuch thing neded others yt ſtore euē agaiſt wils duke sax baniſhed time begā fyrſt preach ſeditiouſly thence wēt norin frō thēce mulhuſe wherhe altered ſenate droue mō kes entred theyr poſſeſſiōs takig vpō hi preacher alſo senator determining al matter liſt ſayd thinges ſhewed reuelation loke ſaid thē ſacred holy theſe partes plaied ſpace two thre monethes whē bowres vp swelande frankonie nūbre fourtie thouſand diſcomfited great parte nobilitie taken ſpoyled fyred many holdes caſtels mentioned thē began ſet hāde ſeing time ſeruing ſo well muncer maketh gonne purpoſe caſt felde peces gray frier gote wonderfull numbre people coūtrie thinking get ſome thīg counſell one phifer bold deſperate felow phifer companion much gyuen dreames viſions nighte dreamed ſawe certeine ſtable innumerable ſorte myſe put flight al toke yt god cōmaunded lead forth armie againſt nobilitie ſcatter muncer albeit made ſedicious ſermons yet ſo hote haſarde whole coūtrey vp armure therfore ſent letter al place namely ſuch digged mine coūtrie maunſfelde exhorting thē wiſe ſet vpon theyr prince without reſpecte ſhortely ſhould thoſe yt vp franckonye come theſe party meane phifer yt could longer phifers enterpriſe abide maketh roode company ſpoyleth countrye iſefelde hardely sacketh caſtelies church diſcomfiteth many gentleman caſteth ſome fetter ſo retournynge wyth great buttie encouraged men herts excedinly mūcer ſuppoſing men redynes departeth mulhuſe wt thre hundreth ioyned francuſe ſame time departed death fridericke noble duke sax fridericke duke saxonie without iſſewe neuer maried leauing brother iohn ſuccede nowe alberte countie mūſfelde hearing ſturre countrey leuied ſpedelye certeine bandes horſemen gyuynge charge ſlewe two hundreth thinge put ſuche feare remayned ſtill frāckuſe tariyng company durſt procede prince make power meane time duke saxonie iohn prince elector george vncle philip lantzgraue heſſe henrye duke brunſwike leuied thouſande v hūdreth horſemen certeine bandes foote men marched towardes rebelles incamped hill litell without towne ſo fenſed ſelues carriage hardely coulde inuaded neyther ſufficiently furniſhed munition weapōs ſkilfull warres wherfore prince hauing compaſſion ſente vnto aduiſed deliuer theyr captaines lay aſide theyr weapon ſhould haue theyr pardon retorne home muncer fearing ſelfe came forth ſower countenaūce ſeditious oration muncer made oration ſe felowes brother farre frō tyrraūtes albeit haue conſpired deathes yet ſo diſcouraged mindes date attēpte nothing againſt v offere ſuche condicions fooliſhe torne weapon know right well haue attempted thinge owne braine priuate aucthoritie neuer experienced ſuche matter commaundemēt god ſeyng ſo ſhal dewtie obey depart grounde god ſelfe hath placed v tymes paſt commaūded abrahā offer vp ſonne although ignoraūt ſhold thēde yet folowyng cōmaūdemēt refuſed nothing therfore god bothe preſerued ſonne alſo rewarded faith wt great benefit ſo likewiſe ought yt ſtād ſaith abraham obteined god great benefites ſame caſe cōmit ſucceſſe thig god nodoubt ſhal haue deſire ſelfes ſhal ſe helpe god manifeſtly ſhal diſcōfit enemy al place god hath promiſed ſūdrie place ſcripture helpe pore toppreſſe wicked ſaying apperteineth vnto v poore afflicted becauſe ſeke ſetforth mainteine true knowledge god doubt victory let v cōſider ſtate enemy muncer rai leth prince called dede prince tirātes care take good ſpende thē wickedly pride riot voluptuouſues light cauſes moue wartes deſtroye pore haue lefte theſe theyr princelik uertues place widow orphane mainteine biſhoppe rome aucthoritie wickedneſſe cleargie youthe ſhoulde brought vp learnyng poore releued eſtabliſhe marchandiſe maſſing abhominations thinke ye god wil ſuffer longer truely euē droue cananites ſo wil expulſe theſe alſo chriſt whipt bier blouddy preacher bloweth crompet ſellers forth temple ſo nowe likewiſe theſe prieſtes theyr patrones mainteiners wherefore play men gratifie god diſtroiyng vnprofitable people ſurely ſuerer waye pacifie matter forſake theyr olde wont wil reſtore v vnto libertie permit v haue true religiō ſeruice god wi ought rather die allow theyr wickednes ſuffer doctrine goſpel taken frō v promiſſe moſt aſſuredly ye god wil aide ſtrengthen v uictorye ſhalbe oures ſelfe ſo promiſe ſelfe lye diſceaſed commaū ded procede wiſe puniſhe magiſtrate herein god power chiefly declared whan ſtronge army deſtroied ſmale handfull appeared example gedeon ionathos god power appeareth ſeweſt men iud vii sam xiiii xvii dauid killed goliah greate gyaunt ſo tyrrible looke vpon doubt preſent day ſhal notable like ſpectacle ſpoken whileſt worlde goeth albeit well fourniſhed wyth weapon thynges neceſſarye owne defence yet ſhall engine heauen earth chaunged rather thā god ſhal forſake v ſo water red sea chaunged tymes paſt iſraelites beyng perſecuted pharao might paſſe therfore feare nothing fight māfully againſt wicked enemy fraide theyr gunnes pellettes yt ſhall ſhoute receaue cote beholde ſe howe mercyfull god haue beholde ſigne token euerlaſtyng good wyll towardes v lift vp eies ſee reinebow ſkie ſeing haue ſame painted enſeigne god declareth plainely ſimilitude ſheweth v muncer diſceaueth people rainebowe highe wyll aide v battell diſtroye tyrrauntes wherfore nowe ſet vpon wyth bolde courage moſte aſſured godes helpe made ende moſt part afraide great daunger yet amonges many lewde fearein mū cer campe deſperate perſons ready vnto miſchief beynge inclined theyr nature euyll perſwaded oration chieflye celeſtiall ſigne ſuppoſyng moſt ſure token victorie ouer hauing ſmalle company numbre eight thouſande place mete ynough kept cried oute men ſhoulde take theyr weapon fight ſtout courage againſt enemy ſinging ſōg wherby called helpe holy goſt ther meſſenger ſlaine agaiſt lawe armes ſent vnto noble yong man muncer againſt lawes armes ſlayne wherwith prince diſpleaſed cauſed trompettes ſoūde battel ſet mē order thā philip lantzgraue heſſe though yongeſt exhortaci lantzgraue ryding vp downe frō one cōpany another exhorted ſoldioures valcaūt although thinges trew wherof accuſed yet lawfull ſubiectes rebell againſt prince magiſtrats vnto god hath giuen ſword wold haue obeyed may proued ſundry place scripture wente aboute execuſe eyther owne faultes prince confeſſe theyr fault graunt many thinges ought amended yet ought people neuertheleſſe abſteyne ſeditiō alledge permitted haue doctrine goſpel iuſt cauſe make rebellion whan peter ſtroke ſworde rebuked chriſt prince perſecute trew religion ought beare yea ſuffer death rather reſiſt force armes take ye name goſpell cloke theyr intent dede take men good ſley magiſtrates force men wiues crime ſhould puniſhed aſmuche pretende name holynes theſe ſo ſhamefull deedes doubte god wyll plage hypocriſie reuenge blaſphemie holye name theſe ſuche like wordes encouraged hys men fyght gaue charge theyr enemy fyrſt wente ordinaunce poore wretch ſtandyng amaſed men rauiſhed theyr wittes neither defended ſelues madnes munceriane ſought theyr ſaftie flight ſonge duche mytre requiringe aide holy ghoſt many truſtyng muncers promiſe looked helpe heauen greate peces ſhotte entred theyr campe ſlayne many laſte fled towarde towne franckuſe others went againe thother ſyde hill valley beneth ſkirmiſhed wyth certeine horſemen ſlewe two three horſemen ſcattered ſelues theyr enemy fledde folowed chaſe oute raye miſſed company wer ſuch rage reuenge theyr felowes death ſlewe fyue thouſand immediatly battell towne taken thre hundreth beheaded muncer fled towne hyd ſelfe houſe ſlaughter mū cerians farre gate hither chaunce came gentleman ſeruaunt goyng vp ſee houſe founde chamber aboue one lying bed aſketh one rebel fled ſayd nay layue ſycke good whyle ague purſe chauſed laye vpon bed chatcheth vp thinkyng haue pece money opened foūd letter albert countie manſfelde ſent muncer admoniſhynge ceaſe enterpriſe ſtyrre vp people rebellion red letter demaunded whether letter written vnto denied thother threatened deſyred content confeſſed muncer led duke george saxonie lātz muncer taken graue beynge demaunded thus abuſed poore ſimple people aunſwered done
