expreſſe wordes empire emperour vnto bounde othe fidelitie ambaſſadour citie appointed iames sturmius receyued league diuines melanchthon bucer george draco aſſemblie receyued league ulriche duke wyrtemberge bernine philippe brother duke pomerane george ioachime bretherne countes anhalde moreouer city auſpurge franckeforte kempten hamborough haunobria treated alſo thynges appertayning league defence therof iudgement imperial chāber decreed moreouer ſende meſſengers letter emperour thereby aunſwere epiſtle ſent frō naples george duke saxon exceadyng hatred bare luther doctrine oftentymes great cōtention ſute prynce electour saxon man father laſt agrement made nowe broken againe ſayde duke george diuerſe wayes prynce electour declaringe whole matter ambaſſadours conſortes aſſemblie requeſtyng aſſiſted ayde counſell caſe attempte anye force violence aſſemblie brake vp tenth day may begynning iune kynge englande hauyng cō dempned lamentable death quene anne wyue quene anne adultrye inceſte vniuſtly ſuppoſed proued ſynce cauſeth head ſtryken ſhe borne hym daughter calleth elizabeth executed certen gentleman kynges priuie chaumbre noreis weſton brewton one markes whiche contrary conſcience reported hope preferement ſubſcribed byll whereby condempned hym ſelfe reſte lorde admirall fizt williams erle southhampton ſayde vnto hym ſubſcribe markes ſee wyll come ſubſcribed receyued therfore rewarde vnloked alſo lorde rochforte quenes brother falſe accuſation errant ſtrompet wyfe whiche afterwardes ſuffered therfore accordynge deſertes whiche doulfull tragedie toke cleane awaye ambaſſade ſhould haue ſent englande whan warre hotely begonne betwene emperour counſel called frenche kyng paule thyrde publiſheth wrytinge vnder bulles lead ſomme wherof call counſell mantua againſt xxiij day may yeare followyng commaunding al archbiſhops byſhops head church ſame day vnder penaltie eccleſiaſticall lawes preſcribed diſobediēce furthermore chargeth deſireth emperour king prince al others either lawe cuſtome haue intereſt loue chriſte cōmon welthes ſake come perſone otherwyſe letted thā ſend ambaſſadours full authoritie remayne tyll ende counſell churche may refourmed hereſies weded cleane warre attempted againſt ennemies religiō effect therof whereunto ſubſcribed ſixe twenty cardinalles ſeuenth iune kyng ferdinando ſent iames sturcelly ciuilian ambaſſadour inſprucke swycers heare ſaith frē che kyng hath requyred ayde obteined great pleaſure haue aduertiſed emperour hereof certenly reaſon would ſhould ſo emperour gaue none occaſion warre fully reſolued ſommer haue warred vpon barbarian ennemies religion notwithſtanding againſt frēch kyng frenche kynge immediatly death fraunces sfortia duke millan albeit hath right title therunto compoſition made touchyng whole matter certen yeares paſte contrary conuenauntes ſought renewe warre recouer lumbardy ſame tyme paſſing alpes great armie inuaded duke sauoye prynce empyre intent hauing one ſubdued countrey might haue way open paſſe nowe emperour hath leuied armie reſiſte hym dede conſtreined informed craueth nowe ayde agayne neuertheleſſe muche breakyng fidelitie hath commenced warres freſhe deſyre doe aſſiſte hym whereby ſhall emperour pleaſure preſerue quiet owne commō wealth proteſtantes ſend emp meane proteſtantes ſent ambaſſade emperour italy make purgation charged letter haue taken churche goodes complayne iudges emperiall chamber ambaſſadours arriued emperoure ſeuenthe iulye ſent letter proteſtauntes towne sauilie ſignifieng hath al tymes preſent abſent letter empe letter proteſtant ambaſſadours ſought quiet germany hath promyſed peace theyr relygion alſo perfourmed ſame nowe muche frenche kynge againſt whome enforced rayſe armie maye perauenture falſe ſuggeſtion perſwade would take occaſion breake treuce religion therfore hath thought good admonyſhe letter beleue ſuche thinge aſſure ſelues woulde obſerue promyſe neyther would moue warre vpon man religion ſtyre vp trouble germany preparation warre mainteyne ryght authoritie wherfor let quiet ſelues ſtyre ſo euer ſhal heare ſhall hym acceptable alſo profitable whan emperours power come altogether marched empe inuadeth french prouinces myddeſt italye ſtronge armie tyll came prouynce fraunce kynge incamped hym ſelfe auignion betwyxte ryuers rhoſne druence deſtroyinge countrey whereinto perceiued emperour woulde come kepyng hym ſelfe geuynge battell brought ennemies great perplexitie myſerie emperour enforced penurie ſcarſcitie thynges loſſe manye thouſandes whiche died famine peſtilence alſo death anthony leuie diſchargeth reſte armye retourneth gene armie warred ſommer uermandoys peronne beſeged beſeged towne peronne cōduicte henry erle naſſowe preuayling leuied ſiege ſame time emperour retyred prouince reporte eyther newes brought vnto paris ſame daye reioyſed citie exceadynglye verye great feare preacher sermon people inuehed ſore againſt emperour kynges lieutenauntes began intrenche cytie kepte gate watche warde william furſtemberge germane ſerued frenche kynge warre begynning warre ended lyfe frenche death fraunces dolphin kynges eldeſt ſonne fraunces daulphin eyghtene yeares age reporte went poyſoned one sebaſtian de moute cuculo italian beyng ſuſpicion fyrſte racked torne piece ſondrye horſes lion kynge afterwardes letter prynces germanye amonges made greuous complainte hereof againſt anthony leuie ferdinando gonzage emperours lieutenauntes whome layd blame herman archebyſhop collon long tyme intending reformation collon reformation churche holdeth tyme counſell owne prouince callynge maner byſhoppes within iuriſdiction liege utreicht munſter oſenbridge myndes herein decree made ceremony doctrine ſet forth booke compyled iohn gropper wherein al popyſhe ceremony moſte parte paynted new colour whiche booke dyd contente byſhop hereafter ſhalbe declared tyme alſo moneth iuly eraſmus roterdam death eraſmus departed lyfe olde man thre ſcore ten yeares buried baſill howe excellently learned howe eloquent man howe muche al learnyng bounde hym workes ſhall teſtifie occaſion puttyng downe papiſtrie englande ſuppreſſing certen abbeyes vnder thre hundreth markes yearely valewe aroſe commotion lynkcolneſhyre commotion linkcolnſhyre market towne call lowthe ſtyred vp doctour mackerell falſe monke named ſelfe captayne cobblar appeaſed duke southfolke kynges lyeutenaunt began yorke ſhyre grear deale worſe thoſe rebelles manye ſtronge came farre dankcaſter duke northfolke met kinges power ſhould haue ioyned together battell mediation erle shrewiſbury man welbeloued common matter taken vp without bloudſhed chief captaine robert aſke executed treaſon certen others nobilitie adherentes unto letter captayne aſke emperour wrote iuly proteſtaūtes anſwer nynth day septembre pleaſed hym wryte ſo gentle ſo lyberally ſhewe hym howe conceaue great pleaſure theyr mindes albeit neuer diſtruſte promiſe yet much diuerſe reportes diſpleaſure came eares agayne iudges imperiall chamber others makyng none accompte peace concluded procede diuerſe wayes agaynſte ſome cauſe doubte feare matter nowe hath wrytten againe ſo louingly playnly doubtes wyll perfourme ſame refuſe ſclaunderous reportes aduerſaries lykewyſe wyll doe geue credite vnto ſuche ſhall otherwyſe reporte al thinges alſo doe according dutie came counſell byſhop lately appointed mantua muche emperour oftentymes promyſed free counſell germany eſpecially peace concluded norinberge ſhall perceiue wryting deſyre hym woulde ſee matter myght indifferently heard vſed ſame moneth byſhop rome publyſheth pope wyl reforme court rome wryting ſayeth howe meane tyme tyll counſel begynne wyl refourme holy citie rome head chriſtendome maiſtres doctrine maner diſciplyne waſhe cleane ſpottes vyce intent owne houſe firſt well pourged may eaſely take ordre reſt becauſe nature man full imbecillitie neyther ſo great thing alone alſo diſpatche affaire common wealth therfore hath choſen certen cardinalles whome liuing god hath ioyned hym coadiutours companion cure office worker neceſſary holſome buſynes cardinall oſtia sauſeuerine ginute simonet thre byſhops whome commaundeth men obeye vnder great penaltie moneth octobre emperour imbarketh ſelfe king scottes maried yt frēch kinges daughter gene ſayle spayne frenche kynge came afterwardes paris new yeares day gyueth mariage madame magdalene eldeſt daughter iames fift kynge scottes came fraunce autumne maner ſame tyme laurence medices treaſon nyght murthered alexander medices duke florence owne kyndred familie duke florence ſlayne coſyn whan allured hym home houſe putting hym hope enioye noble matrone neyghbour beautie honeſt fame farre excelled others ſlayne gouernment came vnto coſmus medices emperours conſent married elenor daughter peter toletane uiceroy naples ides ianuary kyng fraunce came court parliament paris whiche thinge ſeldome accuſtomed great audiēce maketh ſore complaint emperour declared cauſes country flaunders artois whiche emperour holdeth kynges fraunce elder haue done alſo ought called againe patrimony fraūce ſpeaker hereof capell kynges aduocate named swycers ſewe king goſpellers hym emperour charles auſtriche meane tyme city zuricke berne baſyll strauſborough make ſute frenche king ſuch impriſoned religion intreating hym exile myght reſtored kyng graunted partly vnto requeſtes yet accompliſhed deſyre wherfore whan receyued aunſwere foure twenty february anna momorantie coneſtable ſuſpected kynge impulſion dealt leſſe frendly ambaſſadours vſed afterwardes helpe quene nauarre kinges owne ſyſter good ladye whiche bare great zeale true doctrine meane whyle kyng hauing muſtred men beginning marche leadyng army towardes arras beſegeth towne ſtrong caſtell heſdine whiche rendred heſdine rendred hym within moneth ſelfe ſame tyme came kynge ambaſſadour byſhop rome reignalde poole englyſh mā borne bloud cardinall poole pope ambaſſadour frenche kyng roial lately made cardinal cauſe ambaſſade thought worke ſome miſchief againſt kinge englande ſame tyme kyng scottes maried frenche kynges daughter byſhop ſent preſent fayre ſworde riche well wrought exaſperate againſt kyng englande byſhoppes accuſtomed chriſtmas daye nyght amō ge thinges certen ceremony conſecrate thei terme ſworde hallowed ſworde whiche honour token beneuolence geue ſende vnto ſome man whome lyketh sixtus fourth firſt authour cuſtome mentioned booke pooles boke againſt king henry eyght ceremony afterwardes cardinall poole wrote booke whiche intitled defence vnitie churche addreſſeth ſtyle ſpeache vnto king henry reprehēdeth ſore toke vpon head churche title longe byſhop rome whiche uicar chriſte cold reaſōs pope ſupremacie ſucceſſour peter whome chriſte appointed prince apoſtles aunſwered chriſte ſonne god vpon hym vpon rocke chriſte buylded churche howe chriſte prayeth fayth conuerted myght alſo conuerte brother iohn chriſtes death euer obeye peter tyme made haſte bothe chriſtes sepulchre wold go gaue honour cure charge fede ſhepe committed chiefly hym chriſt nette alſo ful fyſſhe whiche many able hale vp drawen vpon ſhore peter alone hath long diſcourſe deathes byſhop rocheſter ſyr thomas moore deteſtinge crueltie moreouer howe kyng afflicted ſtates realme muche myſery brought moſte floryſhynge kyngdome daunger ſtode emperour diuorſement aunt ſubuerſion religion ſheweth hym neyther ought loke ayde eyther owne ſubiectes men whiche hath deſerued ſo euyll common wealth tourning tale emperour many wordes ſtireth vp prouoketh incēſeth emper againſt king englande prycketh hym forewarde auenge notable reproche done vnto familie ſayeth howe turkyſhed ſeede ſowen abroade englande germany ſignifiyng doctrine contrary byſhop rome finally many opprobrious wordes ſharpe rebuke prouoketh hym regentaunce telleth hym howe none remedy retourne agayne boſome churche whiche one defended ſetting forth bookes greatly honour booke printed rome bearyng date long tyme kept cloſe laſt manye yeares came one two germany ſayeth cauſe wrytinge therof kynge deſyred hym wryte opinion albeit certen learned men englande whiche done lyke loſt lyues yet could whiche ſo muche bounde vnto hym diſſemble opinion neyther ought imputed hym raylynge curſed ſpeakynge doeth naturall diſpoſition alſo certen ordre life cleane abhorre vice endeuoureth reduce agayne waye deceiued flatterer ſtrayed farre ryght pathe geueth hym great benefite kynge henry brought vp yought good letter done much poole vnthankful whan alteration englande whiche haue ſpoken myſlyked paule thyrde commendation contarene made hym cardinal ſent hym rome familiarly acquaynted ſay knoweth hipocriſie falſhod ryght well doctrine goſpell ſuppoſe cauſe haue wrote ſo againſt kyng henry auoyde ſuſpicion lutheraniſme cauſed booke printed rome coſte charge reporte taking ſelfe copy gaue reade byſhop ſelf cardinalles others dere frendes vnto ſuch wold commended feared ſyde leſte ſhould red openly men ſhould incure rebuke obloquie oftentymes heard hym ſpeake contrary ✚ eleuenth booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charles fyfte ❧ argument eleuenth booke proteſtantes hauing declared emperour ambaſſade three poyntes heldus cō ming smalcald maketh anſwer reply vrge fre counſel ſuch promiſed vpon pope ſendeth biſhop aſte proteſtants ſet forth apologie vpon refuſal ſuch counſel writ therof french king king england writeth againſt coū ſaile pope spake citie auſpurge nynthe booke chaunge religion whiche cauſe clergie moſte parte noble houſe forſoke citie wherupon senate writing directed emperour wryting auſpurg kyng ferdinando ſtates empyre declareth cauſe doynges howe frendly dealte many thynges ſuffered howe ſcornefully behaued ſelues howe often went ſtire vp ſedition citie whereunto long chriſtopher byſhop aunſwered ſelfe reſte many contumelious wordes exhorteth emperour prince muche daungers concerneth aſwel ſelf would loke time haue heard laſt booke ambaſſadours prote ambaſſad emp proteſtauntes ſent emperour italy gaue commaundement chiefly thre thynges treate firſt confute brute whiche rayſed vp ſhoulde haue made league kynge fraunce england ſecondly emperour would reſtrayne iudgement counſell chaumbre thirdly ſuche come league ſince compoſicion peace norinberge myght inioye ſame peace whiche requeſtes emperour dede hearde wholy occupied warelyke matter ſayde howe woulde ſende ambaſſadour germany ſhould make aunſwere wherfore departure gene spayne ſent matthie helde vicechaū celour heldus emperours ambaſſad germany whan proteſtauntes vnderſtode ambaſſadours nowe retourned appoynte generall metyng smalcalde ſeuenth daye february becauſe daye counſell approched nere neyther doubte emperours ambaſſadour would haue ſome talke ſame agreed alſo bring chiefeſt diuines wherfore daye aſſigned beſydes prynces ambaſſadours city came thether luther melanchthon bucer oſiander diuerſe whan ambaſſadour come smalcalde fyftene daye february ſpeaketh thus howe emperour commaunded hym doe meſſage sration smalcald duke saxony lantgraue muche haue thought good make conſortes alſo partaker ſame contente followe mindes herein ſaith dede knoweth al ambaſſadours league wherfore caſe amongs anſwere emperous doth concerne cauſe ſhoulde ſuppoſe treaty made thē chiefly auſpurge haue oftentymes ſollicited emperour italy spayne religiō nowe alſo lately gene ambaſſadour unto whome emperour ſayde howe would ſende ambaſſadour germany whiche ſhoulde make aunſwere abyding commyng haue altered ſtate religion without contempte alſo making emperour therefore whan came auſpurge beinge conſtrayned neceſſitie chaunge purpoſe treated nothynge hath wrytten emperour whole matter ſtandeth whā exhibited teſtimoniall ambaſſade procedeth ſo diligently pourged ſelues frenche englyſh league emperoure ioyfull heare whiche doeth credit alſo cōmendeth vertue haue ſo wittely eſchewed frenche practiſes full diſceirfulnes afterwards frēche practiſes diſcourſing warre sauoy ſpeakynge many thinges frenche kyng ſayde lette vnto emperour could bende whole power againſt turke alſo conſulted turkes prouoked thē inuade criſtendome alſo daily practiſe ſtyre vp ſtryfe ciuile warre germany nowe endeuoureth al may perſwade emperour wyll kepe promyſe deſireth therfore credite crafty counſelles emperour ſuche honour vertue wyll ſhrinke promyſe may well perceiue mo experimēts one touchinge iudgement imperiall chambre emperours commaundemēt ſhould meddle caſes religion aduertiſed letter oftentymes controuerſies whiche partely concerned religion partlye therfore emperour cōmaunded thē ſuch matter thei ſuppoſed ſequeſtred religiō thei ſhould iudge indifferently pitie lawe ſhould haue courſe ſeyng emperour hath commaunded ſurceaſe determining matter religion ought contente iudges haue done ought contrary emperours decre ſhall eſcape free ſhalbe puniſhed according lawe made regenſpurge emperour againe admoniſhed would nothing raſhely neither preſcribe imperiall chambre thinge neither lawfull voyde ſeditiō ſhould iudges chāber ſeme done contempt emperours iuriſdictiō reproche iudges whiche ar partly men noble houſes partly excellent learning vertu therfore requireth hynder lawe unto thirde requeſte whiche ſuche alſo compriſed peace norinberge ſhoulde inioye benefite therof ſayeth emperour ſafe conſcience graunte haue promyſed ſubſcribed decree empyre whiche contrary religion eche man ſhould ſuffered ſwarue promyſe whan liſte wer ready waye breake pacification norinberge wherfore whan emperour ſhall knowe certenly procedynges wyll ſhall ſeme ryght reaſon meane tyme requyreth obſerue peace ſelues ſee broken others whiche truſte wyll doe conſiderynge counſell ſo nere whereof haue wrytten emperour fourth thyng whiche hath commaundement treate vſeth great long perſwaſiō ſeing emperour kynges nation intende wyll refuſe agaynſt ſame wherein emperour deſyreth vnderſtand playnly myndes caſe ſhould refuſe take exception make delaye emperour thynketh moſt godly purpoſe ſhold ſtopped middes courſe ſtraungers woulde alſo conceaue ſuſpicion loued rather vexation common wealth peace quietnes ſeyng emperour hath reſpect god glory ſet forth ſaluation men conſydered exhorteth earneſtly requyreth would ſatiſfie herein deſyre common wealthes alſo hath alſo commiſſion anye controuerſie ſhall happen matter ſhall ſolute appeaſe ſame wherunto wyl diligence ſhalbe ready deſyre alſo declaration talke woulde refuſe next daye thus ſpoken treateth ſeuerallye duke saxony howe emperour beareth eſpeciall good wyll lette hath declared theſame hitherto hath bene diſſention religion ſeing great hope matter ſhalbe quieted counſell already called deſyreth hym ſame ſende ambaſſadours thether intente diſcorde taken awaye may declare good wyl towards hym refuſe take exception diſpleaſure wyll come knoweth well enough moreouer muche turke maketh great preparation inuade germanye requyreth hym ſende hym ayde decreed regenſpurge againſt turkes force chaunce turke come field attempte germany woulde ſende hym ſame ayde agaynſt frē che kyng hath inuaded sauoye prouince emperour laſt becauſe emperour hath borne whole charge theim periall chambre long tyme alone hath conſumed great treaſure warres requyreth olde cuſtome empyre would contributary portion money hereunto belōging reſidue prynces haue alſo promyſed duke ſayeth duke aunſwere muche theſe thynges concerne hym alone cō ſortes alſo wyll take deliberation xxiiij daye february confederatours make aunſwere together firſt wyſhynge vnto emperour longe health preſeruation concernynge auſpurge haue heard whole matter ambaſſadours ſay howe ſequeſtre theyr fellowſhyp touchyng emperours warre frenche kyng lytle ſory ſeyng ſame commodious turkes ennemies empyre emperour hath taken good parte purgation mynded kepe peace made norinberge ryght glad thanke hym touchynge iudgement imperiall chamber ſayde howe ſore ſhould greue emperour ſtoppe courſe lawe ſhew difficultie thinge time archebiſhop mētz palſgraue interceſſours much long deliberation appered ſurer way eſtabliſh cōmonwelth graūte peace religion al matter annexed ſame till either general counſell europe prouincial counſel germany migh vnleſſe might ſo except yt maner matter procede religion might cōpriſed together howe lightly occaſion trouble may geuen conſidered nowe may alſo perceiued wordes alſo themperours proclamation ſet forth ſame time declare ſufficiently neuer minde pretende cauſe ſaue matter religion neither iudges counſel chāber opiniō able proue cōtrary ſayth themperour gaue authoritie iudge qualitie matter greuouſe accōpt al thoſe action concerne religion whiche dede decided vnleſſe controuerſie religion firſt lawful counſel determined thing haue many time ſignified themperour kyng ferdinando letter ambaſſadours queſtion religiō preiudiciall ought determined counſell ſuche matter examined depend vpō ſame ſeing benefites imployed deſert dutie ſuffer yt thoſe wtin dominion folowe cōtrary religiō frō doctrine enioye goodes church muche either wil execute dutie ſo muche matter cōcerneth cōſciēce mynde remaineth place right poſſeſſiō reſtitutiō ſeing yt whē cōpoſitiō made norīberg expreſſeli named al actiōs ſutes hanged eyther chāber courtes iudgemēt exhibiting thē interceſſours matter religiō promiſed fynde meanes yt themperour ſhould exempt thē frō iudgement ſame thing alſo king ferdinādo toke vpō thaſſēblie cadane thoſe wordes proclamatiō thēperour cutteh ple authoritie iudge ſtate matter cleane taken away frō iudges yt imperial chāber although wold report euil thē yet many ſeyng thē ready geue ſentence agaynſte wer incouraged rather comēce actiōs thing prouoked mo wayes thā one time men require iugedmēt thyng ar admitted alſo contumeliouſe wordes reiected late humborough cōmaūded reſtore clergie citie goodes poſſeſſions alſo olde religiō al iuriſdictiō could ſo wt ſafe conſcience condemned great ſōme money therfore themperour may ſe one fact mynde purpoſe either thꝭ matter religion el none al may vſe matter ſorte truce made vayne caſe meane rite ceremony chaūged may reſtored ſhal nede general counſel wherunto notwithſtanding themperour ſelf ſaith al theſe thinges belong wherfore vpō iuſt neceſſary cauſes haue refuſed iudgemēt whan diuerſe exceptiōs could preuaile nothing touching perſons iudges paſt one two religiō found whole cōpany decre made regēſburg thꝭ behalf vnknowen fierſly thē impugneth doctrine better accepted euē coūtenaūces may eaſly perceiued affectiō thei beare v hādlīg matter whiche thing thus doubt themperoure wyll cōmaunde thē ſurceaſe caſe themperour thinke yt anye prophane matter mixed matter religiō refuſe due examinatiō ſame ſo meane tyme iudgement imperial chāber may ceaſe ſuch cōmen league ſince pacification norinberge former yeres interceſſours require scwinforte ſhould receiue mo league nūbre refuſed ſame whan came norinberge perſeuered ſame opinion ſayd many promyſed cōdicioned alter religion ſome anſwere thus made promyſe al ſome againe made exception priuate compoſitiōs might thus ſome dede promiſed vpō condiciō themperour put thē hope procure coūſell called wtin ſixe monthes ſhould begin within yere wheras yt longer delayed meane god benefit vnderſtode rightly true doctrine thei could differre longer thought duty profeſſe yt thing knew true godly yt byſhop rome lawe ſo teacheth yt man hath alſo bounde ſelfe othe thing yt wicked bound performe like aduerſaries refuſe nūbre ſhould fall take partes may alſo may eſcape come felowſhyp let maye ſo doe wherfore beſeche emperour woulde reſtrayne iudges ſuffer onlye others alſo whyche ſynce come enioye benefyte peace otherwyſe thei haue wrōg offered thē forſake league fellowes lyke profeſſours doctrine neceſſitie declared alſo ferdinādo uiē na cauſe alone iudges chā ber ſhal take vnto thē preuente counſell herein doubteth extortion open wrong againſt conſtrained euen lawe nature defende thē ſelues diſcōmoditie come therof wilbe ende themperour wiſdome conſider thei doubtles wiſhe peace couet gratifie themperour thinges yet ſo men may haue fre acceſſe true doctrine may obtayne wylbe preſt ready accōpliſhe emperour king ferdinā require touching turke charge chābre cōcerning counſaile wherunto themperour ſo greatly perſwadeth haue red copie letter paule third hath publyſhed touching ſame perceius therby ſame minde opinion themperour although adrian ſixt thaſſē blie norinberge cōfeſſed legate yt maner al thinges rome ſore corrupted promiſing endeuour might reformed yet clement ſeuenth ſucceſſour two yeares cleane minde appered legate ſent next aſſemblie ſo muche themperours lieutenaūtes prince decree made ordeined fre general councell might holden germany coūſel errour vice ſo euer crept church might takē away decre afterward cōfirmed thēperour yt ſuite tharchbiſhop mēzt palſgraue prince electour howbeit clement yeare propoūded counſel farre otherwyſe thā ſpecified decree thempire aſſigned place italy thā refuſed ſame thing afterward paule third anſwered alſo following lyke trade nowe alſo doeth byſhop rome attempt ſame although couertly clement ſeuēth openly expreſſe wordes herein doth certen implicatiō condēne doctrine ſpeaketh late ſprōg vp hereſies meaneth ſame doctrine intendeth plucke vp rootes manifeſt thexecution puniſhmēt putteth innocēt perſones profeſſing ſame doctrine yet ſhameleſſe diſſembling pretedeth though wold reforme thoſe horrible e • rours vice church theſe many yeres ſo many good learned men haue cōplained yt themperour crafty policy perſwaded prouoketh thē ye counſel would knew fraude diſceiptfulnes ſame craftes vſeth alſo time legate ſolliciteth kynges prince yea alſo admitte counſell intēt may haue thē fauourers mainteiners wicked purpoſe confirmation counſel myght thē ſelues condemne owne doctrine whiche craft iulian apoſtata diſceaued time paſt chriſten ſouldiours although byſhop rome ſuſteineth perſone aduerſary yet taketh vpō authoritie iudge againſt al right equitie hath others conſenting herein whiche bounde othe manye wayes vnlawful ſame ought graū ted thē themperour doubtles king opiniō iudge yt byſhop rome hath brought errours ye churche doctrine cleane cōtrary god worde alſo auncient toūſelles doctours mainteineth ſame hath alſo made exceading many lawes againſt god cōmaundemēt wherby true knowledge vtterly oppreſſed defaced ſame vereli haue diuines god gift declared therfore intēde accuſe byſhop fellowes lawfull counſell theſe ſo great matter coudēpne thē ſame alſo euil craftes diſhoneſt meanes yea force guyle achiefe dignity filthie life leade euil example thei geue part dutie thei neglect ſuch cōmitted charge wallowe wickednes lyfe ſo wel knowen tried yt nedeth declaratiō cauſes alſo lawfull biſhop euen teſtimony owne lawe appoint coūſel muche leſſe iudge ſame neither may ſworne clientes vſurpe perſone iudge ſeing may dede part lawful coūſel moreouer place coūſel appointed italy cleane cōtrary decree themperour ſtates thempire ſcornefully diſpiſeth thei know ouer yet whether prince chriſtendom wil allowe yt place weighty cauſes ſhold daūgerous come thither albeit ſhould haue ſaufe conduicte yet ſo muche byſhop hath clientes euerye hate doctrine moſt bitterly ther great daūger lieng wayte priuie cōſpiracies thoſe party much feared furthermore ſince matter moſt weighti ſuch vnder ſonne arriſe greater doubtles cōcerneth either euer laſting ſaluatiō dānatiō ſeing greatnes matter requireth yt ſhould great nūbre wt miniſters churche preacher preſent cōmit ſo weighty matter deputes proetours alone ſhould great griefe vnto thē paſſe limites thempire go italy leauing coū trey people ſuche grudge mindes germany wtout garde church long time without preacher wherfore moſte humbly beſeche emperour would way hym ſelfe theſe poinctes diligently ſeing high ſupreme magiſtrate vnto chiefly belongeth ſetting forth trew doctrine wold applie ſelf wholy true knowledge god might aduaunced doe embrace wicked kynde doctrine ſeke thyng glory god holy name aunſwere concerning counſell agreed vnto alſo ambaſſadours george marque brandenburge city norinberge halle hailbrune thinges medled becauſe league time proteſtantes thus ſpoken heldus ambaſſadour aunſwereth ſpeaking anſwer heldus many thinges againe great good emperour frenche kyng whiche conſpired turkes diſtruction cōmon wealth cometh matter touching iudgement imperial chambre ſayeth deede peace graunted matter religion man ſay cōtrary ſtrife conſiſte matter religion take ſuche caſes religion others accō pte ciuile prophane farre againſt reaſon thyng ſhould debated cauſes obiectiōs either part heard ſo procedeth meaning yt ſame matter touching ſuch lately receiued league yt emperour thiketh thus yt cōpriſed within peace norinberg bounde al decree thempire ought yelde ye authoritie coū ſel aſmuch themperours minde wholy addicte peace cōcorde requireth eſtſones yt wyl ayde wt men mony turkiſh warre nedeful charge imperial chābre turke inuade yt thā wold monthes aſſiſte themperour like ayde againſt french king whiche wil doe ſhall repēt thē yt ſeruice wherin deſireth know direct anſwer may aduertiſe themperour therof concerning coū ſel thē ſelues knowe labour trauayle themperour bring paſſe truſt yt ſame ſhalbe appeaſed cōtrouerſie yt religion wt quietnes ſtate cōmō wealth reformed glory god preſeruatiō men wherfore perour truſteth aſſuredly ſhould make none exception ſwarue reſt men ſhould perſiſte herein would grieffull heare againe vſed ſondrye perſwaſions amonges emperour would ſaufeconduicte ſaue harmeleſſe requyred haue determinate aunſwere herein beſydes name come vnto ſynce peace norinberge wherein wrytten marque george city norinberge weyſenburg hailbrine winſem hale ſame religion league wherefore emperours name deſyred knowe league condition ſame ſelfe ſame daye came thether romyſhe legate byſhop aques letter pope ambaſſad byſhop rome duke saxon exhorting come counſell whome byſhop rome ſent germany place peter paule uerger hopinge well newe ambaſſadour ſhould ſome thing haue brought paſſe alſo loſte labour little regarded ſo muche certen day whan deſired ſpeake lātgraue tolde leaſure maner ſame inſtant went ſee howe luther ſame tyme laye ſore ſycke ſtone thyng ambaſſadour pope ambaſſad viſpyſed myght ſee lodging uergerius geuen ambaſſadour inſtructions whole ſtate germany euery man byſhops behalfe muſt enterteined vſed fourth daye whiche laſt february proteſtauntes aunſwer heldus emperour ſelf neuer doubted woulde obſerue peace made whiche hath alſo promiſed publique priuate letter imperiall chamber contrary expreſſe wordes compoſition ſealed confirmed emperour hath taken vpon heare determine call diuerſe alteration religion rite ceremony churche goodes whiche thyng playnly exempted pacification concluded iudges imperiall chamber alſo contrary religion bounden othe geue ſentence well preſcript byſhop rome lawe emperours doe lyttle regarde compoſitiō peace procede directly againſt wherfore haue iuſt cauſe refuſe theyr iudgement deſire reformation diuerſe conſiderations whiche alſo mentioned firſt iudges imperiall chamber moſte parte cōtrary religion bounde othe iudge decree byſhop rome wel lawes empire thei beare fauour aduerſaries manifeſtly frowne vpon v fellowes medle mere matter religion contrary emperours proclamation finally haue condēpued cōfederatours hamborough matter religiō great ſomme gold ſo would procede againſt others caſe refuſed touching name come league ſynce peace making long ſynce wrytten ſent emperour italy ambaſſadours ſeing tyme counſell ſo longe differred ioyned ſelues league thē iudgyng mete preferre conſcience ciuile bonde laſt hedeſyreth knowe fourme maner league thei maruell requyre conſidering emperour knoweth well inough made meanes interceſſours norinberg ſhould haue left made hym ſuche aunſwere moued herein howe aduerſaries haue geuen occaſion hereof miſchiefe haue deuyſed againſt thē right well knowen league ordeined iniurie man defende ſelues framed ſuche condicions nede require may declared emperour man el without ſhame concerning ſuche thynges ſpake counſell emperours mynde towardes common wealth lyke well howe beleue alſo emperour knoweth byſhoppes minde herein therfore procureth counſell ſo erneſtly opinion emperour hath biſhop thei wil leaue vndiſcuſſed neuertheleſſe much wrytte cōtrary emperours minde altogether ſuſpicious diſſemble thinke thereof counſell begyune hath condempned doctrine word dede alſo alſo wel knowen aſſemblies religion treated albeit thei ſee scripture maketh againſt yet wyl preſume take vpon authoritie determination although mynded lawefull counſel accuſe byſhop complices falſe doctrine hereſy pope errours impietie yet doubte accuſtomed maner partie iudge alſo entent wrytte ſelfe witteneſſeth whiche ſhould one allowe vain late afterward talke condition fourme diſputation counſell whether ſuche counſell emperour ſtates empyre haue diuerſe aſſemblies agreed vpon leaue opinion indifferent iudge euermore thoſe wordes free chriſtian counſell wyſelye pourpoſely added ſame deede ſo taken ſhould lawfull euery man ſpeake minde alſo neyther biſhop adherentes depely bound fidelitie promyſe one ſhould pronounce ſentence owne cauſes ought ſo interpreted though place counſell turkes ſuche others accordinge vnto holy scripture partes doctrine might examined determined know moreouer one countrey euery alſo pope vnreaſonable authoritie whole worlde godly learned men diſperſed whiche thinge refreſheth ſpirites thinke vpon conſiderynge hopyng caſe vnreaſonable power byſhop rome might diminiſhed thinges ſhoulde depende vpon one man cōmaundement would come paſſe diuines alſo diuers good men ſondry countreis whiche oppreſſed tyrannie hyde thē coruers ſayde nothyng would applie whole ſtudy endeuour refourmation churche concerning place counſell knowe ſhould better choſen germany albeit counſell doth alſo appertayne nation yet chiefly concerneth germaines whiche muſt come thether ſelues miniſters church kynges prynces may thing deputes olde wōted maner long tyme accuſtomed furthermore ſituation cō moditie mātua wyl diſpute warre italy caſe none yet haue lately declared place ought ſuſpected duke mā tua ſelfe affected wyll reaſon owne brother one chiefeſt cardinalles whiche maketh muche encreaſe ſuſpition therefore nation ſhall heare one reaſons wherfore doe refuſe place fourme pleadyng doubte wyll allowe ſame ſhould dede conceaue wronge opinion emperour place coūſel knoweth alſo germany many city commodious pourpoſe mantua whiche ought chiefly reſpected muche commended equitie iuſtice thoſe ſecret priuie conſpiracies diſpatche men waye ſo well knowen practiſed germany ſome place thei cleaue ſticke wyſe decree empyre wyll permitte ſelues remoued ſame ought ſeme maruell newes emperour alſo tymes paſt liberius biſhop rome frende fawtour athanaſius required emperour conſtantine call counſell alexandria defendant plaintiues dwelled albeit ſame place nothing commodious weſt churche although emperour alledged athanaſius fellowes conſent whole worlde condempned excō municated albeit contended liberius one man emōges athanaſius arrius liberius others ſought diſturbe publique quiet yet neuertheleſſe relent nothyng whan emperour denied ſame long time errour arrius reigned fine doctrine athanaſius vpper hande preuayled euer able recite bloud ſpilte quarell doctrine condition religion like vnto ſame whether aconuenient place geuen otherwyſe lyke cauſe alſo ſuche counſell baſill refuſed ferrare eugenius byſhop ſummoned counſell emperour henry ſeuenth great ſute cōtrouerſie robert kyng sicilie cited hym appere piſa ſame thought vnreaſonable byſhop clement firſte whiche bothe defended kyng alſo ſhewed reaſons wherfore boſide come thether nothynge ſo weighty theſe therfore wher refuſe ſuche maner counſel faulte ought imputed vnto byſhop ſo ofte haue referred matter counſell ment ſuche counſell emperour ſtates empyre decreed ignorant caſe byſhoppes might permitted haue whole orderyng matter would worke owne auauntage oppreſſing true doctrine woulde eſtablyſhe theyr owne wyckednes yet doth paul thyrde ſo collour matter wordes emperour though woulde vſe thynge vpryghtly ſincerely intendeth contrary moreouer counſell requyred thei haue declared writing craft paule peter paule uerger ambaſſadour clement alſo paule thyrde ſayth emperours mynde errours vice might reformed none apparence therof byſhops wryting caſe intended true nedefull reformation would haue cōdempned theyr doctrine heard albeit diſtruſte emperours equitie ſo muche ſory gratifie hym herein yet nothing furthered good wyl diligence albeit emperour ſelfe preſent counſell yet well enough knowen authoritie biſhoppes wyll permitte eyther hym kynges alſo haue ſuche maner caſes moſte wyll graunte ſhalbe perauenture vſe counſell matter determine wyll pope haue emperours ſubſectiō permitte reſerue authoritie themſelues entent caſe emperour ciuile magiſtrates went ſome thynge farre myght hereby bridel hamper fine determine al thinges pleaſure deſire therfore emperour would offeded ſeke eſchew theſe ſnares biſhop wold intrappe geuē naturally euen vnto brute beaſtes ſhunne place knowe layde wayte taken furthermore commonly knowen howe matter handled counſell conſtance emperour sigiſinūde albeit counſel cōſtaſice graunted ſaufeconduicte iohn huſſe yet byſhops deminiſhe authoritie ſaying howe lawfull neyther iohn huſſ • man el preſcribe meaſure behalf wherwith emperour vāquiſhed gaue place authoritie whiche chalenged ſelues ſighinge opinion yet miſerable deſtruction hym truſtinge vppon ſaufe conduicte fell calamitie wherby appereth euidently muche emperour able helpe thē herein though wold neuer ſo fayne haue one intrapped encloſed thē pinnefolde therfore muſt worke circūſpectly yet leſt thyng ſhould imputed ready abyde lawfull iudgement alſo moſte earneſtly beſeche emperour waye pounder theſe ſo weightie matter diligently call lawfull counſell germany wherin neither byſhop conſortes ſhall occupie place iudgemēt byſhop wyl let impeche emperour ſo ſhal permitte ſincere counſel holden germany proteſte opē ly faulte matter brought cō corde incommoditie alſo ſhall ariſe therof ſame wholy aſcribed byſhop concluſion requeſte hym make ſame reporte vnto emperour declare good wylles dutie wardes hym whan matter thus decided amonges heldus promyſed make relation emperour thynges proteſtauntes decree alſo howe mainteyne proteſtaun • e decre mainteining miniſters miniſters church lyuing erecting free ſcholes church common wealth might neuer want learned men laſt ſuche thynges concerne league defence concerning turke aunſwered ambaſſadour might haue quietues matter would glad wyllynge ayde emperour againſt hym nowe brute went howe kyng ferdinādo prepared warre againſt john uayuode therfore requyred ayde whiche perplexitie leſt haply ſhould theyr dutie common wealthe decreed abſence heldus duke saxon lantgraue ſendynge abroade eſpialles common charge ſhould get intelligence thynges brewyng turke entended inuade germany ſhould aſſemble agayne conſulte eche man dutie herein moreouer entent men myght vnderſtand iuſt reaſon proteſt refuſe counſel cauſe refuſe counſell condeſcended compryſe whole matter wryting whiche wardes ſet forth print ſpeaking foreine kynges nation paule thyrde ſaye thei hath ſent forth bulles late ſommō counſel mantua begynne nowe xxiij daye may alledgyng certen cauſes therof moreouer hath ſente ambaſſadours kynges prynces well germanes others aduertyſe counſell exhorte eyther come thither thē ſelues ſend protectours moued v alſo ambaſſadour vnto ſo emperour lyke maner thynge ſelfe requireth ſhould therfore declare peryll loſſe v alſo whole common wealth chriſtendome men ſhould obeye hym herein notwithſtandyng cauſe determination iuſt reaſonable yet doubte aduerſaries ſuche nature wyll blame doyng conſtrewe worſte parte entent may bryng v cauſe hatred wyll affyrme doubtleſſe abyde examination iudgement deſpyſe al nation amonges whome haue often bene many excellent learned men wyll ſaye moreouer wickednes refuſe decree counſell hyghe iudicial ſeate churche whiche men bound obey wyl forge alſo though aſhamed doctrine afraid come light el ſought contentiō nede endure • n vniuerſall quiet nowe myght verefied v dede wicked alſo deteſtable heard wherfore muſt neceſſitie ſhewe reaſon doynge truſte good men whether germany place wyll credit ſuche thynge v wyll alſo doe endeuour moſte weyghty cauſe others may handled vprightly byſhop rome permitted vnder forged coloured name counſell oppreſſe manifeſt truthe kynde tyranny ſhal declare profeſſe pure doctrine alſo reſpecte nothyng el god glory preſeruation common wealth obſtinacie frowardnes obiected vnto v fyrſt proue contemne iudgement nation churche hereby appereth manyfeſtly al care leſt byſhop clientes ſhould take vpon authoritie iudgement thynges myght decided mete ſuſpected perſones whiche thyng truſt godly men would lykewyſe wyſhe dyuerſe countreis remayne certen olde wrytinges complayntes falſe doctrine vice idolatrie crept churche doubte ſame place daye ſome godly learned men alſo whiche vnderſtande ſounde doctrine although oppreſſed byſhoppes tyrannye conſtrayned holde peace theſe dede iuſte deſerte ought counſell ought preſent coūſel myght ſpeake myndes frely accompted free counſell gouerned byſhop fellowes whiche defende falſe doctrine power violence olde cuſtome make decree contrary god worde chriſte tyme inſtituted highe iudiciall ſeate commaunded matter ſhould referred churche requyred reformation whiche ſelfe wordes excludeth tyranny lordſhyp alſo ſclaunder ſaye perhaps feard come abroade abyde opē light aſſemblie imperial auſpurg profeſſed doctrine openly emperoure ſtates empyre againe preacher goſpel haue brought godly workes lyght ſelfe ſame doctrine preached openly dominion learned men haue ſet forth bookes ſame diuerſe aduerſaries confeſſe men wrytinges ſondrye article called agayne lyght whiche laye hidde darkenes nowe true doctrine ſhyneth agayne penaunce faythe chriſte remiſſiō ſynnes good workes true worſhipping vſe sacramētes authoritie keyes magiſtrates tradition men ſuche lyke thinges neither aſhamed goſpell paule ſayth haue eſpeciall deſyre myght declare mynde theſe thinges al men alſo obiected preacher ſhoulde haue falſe yt ſtyre vp 〈◊〉 hereſies reyſed vp agayne hereſies time condempned neither ſhould nede therfore diſputation hearing falſe may eaſlye excuſed haue red confeſſion defence annexed ſame doctrine confeſſe newe verey conſent primatiue churche moſte clerely doth appere neyther haue admitted hereſy wycked opinion men haue reſtored doctrine aunciēt father oppreſſed biſhops monkes vntrue alſo reported v ſhoulde delight diſſention ſory botome harte chriſtē commō wealth thus deuided haue concorde deſyre lawfull counſell muche byſhop fellowes cōdempne true neceſſary doctrine tormente perſecute profeſſers thereof exhorting others ſame miſlike cruel tiranny god wil honored confeſſion name wickednes man ioyne hym ſelfe byſhops tyranny whiche ſo rageth moreouer manifeſt beare ſuſteine maner charge common wealth reſidue ſtates whereby ſeene woulde alſo gladly accorde others relygion byſhoppes ſtyre vp price caſe lawful beſydes vnderſtande daū ger hangeth ouer v ſame byſhoppes haue nowe theſe many yeares declared manifeſtly go incenſe kynges myndes againſt v extreme madnes abide theſe ſo great daūgers ſo great charge iuſt cauſe knowe aſſuredly owe dewtie vnto god nothing ſo much reſpected commaundement take god wytnes ſeke nothing el nowe haue confuted theyr ſklaunders come ſeconde part emonges ſtraungers many parauenture ſuppoſe yt certen curioſitie haue impugned ſome light faultes kepinge quiet mighte better haue bene diſſembled eſpeciallye conſydering ſtate worldly thinges ſuche common wealth euer remaining ſome thinges whiche muſt wincked matter ſtandeth farre otherwiſe fyrſt dede errours falſe opinion may diſſembled chriſt commaundeth v beware falſe teacher againe falſe doctrine borne controuerſie light errours touching doctrine faith true knowledge god principall pointe chriſtian life ſincere worſhipping god ought paſſed ouer ſilence obſerued purely diligentlye taught churche denied doctrine wholy extinguiſhed newe brought greate contuinelie chriſt moreouer reprehende diuerſe ſundrye errours wickednes others alſo haue eſpied longe day therfore deſyred counſell wrong beyng redreſſed concorde might reteined time counſell muche nedefull muche ſame errours vice remaine ſundry place ſtrife contention arriſen many therefore daunger lyues innocent perſons theſe therfore ſo weightie conſiderations onely themperour alſo innocentes perill reſidew ſtates biſhoppes haue determined acounſell chiefly neceſſary church wherin pure doctrine might mainteined vnleſſe ſuche ſort ſawe right well howe would ſtyre vp greater confuſion behold whileſt loke ſuch counſell biſhops buls come forth quite contrary decree thempyre becauſe doth cōcerne v alſo whole commen wealth chriſtendom haue thought nedefull publike writyng teſtifie declare wherefore diſcommende counſell power authoritie iudgement belongeth onely vnto biſhoppes vnto churche numbre verely kinges ſtates wherfore al tha • thoritie iudgement churche beit biſhoppe rome nothing accuſed yet graunted alone ſhould iudges excludyng miniſters churche ſeyng manifeſtly partie one ſuters much leſſe ought permitted becauſe againſt god lawe alſo lawe nature accuſe biſhop rome ſmale crime neyther diſpute onely vſurped authoritie abhominable liuinge reprehende doctrine lawes wicked religion accuſe giltie idolatrie hereſie whiche crime pope accuſed idolatry hereſye beyng obiected biſhoppe ought churche geue iudgement olde lawes biſhoppes ſelues teſtifie furthermore biſhoppe one party becauſe hath condemned oure doctrine longe hathe heaped vpon ſelfe greater ſuſpition ſeyng thus doubte iudgement ſhalbe counſell concernynge doctrine thought contrary olde cuſtome permit man haue determination matter wheras writynge ſpeaketh nothyng maner treatie counſell haue iuſt cauſe ſuſpecte thynges calleth onely thither bounden vnto like lippes like lettuſe diuerſe wayes whoſe good willes aſſured proteſteth alſo cauſe calling counſel hereſies ſprong vp late might weded albeit ſame may taken largely yet doubt meaneth doctrine credible yt ſpeaketh errours yea ſent forth writynge touchinge reformation courte rome wherein expreſſe wordes confeſſeth counſell called intent peſtiferous hereſie luther might aboliſhed ſo dede fyrſt couered mynde craſtely writte myght haue ſome ſhewe diſcloſed afterwarde wherfore doubte fullye bente roote oute craft pope doctrine madnes v allow intention goeth ſuche receiue writyng ſhoulde confeſſe oure doctrine wicked hereticall moreouer kynges prince whiche admitte ſame ſhoulde bounden aide aſiſte therfore ſeing thing concerneth vniuerſal common wealth beſeche men conſider diligentlye thys crafte policie marueiled whie conceaued writynge ſuche wordes doubt whether intent feare v counſel approuing writte haue v intrapped amonges v aſſuredly doubt themperours mynde common wealth neyther thinke allowe forme writte byſhoppe hathe onely appoynted counſell hathe alſo pronounced ſentence againſt v permitte matter may tried scripture aledge lawes cuſtome certen counſelles latter time proue matter chiefly hold affirme ye men tradition contrary god worde oughte reiected admit doctrine church byſhops error tyrannie ought coloured wt title church tholde church neyther receiued law cōtrarie scripture attributed ye vnmeaſurable power biſhop rome taketh vpon ſelfe againe y• ſorte men condemne perſecute doctrine goſpell church paricides generatiō ofſpring cam old time dede godly biſhops dyd oftentimes refuſe coūſels ſeing thoſſpring c 〈…〉 ſame called defende veritie either main tenaūce ſome wicked opinon el eſtabliſhe ſome mē authoritie themperor cōſtantine aſſigned counſel antioche maximus biſhop hieruſalem albeit farre came thither becauſe knewe themperors minde arrians intended although athanaſius came coūſell tyrus yet taried long yt ſaw chiefeſt coūſel plaie part accuſers iudges yt ſaw certen accuſers procured againſt holdē great counſel sirmiū town hungry againſt photynus matter weightie albe themperour cōmaunded biſhops come thither yet wold weſt partes obey ſawe numbre arrians encreaſed ſuſpected yt ſome falſe opinion ſhoulde decreed time oſius biſhop corduba famous man themperor requeſt arrians commaunded alſo come thither spaine come approued yt perilous counſell sirmie brought afterwardes great conſuſiō church cauſe oſius ſore reproued hilarie whiche came cyrillus biſhop hieruſalē neuer came aſſemblies denied chriſt ſame ſubſtannce wt father accompted fyrſt euer appealed counſell writyng counſell kepte millan biſhoppes called thither emperour time paulinus biſhoppe treuers fewe others ſawe howe anxentius byſhoppe millan mate went euill purpoſe departed counſell mill 〈…〉 broken brake vp counſell ſort thoſe worthy men flie ſuſpected counſelles leſt ſhould made partaker crime aſmuche biſhop ſignifieth plainly counſell inſtituted confirme authoritie beſech al men wold impute refuſal v fault blame worthy finally place counſell like diuerſe cauſes fitte offer iniurie altogether ſuch ſhould let libertie ſpeche beſydes muche hatred conceaued againſte v foreine nation ſclaunders aduerſaries though religion honeſt liuing exiled among v perſwaſion mennes mindes thus prepared without great perill wherfore expedient cauſe onely counſell ſhould holden germany entent ſtraungers might ſee order maner oure church city throughe falſe ſclaūders hate trew doctrine weightines cauſe alſo requireth yt many v ſhould come coūſell oure ſelues forſake limites maner way v expedient ſeyng yt moſt weightie cauſes decreed yt counſel ſhould holden germany ſe wherfore ſhould depart frō ſame conſidering therfore yt caſe cōcerneth preſeruation al chriſtendome beſeche al kinges prince geue credit vnto oure aduerſaries herunto rather applie thē ſelues yt trew knowledge god might reſtored cādo nothing yt ſhal redound theyr honor biſhop laboreth ende yt mighte perſwade thē practiſe crueltie thei ought moſte chiefly abhorre euē cauſe placed degre dignitie yt ſhold honor god holy name light vnto reſt good enſample defende innocēt perſons frō wrōg violēce ſhal euer time lawfull counſell thā ſhal ſo defende matter yt men ſhall vnderſtande endeuours haue bene euer annexed preſeruation common wealth aſſemblie theſe duke saxon erneſtus fraūces bretherne duke luneburge ulriche duke wirtemberge lantzgraue philip prince pomerane three erles anhalde albert counte manſfelde beſides many ambaſſadors city moſt large ample cōmiſſion admoniſhed thinges ſhould treated departed thence vj day march addreſſe letter french king wherin firſt excuſed matter poteſt letter frēch king ſatiſfied ambaſſadoure former aſſemblie ſhewe cauſe alſo whie ſende ambaſſadours nowe vnto thā deſyre continew frendſhippe ſeynge haue ſet open way come concorde religion yet haue nothing preuailed would recompence theirendeuor fauor beneuolence fynally declare mynde touchyng counſell deſyre knowe hathe alſo determined herein kinge afterwardes maketh aunſwere tenth kalendes iune accepteth theyr ſatiſfaction promiſeth largely concernynge hys continuall amitie towardes confutyng ſclaunders aduerſaries wrytynge whiche ſent ſaieth opinion counſell euer hath bene vnleſſe lawefull ſure place wyll neuer allowe ſame neyther doubteth kynge scotlande ſome inlawe alſo folowe mynde herin lytle beginning maye retorned home wyfe aboute midſomer ended life queene scottes dieth meane time biſhoppe rome deferreth counſell till kalendes nouember cauſe thereof ſaieth friderick duke mantua mindeth fortifie citie garniſons ſouldiours employe coſt therupon thinge hath happened contrary expectation ſaith ſore affraid leſt many folowyng decree already commen mantua happely beyng excluded dryuen retourne home againe chaunce dede ſory yet taketh matter leſſe greifefully foraſmuche thinge hath fortuned throughe another man faulte longe king englande owne name king england ſuſeth counſell noble realme publiſheth writing counſell called biſhoppe rome hath none authoritie called ſuche time whan mortall warre betwene themperour frenche kynge place appointed mantua whither neyther ſaufe commodious men come dede deſyreth chriſtian counſell wyth harte vnto byſhoppes counſell wyll nether come ſelfe yet ſende hys ambaſſadours alwayes theyr facion theyr l • cre ſake wyll ſuche maner aſſemblies oppreſſe chriſt veritie parte haue nothynge biſhoppe rome regardeth decree wrytynge anye byſhoppe addynge counſelles wont called authoritie emperour kynges maner ought reſtored eſpecially tyme whan byſhoppe hath ſo many graue perſonages accuſe yet neuertheleſſe neither reprehended without daunger man life accuſed preſently lawfull counſel nether prouiſion made ſaufconduicte thoughe yet manifeſt daungers ſhoulde let hym coulde come newes biſhoppes falſefie theyr faith ſprincle deſile ſelues innocent bloude albeit ſhould lawfull others repaire thither yet ſaftie whome biſhop hath laide waite whō hateth deadly ſeketh bring hatred kinges none cauſe aſſuredly tyrranny exiled realme yerely reuenewes taken away thinge dede taketh moſt euill part ſo much worſe feareth leſt kinges warned throughe example hereafter like nowe alſo counſell proroged vntyll kalendes nouē bre yet place appointed ſhould holdē faulte imputed duke mantua delude whole worlde duke mantua ſurely blameles wyll receiue ſo great multitude citie vnfurnyſhed garriſon blame aſcribed alone doeth nothing ſyncerely worketh al thinges craft colluſion caſe ſhall aſſigne place purpoſe wyll eyther appointe ſome citie owne ſome prince yt bound hath ſelf ryght ample large dominion ſame many goodly city predeceſſours haue gotten force ſubtiltie ſmall fidelitie kepeth ſeing hope haue true coūſel men witte iudgemēt ſuppoſe thinketh beſt euery magiſtrate dominion ſeke reformation religion perchaunce biſhop ſhould obiecte vnto cuſtome ſame taketh place euen teſtimonie cypriane cuſtome grounded vpon counſell hath ſayde man haue way better proper ſaying cipriane wil refuſe emperour remained al yere spaine armie flaunders conduict counte de bure wan aſſaulte towne caſtel sanpulle artois moneth ianuary put al ſworde thence went beſeged citie terowen yet vayne length truce taken ten monethes thoſe party piedmōte hote warre neuertheleſſe town cherie taken terowē beſeged invain aſſaulte imperialles made wonderfull ſlaughter ſouldiours citezens whan garriſon turrin ſuffered great penury euery ſyde beſeged ſtopped virtualles frenche kyng harueſt tyme leuied power ſente thether eldeſt ſonne henry daulphin mommorācie making waye entring perforce releued preſent famine moneth october armie kyng ferdinando wherin horſemen saxony meiſſen franckonie auſtriche carinthians bohemers hongarians whome germaines cal huſſares beſeged towne exechium vpon ryuer draue whiche kept ſtrong garryſon turkes ferdinando armie deſtroyed tracted tyme conſtrayned wante victualles leuie ſiege retire fel lappes ennemies layd ambuſches woodes kept ſtraytes could way eſcape diſtreſſe firſte certen centurion captaynes ſouldiours hongarians fled alſo went cacianer kinges lieutenaunt reſte deteſted ſhame running away exhorting ſelues vnto manhode eſpecially horſemen almaigne aboade charge violent force ennemies fine vāquiſhed greater numbre moſte parte ſlayne manye captaynes taken priſoners led conſtantinople moſte miſerable captiuitie fourth ides octobre kyng englande birth kīg edward ſixt ſonne borne hamptoncourt prince edwarde quene iane semer whome maried death quene anne meane whyle byſhop rome ſo muche truce taken twyxt fraunce flaunders went procure like alſo al place entent occaſiō might worke purpoſe ceaſed tyll brought paſſe biſhops deuiſe reported ſetting peace myght ſtire pope hateth kyng vp againſt kyng england hated vnto death againſt lutherians tyme alſo chriſtina emperours nece ſyſter quene denmarke ducheſſe millan leauing italy retourneth flaunders germanye treaty mariage betwene william duke cleaue toke effect alſo men gelderland began rebellion gelderland rebelle againſt prince charles egmonde whiche al lyfe tyme frenche parte therfore ſore hated burgundians ſayd went make country frē che ſo chaſed owne people euery outragious tumulte ſcarſly towne two lefte hym flye alwayes great mainteiner biſhop rome doctrine pope paule euil reported abſtained ſore puniſhment paule third firſt beginning byſhoprike made two yonge nephewes cardinalles wrytten whiche thing euyll reported vouched ſaufe call worthy men alſo nobilitie learning ſame degre honour partly aſſwage enuie diſpleaſure partely haue mete champion whiche able defende hym learnyng eloquence amonges whome caſpar contarene reginalde poole iohn bellie frederick fregoſe vnto within ſhorte ſpace added moreouer sadolete alexander bembus purpoſed alſo eraſinus pope entended make eraſmus cardinall certen epiſtle frend eraſinus himſelfe reporteth remayne alſo certen epiſtles written sadolet eraſinus wherin hath ſpoken muche great good wyl byſhop towardes hym ſayth within ſhorte tyme wyl auaunce hyghe dignitie contarenus noble man senatour ueniſe learnyng ryght famous beyonde expectation whan craued nothynge ſodaynly promoted dignitie ✚ twelfth booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charles fyſte ❧ argument twelfth booke pope paule deputes ordeyned reformation touching abuſes churche permutation voiſomes benefice incompatibles cardinalles courtier chaplelaynes courtiſanes pardoner colloquy eraſmus prohibited proteſtauntes mete brunſwycke whether came king denmarke perſecution aryſeth pan pope emperour frenche kyng mete nice kynge kiſſed foote colledge frenche churche erected straſborough kyng englande burneth bone thomas becket prince efectour brandenburgh aduertiſeth duke saxon preparation great turke ſecte antmomians aryſeth conſpiratie heldus duke brunſwycke diſcouered takyng secretary aſſembly holden franckeforte decree made appointment mode conference peace proteſtauntes whiche let duke henry brunſwicke leui • th armie george duke saxon ennemy veritie dieth henry brother ſuccedeth hym kyng englande hauyng ſet forth booke againſt counſell uicence callſeth certen article made concerning religion gaunt rebell emperour hauing ſaufeconduicte paſſeth fraunce uenetians make peace turke certen senatours diſcloſed ſecretes haue ſhewed counſels wer deferred til kalendes nouēb ſame alſo made fruſtrate notwithſtandyng biſhoppe intent myght feed men hope ſeme ſome thinge longe choſen certen owne ſect amōges whole numbre ſtreightly commaū ded ſhoulde eſpie oute diligently faultes clergie flatterie ſet apart declare vnto releaſed alſo othe yt myghte ſpeake mindes franckly commaunded kepe thinge cloſe ſecret choſen caſpar contarene peter theatrire iames sadolete renalde poole cardinal fridericke archebiſhop salerne hierome aleander archbiſhop brunduſe iohn mathew biſhoppe uerone gregorie uenet abbot thomas maiſter ſacred palace theſe concluſion conſultation comprehended hole matter writing addreſſinge theyr ſtile vnto extolle great praiſes zeale hath trueth wherunto eares certen biſhoppes time paſt haue bene ſtopped chiefly faulte flatterer whiche haue aſcribed vnto ouer muche authoritie tyme haue affirmed clearely lordes althinges haue power liſte welſpring horſe troy haue ſpronge churche ſo many euils wherwith moſt greuouſly afflicted therfore wiſedome vertu great conſidereth remedie muſt fetched thence whence beginning cauſe diſeaſe proceded followyng doctrine paule wilbe miniſter ſteward lorde aſmuche hath committed charge vnto willyng obey herin haue accordyng theyr meane wittes drawen certen article whiche concerne him▪ biſhoppes churche ſuſteineth pope hath double office double perſon onely biſhop vniuerſall chriſtian churche alſo prince many region city onely touche ſuche thinges concerne eccleſiaſticall adminiſtratiō ciuile commen weale gouerneth muche commēdatiō wiſedom fyrſt al ſay moſt holy father like caſe ariſtotle commaundeth lawes raſhly altered ſo ſemeth vnto v alſo theccleſiaſticall lawes caſe diligently maynteyned infringed without ſome vrgent cauſe greater plage inuade commenwealth time thauthoritie lawes weakened diſolued whiche oure predeceſſours would haue kept ſacred holy next pointe biſhop rome chriſtes uicar whan authoritie hathe chriſte geueth graunteth anye thinge take money rewarde ſame ſeynge theſe thinges giuen freely chriſt alſo ſame freely diſtributed others foū dation laide muſt foreſene may haue manye mete miniſters churche gouerne men ſaluation numbre biſhoppes occupie chiefe place herein great abuſe kinde men receiued ordre confuſely without reſpect neither commended learninge honeſt lyuing diuerſe alſo yong wherof arriſe ſundry offence wherof 〈◊〉 meth cō tempt clergie holy thinges come contempt growe oute reuerence ſemeth good vnto v therfore firſt citie rome appoint certen make choiſe ſuche deſyre take order commaunde biſhops like euery mā within owne dioceſe ſuffer none admitted without conſent ſaid commiſſioners biſhoppe let youth alſo purpoſe made priſtes haue scholemaſter appointed bring vp learnyng vertuouſe maners moreouer geuing benefice ſpirituall promotion farre miſſe ſuche eſpecially concerne cure charge ſoules haue reſpect lie beneficed man may well prouided laying apart care flocke therfore whan ſuche office geuen chiefely biſhopricke muſt diligently forſene good men ought made biſhoppes learned gouerne church themſelues bounden law therfore may italian enioy benefice spayne englande spaniarde engliſhman italy furthermore much fraude vſed tyme man leaueth benefice reſygneth another reſeruing ſelf yerly penſion many time alſo whole profytes penſion maye reteined vnleſſe pore ſome godly vſe becauſe fruit annexed benefice ought ſequeſtred bodye ſoule hathe ſame bounden vſe commodity therof honeſtly ſo much ſuffiſeth reſidew employ vpon ſuche vſes beforeſayd notwithſtandyng ſhalbe lawfull biſhoppe caſe ſo require impoſe bondage ſhall pay certen thing yerely ſome pore man eſpecially beyng clergie wherby may liue honeſtly better eaſe againe offende exceadingly permutatiōs thinges done lucre albeit lawefull gyue unlawefull geue benefice legacye benefice legacie yet ſubtill way founde wyttie men defeate law benefyces giuen another yet ſo haue theyr reentrie agayne fame whole profytes miniſtration thus commeth paſſe beareth name biſhoppe hath right authoritie whiche indede poſſeſſion biſhop hath name thing el make ſelfe heyre biſhoppe clementrenewed olde lawe wherby forbydden ſonne ſhoulde priſtes ſon may inioy father benefice enioy father benefice yet permitted truly euill example denied greateſt part ſclaunders arryſe churche good conuerted priuate vſes hitherto many haue loked redreſſe thynge nowe vtter diſpayre ſpeake thinke full euill v therefore euill vſe geue vouſons benefice reuertion man death wiſhed looked others better deſerue haue ſecluded matter miniſtered muche ſtrife contention ſhall ſaye thoſe benefice whiche becauſe coulde employed vpon one man alone called commonly incompatibles herin tholde diſcipline neglected ſome one alſo permitted haue diuerſe biſhoprikes ſemeth vnto v worthy reformation herunto belongeth theſe plurality totquotes vnitynge benefice whan many benefice ioyned together partes membres one body delude lawes finally nowe diſeaſe crept alſo biſhoprickes giuen vnto cardinalles many vnto one whiche thynge ſemeth vnto v dede matter importaunce chiefly refourmed office cardinal biſhoppes diſtinct diuerſe agree one perſon cardinalles ordeined thys cauſe onely ſhould remayne moſt holy father neuer departe ſyde ſhould gouerne vniuerſall churche together vnto biſhoppes belongeth fede theyr flocke committed cardinal fyrſt made god dede done vnleſſe preſent ſee shepardes shepe moreouer thynge ſelfe doeth harme example face audacitie ſhall redreſſe faultes others moſt apparent beſt ſene fellowſhyppe • arice concupiſcēce let counſels may thinke becauſe placed dignitie may therfore take libertie let vnderſtande oughte rather vſe temperauncie becauſe ought ſhine others life maners neyther muſt folow phariſeis whiche made lawes themſelues kept chriſt floriſhed word worke libertie alſo great let good counſels whan minde poſſeſſed luſt auarice beſydes diuerſe cardinal frequent courtes kynges obteyne biſhoprikes cauſe ſo addicte vnto dare vtter nothynge frankely woulde god waye inhibited cardinal otherwiſe prouided might honeſtly fynde ſelues theyr family equalitie obſerued herin yerely reuenewes egall thinge ſemeth vnto v harde broughte paſſe could forſaking couetouſnes folowe foteſteppes chriſt whan theſe faultes redreſſed mete miniſters churche appointed chiefly loked biſhoppes inhabite amonges theyr owne people huſbandes church heuie ſorowefull ſighte ſhewed euerye ſe congregation forſaken flockes deſtitute paſtors deteyned handes hirelinges therfore oughte extremely puniſſhed whiche leade flockes deſerte excommunicated outlawed onely alſo loſe theyr liuinges euer vnleſſe craue pardon within ſhort tyme auncient lawes decreed biſhoppe might aboue three wekes abſent congregation ſe alſo many cardinal abſent rome nothynge properlye belongeth office graunt expedient certeine reſident theyr owne prouinces certein braū ches rote tree ſtretched farre wide chriſtiane worlde men kept theyr dewtie dewe obeidience common wealth yet requiſite moſt parte called againe rome ſo ſhoulde bothe execute theyr office alſo theyr preſence ſhoulde bothe honourable profitable courte rome moreouer punyſhynge crime vice wanteth greate ſeueritie diſcipline ſuche haue offended deſerued puniſhment fynde meane wherby conuey themſelues iuriſdiction biſhoppe iudge ordinary caſe cannot go maſter pentionaries fyne pece money chiefly clergie thing doeth offende many wherfore beſeche bloud chriſt wherewith redemed waſhed ſanctified churche licentious libertie may vtterly aboliſhed ſeyng common wealth maye longe endure wherein ſynne vnpuniſhed howe muche ought ſame looked churche emonges monckes alſo many filthy actes monkes many abhominable actes committed wherefore thinke good colledges couentes diſſolued ſodēly violence ſo mā henceforth admitted order ſo ſhall litle litle decay afterwardes may honeſter men placed theyr houſes neuertheleſſe thinke mete yong nouices haue yet profeſſed religion vow ſolempnely made preſently remoued thence muſte alſo diligent hede taken mete perſons ſet confeſſion herin ought biſhoppe haue vigilante eye chiefly nothinge done money ſame free gyfte ſpake concerneth onelye others like maner moreouer houſes nunnes ſacred uirgins namely▪ gouerned monkes many open crime committed moſt filthy deteſtable example therfore muſt ouerſight ſuche takē monkes cōmitted vnto others perill ſuſpicion wheras many place chiefly italie certen wicked opinion diſputed onely vniuerſities alſo church deſerueth muche diſpraiſe therfore biſhoppes muſte charged ſuche place wheras vniuerſities scholes admoniſh teacher propounde ſuche thynge herafter inſtructe bringe vp youth vertue feare god haue open diſputations matter diuinitie within theyr priuate houſes likewiſe muſte prince magiſtrates admoniſhed giue commaundement printer ſet forthe ſortes bokes ſuche onely permitted commonly read al ſcooles boke colloquy compiled eraſmus roterdā wherin many thynges whiche may beate younge tender myndes vngodlynes infecte frayle bryckel age therfore ſuche lyke bookes muſt bannyſhed scooles permitted monkes haue profeſſed religion cowle maketh monke vowe put theyr owne wede putte apparell thinke well done garment badge monaſticall vowe therfore one forſake theyr cootes let depriued theyr lyuinges eccleſiaſticall function alſo ſuche cary relyques ſaincte anthony lyke iudgementes worthy vtterly abolyſhed innumerable ſuperſtitions brynge ignoraunt people erroure playnly abuſe oftentymes alſo • e permytted marrye whiche haue taken holy order ought graunted man vrgent cauſes whan whole ſtocke defence realme brought one man becauſe lutherians permitte men marry without reſpecte therfore muſt ſtifly reſyſte ſame nother may ſuffered mary together ſeconde degree bloud affinitie vnleſſe vpon moſte weyghtie conſiderations ſuche maye haue lybertie graunted done without money excepte perauenture haue fyrſt carnall copulation lawfull punyſhe purſe money employed immediatly good vſes vyce simonie whiche hath name simony reigneth churche simon magus reigneth ſo churche nowe adayes men nothynge aſhamed offende herein moſte boldely ſeke aſſoyled geuyng money benefice thus wyckedly gotten enioye withſtanding doe denye youre holynes may pardon theyr offence touchynge punyſhement haue deſerued occaſion tranſgreſſynge may taken awaye thynke nede deale ſtrayghtly remitte punyſhement ſhamefull deteſtable thyng bieng ſellyng muſt prouiſo clergie geue away legacie part churche goodes without great cauſes leſt hinderaūce poore ſome ſhal haue aboundaunce ſpende riot voluptuouſnes alſo licence graunted euery man chouſe chaplaine lyſte haue maſſe priuate houſes whiche ought raſhlye graunted leſt ſecrete thinges ſhould come contempt eſpecially chiefeſt ſacrament iudulgences pardōs ought geuen ſo commonly one yeare great city uowes may lightly chaunged conuerted worke vnleſſe correſpondent vowe sometyme laſt wyl teſtatours wont chaunged whiche happely bequethed ſome portion money godly vſes chaunceth cōmonly reaſon pouertie heires wylmakers muſt hede takē vnleſſe teſtatour fall pouertie ſo wil well perfourmed ſuffered wickednes el alter deades wyll nowe haue declared mindes thīges cōcerning vniuerſal churche ſhal adde ſame fewe caſes whiche properly belong byſhop rome citie churche rome mother maiſtres church comlye decent harlottes honoured rome ſhould excelle others religion honeſtie life churche peter haunte many vnlearned filthie prieſtes appareled ſo vile garmentes owne churche alſo vndecēt like worne priuate houſes poreſt ſorte theſe garmentes ſay maſſe great offence lokers therfore muſt archedeacon cōmiſſarie cōmaū ded firſt citie alſo place ſuche filthines auoyded men ſight ſhall ſaye vnchaſte woman ſtrompetes whiche apparell kynde ornamentes differ nothing citie frō matrones honour rydyng vpon mule middes citie euen none dayes accompanied familiar frendes ſeruaūtes chiefeſt cardinalles ſuche like certenly haue ſene ſuche intemperancie diſſolute liuing vſed ani citie ought dede ſpectacle enſample whole vniuerſall world theſe courtiſanes alſo maynteyned inhabit gorgeous houſes doubteles great ſhame alſo citie great contention faction parte amende theſe thinges ſhalbe requiſite yt oppointe certen cardinalles mete purpoſe appeaſe ſtrife reconcile myndes citezens laſt prouiſion wydowes pore people properly apperteineth charge theſe thinges moſte holy father whiche haue thought mete refourmed albeit vnmete charge yet haue done laye v vttered cōſcience vprightly entred great hope yt vnder gouernment ſhal ſee church pure cleane quiet perpetuall immortall glory name haue takē name paule wherfore truſt come paſſe example embrace churche certen earneſt ſeruent zeale god choſe paule ſingular inſtrument preache goſpell gentyles ſo truſte alſo choſen cal light name chriſt gētyles defaced remedy publique diſeaſes reduce flock chriſte one ſhepefolde tourne away god wrath hāgeth ouer v dewe offēces reformation deede conceaued woordes neuer brou • ght effecte publiſhed finally byſhop delayeth coū ſell beginninge nouembre kalendes may next yeare followyng aſſigneth place uicentia large plentifull citie belongyng ſtate ueniſe ſendeth thither three cardinalles campegius simonet brunduſe whiche preſidentes coūſel ſhould begynne treatie receyue came byſhop would haue matter reformation kept cloſe ſayde longe hydde tyme brought rome germany luther anſwered duche tongue iohn sturmius latine framynge theyr ſtyle commiſſioners 1538 reformation luther booke ſette picture whiche playnely declared argument byſhop placed hyghe ſeate certen cardinalles ſtanding whiche fox tayles tied ſtaues lyke beſomes ſweepe thinges vpſyde downe amōges theſe cardinalles nicholas archebyſhop capua coulde abyde reformation beinge ſente biſhop paule crediblie reported contended ſore cardi▪ capua cā abide reformation nothynge ſhould redreſſed amonges thinges ſayde howe lutherianes would make boaſt wer driuē thē ſo doe maner compulſion wherupon byſhop cardinalles cōtenthed perſwaded alter thing yet ſelfe ſo letted reported haue ſent booke priuely certen frende germany whiche manye men take ſo though would haue byſhop ſayde commiſſioners lawghed ſcorne labour others thynke biſhop made priuie booke reformation ſetting forth ſame might appeare hym ſome wyll amendement thynges yet vnderſtande meane though hym ſelfe would haue done greater thinges caſe entended haue publyſhed ſuche like matter touchynge colloquy eraſmus thus ſtandeth amonges manye workes wherby eraſmus wonderfully auaunced learning made colloquie eraſmus alſo booke dialogue chyldren ſeyng red ſo gredely ofte augmented ſame man excellent witte great eloquence toke pleaſure wryte ſondry argumentes taken naturall thynges lyfe men certen maruelous dexteritie ſtyle moſte pleaſaunt ſetteth forth precpres godlye vertuouſe maners noteth ſame occaſion olde accuſtomed errours vice whereof commeth complaynte hym moneth februarye frenche momorāci • made conſtable fra • kyng made anna momorauncie coneſtable fraunce whiche hygheſt degre honoure office bene euer voyde ſynce death duke bourbon kyng beyng greuouſly offended treaſon beſtowed ſame vpon man vntyll tyme ſame office hath bare lucke one two whileſt abuſing authoritie haue ſtyred vp againſt either kynges ſelues nobilitie meane tyme proteſtauntes aſſemble brunſwicke ende marche treate matter cōcernyng league receyue chriſtiane kyng denmarke chriſtiane kinge dē marke receiueth goſpell league ſonne frederick receiued doctrine goſpell appointed iohn pomerane whome called wittenberge ſet ordre church annoynted crowned kyng iohn alſo marque brandēburg brother ioachim prince electour made meanes duke saxon admitted league therfore appointed treate vpon certen cōditions retourne home thā receiue hym name ſame requeſte alſo made albert duke pruſelande whome ſyxe yeares chamber outlawed chiefeſt cauſe whye receyued duke pruſe outlawed ſocietie neuertheleſſe promyſed hym fauour good wyll whan duke saxony lantgraue cō ſortes goyng aſſemblie henry duke brunſwycke denied geue ſaufe conduicte whan ſhould paſſe countrey euen imagined warre hereafter ſhall heare duke saxon company maurice nephewe duke george brother henry young man ſeuentene yeares olde henry proteſtauntes religion therfore duke toke ſonne maurice beyng kynſman bring vp kyng denmarke hym ſelfe came alſo brunſwicke nynth booke ſpake perſecution fraūce lutheraniſme long recite al yeare ides apryll whiche nyne dayes eaſter young gentleman tolouſe learned twenty yeares age brent paris eatyng fleſhe alyue dede yet ſo beinge hanged gentlemā tolouſe burnt paris ryght ouer felte fyre kyndled vnder hym whiche maner accompted great benefite priſon brought forth execution feared cruell wordes morine iudge threatenyng hym confeſſed done wyckedlye agaynſte religion maner repentaunce ſhal ſuffer leſſe torment ſuche abyde conſtant moſte cruelly tourmented two younge men flaunders lyke daunger admonyſhed therof certen senatour learned good iudgement eſcaped death flyeng awaye moneth may biſhoppe rome goeth nice hauen towne ligurie thyther alſo came emperoure themperor frenche king pope meet nice frenche kynge requeſt chiefly nauie spaine kynge lande accompanied amonges others power almaignes whiche lead wylliam countie furſtēberge longe treatie albeit coulde throughlye agree yet trewee made moneth iune ten yeares lady margaret emperours baſtarde daughter enſured octauius duke parma byſhoppes nephew ſonne peter coſmus duke florence woulde fayne haue maried death alexander medices two kynges ſpake together place albeit byſhoppe deſyred muche fewe dayes whan departed mette aegnes mortes towne prouince mouth riuer rhoſne whither emperour retorninge spaine came nauie ides iulye kinge ſent mete uelius ambaſſadoure galleis conduicte whan emperour came nere vnto aegnes coneſtable fraunce readye entreate hym woulde arriue nauie ſaied kynge woulde within theſe two houres would come barke whan emperour ſawe reſt shippes ſcattered daye reaſon miſte come together putteth hauen longe commeth kynge alſo accompanied amonges others anthony duke loraine cardinall brother goeth ſtreight waye ſhippes emperour goynge forth farre ladder ſhippe mete receaueth ſpoken embracynges gratulations whan ſet downe sterne shippe noble aboute emperour come ſalute kinge lowly right curteſly emperour ſent andrewe aurie admirall prince melphite forſoke kynge tenne yeares andr • w de aurie mentioned ſixte booke come ſalute kyng whan came kynge ſaid prince andrewe muche frende ſeruiture emperoure pleaſure ſhould ſpeake wyth contente gratifie herein eſteme brother whan talked familiarlye frendly together ſpace howre kynge departeth next day mornyng ſone light day emperour gyueth commaundement trompet man go lande himſelfe garded wyth certen noble ſaileth dyne kynge came lande kinge quene two ſonnes moſt gently embrace lead palace towardes euenynge themperour aduertiſeth androwe de aure remained meting ofthemperor kynge within borde howe requeſt kinge queene ſyſter purpoſed lie towne night next day diner retourne nauie whiche intent leſte ſhould throughe abſence conceaue ſome falſe ſuſpicion hys minde wherfore next day emperour came againe ſea accompanied king noble whan drunken together emperours cabben ſhippe departed great frendes thing knowen paris place ſonge tedeum made bonefyers biſhop requeſted nice whan peace concluded woulde go counſell uicentia ſende thither ſuche prelate theyr companyes alſo ſende commaundement reſt home repayre thither like maner excuſed ſelues thoſe thinges cardinal whiche ſent thither aduertiſed great ſolitarineſſe againe deferreth day counſell till eaſter folowyng ſendyng abrode letter touching ſame matter fourth kalendes iuly whan retornyng homewarde gene fyrſt metyng kyng kiſſed right foote ſate chayre frēche kinge kiſſed pope right foote reſt noble notwithſtandyng diuerſe kinges traine refuſed although coneſtable warned chriſtopher duke wirtemberge william coū tie furſtemberge germanes mareſchall marchan frencheman george gluchie ambaſſadour kynge denmarke ſelfe ſame time departed life charles ecmonde duke gelders former boke haue harde howe maner turned al poſſeſſions brought diſtreſſe whā laye ſicke deuiſed coſin william duke cleaue conſent nobilitie common brought hys owne gouernement without themperours highe diſpleaſure ſhalbe declared place litle dieth alſo erarde marchian cardinall biſhoppe liege man tourmented religion biſhop liege made graue yet liuing cathedrall churche liege many yeares builded tombe moſt ſumptuous maſſe dirige ſonge yerely papiſtes wonte deade iudged theſe merit prieſtes auaileable beyng liue wherunto attribute deſerte rewarde eternall life knewe man well affirme certen oſtentation moſt deſyrous vayne glorie toke pleaſure pompe ſolemnitie time engliſhe bible printyng paris kinges commaundement engliſh bible printed paris ſhould church englande knowen prohibited printer daunger fraunce haue commonlye scripture vulgare tongue neither doth want ſuſpicion man chaunce read newe teſtament ſuche like thinge frenche neyther lawfull ſtudye scripture ſuch profeſſe diuinite common ſort men know nothing towne wiues whan go maſſe cary bokes latin prayer mūble vp ſorte knowing ſaye perſwaded ſame god acceptable ſhould praie mother tonge practiſe prieſtes ignoraunce people gainefull prieſtes vnto ignoraunce others gainefull biſhoppe retourning home begynnyng auguſt receiued citie rome merueilous pompe triumphe ſtretes way beyng hanged ſpired rich
