brunſwick lay ſide weapon army diſcharged bothe party thoſe force afterwarde george duke megelburge ſonne albarte younge man ſerued duke henry allured vnto cleargy maidenburge prelate head church moſt gentleman borne chiefly offended city waged great reward promeſſes reported aide might auenge thē ſelues deny ſhallbe declared hereafter archbiſhop ihō alberte lately departed wherfore promiſed ye gouernment ye hole prouince caſe could ſubdue wrytings laid pledge iii principal caſtels thus marching firſt ye coūtry halberſtat cam ye prouince maidenburge ther practiſing ſlaughter ſpoyling burning ſurpriſeth towne wancelebe ſpoyleth ſetteth fire whan attēpted caſtel vain loſt diuers mē marcheth forward way ſo euer wēt exceding much harm wherfore ye people country village whē ſaw goodes cattel taken driuen away come ye senate maidēburge crauing aid ſuccor declare wyll refuſe peryl coſte herein senate therfore aſſigned daye wherin ſhoulde redines xxi daye september went maydenburg together huſband men citezens iointly ſoldiours garryſons thre bandes horſemen field piece furniture reſte night two myles citie mornyng daye lyght auauncing campe marche ſtreightwaye towardes ennemie came ſyght put ſelues order battell forewarde thought moſte daunger ſtode citezens ſoldiours placed countrie people duke megelburge perceyuing order ſodenly tournyng rankes inuadeth huſbandmen kynde people neyther well armed exerciſed feates warre vpō ſuche ſoden gaue charge others coulde tourne ſelues ordenaunce able reſcewe therfore caſting awaye weapon ouerthrowe ye maidenburgians fled myght runne faſteſt breaking rankes fellowes make waye open ennemy get victory moſte part thē geuing charge chaſe ſlayne citezens ſoldiours many loſte dyuers taken gunnes carriage al warlyke furniture came handes ennemies meane ſeaſon emperour inſtant decree made auſpurge ſhould obſerued maketh greuous complaynt city maydēburg breme city remayned conſtant albeit bremers outlawed prince make interceſſion require myght haue hearyng matter whan emperour cōſented adreſſe letter eyther citie xxii daye september prince letter thē maydenburg cite appere auſpurge ſecond day nouember ſaufe conduicte come aunſwere cauſe ſendyng ambaſſadours full power authoritie conclude certen woman auſpurge citezen towne ſeing prieſt paſſe caried hoſte woman perill light worde ſycke man lyght borne maner maruelyng therat demaunded hym caried lyght noooe dayes ſo ſaying ſhe apprehended great daunger lyfe great intreaty woman finally interceſſion emperours ſyſter beyng pardoned lyfe bannyſhed mary quene hungary regent flaunders come thither boeth matter alſo cauſe chiefly proclamation lately ſet forth flaūders thoſe party myght mitigated vnleſſe ſo ſhe ſayde would come paſſe andwarpe whiche nowe beſte frequented marte towne whole worlde ſhoulde fall decaye loſe former beautie moreouer ther great daunger place iuſurrection caſe thinge ſhould put execution emperour hardly acconſented laſte altering thoſe thinges concerned marchauntes ſtraungers taketh away name inquiſitione abhorred proclamation religion mitigated men reſidue commaundeth take place obſerued whyleſt letter cōueyed bremers thē maidēburg prince ſtates inquire emperour vpon condicions accorde wherfore propoundeth bremers theſe ſubmit ſelues vnto power humbly craue pardō forſake al league make cōfederacy wherin whole familie compriſed obey chāber imperial contributaries charge therof portion agre archbiſhop ſtand arbitrement ſuche umperes ſhal appoint accorde alſo whole clergie reſtore munition taken duke erricke recompence hym harmes done none within iuriſdiction ſerue warres againſt paie vnto hondreth fiftie thouſand crownes deliuer xxiiii piece ordenaunce furniſhed obeye decree former cō uention ſuche ſhalbe decreed may denburg impoſeth maner ſame lawes added moreouer ſhould aunſwere men lawe obeye ſentence geuen tyme theyr rebellion commence action againſt man raſe fortification bulwarkes receyue citie hym lieftenauntes tyme power ſomeuer brynge without condicion paye two hondreth thouſande crownes publication theyr goodes ratified poſſeſſours thereof diſturbed reporte battell maydenburge immediatly ſowen abroade farre nere within ſyxe dayes brought emperour auſpurg many men thought bene almoſte vndone beholde publyſhe wrytynge fyrſte daye october wherin recite whole matter ſaye haue loſt aboue two hondreth citezens ſouldiours whiche appered nede comfort ſelues confirme others god ſay thei would meane trie conſtancie infinite goodnes towardes v doubt nothing albeit ſhal thus wholy periſh oppreſſed yet euil therin much better abide thextreme peril forſaking profeſſion truth reuolte romiſh antichriſt ſuch either feare certen couetouſnes ambition relent ſubmit ſelues coūſel trēt admit allowe wicked decree made auſpurge doubt life life euerlaſting ſhall ſuffer moſt greuous tourmentes except retourne amendemēt know alſo god hath appointed aduerſaries boundes limites ſhall paſſe wherfore deſire men wold ioyne praiers attempt warre againſt v oppreſſed ſelfeſame calamitie ſhall redounde vnto al germany without reſpect ſeing caſe ſtandeth thus certenly zeale loue preſeruation natiue countrey require ſhould ayde aſſiſte v whiche doctrine ye goſpel afflicted maydenburg ouerthrowe incontinently many prepare ſelues vnto warre amōges others duke maurice electour brandenburg coſyn marque force bent againſt maydenburg albert henry duke brunſwicke moreouer whole nobilitie alſo called vpon bring horſemen many ſuppoſed theſe force leuied intent duke megelburge myght expulſed contrey firſt deede certen would ſeme haue taken armure cauſe ſhould ſtraie farre whā aſſembled eight daye october marchyng forewarde incamped farre citie ſyxt daye nyght runne forth great clamoure euen ditch gate citie proue townes men coulde durſt doe beyng repulſed great ſhotte loſte many theyr men retyred ſelues campe hyghe diſpleaſure waye ſet fyre poore lazarus houſe cleane contrary lawe armes next daye bickered agayne whan townes men made ſaley full courage dyuerſe others many alſo nobilitie repaired thither hatred duke brunſwick expert men warre worthy captaines xii day october truce taken certen ambaſſadours came yt citie treate peace vayne whyleſt theſe ambaſſade againſte may denburge thinges working yt ſtates tharchbiſhoprike maydenburg amongſt clergie principal mete hale xv day october ſende ambaſſadours themperour prince thempire whā came auſpurg x day thei accuſe moſte heinouſly ſenate people maydenburg ſomuch duke maurice taken vnto ye power yt duke megelburg alſo thē ſelues ſent ayde neither lyeth abilitie ſuſteyne ſo great charge long require yt prince woulde finde ſome meane quenche common flame ſo ſhortly may ſoldiours may paide alſo thoſe naughtie outlawes puniſhed tofore recouer againe ſtrength courage late ouerthrow el wil ſouldiours reuolte thennemy thing wilbe moſte preſent daunger thē ar next thē al ſtates alſo intende nothing el deſtruction yt high magiſtrate wholy addicted ſteire vp people rebelliō throughout whole empire demaunded ayde viii fotemē cc horſemē ſame day red aunſwers bremers ſenate maydenburg made yt prince letter befor ſaid yt bremers firſt declare greatly thei alwaies haue deſired peace emperours frendſhip ofte haue ſued vnto peace ambaſſadours alſo yt king denmarke city ye border ye ſea ſhew ſtrayte condicions offered yet thende may appere much eſteme themperours authoritie ſaye wil refuſe ſende ambaſſadours promyſe may haue religion libertie permitted thē contente thing maydēburg anſwer maydēburgians fourmer aſſemblie empire made great ſute emperour peace condicions impoſed intollerable ſaye ſynce tyme haue ſuſteined great dammage ende meaſure wrōges repulſed violēce yet moderatly cauſe hatred couet retayne trew doctrine flee idolatrie concernynge daye preſcribed becauſe commaunded ſende ambaſſadours full authoritie fynde none wyll go ſorte moreouer george duke megelburg hath lately moued warre againſt confeſſeth openly doth commaundement emperour thempyre nowe alſo ennemies armie lieth citie may remoued ambaſſadours well aſſured ſhall may reporte demaūde vnto refuſe ſome ſent beginning nouēber dieth ulriche death ulriche duke wirtemb duke wirtemberge ſuite hanging ſtil kyng ferdinādo ſayd ſonne chriſtopher ſucceded emperour receiued aunſwers two city concerning bremers thinketh good tary thē aſmuch ſay wil come touching maydenburge ſo much thing farre otherwyſe ſay becauſe aunſwer frowardly maner contemptuouſly requireth procede conſulting determided againſt chiefly wold waie diligētly requeſtes ſtates byſhoprike herein thing whiche may commoditie dignitie thempyre prince ſtates perceiued right well would neuer pacificatiō made vpon theſe condition wherfore thei require gentle thinges might propounded emperour perſeuereth cruell decree againſt magdeburgians purpoſe length albeit againſt many willes namely city aſſente vnto promyſe ayde againe deſire emperour firſt ſelf would cōtributory herunto secondly caſe warre ſelfe would appoint generall charge cōmit duke maurice ſeme ſo good vnto ſay ye charge war muſt borne yt ſame mony already leuied vſes affayres cōmō weale themperour replieth charge ben ye fourmer war ye might reſtore peace vnto germany requireth thē haue cōſideration therof touching duke maurice wel pleaſed ſaieth yt knoweth man preſent time yt fit yt charge diuerſe cauſes yt mony ſhuld taken cōmon treaſury doth allow permit ſo yt ſo muche takē frō thēce within certē time reſtored yt mony gathered vſe exhorteth thē followe thing wt whole indeuour yt may puniſhed according demerites ſheweth may thus yt citie inuironed wt trēche bulwark made ſiege cōtinued til thei ſubdued vnleſſe yt licēcious obſtinat rebellion repreſſed ſe gret daūger ſhame wilbe thempire thus therfore duke maurice whiche buſied ſelf herein ſaid cōmon aſſēt made high duke maurice general war generall warre charge war appointed lx thouſand crownes monethly hōdreth thouſand crownes payed charge paſt concerning counſell emperour affirmeth prince ſhalbe continued againe trent eaſter ſo doeth byſhop promyſe yet doeth meane ſeaſon vrge decree auſpurge commaundeth declare cauſes vnto hym thoſe order wrytten two yeares ſynce religion reformation clergie obſerued archebyſhops electours ſaye howe haue omitted nothing yet wholy ſame cauſe letteth fully accompliſhed exemption priuileges certen deputes electours abſent ſay haue applied thing diligently long continuaunce tyme hath bene hinderaunce religion ſo ſodenly plucked men myndes nede inſtructed men might litle litle accuſtome ſelues thorowly perſwaded theſame decree diſſenteth much holy scripture nothing violently altered without trouble ſedition man ſhould cōſtraine ye prechers ther would man ſerue yt churche hardely one found wyll abaſe ſelfe hereunto ſtate ſyngle lyfe condition lordes ſupper reſidue prynces ſtates romyſhe religion alledge theſe cauſes yt cauſes decre obſerued scholes wherin yougth ryghtly inſtructed miniſters churche diſwade people ſame decree want prieſtes negligēce magiſtrates ſaye moreouer thing hinderaūce many ſpiritualtie liue vitiouſly many inuey rayle vpon decree made bokes reproche vnpuniſhed iuly byſhop rome oft treated emperour eight day nouember ſending forth bulles calleth pope iuly ſomoneth counſell coūſell affirming coincident office call directe counſels coueteth alſo prouyde trāquillitie germany hath alwayes ben moſt obediēt church byſhops rome earth chriſtes uicars wherfore let men repare trente againſt firſt day may whiche either ryght cuſtome priuilege haue intereſt ſuche paule thirde hath called tyme ſomoned counſell ſame place daye ſhall counſell continued ſo thei repare trent bē fore contemned fortune either age ſicknes affayres commō wealth himſelfe preſent yet legate preſident ſame bulle ſent themperour duke maurice made chiftayne attempteth thing great force buylding vp certē bulwarkes ſouldiours myght wynter therin thende nouember aſſayleth citie whiche citie diuided thre partes maurice beſegeth maydenburg wherof one whiche called newe ſurpriſeth nyght ſcalyng walles gate neither drumme went trompet blewe tofore brought ſouldiours citezens reiſed vp clamour ſo many found armure put ſworde reſt taken ſpoiled expulſed wherfore citie intēt might take away ennemy commoditie ſendyng forth ſouldiours burne part agayn part whiche called sudeburg ſette fyre alſo receiuing townes mē citie tyme came lazarus schuendie campe duke maurice myght emperours name gyue counſel ſame tyme erle hedeck saxony whome emperour hedeck manſfeld diſcomſited duke maurice outlawed two yeares paſt mentioned albert erle maunſfeld leuie bandes ſouldiours city sea coaſte ayde maydenburge duke maurice therfore moneth december goeth vnto thē part armie ſcattereth allureth vnto foure enſeignes ſame men alſo counte decke ſhall heare ix daye december emperour long proclamation heinouſe word inueieth empe proclamatiō againſt thē maydenburge againſt maydenburge commaundeth man ayde ſtraightly chargeth captain ſoldiours whiche within citie within fourtene day theſe letter deliuered departe citie geue knowledge hereof vnto duke maurice abſence lazare schuendie obeye promyſeth pardon appointeth extreme puniſhement citie albert erle manſfelde whome emperour dede banyſhed tourned al poſſeſſiōs tyme perſeuered fidelitie frendſhip iohn friderick duke saxon howe emperour left lantgraue machline taking iourney auſpurg declared duke maurice marque brandenburge earneſt ſuters might deliuered aunſwere made alſo ſonnes coū ſellours ſo demeane ſelues yet might deliuered kepers alſo ſaid vnto ſhould caried spaine wherupon requireth ayde ſonnes admoniſhynge faith duty owe vnto hym lantgraues ſōns ſue father commaundeth ſue duke maurice marque brandenburg yelde ſelues pryſoners according forme obligation fulfill promiſe ſonnes obey herein ſending ambaſſadours moſt earneſtly oft admoniſh ſue one whyle ioyntly together another whyle either thē ſeuerally ſelfe ſome tyme meſſengers ſometime preſently excuſe matter declare expedient either father ſhould ſo euer bring newe reaſons wherby truſt may deliuered without daunger therfore deſire forbeare thē whyle geue reſpite ye emperour moued lātgraue lirane deliuer thoſe obligation declared whan ſued vnto ſendeth lazare schuendie ſonnes counſellours commaunding henceforth neither cōmence action ſue duke maurice marque brandēburg alſo ſende vnto ſuche maner wrytinges ſurceaſe ſute vnleſſe obeye threateneth thē greateſt puniſhment may deuiſed yet vayne moreouer releaſeth letter prince bounde pronoū ceth fre bonde wherfore whan lantgraue lantgraues purpoſe ſawe hope fully prefixed make eſcape might deuiſeth ſondry meanes ſeruauntes whō ſent heſſe ſome gentleman good houſes afrayd daunger ſought delayes laſt perſwadeth two conrade bredeſten iohn rommelie waye heſſe vnto machlin layed poſt horſes whiche might leape vpon eſcape matter came light certen man told one frendely machlin within fewe houres maiſter ſhuld libertie ſame going one reported captaine garde ſame moment deuiſe fleing bewrayde inſtant ſhould haue fled al matter daſhed two ſeruauntes ſlayne hand others taken beheaded ſelfe caried ſtraiter pryſon emperour knewe therof toke moſt diſpleaſaūtly wryting letter duke maurice marque brandenburg ſignifieth ſo bolde enterpryſe apperteineth iniury hym dominion ſaith wil ſore auenged haue geuen either aide counſell herein copie theſe letter ſende william lantgraues ſonne amongeſt thynges ſaye caſe ſuche parte played henceforth wyl ſtande bounde yet neuertheleſſe duke maurice ſeuerally comforted deliuer father promyſeth ſpende goodes life bloud alſo ſayeth ther ſhalbe tyme conuenient yelde ſelfe whan ſtate thinges ſhalbe ſuche diſpleaſures certen leſſe feared xix daye december fotemen horſemen maydenburge appointed watche iſſue citie midnight might oppreſſe iſſuyng victory maydēburgians ſtoute courage ennemies vyllage farre enterpryſe daungerous yt muſt paſſe theyr ennemies campe yet chaunſed luckely ennemy could armed thei taken uillage ſet fyre diuers place put ouer harneſſe white ſhirtes maner camiſado many ennemies reſiſted wer ſlayn wer many noble gentleman diuerſe fought houſes ſame ſet fire burnt uery many ye nobilitie wer taken immediatly brought citie two hōdreth lx horſes morrowe ſone daye appeared retired home warde way met troupe horſemen whiche led duke megelburge laſte duke megelb takē priſoner geuing charge whan horſemen preſſed fotemen gaue onſet back takē brought citie euen whiche firſt begon warre theſe dayes alſo came spaine auſpurg maximilian marimilian cometh spayne auſtriche emperours ſonne law created king boheme abſence called home father king ferdinando betwene emperour great contention ſucceſſion empire whiche cauſe alſo emperour ſayde haue ſent ſyſter cōtentiō empyre betwirte emperour ferdinando mary retourned thither moneth ianuary ſhe might meane ſhe departed thence september emperour knewe commoditie annexe germany inheritaunce coueted eſtabliſhe ſonne whiche ſhould reigne ouer ſo many large diuers region ſure fortreſſe kyng ferdinādo hauing ſame reſpect thought nother expectation commoditie child ought diminiſhed herein moreouer maximilian prince great towardnes could ſpeake ſondry language eſpecially highe dutche prince like maners excelled muche fauoured beloued mē thoſe letter wherby counſell denunciatour haue ſaid byſhop promulgat rome latter ende december thing offend many whiche many thynges whiche myght offende men myndes ſorte ſayth part gouerne counſelles calleth hym ſelfe chriſtes vicar haue action continued repeted beginning chalengeth ſelf place authoritie preſident ſemeth call thither mē order theſe thinges alſo emperour whan letter deliuered hym ſayde haue noted right well haue required ſuche thinges ſomwhat rough might altered fearing thought leaſt germaines affrayde theſe thinges mariner rockes would either refuſe ſommoning el fynde ſome let delay buſines ſo great labour brought paſſe wyll affirme true ſuche maner coūſelles ar wont kept ſecret trwe manifeſt obteined nothyng ſame fourme ſpake byſhop publiſhed one worde altered yea ſome ſuppoſe dyd ſette pourpoſe might feare awaye germaines counſell ſhould come came might haue intrapped certen ſnares certenly paule thirde reported haue vſed policie haue ſayde ix boke learned eſpialles ye proteſtauntes could beare refuſed calling counſell would vrge propounde thoſe thinges chiefly knewe myndes moſte offended man may aſo perceiue bull iulius whiche framed ſame paule thirde theſe dayes duke maurice electour brandenburge offer condition peace maydenburg thei maidenburg moued rē der requyre render ſelues ſhewe fidelitie vnto archebyſhop thus wyll doe ſhalbe permitted haue retaine religiō doctrine exhibited time paſt auſpurge ſhalbe nothing deminiſhed priuileges lawes lyberties fortification alſo citie goodes ſhal remayne ſafe violence offered vnto man moreouer promyſe make interceſſion emperour wyl abolyſh ſentence publication verely vpon theſe condition prince city ſo alſo may humbly deſire pardon deliuer xvi piece ordenaunce hondreth thouſand crownes end may inioye goodes already confiſcated ſomme mony ſaye laye debource reſtore vnto clergie goodes concerning hurte done either ſyde touchyng habitation clergie ceremony cathedrall churche ſelues take order intent emperour may eaſlier perſwaded garriſon receiued citie tyll emperour haue confirmed pacification reſt condicions ſhalbe accompliſhed ſoldiours ſhal iniury thei ſelues wyll forſee caſe emperour refuſe theſe thinges wyll haue ſouldiour immediatly reſtoring vnto citie ſafe euery point ſuch founde senate refuſed make ſurrender receiue power citie moneth december state byſhoprike maydenburg thiefly clergie ſet forth wrytinge writing clergie againſt citie vulgare tongue againſt senate people maydē burge ſaye howe haue aunciently right apperteined iuriſdiction archebiſhop proued letter otto firſt emperour many thinges ſaye haue proudly preſumptuouſly done chiefly againſt burcarte gunther archebyſhops reduced dutie haue ſuffered condigne puniſhment hiſtories may declared ye tyme erneſt houſe saxon albert brandenburge byſhops compoſition made controuerſies kept conuenauntes ſo ofte byſhops common aſſent ſtates decreed thyng profit common wealth alwayes drew backwarde ſought meane howe myght rule reſt tyme cardinall mentz reciued iohn albert coſyn coadiutour would allowe ſame alſo toke hym title honour due vnto hym although oftentymes ſpoken ye ſame agayne whan ſucceded byſhopryke death cardinal albert would neither take hym byſhop geue hym fidelitie herein perſeuered ſo longe liued albeit noble men ofte time intreated therin intent myght obteine gouernment whiche may eaſely appere vnto man wyll conſyder doinges albeit bookes ſet forth intent reyſe commotion go perſwade people though nothing offended though clerely faultles though ſtoode daūger truth ſake religiō matter far otherwyſe religion hath let nordiſturbaunce although thei poſſeſſed yt church iuriſdiction actes againſt clergie ſo much ſayd would aunſwer lawful coūſell ſuffered thinges patiently content therwith made conſpiracie entring league whiche thing lawfull doe conſent archebyſhoppes would haue inforced v theyr religion wherof doth well appere ſought religion goodes churche yt wrought might vnder ſome honeſt pretence couer cloke treaſon rebellion full many ſeditious thinges haue thei wrought againſt emperour ſtates empire neither recited ſhall touche thoſe thynges whiche properly apperteine vnto v foure yeares paſt breakyng faith conuenauntes wherby boūd v thei gaue v defiaunce entring houſes toke goodes expulſed v ſome alſo caſt priſon wherof ſome dead reſt doe remaine captiue thys preſent bete houſes euen groūd brought townes landes gouernmētes ſubiection fortifiyng citie ſtrongly might ſafely rebelle impoſed commō people payment mony monethly certen charge church houſes religion partly raſed partly defaced caſting downe belle ye ſteples made gunnes toke vp dead body monkes prieſtes alſo noble men caſt vpon rampares image aultars graueſtones haue cowched layde walles church ſtanding thei haue put downe god ſeruice ornamētes precious iwelles wrytinges monumentes ſo euer founde church ſpoiled beating prieſtes miniſters churche fiſtes ſcourges droue thē holy place yea aultars haue ſondry place exacted new tribute cleane contrary cuſtome countrey yea haue broken fury ſepulchre founder great otto emperour theſe domeſtical euils contented herewith inuaded byſhoprike halberſtate ſpoyling college hamerſleb plucking prieſtes yt ſaying maſſe aultars ſome woūded ſome ſtewe polluting thinges hallowed trode hoſte conſecrated vnder feete diſguiſing ſelues monkes apparell whan done many thinges great oultrage mockerie returned home loden ſpoyles boties certen wall rampare yt countrey made gret coſt right neceſſary thoſe party caſt without cauſe burning cutting vp bridge mā might paſſe moreouer haue ſought take away liues alſo preſēt inſomuch ye neither remaine houſes frēdes without gret daunger whome ſuſpected geue v lodgyng would breake houſes night take goodes cary away diuers nobilitie captiue alſo put vpon racke yea haue ſpoyled noble matrones virgin ſtriped apparel ſo euil intreated thē thei haue brought daunger life haue kept handes alſo frō yonge babe child briefly ſuppoſe like example crueltie ſene amongeſt turkes man wold make eſtimate aſwel thoſe goodes haue gotten alſo harmes done v ſhal finde yt leaſt mount aboue viii c crownes ſpeake nothing meane ſeaſon contumelious reproches raylinges ye famous libel picturs haue ſet forth contēpt mockery thē perour ſtates imperial iniuries alſo haue ſuſteined fully xxvii yeares haue caſt ſtones v throwen vpon v filthe ſtretes haue gone citie haue oftētimes made clamorous outirie againſt v driuen v place place many tymes alſo nyght haue ſet houſes gate fyre ſtones broken glaſe wyndowes finally kynde outrage hath bene thē omitted foure yeres ſince ye xxvi day iuly whā ye requeſt yt conſuls aſſembled college required v firſt ſhuld profeſſe ſame religion yt secōdly yt towardes furniture ye war within eight dayes ſhould paye xx thouſand crownes entring churche citezens reparinge thither thruſte prieſtes violence ſhut vp churche dores demaunde inferiour ſorte prieſtes great ſome mony wer able pay wer driuen citie exile ſelfe ſame ſorte alſo haue handled reſt clergie entring vpon landes goodes whiche thing verely haue tranſgreſſed lawes god man alſo broken conuenauntes faith geuen megiſtrates may chiefly thanke v landes goodes time lately george duke megelburge interteined thoſe force whiche defended alſo beſeged citie brūſwick nomber thre thouſand without knowledge marched coūtrie may denburg halberſtat wonderful preſumption iſſued citie intent purpoſe firſt diſcomfited ennemy might bend whole force brunt war againſt v yea vtterly diſtroye v two tunnes full haltars hired certen hangman ſwordes ſome thei might hāge head ſome howbeit goodnes god chaunced far otherwyſe wer eight thouſād men diſcomfited ſlayne aboue two thouſand ſlaughter citezens amongſt theſe many innocēt people partly force partly flattery allured vnto thē eight enſignes taken al munition furniture goe aſcribe cauſe warre vnto v ſay duke megelburg moued warre impulſion falſe oftētimes alſo battel ſent ambaſſadours peace wiſhe non thing tyme reconciled themperour woulde reſtore vnto v olde tranquillitie quietnes ſo muche refuſe peaceable wayes deteyne force iniurie caſtels townes village driuen ſeke ſome meane wherby may recouer ſame ſuch thynges inferre alledge purgation forged fained commonly knowen haue diſturbed hindred religiō whan lately moſt noble prince duke maurice lectour brandēburg offred reaſonable cōditiōs proudly reiected thē making ſalee truce time aſſaulted night certen aūciēt gentleman home owne houſe done thē diſpleaſure ſlepe bed cōming whan hardly eſcaped awaye half naked rauening diſtroying goodes ſpoyled wyfe chyldren theyr apparell threatening ofte death left thē ſtarck naked ſo muche one nobilitie comming thither chaunce couered woman owne garment certenly oultrage dyd nyghte fewe wordes expreſſed haue alſo made aduaunt openly may loke reſtitution vayne ſo highly auaunced landes goodes haue accuſtomed ſelues finer kynd lyfe neither eaſely brought render agayne men goodes matter thus ſeing add vnto iniuries former yeares contempt alſo vtterly bene vpon diſtruction could recite theſe worthy actes though ſomewhat briefly wherfore meanes founde reduce thē agayne dutie man ought maruell therat ſoeuer loue ciuile common ſocietie men choſe ſtomake againſt muche leſſe ought ſuccour aide ſame ſort thei accuſed litle ſending ambaſſadours torge duke maurice helde aſſē blies concerning ſame warre many dayes ſame moneth senate maketh anſwer opon wrytinge howe ſuppoſe ſtates byſhoprike make complaint procedeth altogether anſwer yt citezens clergie greueth ſay goſpell taught ſincerely amongeſt v wickednes diſcloſed dignitie decayed chief cauſe hatred theſe thinges haue pricked thē forwarde accuſe v falſely emperour beyng outlawed myght ſo muche ſubiecte iniury aſſuredly haue offende emperour nothing inioying religion libertie nothing may haue handes dede bounde archbyſhop citie yet vpon certen condition ſhall diſturbe v liberty thoſe condition haue broken aduerſaries counſelled archebyſhop iohn albert ſhould demaunde certen newe thynges accuſtomed therfore refuſed geue fidelitie yet great cauſe ſhould alledge hym faithful ſelues greued tyme former yeares ſawe waye prepared hym archebyſhop rather haue excluded vnto ſubiect bounde point longe conuenauntes former time obſerued refuſed kinde dutie ſwarued ſame reſiſted hereof grewe ſondry diſpleaſures verely theſe latter yeares whan new wayes inuented exacte mony prouince ſpake againſt opē aſſē blies declared vſed byſhops former time although al uayn diuers ye ſtates chiefly clergie great part pray yt frowardnes obiect againſt v went citie yt clergle forſoke yt citie owne accorded incenſed certen pryde whan ſawe duke saxon lātgraue ſubdued ſuppoſed tyme come wherin might accompliſhe mynde obteine gouernment come filthy kinde life certēly expulſe thē albeit preacher ſermons reproue abhominable liuing yet dwelt ſafely amongeſt v many yeares euen lately certen inhabite citie bene diſpoſed haue wrought violēce againſt harde done attempted nothing whan ſtate thinges ſuch conſtraimed feare power ennemie called together fellowes cathedral church ſo much light goſpel reuealed god alſo requireth profeſſion ſame requyred dilligently doue many tymes ſelues woulde choyſe ſome experte diuine whiche myght teache goddes worde cathedrall churche ſame boeth ſelfe godly wold alſo helpe greatly increaſe mutuall loue beneuolence betwene citezens refuſed ſelues prouided thyng becauſe ennemie hande already inuaded limites requyred would paye v certen ſomme mony ſhould ſende letter citie ſhould remayne v inioye owne poſſeſſions long departed citie beyng requyred v ſende theyr ambaſſadours certen day salſie whome might treate proudely reiected talke wherfore whan vttered malice ſpitefull hatred againſt v alſo conſtreyned requite lyke caſe remayned v trouble myght haue bene auopded burned malice againſt v many time diſtruction forged new diuiſes ſo muſt neceſſitie take armure defence vnleſſe taken townes village bene place refuge left enne ſeing reuenewes church mayden burg perſecute ye church may rightly imployed defence religion againſt falſe doctrine idolatrie neither doeth thing want example fourmer tyme themperour hath dede outlawed v deſert haue heretofore oftener declared fortune ſtate common v prophes apoſtles godly folke afflicted proſeſſinge veritie finally chriſte ſelfe profeſſion yt truthe afflicted ſeditiouſe rebelles moſte hurt full men others haue intreated emperour cōcerning religion liberty hitherto labour vayne ende belonge deuiſes former wrytinges haue ſufficiently declared verely thing ſelf ſpeaketh ment wicked papiſtrie may reſtored controuerſie hath oftentimes bene brought cōmunication certen conuētions haue ben ſame cauſe principall pointes neuer ſatiſfied thambaſſadours ſayd cōmiſſion ſtretched ſo far aſſuredly greueth v exceadingly man ſhuld ſuſteyne dāmage cauſe yet ſuch godlymē doubt thinke doe iudge thinges ſuffered rather confeſſion truthe thynges muſt ſuffered truthes ſake ſhuld forſakn ſeing chriſt hath ſo lōg prophecied incōmodities inſue vpō profeſſion hath alſo appointed euerlaſting rewardes leaue wyues chyldren poſſeſſions ſake truſte theſe certen large promeſſes certenly relent feare owne daunger feare diſpleaſures thoſe procure vnto ſelues euerlaſtyng damnation vnleſſe repente thing whiche aduerſaries impute vnto v may rightly aſcribed vnto lyue fylthie ſhamefull beaſtly lyfe place thei beare rule citezens hardly deſende chaſtitie wyues daughter toke common litle monie ſuche extremitie fayne dyd unto whiche ſpeake cuſtome aunſwere myght made yf ſpoken playnly rampare wherof make mention whiche yet belongeth nothyng cut ſonder commune commoditie meanes therof many tymes hath hurte bene done countrey whan thei taken botie ſpoylers wont eſcape waye retyre ſelues daunger theycrie haue intreated euill gentleman neighbour ſo euer haue done behalfe haue bene conſtreyned doe whan yeare ſuffered iniuries many whiche ſaye concerning woman maydens vtterlye denie ſuch nobilitie taken pryſoners releaſed ſeruaunts without raunſome matter quieted emongeſt v cōpoſition enlarge exceadinglye accoumpte harmes done name eight hondreth thouſand crownes ſhuld ſhew againe much myſery thei haue brought v picture ſuche thinges haue bene ſet forth priuely mo place one al blame layd v certentie haue ſtraightly commaunded ſetting vp letter openly man ſhould attempte thyng preſumptuouſly againſt emperour prince certen alſo haue therfore bene puniſhed haue bene bookes alſo ſet forth amongeſt v denie wherin idolatrie impugned many men conſciences erected confeſſe ouerthrowe good wyll god ſo vtterly diſtroye v alure v amendemēt life certenly thei died honeſtly godly glory god holy name preſeruation common wealth god woundeth healeth doubt god ſeeth tyme mercifully loke vpon affliction alſo puniſhe aduerſaries neither chaunced thing fortune pretende intiſed hereunto george duke megelburg large giftes promeſſes yet meane tyme crafty policie called ſtates byſhopryke staſfort conſulte meanes might driue thoſe robber themſelues called coſitrie proued letter hired ſoldiours yea boaſte glory care greatly common hurte dammage beit ſuſteyne ſome loſſe hinderaunce yet ſaye howe lande grounde remaineth poſſeſſiō time therfore word brought v towne wanſlebe ſodenly taken ſpoyled brent great nomber alſo village diſtroyed ſo muche came rūning vnto v countrey huſband men woman maiden plentie teares deſiring aid could aſſuredly fayle thē although thing good ſucceſſe yet doubt god thanckfull ſeruice ſaye pike thanke intent oppreſſe nobilitie ſtates byſhoprike ſtarhe lie proued haue euerntore honoured nobilitie haue indammaged ſuche haue done violēce toward men haue paſſed fro ſo vnreaſonable iudge impute thing vnto v crime blame worthy touching reporte ſwordes founde battell fained thing haltars collar denie vſe thē right neceſſary wagon cariage manifeſt condicions peace offered duke maurice marque brandenburg could admit cauſes moſte weightie caſe yelded receiued power eaſy vnderſtande ſhould haue bene ſtate religiō common wealth alſo god infinite mercy hath opened vnto v knowledge goſpel befeche graunt vnto v ſo great benefite perpetually thoſe whiche promiſe v aſſiſtaunce herein howe credible alſo wyll perfourme ſame whan ſelues wauering myndes religion ſtudy pleaſe men aduerſaries may recouer goodes dāmage done party may egally borne refuſe ſhould retourne citie agayne ſet vp idolatrie meanes ſuffer thei ſay impediment v religion certenly wanted wil therunto haue cauſe geue god thā kes yt ſent ſhrewed cowes ſhort horne body dead men ſo intreated thei report defence plucked certē church nere vnto citie ſo many body founde wholy cōſumed cōueied place buried deper permitted vnto al men ſuch kinred foūd might tranſporte whether would ſame thēperour otto firſt moſte falſe ſhameful lie deuiſed prayſe great otto ignorant honour due chief magiſtrate eſpecially ſpeake thēperour otto many worthy actes moſte earneſt defendour protectour yt libertie germany ſeruice call holy godly complaine haue diſturbed church nothing leſſe holy cōcerneth high reproche god thēſelues lōg caried citie veſtimentes chalice ornamētes wrytinges publique monumētes kepe ſafely haue aboliſhed falſly accuſe v moreouer prieſtes wer whipped thēſelues ſpoiled church caried pray el college monaſtery hamerſlebie neuertheleſſe belōgeth thē therfore aſſaile laſt yt ennemies place refuge therin deuided boties takē frō felowes v wher adde moreouer men many thinges inſolētly outrageouſly ſame forged monkes cōcerning iniuries ſay done vnto thē citie thus ſtandeth matter xxv yeres ſince whā eight day eaſter whiche called palm ſondaye hand fond trifling ceremony laughed ye cōmon people thether reſorted whoſe folyſhe ceremony raſhnes boldnes proceded ſuch brake glaſſe wyndowes ſuerly puniſhed v baniſhed iniuries knowe none neither haue euer brought thē v wherfore haue done nothing contrary promeſſe cōpoſition neither haue geuē aduerſaries cauſe warre ſeing matter thus deſire mē geue credite ſclaundrous reportes lament chaunce cōſtreined defend warre yt attēpted againſt v thintent might mainteine ye pure doctrine goſpel liberty receiued elder thinges alſo godly kinges magiſtrates fourmer time machabeis men moſt ſtoute courage haue refuſed perill daunger wiſhe peace moſte chiefly aboue al thinges denied v hetherto wherfore lōg ſore afflicted inuaſions nere neighbour could repulſe frō v vniuſt violēce wherby haue alſo ye better confidence ſuche haue prouoked iniury wil iudge war cōcerne thē nothing ſtande awe feare god reuenger al vnrighteouſnes ſelf ſame cauſe hath ſtired vp trouble againſt v wyl ſhortly wrap vp thē alſo great diſtreſſe peril ſo many couet retein maintein pure doctrine letter 1551 wherwith byſhop rome called coūſell themperour fifth day ianuary cōmaundeth red senate ſtates prince exhorting thē wold prepare thēſelues ſame day king ferdinādo informeth ſtates yt truce time turk waxe buſy hongary build caſtel within dominion went ſurpriſe caſtel zolnock fortifie garriſon alſo haue made inrode tranſſyluania wherof verely hath geuen none occaſion doth al truce taken may obſerued caſe turke ſhal refuſe deſired haue aide geuen told xx boke stephen byſhop wincheſter cauſe apprehē ded englād perſeuered opinion wold neither allowe ſtatutes already made ſuche ſhuld made hereafter cōcerning religion kinges nonage depriueth byſhoprike yeare moneth ianuary cōmitted warde andrew oſiāder ſayd went pruſſe ſet forth time new opiniō affirming newe doctrine oſiander ye man iuſtified faith rightuouſnes chriſt dwelling v ſaith luther alſo opinion reſt diuines fellowes ſtoutly impugne affirming ſaid luther falſe many monthes death left moſt ample goodly teſtimony preface firſt tome melāchthons boke wherin treated cōmon place holy ſcripture therfore inueieth againſt melanchthon maketh alſo luther aduerſary one opiniō moreouer conference made proued manifeſtly luther taught cleane cōtrary matter ſay yt doctrine peſtiferous ſaith yt iuſtification fayth cōſiſteth bloud death chriſt wherby redemed iuſtified matter handled great cōtentiō ſelf verely pretended ſaid though luther ben opiniō ye meane time made auaunt amongſt adherentes written yt luther melāchthō made cōpiled diuinitie ariſtotels doctrine ſauereth fleſhe ye ſpirite albert duke duke pruiſſe addicte oſiander pruſland deſired yt firſt yt matter might haue ben appeaſed mediatours perſwaded oſiander much debating became opinion cōmaundeth aduerſaries depart dominiō amongſt whō ioachim merlin muſt nedes packing although ye citezens alſo womē child beſought yt prince right hūbly might depriued ſuch paſtour oſiander taught many yeres norinberg much cōmē dation neuer made buſines ſemed al thing folowe luther doctrine ſo long liued whan themperours decree religion forſoke norinberg went land pruiſſe reiſed vp ſame queſtiō many mē ſuppoſed yt durſt neuer ſo long luther liued chiefly prouoketh wittēberg confute theſe thinges ſayth wil defend opiniō whoſoeuer impugne theſame taunteth melanchthon bitterly whoſe opinion al learned men moſt part namely saxonie reproued bokes ſet forth rebuked time moſte troubleſome diſturbed congregation hādled ſo vngodly melanchthon man ſo great modeſtie learning yt al men offended exceadingly certen booke melanchthō beſt learned modeſte contendeth albeit mankinde ben loſt ſinne adam yet ſhuld chriſt haue bene borne neuertheleſſe eight day february diſſolued coūſell thempire therin made themperour decre forſomuch ſaith decree auſpurg great diſſention religion meanes better appeaſed general godly fre counſell yt former aſſemble ſtates haue ſubmitted thē ſelues vnto counſel therin perſeuer ſhalbe cōfirmed ratified thing alſo ſelf promiſed wil procure trauell diligence eche thing may orderly rightly done ſithe bull byſhop rome apperteyneth vnto chriſtian realmes prouinces ſuppoſe verely kinges ruler remembring dutie obeye furder ſo godly buſines thuttermoſt power ſoeuer alſo ſhal become therin aduocate church defendour counſelles yt ſame performe al ſuch wil repare coūſel whether haue chaunged religion wil graunte ſaufe conduicte yt may remayn propoūde ſuch thinges ſhal thinke concerne ye quiet conſcience ſhal may ſafely retourne home againe garded cōmon cōduct moreouer indeuour yt whole matter ſhalbe treated determined godly chriſtiāly al affection ſet apart according holy ſcripture doctrine yt father yt wel ciuile eccleſiaſticall ſtate may reformed errours falſe opinion cleane taken away intende moreouer remain within limites thempire leaſt neare thintent defende coūſel ſo may come vnto thende wiſhed fruict therof may redoūde vnto al men may chiefly cōmoditie germany wherfore require exhort al prince ſtates chiefly thē clergie thoſe haue altered religion cleaue ye confeſſion auſpurg according byſhops bul prepare thē ſelues come thither furniſhed leaſt complayne yt ouermuch haſte ſupplanted el admitted ſufficiēt declaration cauſe ſaid aſſure ſaufe conduict bring paſſe ſhalbe heard ſo much ſhalbe requiſite ſtates haue alledged ſondry reaſons decree former conuention auſpurg concerning religion reformation kept al reuoke mine owne conſideration wil know eche man ſeuerally impediment therfore let euery man ſee yt matter may come reherſall alſo decreed ye firſt day april thambaſſadours thelectours ſyx prince ſhuld mete norinberg conſulte howe mony yt warre maydēburg mony taken cōmon treaſorie war maydenburg ſhuld reſtored whatſoeuer ſhall determine cōmaunded like force ſame ben enacted full aſſemble thempire ſo much war ſhuld concerne welth al germany ſhalbe lawfull euery magiſtrate taxe yt people yt ſame cauſe againe caſe citezen thempire ſtraunger ſhall ayde maydēburg thā doeth thēperour alſo promiſe charge concerning iuriſdiction goodes churche themperour ſaith wil foreſe yt ſued thē concerneth wil miniſter iuſtice vnto thē euery man ſhal recouer inioye decreed ayde king ferdinando againſt turke although vnwillingly ſuche ayde promiſed former conuention finally becauſe therles manſfelde hedeck muſtring men laſt wynter intended aide thē maidenburg ſayd emperour chargeth cōmaundeth yt caſe ſouldiours aſſemble hereafter part germany prince ſtates next thē ſhal immediatly ioyne force together ſubdue thē quēche yt flambe force violēce ſelfſame time henry frenche king receiueth faith tuition octauins farneſius mortal ennemy octauian farneſe cliente frēch king ferdinando gonzage themperours lieftenaūt lūbardy ye ſlaughter father alſo ſo nere vnto placēce thēperour held fearing leaſt ſhuld able kepe parma owne force craued foreine aide receiued ye citie garriſon frenchmē thēperour toke right diſpleaſauntly eſpecially biſhop rome ſhalbe declared hereafter theſe day gaue thēperour ſentence againſt lantgraue contie lorſhip diece condē ned contēpt anſwered ſaid lay power anſwer ſo muche might cōferfrely wt coūſellours awayting harkening thē ye cuſtody came light would haue made eſcape lately ſhewed man might haue acceſſe ſpeake wt without witneſſe xxviii daye february bucer ended life death bucer cambridge buried honorably celebrated wt thepitaphes lerned mē amongſt alſo wer two noble yong men houſe suffolke brother whoſe mother ducheſſe al time whileſt ſick alſo ſhe wed al fauour beneuolence bucer woman moſt earneſt zeale towards religiō theſe day byſhop straſburg maketh greuous cōplaint ye ſenate preacher complainte byſh straſb letter written though ſhuld ſtyre vp yt people put prieſtes hazarde line wherfore requireth yt theſe thinges may reformed el counſell ſhal ſerue x day march king ferdinādo ſōne maximilian depart frō auſpurg vnto time thei ſtode termes thēperour regēt flaūders thambaſſadours alſo breme depart length without peace making meane time maidēburg diuerſe cōflictes ſkermiſhes ofttimes wold townes men iſſue whan riuer elbe ouerflowed ye ſhips yt made brought vitayle vp ſtreame ſame time diuers wonder ſene saxony amongeſt thinges thre ſunnes many mones one pale colour wōders saxonye red bloud maydēburg deſired aide city ſea coaſte uolrate iohn ſōnes erle manſtelde vain thennemies build bulwarkes riuer elbe aboue beneth citie laying ſhips either ſide wel māned kepe townes men frō ſayling oftentimes fought alſo whā wold driue away cattel townes men daily turned paſture citie xi day april ye byſhop pope accuſeth octauian farneſe rome boke ſet forth ſore accuſeth octauius farneſe time ſaith receiued parma ye high gouernment promyſed fidelitie wold neither addict ſeruice none prince receiue forein power parma licēce time appered bend towardes alteratiō oftentimes admeniſted duty frendly intermeſſages brother alexāder cardinal becauſe anſwered yt time ſomwhat ſtraūgly ſending letter threatned wt moſte greuous puniſhment ſhould doe otherwyſe afterward aduertiſed kepte conuenauntes well became ryght ſore offended ſhoulde worke ſuche iniurie whome auaunced ſo great honour benefites nowe therefore although might ſtraightwaies determine matter ſo euident yet thintent may vnderſtande oure great humanity wil commaund within xxx day appeare rome anſwer accuſations make v good aſſurance henceforth neglect wil euen condemned treaſon periury moſt greuous crime landes goodes ſo euer hath cō maund publicke common require herein themperors fidelity wil aid puniſhing ſame commaund yt man aid thing may day come thaction counſel commenced becauſe wer counſel trente cold commen thither warre parma hand matter adiourned firſt day septembre thambaſſadors prince met norinberge moneth april toke ordre ſhould new contribution mony ſiege maidenburge albeit themperoure commaunded ſame afterward proclamation yet ther exceading great difficulty thing men vnwilling paye ſiege long appeared end wherfore duke moris alſo treated oftwith townes men peace fiſt day maye time come campe ſafe conduit matter long much debated ſelf preſent fewe monethes duke maurice taken ſeruice counte hedecke whome emperoure outlawed erle hedeck frende thē maidenb made gouernour lipſia zeale vnto religion hatred bare themperour wiſhed wel maydenburge counſelloure peace ſame war beinge finiſhed duke moris might attempte greater thinges euen entred theyr head deuiſe war moued afterwards againſt themperor ſhalbe declared place notwithſtanding coulde agre vpon peace ouer hard condition propounded ſet purpoſe many ſuppoſe whileſt duke moris differred time ſoughte oportunity enterpriſe length geuen french king proclaimed war againſt emperor ſhalbe ſaid hereafter meane ſeaſon roſe great rebellion campe maidenburge want paiment certaine monethes wage neither came prince octauius rome whan cited aided french kinges garniſons toke hand defend parma wherfore emperour xiii day may publiſhing letter much ſaith duety good wil towardes yt biſhop church rome couet perform ſuch thing den forſee leaſt occaſion greater commotion ariſe italy place whileſt conſider vpon iuſt cauſes biſhop moued hath omitted nothing octauius might dutye haue committed thys charge fernando gonzage becauſe cānot ſelf preſent yt ſhal aid biſhop name wherfore wil command al louing ſubiects throughout lumbardie yt obedient war none otherwiſe thā ſelf yt indeuor anoy thenemy muche poſſible therfore gonzage beginneth war firſt ſpoyling country war parma betwixt themperoure french king ſegeth city parma biſhop rome mirandula therle mirandula french parte except cooped might haue holpen greatly prince city parma twenty day maye biſhop rome wrote swiſſes louinglye like taken vnto name iuly ſecond loued intierlye well ſo alſo purpoſed louinge immitate example foteſteps hitherto dede hath bene ſo occupied ſondrye moſt waighty affaire publick weale hath leſure declare thaffection mind yet hath borne ſtill perfect memory ſame apeareth chiefly ii thinges firſt cuſtody body hath choſen citye garde ſame nation secondly hath done alſo ye ſame boloigne lagraſſe truſting induſtry fidelity alſo much counſell called latelye firſt day may begon trent occaſion geuen wryte vnto wher therfore preſence ſhould great help furtherance ſo godly nedeful worke exhorteth much yt ſuch prelate church within iuriſdiction liberty wanting next ſeſſion firſt day septembre reſt ſhall vnderſtande hierome franch knight ambaſſadour whoſe faith diligence hath many yeres ben wel tried becauſe matter hand greatly contētation wil ſend belōg one principal biſhops may treat touchinge counſel large thend may emperoures ſonne departing auſpurge italy returneth spain wente maximilian coſin brother lawe fetche awaye wife mother two child meane time kinge fraunce appeaſe biſhoppe senate french king excuſe pope cardinal declareth rome ambaſſadoure mounſour de thermes hath receiued tuition octauian prince parma deſerueth reprehenſion thys thing proprely belongeth vnto king ſuccor thafflicted moreouer hath ſought priuate commodity matter whatſoeuer hath done haue done church rome ſake thexāple progenitor haue ben beneficial ſame others many time alſo defēded force armes ſeing parma patrimony ye churche careful forſee ſhuld come men handes ſame cauſe great coſt charge daily wherfore deſireth moſt earneſtly wold take part leaue opinion hath conceiued ſame ſhalbe great cōmodity cōmon weale refuſe ſatiſfaction chuſe warre peace ſelf ſeeth greatly wil damage daunger italy europe alſo certen treaty religion may continue wherefore concerninge mooſt pearillous commotion ſhal ariſe hereof counſell already called aſſemble neceſſity muſte diſperſed troubleſome time ſende none biſhops realme vnto trent theſe thinges ther fault laid willing offer condition peace alſo take ſo proteſteth ſo openly howe biſhop truſting thaid promeſſes themperor nothing ſterſe minde pope iulye mileder thys ambaſſade xvii day iune duke moris graunteth againe ſafeconduite maidenburge ſhould ſend vnto ambaſſadours concerning peacs taking theyr iourney conducted marque alberte finde duke moris pirne towne meiſſen retourned home ſemed worke ſlackly come themperors name propoundeth theſe condition ſhould yelde ſelues without condition humblye deſire pardon ſhal make leage againſt themperor king ferdinando auſtriche burgundie ſhal obſerue al decree thempyre ſhall aunſwere law recompence cleargy domage done caſt theyr fortification rampires admit theyr city garriſon cc ſoldiours ſhall receiue themperor kinge fardinando theyr deputy time wyth power ſomeuer brynge deliuer twelue greate piece ordenaunce paye c crownes confirme theſe condition oth theſe thinges although able perfourme yet vtterly refuſe thinterceſſion counte hedecke little little ſome thing remitted themperor ſending letter germany eſpecially ſtates ye proteſtants religion ſufficiently aſſured thē ſafeconduit exhorting thē trent firſt day maye inaſmuch war parma day counſell differred firſt septēbre ſaid admoniſheth yt come wiſe promiſing thē equity faithfulnes albeit ther many ſame profeſſion yet confer together thing hath ben chiefly neceſſary either yt diſpaired touching ſucceſſe thing el feared themperors diſpleſure yt waxed faint hearted entrance daunger amonges ye city strauſburge ſent meſſagers enquire thinge yt nere alſo far wer purpoſed herein certenly duke moris gaue cōmaundement philip melanchton confeſſion duke moris melanchton ſhuld pen tharticles doctrine ſhuld exhibited openly whan boke finiſhed prince commaunded al diuines miniſters church mete lipſia viii iuly wheras ſame red approued conſēt al ſame ordre alſo toke chriſtopher duke wirtemberge cauſed brentius compile boke ſame argument albeit ſence either wryting one yet wold duke moris haue boke exhibited ſelf leaſt many together ſhould propound ſame thing common themperour might conceiue ſuſpition ſome conſpiracy made neuertheleſſe ſēding bokes fro wirtemberge approued saxon boke saxon boke wirtemberge diuines strauſburge ether whan red ſame ſo agreed time ſhuld ſerue ther ſhuld ſent counſel certen prefer defend theſe thing duke wirtemberge thexample father made muche ihon brentius excellent learning vſing aide reſtoring godly doctrine alſo reſtored miniſtration humanity duke wirtemberge ward brentius church made preſident stutgarde xxv day iuly marque albert thabſence duke moris reiecteth ſuch thinges trompetter maidenburge anſwered condition peace propounded pirne duke moris day taken ouerthrow bickered greater force euer viii day auguſt ther like haue bene greate ſedition city letter wer brought ſoldioures wherein conteined ther wer certen senator wold betray city thenemy amonges henry alman wherfore ſoldiors flocking together cal whē came ſaith iniury refuſeth puniſhment cā proued affirminge inuented ennemye thing hable power force armes might bring paſſe craft policy againe whan hole senate become ſureties matter appeaſed certain nombre citezens souldiors choſen whiche ſhuld marke manner letter henceforth ſent fro eight day duke moris adreſſing letter ye duke moris letter emperour emperoure declareth verely content ſafe conduit geuen neither doth greatly find lacke therin heareth ſay decre made coū ſell conſtance inquiſition ſhoulde made againſte heretickes ſuſpected hereſy haply called counſell repaired thither ſentence ſhoulde pronounced againſt although emperour graunted ſafeconduit decre remaine common recordes like decreed ſo practiſe deede burninge ihon huſſe came thither ſafeconduite emperoure sigiſmunde ſeinge ſo canne ſende none trente vnleſſe prelate graunte alſo ſafeconduit whole name counſel time paſt done counſel baſil next vnto ſame bohemers feared former example would come burnt child fyre dreades thither ſame time vnleſſe firſt receiued publike ſafeconduit whole counſell requeſt therefore ether authority fauour would obteine theyr handes except might like caſe aſſured wer time paſt baſill ought preiudiciall ſame profeſſion ſuffered man theyrs trauel thither cōcerning bohemers ihon huſſe brent coſtantz warre inſued therof haue ſpoken ye third boke becauſe decre made coſtantz next counſel ſame ſhould holden fift yeare vii yeares time foreward euery tenth yere father aſſemble baſill ſo muche bohemers yet reconciled matter treated betwene letter intermeſſagers towne egre made draught ſafecōduit yt father wold admit bohemers ſaid woulde refuſe come thoſe ſent declared theyr ambaſſade father approued ſame fourme ſet theyr feales ſending vnto withal moſt frendly letter exhort prepare ſelues time ſafe conduit alſo emperour sigiſmund ſhall come vnto may take iourney fourth ſeſſion yeare grace mccccxxxii maner aſſuraunce father ſame ſhalbe ſhewed boke followeth wherefore whan duke moris warned hereof counſel maketh ſute themperor vrgeth preſcript baſil laſt moſte conuenient time proteſtantes caſe maner al one bohemers much like cauſes counſel trēt called time paſt baſil wit hereſies might roted peace tranquillity mighte reſtored common wealth vice taking away church might refourmed xxvi day auguſt yt morning ſermon doctours preacher churche auſpurge nombre ten ſent lodginge biſhop arras euery man ſelf come thyther ſome others knowing nothing matter commaunded ſtand apart ſpeake together called hall ſate biſhop arras haſie seldie maluēda certain others ordre one interrogatory miniſters auſpurge seldie talke commaunded propoundeth queſtions whether lord ſupper much cō tained vnder one kind vnder moreouer many sacrament beleued finally taught forme preſcribed themperor thre yeares paſt wheras promiſed ſo wel senate ſtates make aunſwer euery man ſelf ſeuerally chriſt inſtitute whole ſupper whoſe preſcript followed holy ſcripture found two sacrament baptiſme lordes ſupper receiued fourme doctrine diſſenteth holy ſcripture ſpake biſhop arras great coler thinke themperor may conſtancy prelate wel deuine matter ciuill make lawes preſcribe certain order themperor may diſpute ſay haue ſaied fourme neither receiued certenly allow waxed alſo angry ful furye taunted ſore rebuke whan alſo ſpake sacrament seldie ciuilian interpretoure rebuke thus ſent cōmaunded tary led keper beſtowed euery man place might come together ſent certaine chiefeſt senatours whan commen let altogether commaūded within iii day theſe preacher ſhuld depart city ſonne ſetting hereafter preach within limites thempire ſo farre emperours dominion ſtretcheth ſpeake none frendes kinſfolkes nether tell man cauſe preacher exiled departure wryte man within city ſignify done theſe thinges conſtrained ful ſore againſt wils holding vp finger ceremony promiſe othe senate commaunded ſhutte vp church dores wherin luther religion taught til emperor ſhould contremaund ſame ſort alſo dealt afterward ſcolemaſters city meminge others sweueland alſo ſent come thither forbidden teach alſo retourne home againe wheras one alledged wife neare time deliuerance therfore beſought earneſtly might permitted ſe biſhop arras turning towardes company calleth ſaith wife harlot thus therfore beinge compelled depart cauſed great heauines city citezens ſhewed pleaſure could giftes liberality duke saxon alſo priſoner whan hard therof comforted intermeſſagers alſo holpe mony theyr departure cauſe emperor proceded thys wiſe againſt thought firſt ſtirred vp hereunto many ſecondlye inquiſition made found preacher let decre religion toke place finally heard report conſent agrement diuines saxon sweuelād strauſburge readieſt way thought exiled end father trent might haue leſſe victory eaſily caſe ſhould hardly haue anye aduerſaries ſend againſt therfore thus driuen oute baniſhed fled partly swiſſes partly place brute thinge blaſed abrode made manye men fraid chaunced man douted ſame ſhould alſo done place behold whileſt men ſame feare french king maketh warre againſte themperor french king warreth vpon themperour withall taketh certain ſhips flaunders carieth away fraunce ſpoyleth piedemount turrin ſurpriſeth many townes amonges cherie san damians conduit briſſake touching ſhippes intercepted imperial writing ſetforth report whan themperour loked nothing leſſe warre commaunded hys ſubiectes ſit quiet french captaine poline chaunced vppon though caried quene scotlande ſignified vnto honoure ſake olde accuſtomed facion ſhuld vaile bonnet ſtrike ſaile hailſe ſhoting ordinaunce thing whan done beinge vnarmed fradulently circumuented caried awaye many men great maruel king durſt ſo great good fortune proſperity emperor renounce frendſhip yea ſayed haue chaunced emperour contrary expectation warred againſte duke parma yet would ſeme therfore enemy french men whome made peace ſeuen yeares king ſawe howe ſide octauius ſelf ſhuld alſo wounded yt alredy intelligence ye turkes wer ſailing sea intelligēce intermeſſagers duke moris affected ſo muche emperoure thought imbecillitye bodye diſeaſe retourned ofte longe life attempted thing ſtout courage manner ſame time turkiſh fleete whan aſſailed malta vaine ſurpriſeth tripoli city affricke blame hereof emperoure laying together french king ſendeth ambaſſadors prince city cōtrarye tale ye king emperour germany affirming done craft policy king ſo ſone knew therof ercuſeth matter ſaith cauſe turkiſh warre emperor reſtoreth city affricke according promes king fardinando doth hold fortify caſtel zolnocke ſtanding frontier hongary within turkiſhe dominion denieth pay yearely tribute attempteth new enterpriſes tranſſyluania confuteth emperours narration wherin declared tripoli loſt treaſon aremount french ambaſſador contrary narration confyrmeth ſame letter great turke whileſt theſe thing wer bruing day conſel came firſt septēbre day ther preſent beſides biſhops italy spaine tharch biſhops mentz treuers great ioy gladnes appered al mē long came alſo tharchbiſhop colō themperor earneſtly moued thē preſētly ye coūſel auſpurge alſo letter meſſagers yt ſhuld ther exceld al others dignity welth power moſt part yt biſhops germany cōpriſed vnder theyr dominiō wherfor thincking tary lōg ſold altheyr horſes reſeruing made theirprouiſiō houſkepīg lōg ſeaſō thither came alſo yt biſhops ſtrauſ uienne coſtintz chur numburge others let affaire age ſicknes whan obtained licence ſente theyr proctours biſhop rome name cardinal creſcēt preſident ioyned commiſſion tharchbiſhop counſel renued trent sipount biſhop uerona themperor ſente thither fraunces toletane hugh earle mounforte william pictaue diuers alſo place king ferdinando hongary making therfore aſſembly head church call ſeſſion firſt day septembre whan maſſe done accuſtomed ceremony finiſhed ſodēly came french kinges ambaſſadoure abbot belloſan letter indorſed conuention trent french kinges letter counſel deliuered biſhops legate red ſuperſcription queſtion aroſe ſhuld call conuention rather counſell vnleſſe could ſhew commiſſion thoſe letter neither red yet receiued exceading great clamour raiſed eſpecially spaniſh biſhops affirmed commiſſion compriſed letter biſhops legate ariſeth calleth ſide father reueſtry matter decided indorſinge mighte taken good part condeſcended heare therfore whē red letter priuately wherin king briefly ſignify grief iniury done required credite ambaſſadour ſit downe againe reading letter openly make anſwere kinge vnder name conuention doth ſignify counſell takē good part neither therefore conceiue ſiniſtrall ſuſpicion ſo great king hath title mooſte chriſten caſe mind wil otherwiſe take thoſe letter wrytten commaunded declare meſſage reciteth long oration wrytten firſt king rehearſeth treated ambaſſadour paulus thermes biſhop senate cardinal theſe meanes hath nothing preuailed notwithſtanding opened alwaies vnto peace ſaith biſhop iuly thexample predeceſſoures ought appeaſe controuerſies prince hath kindled exceading great fire ſuch time ought leaſt haue done whan doubtleſſe ſtate chriſten common wealth ſore afflicted ſeing matter thus ſo much dealeth ſo ſharply roughly theldeſt ſonne church proteſteth ſaith likewiſe done rome firſt moſt troubleſome tumultes warre may ſend biſhops realme vnto trent taketh publike general coū ſel rather certain priuate conuention inſtituted profit common wealthe vtilitye finally nether man within realme bounden decree therof declareth alſo furthermore wil vſe ſuche remedy caſe ſo require like matter progenitor haue accuſtomed euer ſounde ſincere mind towardes religion church rome neither wil cōmit thing worthy iuſt reprehenſion much burthened thiniuries hatred certain without deſert otherwiſe preſent therfore let thē take proteſtation good parte communicate vnto doctrine teſtimony action thend may certify prince people chriſtendome concerninge whole matter wheras ſaith wil vſe remedy progenitoures thus ſtandeth like region ſo alſo fraunce biſhoppricke abbotſhip vacant ſuch called chanons monkes fre election chuſe meane benefice electiue terme biſhops patrones beſtowed moreouer maner ſutes controuerſies touching benefice matter church wer decided within euery prouince biſhops rome couetouſnes reſeruatyōs graceser pectatiue increaſed began ſubuert thoſe election reſeruatiōs grace expectatiue name haue deriued gaine rome ſelues called alſo rome ſutes euen fyrſt inſtaunces call beginning alteration chanced fraunce time king lewes ninth reſiſted ſtoutly yeare lord cc lxvii made law thold cuſtome ſhuld reteined nether tribute ſhuld cauſe paid biſhop rome law verely force many yeares lengthe violence biſhops preuailed againſt ſo far chriſtendome ſtretcheth publiſhed thoſe foreſaid grace reſeruations chargeable men vntill synode baſill toke away kinde pillage reſtored aunciente lawes contribution election prohibited firſte frutes paid decre counſel king france charles ſeuenth thaduiſe counſell ratify yeare cccc xxxviii confirmed proclamation eugenius fourth pronounced counſell fruſtrate none effect ſaid firſt boke biſhops ſucceded reiected decre ſaid sciſmaticall dede pius ſecond ſendinge ambaſſadoure lewes eleuenth ſonne charles ſeuenth moued earneſtly aboliſh ſame confirmation king aſketh counſell senate paris mooſt famouſe fraunce maner conſiſteth wholy lawyer repeting many thinges great antiquity declare biſhops former time counſels finally progenitor clodowey charles yt great phillip deodate lewes ninth philip le beau lewes hutine ihon firſt laſte father grandfather haue herein determined except thauncient lawes obſerued wil come paſſe ſay al theccleſiaſtical ordre ſhalbe brought confuſion fraunce ſhalbe leſſe populous whan ſo many ſhal run rome ſhalbe ſo much impoueriſhed church many ſuch ſumptuous building france ſhalbe neglected fall ruine touching mony matter vnles father confirmation decree baſill maye ſum mony caried rome force ſhalbe caried yerely fraunce vnto rome ten c crownes let thinges paſſe time pius ſecond biſhop haue bene vacant leaſt twentye biſhopprickes haue paid euery one aſwel firſt frutes charge vi haue fallen abbotſhips lx euery one haue paied two thouſand benefice haue bene void aboue two hondreth whiche haue paid v c crownes piece moreouer within realme hondreth thouſand pariſhes aboue infinite quantity gold hath bene gathered ſame deuiſe biſhop rome walke therfore father foteſteps ſwarue decre baſil certainly counſell senate king ouercommen biſhops either authority policy would neades aboliſh confirmation vniuerſity part apealeth frō pope chief worker matter cardinall baluen great fauor king biſhop rome corrupted kinges procurer alſo vniuerſity paris whome much concerned reſiſted ſtout courage appealed frō biſhop counſel afterward lewes twelfth great emnity ſame cauſe iuly ſecōd matter brought counſel laterane fraunces firſte ſucceded lewes concluded length leo tenth vpon certaine condition bononie taken millan verely biſhoppricke abbotſhip vacante couent dede ſhould haue thelection therof king ſhoulde within vi monethes nominate ſome man biſhop rome whome thought worthy office ſame therfore thing amongs others king henry ambaſſador ſignified vnto remeady king wiſe wōt bridle biſhops diſſention ſo put practiſe confirmation decre baſil eſpectally time thondrebolt ſo greatly feared time paſte ſo muche realme fraunce moſt large rich alſo rome without great hinderance want reuenues therof ſignified would ſame longe ſhal hear ſame remeadye alſo time paſte vſed king fraunce tharrogancye poope boniface againſt ye king fraunce phillip le beaw againſt boniface eight wheras commaunded war againſt sarazen refuſing excuſe forbad ſhuld take mony church within owne realme king driuen neceſſitye warres vnleſſe obeyed ſame ſuſpend church aſſembleth noble ſtates paris reciting wronges boniface whan biſhops prince nobilitie demaunded confeſſed held al landes reuenues liberality benefit commaundeth henceforth ther mony conueid rome cauſeth alwaies paſſages watched diligētly wheras senate paris made thaccompt much biſhopprickes abbotſhips vacant pay ſaid ſay vnderſtand former time paimēt dubled exceadeth yearely reuenues ſo much many beneficed men reaſon great exaction leaue buls handes banckers within realme fraunce xii archbiſhopprickes aygnes uienne lion narbony tolouſe burdieux auxi burges tour roan rain sen twelue archbiſhopriks fraunce biſhopprickes aboute lxxxxvi vacation whereof terme caried rome wonderful ſome gold tharchbiſhopprickes verily thre ſcore thouſand crownes thre hondreth thaccompte made time lewes twelfth time theſe letter red father ſay howe ſhalbe anſwered next ſeſſion caſe ye king wil acknowledge counſel trent ſuch thinges nowe treaty admit much may lawfully therfore graunte teſtimonye inſtruction action whan day next ſeſſion appoynted xi octobre euery man returneth home ii clock none ſemeth mete place declare manner ordre publicke ſeſſion whan ſame day came father vſe ſpeake aſſemble houſe biſhops legate ſtil ye cathedral church vnto lodging ſtand ſouldioures either ſide way foure hundred fifty horſmen mo ix clocke commeth forth legate croſier cardinall trent goeth lefthand follow thoſe commiſſion tharchbiſhops prince elector ambaſſadors themperor kinge ferdinando ioyned together afterwarde reſidue biſhoppes euerye man ordre whan laſt come church souldiours diſcharge piece repair market place temple kepe warde till counſell breake vp mooſt part taken vp country maye preſt ready ſame day towne ſelf alſo doth kepe many whan come church heare maſſe done decree counſel recited day alſo aſſigned next ſeſſion come alſo ambaſſadours haue ought ſay hard reaſon diuers ſondry many buſy ceremony vſed matter thaction delated til far day lengthe beinge finiſhed legate retourneth home ſame pompe ſittinge biſhops legate hath chief place next cardinal trent legate copartner tharchbiſhops elector lefthand ſate thambaſſadors themperor prince middle fourmes ſit archbiſhops biſhops prelate euery man order came ſecond day septembre theames geuen deuines deuines theme geuen diſcuſſe reaſon vpon wherof euery man may ſpeake mind thintent next ſitting may determined pronouncing ſentences meane preſcribed ſhould cleue holy ſcripture tradition apoſtles receiued approued counſels authority holye father vſe breuitie abſtain ſuperfluous vnprofitable queſtions eſchue frowardnes contention cō cerning ordre agreed thoſe deuines ſhoulde ſpeake order ſpeaking firſt biſhop rome ſent ſecondly whome emperor ſent ſo forth moreouer biſhops legate permitteth ſearching truthe ſaye confute falſe opinion might read ouer maner bokes deuines great nombre spaniard italian germanes whome biſhop rome themperour alſo ſiſter mary ſente whome alſo tharchbiſhops collon treuers biſhops spaine italy broughte wyth unto whome referred knowledge al matter nether lawfull others ſuche ſame profeſſion taken degre doctorſhip ſpeake thing yet fauor archbiſhops colon treuers admitted ihon gropper lawyer ihon delphe batchelor diuinity doctor ſo much certaine former ſittinges yere xlvi yeare following made determination original ſinne iuſtification frewil vii sacrament new law terme general alſo baptiſme confirmation particularely condeſcended al thoſe ſtanding force decre ſhuld procede reſt firſt dede sacrament thanckes geuing wherfore certain theames wer deliuered deuines theſe ſelf ſame word ſhuld ſearch try whether heretical mete condēned holy senode theames collected oute bokes luther zwinglius bucer ſuch others deuines vſe matter ſort aſſemble daily houſe byſhops maner making ye article faith legate ſpace many hour obſeruing thordre foreſaid euery reaſoneth ſaid theames without interruption yet ſo ſubmit al ſayings iudgment church rome none proteſtāts wer ther place open indifferently men biſhops legate reſidue father many time ther preſēt deuines ſpeake wordes ſentences euery man regiſtred scribe time men done reaſoning accuſtomed done monethes ſpace biſhops reſorte biſhop rome legate examine maner making ye decree ſentences deuines whiche scribe noted euery nōbre natiō wer choſē certen peruſing ouer al opinion might therof make doctrine thinge ſhould determined beleued euery poynt cō demne contrary doctrin errours call wyth greuous ſenſure yet many word al theſe thinges fine related whole aſſemble throughly agreed come vnto open ſeſſions ſaid decree red openly done biſhops demaunded whether allow ſame anſwer pleaſe well ſo deuines declare theyr opinion euery matter biſhops mitred men haue authority determine thing thus decreed commaund ſacred holy call thoſe decree canon theſe thinges dede thus done outwardly thoſe better acquainted romiſh matter wil affirme thoſe article doctrine written rome biſhops commaunment ſent legate time deuines may reaſoning folow preſcript ordre biſhop finedeth ther diuers many biſhops alſo therfore commonly ſpoken fond prouerbe holy ghoſt commeth many time rome trēt incloſed male cauſe verely biſhop ſendeth ofttimes letter poſte ſignifying holy ghoſte pope commaundemēt legate woulde haue done fourth day septembre erle hedeck commeth maidenburge duke moris ſo mitigate condition propounded thought mete proceade treatye meane truſe taken alſo prolonged many day ſhall hereafter declare french king hauing mind alienated french kinges wryting agaynſt pope biſhop rome publiſheth wryting ſpeakinge many thinges thiniury done vnto cauſe warre parma whye receiued octauius tuition commaundeth vnder great penalty mony henceforth conueied rome conſidering ſinewes warre conſiſteth mony madnes mony ſubiectes maintaine force aduerſarye ſtrengthen power peculiare office biſhops rome appeaſe controuerſies king verely paule ye third almoſt worn age came nice ligurie make reconcilement betwene father themperor iuly followeth cleane wates hauing lately called counſell neceſſary dede common weale hathe ſtirred vp war againſt ſurely ſet purpoſe mighte exclude french church one principall ſo ther holden lawful counſel wherin therrors prelate miniſters church mighte refourmed faultes amended proclamation king openlye proclaimed paris vii day septembre whereas day ther moſt hainous proclamation ſetforth againſt cruell proclamation againſte lutheranes lutheranes whiche partly confirmed ſuch like decree former yeres partly ſemed diligently enough writtē ſharpned omitting nothing concerneth great ſeueritye ſuch wil vtter thing promiſed great reward whiche thing dede king thought haue done intēt might bridell hereby ſuch fraunce deſired haue alteration religyon leaſte reaſon thys diſſention hys biſhop ſhould take ouermuch libertye againe leaſt whiche beare reuerence churche rome ſhuld conceiue apinion minde ſhould altered concerning religion finally biſhop ſelf senate cardinal might ſee might receiued frendſhip whan wold themperours court came forth wryting wherin recited original cauſe warre parma iuſte occaſion diſpleaſure biſhop rome hath againſt octauius earle mirandula vnquiet mind frēch king ſeketh manner occaſions bendeth whole force maye impeche defeat moſt noble enterpriſes themperor beit themperor nothing moued withall theſe thinges wil ſo much couragiouſly ſtoutly procede octauius pretē ded though come neceſſity thobeiſance tuition french king thiniuries laying wayt fernā gonzage confuted wrytinge cauſe feare occaſion geuen ſelfe hath ofttimes laid wait life gonzage recited placence came hand themperor peter aloiſe biſhop rome baſtard ſonne whan obteined pirma placence gouerned common wealth cruelly like wicked luſtes pope ſonne nero accompliſhed wicked luſt vpon womē men alſo wherfore ſlain home murthered citezens could longer abide ſo great crudelitye townes men yt ſaw preſent daunger prepared againſt caſe ſhuld come iuriſoiction biſhop church rome refuge ſaue gaue ſelues themperor eſpecially conſideringe alſo howe fre citezens empire ſo therefore moued gonzage deſired mighte receiued themperors tuition otherwiſe wold prouide aid ſuccour elſſe wher therfore vntrue ſhuld faine ſelfe fraid themperor hath imploid many benefit vpon farneſians hath choſen octauius ſonne law gaue father aloiſe city nouaria euer honored hym dignity marque great hath bene vnthākfulnes time chiefly whan pretence frendſhip aided puniſhing certain rebel germany whole endeuor haue taken gene lumbardy verely ſame tumult ſlain ful wickedly amonges others ioannine aurie man excellente vertue whileſt themperor faithful ſeruice repulſed pearil country came forthe anſwer theſe thinges purgation french kyng french kinges name wherin made mention themperor haue frendſhip biſhop rome paule thyrde gaue vnto ſonne peter aloiſe title degre marque toke vnto octauius ſonne peter ſonne law preferred ſonne alexander many eccleſiaſticall promotion afterward made league biſhop wherin prouided decre senate cardinal made concerning gouernment parma placence themperor ſhuld confirme houſe freneſians time themperor made war germany pretē ded cauſe diſſention twixt ye pope emperor though moued ſame war religion puniſh rebellion certain deuiſe diſpleaſaunt biſhop ſaw meane went priuate affair procure ſelf rule gouernment neither diſceiued iudgement war almoſte finiſhed whan themperor great neade freneſians ſeruice declared plainly bare biſhop great good euen lieftenants lumbardy fixed eies mindes ſurpriſe placence long procured certain murtherers whiche ſlue peter aloiſe chamber townes men heard murther committed ſouldioures brought themperors name take caſtel themperor priuy act yet ben reaſon death biſhop paule ſhuld haue reſtored city churche rome hathe onlye reſtored ſame hath alſo gone take parma ſonne law euen hand ſame deuiſe whan biſhop yet liued ſo muche paulus beinge ſore vexed minde thinke vpon ſuch vnkindnes departed life afterwarde wer murtherers takē parma ſpake theyr mind fernando gonzage waged ſlay octauius whan therfore brought diſtreſſe whan ſaw whome loked healpe alſo father lawe laye wait take bothe landes life alſo requireth aid ſuccor could deny ſo humbly crauing ſame ✚ xxiij booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charles fyfte ❧ argument xxiij booke father trent enter matter graunt ſafeconduit come counſell french king accordeth ſame pea diſſwageth swiſſes goinge thither compoſition made maidenburge vnder certaine condition moſt part city germany ſend counſell ambaſſadours duke wirtemberge might harde duke maurice hauing laſt time ſent ambaſſadours emperoure deliueraunce lantzgraue obtaining nothinge delay ſecreatly reſolued make warre monke biſhop uarady whoſe meanes king ferdmando taken tranſiluania ſlaiue themperor letter ſendeth appeaſe archbiſhops aſſureth ſelf duke moris make fayre weather ſendeth ambaſſadors counſel whome thothers ioyned make requeſt ſafeconduit theyr deuines aboue thoſe contrary parte iudges counſell obteining nothing departe vpon brute preparation warre theyr prince would make father counſelare diſcorde newes came takinge auſpurge fled al creſcencethe pope legate fel ſo terrible feare admitteth conſolation death duke moris pacification aſſembleth ſtates dominion thend septembre cōmaundeth repaire wittemberge thither alſo maidenburge ſend ambaſſadours couenaunted tenth day return home conuoy marque albert haue ſhowed howe duke moris letter required deuines might haue ſafeconduit whole counſel emperor therfore commaundeth ambaſſadoures preferre matter father bryng paſſe wherfore xi day octobre commen ther decree trent lordes ſupper ſitting wherin fyrſt rehearſed expoſition doctrine corporall preſence chriſt sacrament thanckes geuing manner inſtitution therof tranſubſtantiation call worſhipping adoration sacrament reſeruing hoſte cariyng ſicke preparation man may receiue worthely al chriſtians forbiddē beleue teach otherwiſe decreed cannon recited wherein thoſe theames condempned ſaid collected oute luther workes others notwithſtanding gratify emperour leaue foure vndiſcuſſed whether neceſſary ſaluation commaunded goddes lawe men ſhould receiue sacrament vnder kind whether receiueth one taketh le receiueth whether church hath erred ordeining prieſtes ſhoulde receiue vnder bothe kindes reſidue whether ſacramente oughte miniſtred vnto child alſo touchinge theſe theames synode ſhoulde determine thinge ſaied proteſtantes deſired heard haue ſafeconduit graunted therfore haue longed greatlye hitherto theyr comming hope returne auncient concord church graunt ſafelye come ſafely retourne differ determination theſe queſtions fiue twenty day ianuary may fore day repair thither declare haue ſay thē treat alſo touching ſacrifice maſſe becauſe argument like theſe thinges read openly ſuch ſort theyr aduerſaries made requeſt heard theſe thinges wheras neuer thought ſuche matter beſides duke moris man moued emperoure hys ſute framed ſort ſaid matter much waighty would haue propounded intent thing thus pronounced man may make coniecture nothinge affirmed two thinges one muſte neades either requeſt duke moris coldlye ſlenderlye preferred vnto el haue vſed matter craftely negligentlye thing like true ſafeconduct ſent duke moris would haue ſelfe ſame aſſuraunce men bohemers time paſte wrote ſafeconduite wordes negligently ſafeconduit father trent ſetting neither ſigne ſeale publicke lawful germaines indifferentlye repaire vnto counſel matter treated either full aſſemble certain commiſſioners propound confer reaſon ſhal thinke good either talke wryting without contumelious wordes reproches whē wil depart return home conſideration ye counſell graūteth thē ſafeconduit farforth ye ſame apertaineth moreouer ſhalbe lawfull wel ſinnes paſt hereafter committed although moſt heinous ſinell hereſy may owne pleaſure chuſe iudges ſelues ſame eleuenth day octobre mentioned made certain lawes vnder title reformation whiche concerned theyr iuriſdiction ſeſſion decreed xxv nouembre wherein ſhoulde treated penaunce extreame vnction alſo
