electoure brandenburge ioachim ſending ambaſſadour chriſtopher straſie doctour ciuill law offered duety obeiſance certainly thāmbaſſadour ſpake manye thinges large great good marque brā denburge ſtatereth counſell wil prince anſwer haue taken much pleaſure hear whole oration eſpecially part wher prince ſubmitteth ſelf wholy counſell ſaith obſerue decree ſame truſte thing hath nowe preſently ſpoken ſame perfourme dede deathe ihon albert whiche archbiſhoppricke maidenburge wealthy large gouernement committed fridericke ſonne thelectour brandenburge whome colledge deſired archbiſhop matter impeached could broughte paſſe rome becauſe thelectour ioachim proteſtantes religion openly knowen ſame great let wherfore auoid ſuſpicion ambaſſadoure ſent fawning vpon prelate omitted poynt exquiſit diligence ther peace concluded wittenberge beit ſiege leuied immediatelye yet frendly metinges betwene xii day octobre ye ſelf ſame time duke moris conſtraineth chat people countrye duke moris ſeaſeth vpon dominiō chat heſſe wer iii yeres paſt themperours ſentence taken frō lantz graue priſoner ſworne vnto conſent lātzgraues ſonne reaſon league inheritāce ſaith betwene houſe heſſe saxon ſo default heir male one houſe ſhould ſuccede thother man doubted concerned iniury themperor geuen ſentence ſome new commotion mē marueled would thend therof emperor court manner talcke made knew therof time duke somerſet vncle kinge englande apprehended ſeconde time lorde duke somerſet apprehended paget lord gray certain others ihon duke northumberlande chiefe rule gouernemente cauſe apprehenſion reported duke northumberland ſaid howe laid wait life law newly made deathe amonges eight day octobre biſhop rome created cardinall george martinuſe biſhop wardin high authority hongary common people named monke becauſe thordre paule firſt hermit french ambaſſadour commaunded attend anſwer xi daye octobre ſo king would acknowledge counſell haue tould certes came yet counſels name ſetforth wryting king firſt recken vp loked moſt ample thing hand ſondry cauſes comminge counſel writeth yt french king meſſenger red letter conceiued inward ſorow fallen expectation yet forſomuch neither touched gilt conſcience haue geuen none occaſion diſpleaſure haue yet laid aſide thold hope wherfore thopinion hath conceiued though counſel called priuate profit leaſt take place ſo worthy sinode cauſes calling counſell propounded cauſes calling counſell biſhop alſo paule thirde verelye hereſies mighte roted oute ſchole diſcipline amended peace reſtored church plaine inoughecan ther godly chriſtianlike thing done hereſies ſpredde throughout germany manner country great calamity counſell redreſſe cauſe alſo end theyr doyng thinges referred poynt let therfore permit biſhoppes realme ſo godly buſines neaded feare leaſt might ſuffred ſpeake frely thought lately ambaſſadoure bothe quietly patiently heard whan told ioyfull newes ſeing priuate man heardwith ſuch lei tie ſhould man beleue ſame ſhuld denied vnto publike parſons ſuch placed ſo high dignity though ſend man yet ſhall counſell neuertheles haue bothe dignitye authoritye lawfullye ſummoned iuſt cauſes reſtored ſignified would vſe remedy progenitoures done ſuppoſed would neuer procede ſo farre reuoke thoſe thinges taken away aboliſhed time paſt great commodity kinges fraunce ſeing god hath ſo highly auaunced indued ſo great benefites truſte verely wil nothing wherby ſhuld ſeme vnthankeful ether towards god mother holy church let haue reſpect progenitor ſame title ſurname moſt chriſten king finally father king fraunces honoured former sinode ſending thither biſhoppes ambaſſadors men moſt excellent learning oughte walcke theſe foteſteps freſh domeſtical follow exā ple remit priuate diſpleaſures common wealthes ſake themperor biſhop exhorted swiſſes ſhuld counſel vaine biſhop dede treated hierome francke ſaied french king gaue charge vnto morlet ambaſſador french diſſwageth yt swiſſes frō counſell ſhuld indeuor perſwade ſend man thither morlet fineding ſome difficultye herein ſendeth uergerius expert man ſuch affaire rhoetia axeth counſel furniſhed argumentes ſhortly ſetforth boke eſchuing counſell morlet beinge thus inſtructed came vnto thaſſemble baden alledgynge reaſons perſwaded longe ſence forſaken papiſtry alſo reſidue swiſſes euen deſired wherfore none came trent rhetia cam thither biſhop rome commaundement thomas plāt biſhop chur whan rhetians vnderſtode aduertiſement uergerius biſhop rome intended howe would recouer authority amonges called home againe spaniardes wer land wirtemberge ſent time themperor ſent italy ſerue land wirtēberge delyuered spaniardes warre parma theyr departure whole country deliuered moſt greuous ſeruitude wherwith ben oppreſſed ſpace fiue yeares onlye caſtell aſperge emperoure reſerued ſelf placing garriſon almaines theſe day alſo henry haſie emperor commaundement traueling throughout sweaden euery wher chaungeth ſtate common wealth ordeineth newe senator diſchargeth alſo preacher scholemaſters vnles wyll obey decre religion latelye done auſpurge mentioned duke moris duke wirtemberge commaunded article doctrine wrytten ſhuld exhibited alſo senate straſhurge ioyned ſelues vnto theyr wherfore duke wirtemberge ſending two ambaſſadoures ihon theodoricke pleninger ihon hecline commaunded thambaſſadour wirtemberge counſell exhibite openly confeſſion doctrine ſay alſo deuines ſhuld come ſhal treat al thinges plentifully defend ſame ſo may haue ſafecōduit according decre baſill ſo ſone came trent almoſte end octobre go vnto earle mounforte exhibite vnto commiſſion theyr ambaſſade ſhew theyr prince name would propound certaine thinges counſell talke tended end thoughte good ſhould repair biſhoppes legate ſeinge ſhould confer thing wold apere ſhoulde attribute vnto chiefe right authoritye iudgemente wherin perceiued preiudice hinderance matter wherfore come wryting letter theyr prince fary anſwer pleaſure herein meane ſeaſon deuines reaſon theyr manner queſtions propounded concerning penaunce vnction third day nouembre counte hedeck ſent duke moris came maidenburge calling captain ſouldiors place pacificacion maydenburge without city made ful end wrytinges ſame matter drawen ſealed ſoldiors dede aſſured ſafe conduit might ſafely depart viii daye ſame month ſo ſone diſcharged priuelye reteined hired againe duke megelburge pacification releaſed duke moris purpoſely woulde owne name condition peace theſe ſhould humbly craue pardon themperor ſhuld nothing againſt houſe auſtrich burgundy ſubmit thē ſelues chambre obey laſt decre auſpurge anſwer al mē law caſt fortification city themperoures pleaſure admit theyr city themperors garriſon time ſet open theyr gate pay l crown themperors cofers charge warres deliuer themperor xii great piece ordenaunce ſet liberty duke megelburge thother priſoners whan ſoldiors garniſon wer gon citye ſame daye nombre ii fotemen hondreth horſmen duke moris ſent v enſeignes footemen nexte day senate going forth mete entreth city wt hys whole army receiueth al thobeiſance themperor thempire ſelf bene chiefe captain ſame warre leauing garriſon leadeth away reaſt cauſeth preacher ſente counſelloures faccie carlebice mortiſie complaineth iniurye done reaſon bokes picture ſetforth though ſhuld haue forſaken doctrin goſpel though ſhould haue moued warre againſt city conſtant profeſſing true doctrine wherfore hath iuſt cauſe offended would followe affection theſe thinges remitteth common wealthes ſake requireth wold henceforth exhort people amend liues honor magiſtrates commaundeth alſo praiers openly made emperoure ſelfe magiſtrates ſaith moreouer howe preſente counſell holden trent wherin exhibit confeſſion godly doctrine well owne name alſo prince ſtates let thē pray therfore god would proſper turn good whole action counſell raile againſte ſame haue accuſtomed deliberating vppon matter make anſwer dede ſet forth thoſe picture iudge worthy reprehenſion certaine dominion haue ſpace iii yeares ſwarued pure doctrine goſpell cannot denied bokes monument extant city beſieged becauſe goſpell eaſy proue man conſider fyrſte author warre admoniſhinge people haue omitted nothing ſame wil alſo hereafter counſel aſſembled quench verity wherin romiſh antichriſte obteineth higheſt place none otherwiſe pray god may confound breake diſſipate enterpriſes deuiſes good thinge loked theyr handes conditious peace dede ſpread abrode certaine well aſſured liberty religion duke moris alſo rather city ſhould open themperour thend declared afterward ſorte maidenburge deliuered beſides thexpectation many got ſelues great praiſe renowne amonges foraine nation ſo much manner alone throughout al germany declared theyr example thing conſtancy may moreouer noble fame conſtā cy maiden burge thend theyr miſery thentry beginning warre againſt whoſe aid counſel afflicted ſhalbe declared whileſt duke moris city declared ſufficiently intent wit wold hazard life deliuer father inlawe neither diſſemble ſame next daye moued certen man ſent ambaſſadours emperour ye deliueraunce lantgraue alſo ioyned herein king denmarke many prince germany ſhall heare hereafter vnleſſe could bringe paſſe fully determined attempte thing force duke maurice intēdeth war vpon emper already compact french kyng touching ſame ſent priuely iohn fraxinie byſhop baion man well acquainted germany vnderſtode tongue emperour appered nothing moued theſe thinges wholy addicte war parma treaty counſell trent tyme alſo maximilian emperours ſonne inlawe cōming spaine arriued gene wyfe child frenche men ſayling porte marſeilles bording certen ſhippes toke ſpoyled ſame cauſe whereof ſaid bee thoſe horſemen king ferdinando ſent italy receiue conduicte ſonne comming spayne ayded ferdinando gō zage certen warlike exploicte frenchemen alſo vnder pretence amitie entring hauon barcelona takē away galley ſix ſhippes burthē furniſhed thinges neceſſary vſe nauigatiō maximilian certenly imperialls recite certē inuectiue wherin complaine iniuries frenchman peace broken prince intreated emperour conuentiō auſpurg caſe might preſent leaſt wold far place coūſel thing graūted ſaid vnto thē wold remaine vpō border thempire ſhewed wherfore departing frō auſpurge beginning nouēb came inſpruck thre day iourney trent thought haue done bicauſe coūſell alſo warre parma ſo nere al thing ſhuld done diligence shortly xxi day nouēb iohn sleidane ambaſſadour citie straſburg iohn slefdan ambaſſadour straſburge counſell came trent yt might ye cōmon cauſe ioyntly wt duke maurices duke wirtēberges ambaſſadours vnto citie ioyned themſelues eſting rauēſburg rutelinge bibrach lindawe gaue commiſſion ſhould treate alſo name frankefort chiefly norinberge ſent may doubted ulmes hadde chaunged theyr religion preſcript emperour auſpurg place preacher banniſhed lately ſayde could well ſende howbeit though ſame chaunced senate would haue done nothinge herein emperours conſent moneth nouember byſhop rome one daye created xiii cardinalles italian wont pope createth xiii cardinal prouide ſuch garryſons defende ſelues whan xxv day nouēber come father placed ſeates accordingly decree recited penaunce sacrament inſtituted chriſte neceſſary ſuche baptiſme fall vnto ſynne agayne decree penaunce alſo ſeuerall sacrament baptiſme table ſaluation ſhipwrake hath chaunced ſame wordes chriſte whiche geueth apoſtles holy ghoſt ought vnderſtande power forgeue ſinnes sacrament ſinn ſhuld forgeuen thre thinges required contricion confeſſion ſatiſfaction contrition dede true profitable ſorrowe prepareth man vnto grace confeſſion maner ſecretly recite ſynnes prieſte bee ordeyned goddes lawe neceſſary ſaluation ſinnes whiche come remembraunce circumſtaunces ſame reherſed confeſſion ought euery yeare leaſt chiefly tyme lent abſolution bare miniſtery wherby remiſſion ſinnes denounced act iudicial prieſtes though neuer ſo ſynfull haue authoritie geue abſolution byſhoppes doe reſerue vnto ſelues certen caſes offence whiche prieſtes aſſoyle well done although crime remitted yet puniſhement therfore releaſed ſatiſfaction conſiſteth worke fayth ſuch penaunce eyther god ſendeth vpon v prieſte inioyneth el owne fre wyll choſe vnto ſelues ſynnes clenſed concerning temporall punyſhement ſatiſfactions wherby ſynnes redemed goddes ſeruice prieſte hath power bynde lowſe therfore may inioyne penaunce hym confeſſeth ſynnes muche concerning penaunce decree extreme vnction sacrament inſtituted chriſte geueth grace remitteth ſynnes comforteth ſycke vſe sacrament ſame wherof ſpake saint iames apoſtle thoſe ſeniours alſo wherof made mention aunciēt yeares prieſtes thei miniſters sacrament doctrine commaūde celebrated obſerued suche teache beleue wyſe deteſte accurſe peſtilent wicked next daye ſeſſions brought duke wirtemberges letter ambaſſadours whome commaunded ſhould procede aſſeſſion xxv daye nouember ſhoulde exhibite confeſſion doctrine wryttē therfore thoſe letter brought ſo lyttle tyme late long ſeaſon next ſitting earle mounfort alſo abſente goe cardinall trent ſaye haue certen thynges whiche ſhould prynces name propounde counſell howe ſame ſhould haue bene done laſte ſeſſion letter came ſo late occaſion paſte wherfore requyre whiche germayne borne would loue countrie prynces ſake alſo whome knewe thē caſe bring paſſe father called together myght declare meſſage moſte ample wordes promiſeth great beneuolence howe wyl preferre matter byſhops legate ſayeth howe agreed amonges father man ſhal propounde thyng openly vnleſſe diſcipline amongſt father firſt knowen maner thyng ſhould frenche ambaſſadour cauſe ſame decree whan lately opē ſittyng reyſed vnſemely vprore clamorouſe outcrie wherfore inquireth ſhould effect requeſte deſire matter ſhewe letter cōmiſſion wherby vnderſtanding ſhould exhibite ſome boke doctrine letteth thē ſo departe time put hope within fewe day thing might take effect next daye calleth againe ſaieth howe hath conferred legate whole matter better credit alſo ſhewed letter cōmiſſion ſore offended ſhoulde thynke exhibite wryting thynketh thus thoſe whiche ought dutie reuerently receiue obeye rule order doctrine woulde preſcribe theyr elder whiche thynge abſurde vncommely aunſwere coulde get none thys preſent yet woulde bee hande wyth hym agayne biddeth alſo good comforte within fewe ambaſſadours wirtimb deluded dayes tyme maximilian auſtriche approched nere cardinal going forth mete mantua admoniſheth ambaſſadours wixtemberg ſo much muſt nedes departe thei ſhould repare toletane emperours ambaſſadour vertue office authoritie may profite greatly right gladly euen ſake whiche hath cōmended matter vnto followyng counſell ſpake vnto promiſing gently many thynges ſo departeth whan thei came againe ſecond tyme began make excuſe reaſon diſputations diuines ſhould nowe haue wher father muſt preſent whiche finiſhed would eſpie occaſion thought receiued muche like aunſwere cardinall done leaſt ſhuld take awaye hope heard hereafter alledged cauſe eſpecially conſidering bothe howe emperour hath procured counſell permitted publique decree empire euery man myght frely propounde matter ſoeuer wold meane ſeaſon ambaſſadour straſburge goeth emperours ambaſſadour william pictaue abſence erle monforte ſo muche lyke condition authoritie ſheweth commiſſion ambaſſade maner cuſtome ſayeth ſent thither ye intent might conferre conſulte reſidue profeſſion auſpurge howe controuerſie religion doctrine myght appeaſed publique quiet eſtabliſhed taking copie commiſſion whiche ſayde would ſende emperour ſpeakyng many thinges doctrine dignitie counſell like dede learned man oratour offered ſeruice diligēce laſte nouember ſame tyme diuines theames deliuered touchynge ſacrifice maſſe terme myght ſpeake myndes ſame maner mentioned howe duke maurice ſent ambaſſadours emperour thambaſſadours mauris marque brandēb emp lantgraue declared thē ioyned ambaſſadours prince electour brandenburge wherfore admitted ſpeache aboute begynnynge december whan theyr prynces name done theyr commendation knowe ſaye moſte redoubted emperour diſtreſſe ar moſte noble prince electours duke maurice marque brandēburg oration ye deteyning lantgraue wher thei chaū ced beyond expectation whileſt ſinguler induſtrie wolde procure vnto eaſye honorable victorye demynyſh charge warre reſtore common countrye peace quietnes thing hath ben cauſe alſo haue ofte intreated ſometime ambaſſadours ſomtime perſons wold haue cōſideratiō ſet lyberty time verely added moreouer caſe ye requyred aſſuraunce beſydes ſuertyſhipp wherwith wulfegange countie palatyne people heſſe bounden wolde refuſe unto theſe requeſtes made aunſwer chriſtopher carlebyce iames schillinge ſent laſte vnto deliuer hym ſhould appeare action emperiall aſſemblee ſhould whiche hande myght againe promiſed nothing el kept conuenaūtes ſhould deteined priſon perpetual occupied affaire could ſelues come aſſemblee moued agayne counſellours letter auſpurg writing againe cauſe offended wyth might deliuer pronounce free bonde wher bounde lantgraues ſonnes wherfore determined moue highnes againe woulde haue come ſelues knowe howe letted war maydēburge marque alſo ſicknes therfore wold haue thing done v firſt dede whan pleaſure lantgraue ſhould ſubmitte ſelf vnto without condition receiued intelligēce byſhop arras mynde verely ſhould admitte obſerue condition propounded deliuered vnto nowe ſhould haue ben perſwaded render ſelfe ſorte aſſuredly nedeful declare vnto ſhold neither deteined priſoner farther burthened pacification preſcribed therfore ye prince aſſure thing alſo coūſellours vnderſtode right well deſired yt certē article yt ſame peacemaking might declared vnto alſo requeſted yt might ſtaied ſame matter aboue vi day ye thing ſignified ye biſhop arras thinges alſo prince maner obteined would albeit ſame treaty caſe vnderſtande men one ſorte ſo muche whan came contrary promyſe committed warde yet neuer blame ceſar ſame neyther ſtode termes therfore counſellours ſauing whan lantgraue coming ſignified vnto ſhould come vnto numburg thā ſpake ſelfe ſayde perſwaded admitte condition propounded cō ming far wold permit wold go mete ſo moch come thither vpon ther fidelitie beſought might otherwyſe burthened pacification compriſed thing ſelfe graunted frankely went forth brought hale laſt treatie ther mention made ſhoulde detayned priſoner lantgraue kepte priſoner againſte leage made thing thei ſuppoſe owne men alſo teſtify namely biſhop arras onely conference seldus whome many time ded aſſociate vnto cōditions admitted humble ſubmiſſion prince beleued verely ſhoulde haue bene releaſed immediately many cauſes thought ſo fyrſt bycauſe youre counſelours made mention impriſōment chiefeſt point ſame peacemakyng diligētly marked ye lantgraue doubtles aboue al thing agayne pacification many thing contayned cannot perfourmed captiue prince onely libertie made ſubmiſſion pardoned offence promyſed abolyſh preſcription geue letter reconcilement moreouer ye content ſuertyſhip wherby prouided caſe obſerued cōuenauntes people ſhould preſent captiue ſuerties force armes ſhoulde compell dutye certeinely theſe thing purpoſe al together ſuperfluous ther ſuppoſed ſhould haue ſuffred puniſhment owne body neuer thought ſuch matter yet coūſellours made mention therof vpon truſte cōfidence ſent thing ſhoulde chaunce vnto beſyde promyſed bound ſonnes abyde lyke fortune ſhoulde minde opinion alſo cōfirmed time ſubmiſſion duke alba badde lantgraue ſupper bedding hoſpitalitie maner prince cuſtume germany could ſo interprete thing ſhoulde goe duke alba houſe vnto priſon ſhoulde accompany bring thyther conceaued leaſte ſuſſpection lantgraue blod • ſupper kepte priſoner world matter ſhoulde beleue euer wolde haue done ſeing prince empyre electours borne moſte noble houſes wolde neuer haue imployed ſeruyce ſorte tyſe noble prince nere friend kynſman ſuch diſtreſſe themſelues bring priſon neither knew thing therof till ſupper ded duke alba fyrſte ſay vnto howe muſte remaine caſtell cuſtodie howſoeuer ded good mynde ſayd begenning ſo moch bounden fidelitie may eaſely perceiue caſe ſo great long ſuite ſuerties put ſhoulde longer detayned howe greuous harmefull ſame wolde chyldren kynſfolkes ſe alſo moſt mightye emperour cō ſydering come germaynes race aſmoch ye lantgraues ſonnes pourſue theyr ryght vrge yelde ſelues captyue fourme obligation mete doe maintayne ther honour eſtimation according auntient accuſtumed manner nobilitie germany haue none excuſe vnto prince although eyther ye power ſue dede obligation haue ſhould taken waye peraduenture lantgraue neither cōpoſitiō geuyng faith ſame occaſion haue ſhewed deteyned priſoner certeyne wearynes impacience long impriſōment hath ſought ſom meanes obteine liberty perchaūce miniſters haue attempted thing againſt kepers prince doe beſech ſame preiudicial ſomoch reaſon ther obligatiō ar great perplexitie ye nexte almighty god may delyuer ſo moch vnknowē vnto ſtroke vpō theſe rock ſo moch haue certen inteligence good fidelitie duty time aduerſitie employed land good lyfe bloude commoditie followyng herein foteſteppes aunceſters moſte hartely earneſtly require would releaſing captiue ſuccour haue reſpect herein ſo much lantgraues doinges vnto thē honour exceadingly eſpecially ſince fewe family haue progenitours houſe auſtriche burgundy ſpared neither coſte perill caſe feare leaſt ſet libertie ſhould kepe conuenaunt highnes knoweth well enough whan matter ſhal come iſſue nobilitie people heſſe haue promiſed othe prince haue done likewyſe ſuertiſhyp require aſſuraunce haue made offer diuerſe tymes heretofore nowe alſo haue geuē v authoritie treate ſame matter moreouer concerning condition ſuche might ſtreight wayes accompliſhed ſuppoſe lack founde caſtels ſo ſodainly raſed knewe wel cauſe doubted matter would holde lantgraues ſonnes excuſed furthermore lacke founde wyll whole indeuour may cōtented ſatiſfied wherfore thei themſelues haue time father grandfather done thing hath bene acceptable either emperour maximilian reſt progenitours thinke may doe perfourme thing tyme come may pleaſāt ioyfull deſire moſte effectually woulde ſuffer nowe receiue ſome fruicte ſame would cauſe hope promeſſe appeare whiche firſt made hale numburge laſt alſo auſpurg intent verely maye honor hēceforth ſo muche induſtrie courage may reioyce ſidelitie ſeruice thei haue done hath bene well imployed largely rewarded ſhould otherwyſe ſhould nowe obteyne nothing may coniecture moſte puiſſaunt emperour diſcommodities wyl ſue tyme ſhalbe enforced anſwer matter declare innocēcie hope vndoubtedly graunt requeſtes whiche verely accept high benefite alſo lantgraue ſonnes frendes ſhall euermore endeuoure may requite benefite bycauſe ſame thing doeth ſo muche concerne eſtimatiō haue alſo intreated prince make interceſſion whoſe ambaſſadours ſe haue done intent thynge whiche could yet obteine prayer meſſēgers letter ſame myght bryng paſſe commendation fauour praye take parte tyme thus ſpoken deliuer vnto hym letter ferdinando kyng romaine albert duke bauier brethrē duke luneburge wrytten behalfe lantgraue name ye prince intreated lantgraue prince ſent ambaſſadours theſe friderick electour palatine woulfgange prince bipounte iohn marque brandenburg henry iohn albert duke magelburge erneſtus marque baden chriſtopher duke wirtemberge ambaſſadours ſtreight way oration reherſed whan ſhewed cō miſſion duke maurice ſay marque brandē burg electours wher deteining lantgraue great perplexitie ſayde would make ſute oratiō price ābaſſadours emp highnes hym moſte mercifull emperour intreated prince would ſue intent treatie myght commendation importaunce whiche dutie verely could ſo iuſt cauſe denie thē great frendſhyp alliaunce amongeſt conſidering therfore matter thus hath bene ſufficiently heard either ambaſſadours becauſe longer deteyned ſame ſhulde greatly obloquie defamation haue promiſed fidelitie prince whiche haue ſent v praye beſeche ponder theſe thynges dilligently ſuppoſe concerne alſo dignitie honour eſtimation preſerued neyther thinge chaunce vnto greuous blotte ſhould redounde noble fame whiche doubtles wyll come paſſe vnleſſe captiue deliuered wherfore moſte inſtauntly require theſe interceſſions praiers maye take place may ſhortly deliuered eſpecially ſince hathe acknowledged faulte humblie alſo craued pardō bene nowe deteined captiue long ſeaſon chiefly becauſe great neceſſitie two prince electours ſo requyreth tyme handled matter right faithfully would gratifie fell pecke trouble albeit peraduenture treatie ſome errour committed ſome thinges wel vnderſtande yet conuenient comly clemencie preferre equitie extremitie regarde ſo muche captiue fatall neceſſitie electours deale frankely example progenitours euer great reſpect care dignitie prince imperial verely ſhould redounde honour amongeſt almen alſo excite ſhewe vnto fidelitie beneuolence make preſte willing doe thinges ſake king denmarke alſo ſending ambaſſadours maketh interceſſion maner like effecte emperour fewe dayes maketh aunſwere empe aunſwer ambaſſabours muche matter weightie requireth deliberation meane ſeaſon mention made vnto hym duke maurice certen weightie cauſes wyll ſhortly repare ſo muche hauing wrytten letter loketh dayly therfore bycauſe matter may beſte treated whan preſent differ vntil thē may retourne home vnto prince ſhewe name remember interceſſion ſo vſe matter may vnderſtand cōmendation lightly eſtemed long william lantgraues eldeſt ſonne came lantgraues ſon cometh maurice duke maurice bycauſe put hope interceſſion made certen moneths paſt ſince ye ambaſſadours toke iourney inquireth done ſaieth ambaſſadours denmarke came late till emperour went auſpurg inſprucke thing delayde againe ſheweth anſwer emperour made bycauſe deſireth ſpeake differreth matter till albeit lothe preſent leaue countrie yet tendreth caſe greatly ſayeth determined go hauing firſt receiued letter ſayeth anſwer vncerten doubtful neither ſee good loked ye meane whyle father eſtate miſerable pineth way ſorrowe lotheſomnes pryſon whome may meanes leaue deſtitute bothe bycauſe duty alſo promeſſe therfore let hym indeuour bryng paſſe within certen ſhorte tyme made direct aunſwere ſame done neyther marque brandenburge may take diſpleaſauntly ſued cōmaūded anſwer obligatiō cōcerning iourney wold ſhuld take delibe knoweth whether wyſdome ſo theſe thinges thus handeled countenaunce certen counſellours whome duke maurice woulde make priuie deuiſe ſince firſte began treate counte hedecke tyme allured •• part force told fourmer booke would ſcarſly let owne coūſell know thyng matter ſo muche none vnderſtode wherfore fraxineus ye frenche ambaſſadour came made whan therfore receiued anſwer themperour fixed minde make warre taried ſeaſonable tyme yeare touching thoſe forſayd theames began diſpute ſeuenth daye december ſixt daye whiche ſhorteſt daye wynter maximilian entring trent wyfe child receiued byſhop rome legate maximilian entreth trent byſhops spayne italy diuers alſo germany yet electours brought spayne olyphaunt inde whiche kyng portugall geuen rare ſpectacle beaſt often ſene germany next daye fortuned yt iohn gropper whome ſpake diſpute waxed hote inue • ed railing groppes ſore againſt melanchthon bucer though dead rayled moſte bitterly thē germain spaniardes italian great deale temperate whiche thing againſt decree thempire alſo againſt lawe ſelues made verely matter ſhould treated affection ſet aparte without rayling wherfore day iohn sleidane occaſion talke ſpake ſame emperours ambaſſadour pictaue complaineth ſhould permitted haue ſuche libertie ſayde cleane contrary willes alſo mindes father haue bene moſte earneſtly admoniſhed thei ſhould abſtayne albeit perchaūce prouoked example aduerſaries whiche haue nowe theſe many yeares triumphed kynde yet take ſuche order ſhall ſo emperour wold alſo loth occaſion offence ſhuld geuē mā cardinal dalmatia ſlayne owne houſe xviii daye december byſhop wardin hongary lately made cardinall ſlaine home owne houſe ſuſpicion conſpiracie turkes authour murther iohn baptiſte caſtalde italian whome emperour ſent hongary aſſiſte king ferdinando ayde counſell sfortia palauicine alſo preſent ſame byſhop rome heard murther appointed certen examine matter alſo doeth excommunicate parſons aboue named whan wydowe iohn uayuode ſawe yt ſhe coulde hardely defende tranſſyluania ſhe made conuenaunt king ferdinando permitted haue gouernment deliuering armes ornamētes realme retourned lande poole meane therfore ferdinando poſſeſſeth maner tranſſyluania helpe byſhop wardin becauſe appered afterwardes attempt newe deuiſes aſpire gouernment loſt life ſhewed fourmer boke preacher miniſters churche expulſed frō auſpurg wherfore moſte part church diſtitute prieſts without great grudge people ſuppoſed ſenate cauſed emperour thus therfore feared leaſt heate would ſomtime breake length whan ſought long much foūd one caſpar huberine whiche profeſſed fourme doctrine preſcribed emperour certen bokes wrytten concerning religion whiche alwayes wel commended euen luther ſelfe nowe altered mynde affirme came auſpurge began preache feared mutinie people chriſtmas began wō der many red bokes ſoldiours well ſuche beſeged maydenburg thoſe defended ſame wyntered thuringe aboutes much harme eſpecially men churche amongeſt others alſo archebyſhop mentz whoſe limites reache vnto thoſe place tharchebyſhops mentz treuers collon herewith offended damage receiued yt ſawe alſo ſame chaunce might redounde vnto determined retourne home ſending bothe letter meſſengers emperour ſame matter emperour deſired greatly haue counſel continued anſwering third day ianuary letter ſaith 1552 xxi decēber come handes bycauſe commaunded empe letter byſhops eleciours fraunces toletane treate ſuche matter wryte vnto againe much ye byſhop arras declared vnto procurer certen thinges ſame ſorte name thought bene ſatiſfied ſo much heare ſay vnpleaſaūt brute reiſed intende retourne home thought good admoniſhe wryting geue credit althinges reported although hath ben certen tyme brute though feared leaſte ſhould ſome commotiō heſſia yet credible informed thing deuiſe fewe whiche greater part alſo diſcommendeth wherfore rather thought thē ſelues wilbe mindful othe fidelitie wherby bounde alſo dutie whiche owe common wealth neither truſting thinges vncerten take ſo great daunger vpon moreouer haue ſent intermeſſagers vnto prince ſtates city thereaboutes haue ſearched diligently matter ſhoulde euery man goeth haue founde men obſequious dutie ſurely haue geuen none occaſion offence man duke maurice dede went reporte alſo long ſince whiche peraduenture original hereof bene captaine ſame bandes whiche rendring maydenburg aſſembled together hurt certen place wryting letter late ſending ambaſſadours alſo promiſeth al endeuour euen preſent two ambaſſadours ſhal go hence morrowe coū ſell trent furthermore hath ſignified ſelfe repayre vnto certē weightie neceſſary affaire knowe certen reportes wyll either daye morrowe furtheſt take iourney hytherwarde maydenburg finally maketh ſo large ample craft dawbyng promeſſe loialtie obeiſaunce ought loke nothing hande honorable caſe fayth worlde yet remaining ſeing bloud birthe germayne brought beleue ſhould attempte imagine ſo craftie deuiſes concerning thoſe bandes wyly begy • ed maydenburg haue heard many complaine certen ſtates carefull leaſt remoue campe worke ſome greater miſchief vnderſtode lacke paiment wage flocke together worke oultrage ſending ambaſſadours gouernours cōmaunded thei ſee wyſe mony leuied paie wryting letter alſo duke maurice became ſuertie ſame money owyng ſo ſoldiours may diſcharged bycauſe bounde loue chiefly peace tranquillitie germany nowe therfore loke maner euery moment ſame done ſuppoſe verely ſhal ſlippe awaye without dammage man mutinie trouble appeaſed caſe whan payment made armie diſcharged eaſely perceiued ſome deuiſe hande ſhall alſo take waye whiche haue head preſent nowe touching reportes brought vnto whiche many dede yet doubtfull ful contrarietie al theſe ſuppoſe imagined moſte part ennemies according olde maner lightnes ſpred abrode diſturbe counſell peace germany truſte god ſuche priuie conſpiracies ſhall laſt come lyght haue ende according demerites ſince rendring maydenburge thinges quiet germany prince ſtates ſo louingly obediently demeane ſelues towardes certenly ſee cauſe new mutinie ought imagined pretēded ignoraunt men ought circumſpecte eſpecially time theſe ſturres foreine nation ſuſpicion leaſt daūger neglected againe neyther ſo cleane voyde care diligence wyll let paſſe deaf yeare ſuch thinges reported haue maner place eſpialles inquire euery matter herein ſpare neyther coſte king haue long armes trauell howe make full determinatiō thing vpon euery light reporte ſelfe wyſdome conſider vndiſcrete thing ſhuld nowe leaue counſell vnleſſe ſome extreme neceſſitie vrged wyſe committed conſidering howe great furtheraunce conſiſteth preſence feared leaſt departure counſel ſhould diſperſed alſo religion ſelfe ſhoulde vtterly peryſhe wherin verely bothe common ſaluation men priuate commoditie reſteth conſideryng caſe ſtandeth thus hartely deſyre lordes mentz treuers altering counſell doe yet take iourney lorde collon make ſo great haſte exhort erneſtly perſeuer ſtyll generally require occupie chiefeſt place amōgeſt ſtates empire would helpe one ayde counſell declaring amonges ſelues brotherly loue beneuolence meane tyme wil kepe diligēt watch common wealth muche able polycie power ſeke quenche tyme flambe ſhall haply ariſe intent ciuile euils oppreſſed force increaſed forrein warre may eaſely defended hauing country quiet trāquilitie recouered may altogether applie affaire chriſtian commō wealth yet neuertheleſſe would aduiſe ſuche counſellours officer haue left home prouide thinges nothing chaunce vnloked conferre counſelles ſuch frēdes neighbour truſted wherin may alſo profite thing gladly tumulte thinke wyll may ſo muche ready ſo euer chaunceth ſeing great diſtaunce betwixt v ſhall pleaſure caſe ſhall wryte vnto ſuche thynges hence forth ſhall haue intelligence ſhall ſame whatſoeuer ſhall thinke concerne common wealth wyl let vnderſtande haue oftentimes promyſed ſo wyll dede perfourme defence tuitiō day erle montfort returned trent unto therfore go ambaſſadours wirtemberg declare howe haue brought nothing paſſe hitherto cardinall toletane ſo much fellowes ambaſſadours preſent emperours perſone require yt theyr prince demaundes might heard receiued good aunſwer almoſte diſpaire thynge pourpoſed goe home prince lately commaunded caſe longe delayed ambaſſadour alſo straſburge declared commiſſion erle monfort done pictaue alſo toke copie commiſſion diuines diſputations ceaſed father aſſembled dayly ſearching opiniōs might make decree ſhewed contrie germany choſen ſame thre biſhops collō uienne nūburg iulius pſſugius whileſt occupied thoſe affaire prepared al thing ye next ſitting vii day ianuary come thither ambaſſadours duke maurice whome emperour written litle wuolfie coler leonard badehorne ciuilian coming byſhops whome ſpake well chered vp chiefly emperours ambaſſadours thought nowe doubte duke maurice whiche followed peaceable wayes thyrde daye came declare meſſage thābaſſad du maurice come counſell emperours ambaſſadours firſt recite howe diuines ſhould come ſufficiently aſſured counſell cauſe prynce ſende man dede right wel affected towardes common wealth deſyreth much ſome waye concorde might foūd therfore fully reſolued ſende owne ſuche good men louers concorde doubteth diuerſe others wyll lykewyſe ſame ſame may done theſe requeſtes firſt thoſe ſhall come may haue ſaufeconduicte according fourme decree baſill bohemers aſſured tymes paſt ſurceaſe action meane tyme tyll come ſhal come fourmer actes may retracted daie appointed ſeſſion adiourned may counſell wherin nation people may aſſemble byſhop rome take vpō hym authoritie preſident ſubmitte hym ſelfe counſell releaſe byſhops othe men voyces counſell may free iudgementes intangled whiche thynges alſo whan ſhall thinke good wyll declare large aſſemble father make requeſte ſome thing may done ſo ſhortly may diuines haue already taken iourney come leaſt fortie myles waye tary nowe tyll called tenth daye ianuary ſayed howe ryght glad comming alſo woulde preferre theſe thynges vnto father ſignified alſo whole matter emperour gratifie duke maurice aduiſe counſell father ſhould maurice feared emperour aunſwere myldly frendly requeſtes moreouer duke wirtemburge heard certentie knewe duke maurice ſent thyther commaū ded ambaſſadours tary tyll next ſeſſions exhibite theyr wrytinge ſame ſent alſo wrytinge howbeit brief ſame tenure maner requeſt duke maurice wylled put vp alſo confeſſion doctrine ambaſſadour straſburge commaunded attende till either duke maurice men came certenly knowē wold come whan come therfore communicateth cauſe ambaſſade ſheweth thinges ſtode vnderſtandeth againe commiſſion ſame ambaſſadours wirtemberg caſe comen al notwithſtanding long came followed vrged chiefly therfore intreated diligently thre archbyſhops electours cardinall trent greatfrende duke maurice emperours ambaſſadours common wealth ſake would wylling ſelues alſo perſwade reſt father herein none ambaſſadours would go legate creſcentius fellowes legate leaſt thei ſhould appere attribute thing bycauſe ſent followe emperours mynde ſatiſfie decre empire therfore vſed ambaſſadours high chief magiſtrate interceſſours preſent time came newes ye within day duke maurice wold come emperour whiche made al men better hope great deale willing moneth beheaded lōdon ye duke somerſet vncle ſaid king englande certē frendes michel stanope ſir duke somerſet beheaded rafe fane ſir myles partrich knightes ſome reported ſame done procurement duke northumberland wittier ſorte began euen feare good king whome kinſfolkes diſpatched waye ſawe open daunger treaſon duke somerſet dead duke northumberland put king newe chamberlaines amonges ſonnes kinſmen whan daye next ſeſſion hand emperours oratours ſending thambaſſadours duke maurice declare thei haue done father cauſe thei haue obteined ſaufeconduict ſuch wyſhed alſo thaction may diſcontinued differred vntill come may preſent ſame al nation people aſſembled lieth father perfourme counſel lawfully ſōmoned although al mē come yet ſtandeth neuertheleſſe ful ſtrength dignitie ſuche decree made ſhould reuoked let conſider ſelues howe vndecent thing belongeth reproche infamie ſo great aſſemblie let diuines come ſhall matter hearde alſo intreated moſte gently thyng offende thē done without reaſon ſee ſelues ouermuche aggrauated haue free libertie departe whan wyl deſyre earneſtly would geue ſome thynge tyme couet haue thynges graunted thē one moment whan ſhall come action may dyuerſe thinges occaſion obteyned whiche appeare nowe harde father ſaye deſyrous reformation wyll fayle doe dutie longe ſore diuines comming vnto whome wyll ſhewe good wil fidelitie haue thynges propoūde great importaunce deſyre may begynne intent occaſion may come forth alſo whiche requyre moreouer touchyng ſubmiſſion byſhop rome deſyre ſome thyng qualifie father ſee perceyue ſom high dignitie may reprehended ought dede redreſſed yet muſt procede ſome fine deuiſe emperours mynde wyll thinges ſhould ritely lawfully done finde daily experience howe fayre diſſemblingly muſt treate byſhops legate verely muſt vſe ſingular dexteritie deale policie wherfore let nowe contente ſelues ſuche thinges graūted ſurely without great trauell obteyned fynde meanes diuines may make haſte neyther publique priuate cauſe omitte parte dutie whan come hytherto deliuer vnto ſaufeconduicte whiche byd reade ſende againe xxii daye ianuary thus ſending awaye ſelfe ſame momente maurice ambaſſad ſent awaye call ambaſſadours duke wirtemberge firſt make excuſe touching fourmer tyme moſte weightie affaire father nowe haue anythyng doe ready theſame ſayd haue long tyme nowe thinges propounde hearde ſpede aſſone dimiſſed ſende ambaſſadour straſburge ſpeake ſame effecte declared briefly wherfore ſent reaſon coletane vnto whome ſpoken preſent ſayde nothing el ſaye loked dayly letter frō home immediatly duke maurice ambaſſadours come commaunded wryte home cōmiſſion attende senate would haue done howebeit required thē meane tyme thoſe matter whiche ambaſſadours duke maurice preferred vnto would ſo vſe ſelues myght come forthwith open treatie ſaide againe howe certen thinges ambaſſadours duke maurice duke wirtemberge whan thing ſhalbe done let hym vnderſtāde may ſignifie ſame citezens verely greatly wyſhe concorde emperour alſo applieth whole endeuour ſtudy ſame deſire muche alſo thaction might beginne doubte god wyll aſſiſte moſte honeſt enterpriſe whan done ambaſſadours saxon wirtemberg straſburge hauing cōference together way fourme ſaufe conduicte whiche receiued ſo muche wrytten euery chapter decree baſill ye men might ſee eſpecially ſuche thynges concerned weightie matter hard diſcerne place diſſented whan ſaufecō duict altered therfore peruſed ouer ſtreight waye perceiued chiefeſt place partely altered partly omitted ſaufeconduicte time paſt geuen bohemers theſe thinges amongeſt others ſhuld haue alſo authoritie decide matter al matter cōtrouerſie holy ſcripture order primatiue churche ſuche counſelles interpretours agreable ſcripture ſhould ſtede iudge might vſe owne ſeruice home nothing ſhuld done contēpt reproche doctrine wherof firſt thirde laſte cleane omitted ſecond chiefeſt thing dede ſore altered whiche thinges conſidered ſelues deuiſe new fourme following foteſteppes decree baſil meane tyme toletane ſent ſeruaūt twyſe ye paper fearing appered ouermuch diligēce neuertheles procede laſt whā thing finiſhed duke maurice ambaſſadours come againe vnto toletane comparing thone thother ſhewe lack find therin began ſtomack matter right ſore offended ſhould content ye whiche great labour dilligence obtained ſuche ſhould come aſſured ſufficiently chiefeſt point wherby prouided may ſafely come ſafely goe thinges ſerue nothing purpoſe concerne maner treatie coūſell thing might great deale better determined time diuines preſent make aunſwer may paſſe bōdes cōmiſſion may receiue ſaufeconduicte contrary baſill two dayes father aſſemble houſe byſhops legate themperours ambaſſadours call thambaſſadours duke wirtēberge day ſayd would doe whan brought cōmaunded declare meſſage ſhewed cōmiſſion made brief preface bring forth confeſſion doctrine written deliuer ſcribe counſel maner ſaid alſo diuines ſhould come prince whiche ſhould treate thing aboundantly howbeit vpō theſe cōditions firſt yt cōſent party conueniēt iudges ſhuld choſen ſhuld heare diuines reaſon iudge vprightly matter yt cōtrouerſie aſmuch prince perceiueth yt doctrine diuines doth ye moſt part diſagre ye doctrine ye biſhop rome biſhops whiche ar many wayes boūd thinketh vnreaſonable againſt al right ſuſteine ye parſone either plaintife defendāt ſhuld chalenge thē ſelues thauthoritie iudgement secondly decreed thaſſembles thempire auſpurg counſel ſhuld continued althinges godly rightly done euermore ſo takē prince ſuch thinges decreed counſel fourmer yeares ought haue force law thinges ſhould repeted frō beginning right reaſon whan two men go lawe thing whiche decreed whan one hath iuſt cauſe abſent ſhould taken ferme ſtable moreouer ſeing many dcerees made fourmer alſo ſame counſell contrary holy scripture alſo many olde errours eſtabliſhed prince requireth ſame none authoritie ye al thinges may come dew examinatiō thoſe ſame article cōpriſed writīg exhibited together wt cōfeſſiō doctrine whā done anſwer made father whā ſawe time ſhould ſhew opinion thus dimiſſed theſame daye euening ſent like wiſe thambaſſadours duke maurice whan came recite long oration ye demaundes prince like ſorte late ye franke ſpeache maurice ambaſſad father emperours ambaſſadours ſauing ende pithie wher ſaid moreouer ye ſame ſeruice order vſed popiſh church true religion countrefeated thing ſhadowe religion whan made end thoration anſwered ſelfſame wordes ambaſſadours wirtemberg amongſt thinges greued thē moſte yt religion deſcribed ſo vile contēptuouſe name afterward well knowen thambaſſadours intended haue vttered meſſage openly publique aſſize auoyde knew certenly wolde heard priuatly either muſt thei nedes el leaue al ye cōmon treatie brought thē confeſſion doctrine written philip melanchthon ſhowed cōmaundemēt thing know cauſe thei preſent ſame next day ye xxv ianuary thopenſaſſions biſhops legate brought church ye pompe reherſed nōber ſoldiours much augmēted alſo greater reſort people ſōdry place ſuppoſed treatie theſame day ſhuld notable whan maſſe ceremony fully finiſhed recited pulpit proteſtātes cauſe whole matter ſhould differred till xix daye marche whiche day good time propound matter frendly graūted thē counſel truſteth wil come obūinatly impugne catholique faithe zeale knowe truth fine admitte obeie decree ye churche ſchole correction haue ouer larger ſaufeconduicte ſo lack founde furthermore next ſitting treatie ſhalbe sacramēt matrimonie third daye whan nothing came forthe al ambaſſadours duke maurice fellowes demaunded fraunces toletane chaunced dine day copie theſame ſaufecōduict ſpoken openly made gentle anſwer whā thre day paſt thambaſſadour straſburg ye requeſt reſidue goeth vnto pictaue cōplaineth ſixt daye wherin heare nothing longer delay ſaufeconduicte ſufficient nowe time tracted certenly diuines wil come ſuche time magiſtrates contented ſaufeconduicte ſaide howe faulte marueiled toletane thus differred chiefeſt place amongeſt would go talke doubted matter ſhould diſpatched ye ſame day thing whiche ſhould learne wolde ſhe thus went laſt daye ſauing one ianuary within fewe houres al thambaſſadours commaunded come houſe toletane deliuered euery copie ſaufecōduicte ſigned vnderneth ſcribes counſell alſo ye earle monfort pictaue beginneth talke firſt dede excuſeth delay made ſpeaking much zeale great good wyll emperour admoniſhed diuines might come poſſible diligence whiche truſted doubtles would hauing receiued ſaufeconduict go apart reade ambaſſadours ye proteſt deluded place whiche amended ſeſſions finde nothing altered wherfore come againe complayne therof ſhe lacke finde euery point thambaſſadours saxon deſire alſo know anſwere father haue made requeſtes theſame wirtemberge againe ſpeaketh pictaue touching ſaufe conduicte anſwereth deſire men might haue authoritie decide ſame ouertimely whan diuines preſent ye worke ſelfe many thinges may fortune vpon occaſions graunted whiche nowe refuſed would holy ſcripture ſhoulde iudge euery controuerſie man againſt whan arriſeth ſtrife thinterpretation ſcriptur vnto ſhuld credit geuen ſoner coūſel scripture dome thīg without life alſo politike lawes muche papiſtes eſteme scripture mouth iudge muſt applied therunto may wel perceiued mout verely voice councell maner hath bene alwayes obſerued ſince apoſtles time whanſoeuer aroſe doubtful matter would vſe owne ſeruice home indede openly graūted thē neither yet prohibited leaſt thing ſhould contemptuouſly done againſt religion doctrine nede feare ſhould ſtraightly prohibited emperour wold haue ſo father alſo hate ſuche intēperauncie ſeing thaſſemblie made peace vnitie immodeſte opprobrius wordes ſhall vnpuniſhed unto ther requeſts make maner lyke aunſwere lately ſitting al treatie diſterred cauſe vntill tyme decree made ſhould againe repeted pray diſgrace ſo many notable men promyſe become ſuerties yt whan diuines ſhal come ſhal heard althinges would haue biſhop rome brought ſubiection releaſed aſmuche ſame belongeth properly hymſelfe ye father determine nothing matter declared concerning requeſtes thambaſſadours wirtemberge ſo muche ſame ſorte iudgement father like alſo wherfore intreate would ſo ſmall matter ſuffer occaſion ſo long wyſhed accompliſhyng moſte holy thyng letted diſpointed wherof doubtles nation europe ſhall receiue fruite would indeuoure perſwade magiſtrates diuines might come ſpede thei time worke greater benefite common wealth whan ambaſſadours againe replied vrged thing chiefly againſt reaſon ſuche ſuſteyne parte ſuite ſhould iudge matter controuerſie length departe thus receiue copie ſaufecōduite vpō cōdition ſende ſame magiſtrates whiche would immediatly expedition neither wyl faile matter ſo much lieth nother diſpaire alſo cōming thambaſſadours duke maurice ſende copie hand ſo thambaſſadour straſburge wirtemberge carie copie going home firſte daye february prince permiſſion long ſent others hereafter ſhall heare litle tyme came diuines duke maurice norinberge amongeſt malanchthon diuines come norinberge commaunded remaine tyll ambaſſadours ſent ſaufeconduict trente fewe dayes come thither forbidden goe attende til know prince ſhal make wt emperour vnto whome ſaid ſhould go whan decree confirmed counſell houſe theames wont deliuered diuines next diſputation ſhewed ſynce laſt ſitting cleane omitted wherof reported cauſes mo thā one yet ſayde commonly done proteſtantes ſake beginning february whan one duke maurice ambaſſadours ambaſſadour straſburge went forth pleaſure ſee hether part italy ueniſe whiche ſene italy treated emperours ambaſſadours ſo much ſuppoſed diuines would come right ſhortly whiche opinion auſpurg ye whole intreatie might differred vntill father would patiently beare ſo ſmal delay tharchebiſhop treuers black freer ambroſe pelarge certen holy day whiche vii february expounding yt place goſpel cockel mixed yt wheate ſaid amonges thing bitternes freer pelarge againg yt proteſtauntes thyl cockel muſt deſtroyed ſorte maner ſo yt ſame might done without loſſe wheate appliyng ſermon heretikes whiche ſignified worde cockell reported thambaſſadour duke maurice rayled bitterly againſt heretikes ſaid alſo faith promeſſe kepte haply made therfore made diligēt inquiſitiō goeth cardinal trent authoritie emperours ambaſſadours complaineth heard freer called confeſſed dede ſpake heretikes generally ſhould diſtroyed fyre ſworde hanging meane caſe ſame may done without great hynderaūce publique commotion concerning promeſſe kepte within ſpoken neuer worde ſo done ſhould haue incurred penaltie loſyng lyfe breakyng decre counſell call ambaſſadour reciting freers purgation bid hym loke nothyng father fidelitie vpryght dealing thyng alſo blabbed lyghtly whiche neuer theleſſe ſtraytely prohibited ought moued therewith whether freer belied knowe certenly ſome auditours beinge demaunded duke maurice letter ambaſſadours ſayde ſame thynge theſe day brought thither yt letter duke maurice dated laſt ianuary ſignified ambaſſadors ſuch thinges obteined father hitherto ſhould vrge together preparing ſelf go ſhortly emperor amongs thinges treat alſo theſe matter preſently alſo diuines ſhould come moreouer ambaſſadors diuines certain prince city amonges named duke pomeranes coſins copy letter thone thambaſſadors felowe yet retourned iourney ſendeth cardinall trent brixna lately gon thither becauſe moſt ſeruiceable emperor alſo loued duke moris reaſon muche familiarity dearely well chiefly wiſhed counſel might procede toke heauely diſſention growing wherof ther much talk cauſe thambaſſador ſent theſe letter wherwith knew ſhould comforted verely receiued thoſe letter doubted length began take comforte hope well wrote againe thambaſſador ſo ſone duke moris ſhall come inſprucke go thither immediatly great way reaſon amity frendſhip betwene thoughte could perſwade peaceable way theſe letter ſubſcribed wyth duke moris hand alſo annexed letter theyr commiſſion exhibite nede required ſame neglected long tharchbiſhop treuers refreſh ſelf departeth trent homeward xvi day february ſaid themperor geuen leaue ſo ſone might recouer health ſhould come thither yet left frier pelarge ther might preſent al action tharchbiſhops mentz collon brought goinge mile two way tourned lefthande toke iourny inſprucke wher themperor lay shortly many began mutter counſell ſhoulde proroged duke moris making league frēch brute war againſt themperor king prepared warre vpon themperor rumour great firſt increaſed daily ſecreatly one ſent trent themperor vnderſtād pleaſure alſo came one thither themperor thinges kept cloſe ſeconde daye marche whiche aſhewedenſday biſhop rome legate ſettinge vp paper churche pardon walles whiche call indulgence pardones graunteth remiſſion ſinnes al men generall ſpecially biſhops ambaſſadoures deuines whiche either haue confeſſe ſinnes time preſcribed go certaine church trent day appoynted ſaying fiue pater noſters fiue aue mary praiers pray god concord prince conſent vnity church lucky ſucceſſe counſell ſo great benefit geuen high biſhop iuly third careful health ſoules yt men may wel enioy ſame trent rome wherfore many ran daily church biſhops others eſpecially spaniardes obſeruing difference day attributed religion one le time great taciturnitye ſaide ambaſſadoure straſburge inquired themperors ambaſſador pictaue ſtate thinges ſaid brute went counſel ſhoulde proroged vntrue themperor would haue wiſe proceade continue action alſo ther hath nothing bene done late theyr cauſe whiche haue put father hope comming diuines beginning marche whan duke moris aboute thend february called backe deuines norinberge brute raiſed ſhould come themperor whē paſſed certain way iourny retourneth home beginneth take munſters nexte boke ſhalbe recited theſe thing wer knowen ſondry meſſagers came daily one another matter doubt archbiſhops mentz colon vnto whome came lately great plenty vitaile nether partes germany prepared thē ſelues horſbacke great expedition eleuenth day march depart dawning day wheras ouer nighte biſhops rome legate accompanied reſidue biſhops italy spaine came vnto bid farewel ſame day came thither new ambaſſadours duke new ambaſſadors wirtēberge wirtemberge werner munchinge hierome gerarde ciuilian go next day themperors ambaſſadoures ſhewing commiſſion wryting deſyre haue anſwer theyr prince demaunds exhibited father xxiiii ianuary ſay moreouer deuines wil ther within theſe dais declare large confeſſion doctrine yt lately put vp whole aſſembly wherat meruailed greatly know cauſe except wer one thē made thing ready take iourny purpoſed go home neceſſity muſt tary ther ful ſore againſt anſwered muſt deuiſe haue conference matter father loke ſhall hear let vnderſtand meane tune duke moris ambaſſadors great diſtres carefulnes wer ſuppoſed haue handled matter craftely haue bene priuy prince doings haue plaid together diſſemblers againe affirmed neither knew thing home yet receiued letter thence knew way retourne home daunger ſo muche ſawe longer taried daunger xiii day march depart priuely coulde aſſone day apeared ſpeding haſtly brirna axe thaduiſe cardinall trent beſt done laſt thone thambaſſadors came trent made longe abode iuſpruck prince name ye reſt made interceſſion themperor lātzgraue hauing firſt receiued except diſceiued ſafe conduit came inſprucke made purgation themperors counſel proueth made priuy war ſuch ſort credit thēce goeth ſtraight home thother taking iourny carnia returneth saxonie tharchbiſhops mentz collon approched nere vnto inſpruck honorably receiued ſuch themperor ſent mete amonges biſhop arras talking long much emperor alone ſpede thē iourny matter required haſt vi day thambaſſadors duke moris diuines wyrtemberge departed trent came thither iiii diuines duke lirtemberge wherof brentius one ii straſburge wherfore thambaſſadors immediatly repair earle monfort name diuines vnto cummen praye ſo deuiſe fellowes father may anſwer theyr demaundes action may begin next day xix march appoynted open ſeſſions ſaid father aſſēble houſe biſhops legate thambaſſador kinge portugall lately come thither ſhewed cōmiſſion ſolemne manner receiued admitted father done cōmon ſeſſion adiourned firſt may thing ther none done theſe thinges wrought priuatelye duke wirtemberge confeſſion duke wirtemberge cauſed yt meane time ye confeſſion doctrin ambaſſadors exhibited ſetforth print wherof firſt thambaſſa alſo diuines brought certain copy wherof though many ſight yet great deale moe wanted biſhoppes legate reſerued ſelf wryting openly exhibited xxiiii day ianuary would hardly ſuffer read thing firſte knowen ſo much whan commen forth printe diuers biſhops italy spain diuines ſought diligētly althoughe perauenture one intente legate creſcentius taking ſame diſpleaſauntly blamed ſore certain learned phiſition trent hadde ſowen abrode ſuche kinde bokes alſo thearle mōfort diſſembling matter one whit ſpake ſuch ſort though tranſgreſſed condition ſafeconduit ſaid ſuch openly aſſured daunger oughte alſo eſchue occaſion offence two day priuate treaty legate houſe pictaue ſheweth ambaſſador straſburge night whē reaſoned together certaine houres treatye commenced caſe would haue thing propounded father fellowes wold fail herein alſo appoynteth hour wherfore next day xxii march thambaſſadors duke wirtemberge straſburge reſort houſe toletane whan pictaue begon talk thambaſſadors wirtemberge ſaid deſire ſame fyrſt cōming namelye might haue anſwer demaunds long ſince exhibited thing done may better procede vnto reſt wher many word fro appeared euidently ſtick whole treaty ſhoulde let thereby ambaſſadors wer commaunded make recitall cā obtaine ſuch thinges required yet thintent may appeare knowen howe greatly deſyrous theyr prince peace concorde againe treatye matter ſhoulde longer delaied moreouer obey emperoure fulfill decre thempire contente admit diuines diſputation preſēt prince name howbe vppon condicion graunte part theyr right hereby ſuch thinges may remain ſafe whole vnto theyrs agreable lawes cuſtomes decree thaſſemble auſpurge whan pronounced forme proteſtation deliuer vnto wryting depart place whan called againe others commend ſay perceiue rightwell wholy bent concorde ſeing ſo next conſultation ſay concerning manner treaty deſyre know opiniō touching ſame thambaſſadors go ſide conſulted matter declare vnto haue found two wais wit ether deuines may hard touching decree doctrin made counſell el confeſſion doctrin preſented father alſo ſetforth print may laid forth amonges euery chapter therof decided ordre theyr diuines commen intent yt may large erpound declare doctrin compriſed boke anſwer ſuch impugne ſame ſemeth vnto readieſt way know way better alſo thambaſſador straſburge ſaid magiſtrates city red ſame wryting doctrine wirtemberge approue profeſſe ſame ſent diuines thither whiche ſhould ioyne ſelues confeſſion diuines wirtemberge ſhould defend ſame commaunded ſhew confirme name city fellowes wherunto anſweared wer ſo forward wrought ſo plainlye ſincerely alſo ſtate straſburge city ther vnto annexed haue ioyned ſelues ſame doctrine right glad geue harty thankes withall expedition wil ſignify ſame themperor doubtinge deſirous hear touching treaty deuines manner diſputing deuiſed ſhortly aduertiſe thopinion father therin dais wher kept ſilence biſhop numburge departed thence reſidue alſo germane biſhops wer ii remaind ſaid prepare ſelues take iourney thambaſſadors went monfort heare father anſwered thing nothing el ſay father yet made none anſwere whan mention made biſhops departing ſaid howe biſhop numburge went themperoure ther ſhould come certain commiſſioners thither saxonie treat peace duke moris ſo much yt ſame country one principall beinge hereunto requeſted could ſay nay reſidue ſaid knew nothing ſo much emperour deſyred ſo greatly counſell might procede ſelues alſo applied hereunto theyr wordes dedes leaſt men ſhould diſpair thinge nexte day xxvii day march thambaſſador straſburge goeth themperoures orator pictaue tolde howe ſtate buſines ſuche muſte return home therefore deſired knowe ſhoulde reporte home deuines matter occaſion entred againe talke manner treaty ſhould affirmed verely procede thordre lately preſcribed might conueniently hand maſſe thinge ſhould next diſcuſſed matter ſemed vnto mete firſt diſcided come vnto ye reſt ſaith ſpeaketh ſelfe priuately fellowes haue ſo willed thother inferreth againe howe like deuines haue accuſtomed debate thinges beginning ordre creation fall man originall ſinne terme iuſtification faith workes finally sacrament ſo ought nowe alſo permitted vſe ſame ordre moreouer ſame daye wherein deliuered ſafeconduite end ianuary theyr promiſe deuines ſhould hard matter wher ought perſeuer ſubuert altare nature thinges vnleſſe former thinges well determined diſceptation laſt depend firſte purpoſe could agre thinge betwene ſelues anſwereth touching iourney may graunted themperor hath commaunded ſuffer mā depart much talcke alledgeth hathe whatſoeuer alſo remaineth ſhoulde done diuines commiſſion wryting ſame biddeth go thearle monfort ſhew letter commiſſion verye gently biddeth farewell wiſheth wel retourne whan thearle montfort ſene commiſſion ſaid dede would buſineſſe ſo required yt might longer remain ſo much time muſt ſerued againſt ſo letteth frendly depart next daye whan ready depart themperors ambaſſadours ſend thambaſſador straſburge deteyned pictaue beginneth ſpeake wher yeſterday wer agreed might depart haue diligently conſidered thing conferred heades together geue leaue depart nowe matter brought yt paſſe frute time ſpent loked thaction commenced ſo biſhops legate ſickly ſome thinge might determined ſelf ſame day therefore muſte ſtill remain ſhould depart inſtaunt father wold offended know hath ben certain monethes preſent themperours commaundement alſo ſuche man may depart magiſtrate haue ſo commaunded ought exhibite letter ſame thintent mighte excuſe themperor ſaid commaū dement senate owne matter ſo required alledging certain cauſes vnleſſe wer ye ſame ſaid wold ſtirre one fote thauthority senate whych would haue remain ther longer alſo honour requeſt hereunto cauſe ſelf moreouer whiche loueth reaſon ought obtain howbeit ſince deuines commen may much better abſent eſpecially ſeing thing remaineth admitted thaction alſo thambaſſadors wirtemberge aſſiſt deuines cauſe common lately declared ſo matter earneſtly conſtantlye handled poſſible senate ſubſtitute place whō hath ready aduertiſed departure hence ther replieth againe willing leaſt abide ſo long till thaction commenced ſhould hand perchance legate creſcentius recouer health yet ſo folow cauſe felowes commiſſion ſhal execute thing whan could neither excuſing intreating preuaile thing fleeth laſt remeady vntill time purpoſelye reſerued ſaid others wer proteſtants might lawfully theyr ſafeconduit depart thence time laſt ſaith toletane ſo dede neither let againſt may depart howbeit could declare themperor hath commaunded alſo ſelues would haue done thus therfore departing commendeth vnto cauſe deuines alſo father diſſention amonges ſelues bent al one way spaniard neapolitan siciliās whoſoeuer wer themperors part chiefly spaniardes themperors ambaſſadors wer importune thaction might continued biſhop rome client ſuppoſed spaniard wēt reformation court rome ſought find ſome let delay ſo much chiefeſt biſhops germany reaſon ciuill tumult wer departed ready loked alſo ſame occaſion ſo much rather daily letter meſſagers reported duke moris confederats already armure french kinge alſo cardinall tournon treated diligentlye biſhop rome peace toke effect much yt french king war time themperor man doubted ſake alſo counſel ſhould diſſolued wherfore themperors ambaſſadors knew feared theſe thing laboured chiefly thing moſt coueted might bring paſſe thambaſſadors proteſtantes thys little perceiued afterward certenly knowen blaſphe gray frier thend march certaine graye frier expounded epiſtle paule romaine great audience oftētimes octaſion railed bitterlly againſt luther felowes waded ſo far ſaid ſuch knowledge chriſt yet liued honeſtly haue obteined ſaluatiō alſo meaning saint paule ſecond chapiter foreſaid epiſtle whan certain deuines proteſtants heard ſpeke opēly deliberatiō takē cōmon aſſent write requeſtes proteſtantes deuines themperors ambaſſadors laſt day marche declaring intent ſent verely expound defend confeſſion doctrine exhibited complain ther none action commenced decree counſel already made haue manner nothing el bitter reproch deteſtinge doctrin profeſſe alſo daye gray frier ſpake many abſurd thing openly contrary conſent church expoſition thold doctor alſo poured great aboundaunce railing word againſt doctrin church many ſay dothe theſe thing againſt wil ye father yet ſe wt aſſent teacheth hard thonly cauſe wer ſent hither might verely ſpectakle laughing ſtock others ſhould compelled hear daily thiniuries reproches theyr doctrin ther doubtles nede haue taken iourney hand theſe thing might haue ben declared wryting wherfore earneſtly require according office authority would bring paſſe father would laſt declare lack find confeſſion exhibited may againe alſo openly hard matter thoſe letter thambaſſadors receiue gētly ſay glad alſo haue occaſion miniſtred vrge matter thintent legate creſcentius refuſe may treat fellowes father alſo ſame frier left reading excuſing matter ſickneſſe firſt day aprill duke moris league frends laid ſiege duke moris taketh auſpurge cō poſition city auſpurge toke third day compoſition boke foloweth ſhalbe declared v day aprill ambaſſadors duke wirtemberge beinge ſent houſe toletane came brought cō maunded two diuines brentius ihon marpache straſburge pictaue beginneth declare firſt owne good zeale legate ſickneſſe vnleſſe preſent neither fellowes yet father wold thing fault hath bene procede ſheweth alſo hereafter omit manner diligence hereof maketh proteſtation thothers whan conſulted ſay know rightwell good diligence howbeit loked certain anſwer demaundes might haue ſignified magiſtrates ſith matter thus muſt take coū ſel beſt ſelues ſaid againe matter brought poynt neither ought ſo taken though ther wer hope action remaining aduertiſe magiſtrates ſignify vnto caſe thing ſtand wel done according duty nether doubt ſhal hear therof wil maruel long delay ſurceaſing take alſo euill part howbeit requireth take paciently tediouſneſſe day meane time trauell may haue direct anſwer unto ſay gladly ſakes acconſent next day great expedition came meſſagers letter auſpurge taken howe prince marched ſtraightway toward thalpes ſtop wais paſſages wherefore commaunded take armure county tiroll bandes ſoldiors hired commaunded repair inſprucke wer biſhops germanye father fle frō trent departed thence ther remained deputy biſhops spier manſter whan theſe newes broughte immediatly biſhops italy flee carying baggage riuer atheſis wherfore thambaſſadors wirtemberge herewith moued time accord councell nowe ſlipped away come themperors orator ſhew thē cauſe purpoſe go home diuines alſo dede firſt ſore againſt ſay howe may aſſente therunto except themperors pleaſure knowne might preuaile require haue cauſes departing deliuered writing ſigned hand thintent may make excuſe themperor father pictaue demaunded alſo haply theyr departure father ſhall proceade thaction ſhall diuines ſay wherunto thambaſſadors conferring diuines vppon matter ſay wil make anſwer viii day aprill early morning deliuer vnto wrytinge ſame recite time confeſſion doctrine anſwer proteſtantes ambaſſadors exhibited wherfore diuines came haue vain ſollicited hitherto might receiue anſwer prince demaundes vnto day ther appeared hope action ſhould alſo ther war raiſed ſo yt biſhops germany alſo italy depart ſtates ſo intangled trouble loke nothing preſent moreouer biſhops germany abſente perauenture expediente anye progreſſe ſhoulde made time hereafter chance wherin buſines may treated wel ordrely ſuppoſe prince wanting diuines moreouer thinke thus ther many decree made alſo former counſel might wel reproued caſe lawfully hard father procede herein thought doings wil like reaſt neuertheleſſe caſe ether decree already made may amended ſuch may hereafter decreed conſonant holy ſcripture ther doubt ſame receiued moſt obedient hart thing vnto doutles moſt ſorowful certain place confeſſion exhibited hath bene declared wryting verely iudge good godly alſo whan time ſhal ſerue declare large pray therfore take good part departure ſay dede might vertue ſafeconduite depart thence time liſt bounden make man priuy ſo much haue manye time proued gentlenes wold omit kind duety thus therfore taking leaue departe aboute none time fewe hour met cardinall trent whiche rode great poſte haſtr brixna trent whan heard wirtemberge inquiring brentius ſpake vnto gaue moſt gentle wordes two day met king ferdinandoes daughter went inſprucke brunecke towne alpes bordering limit uenetians father ſhewed drue one line spaniſh biſhops dede ſemed others moſt diuers mindes counſel trent diligente diuers alſo germanes pretended thoughe thing required much reformation mind yt thought beſt al others ſchole correction maners church ſhould refourmed al ſuperfluous exceſſe ambition diſhoneſt example liuing ſhuld taken away euery man reſident church eche man ſhuld haue one benefice man permitted haue mo furthermore purpoſed alſo include within certain limites power refourmation papiſtes biſhop rome attribute vnto court ſo great authority ouer realmes theſe ſuch like thinges compriſe word reformation thoſe thinges acknowledge belong proprely vnto touching religion doctrin acknowne none error yea decreed church erre counſels could erre thought verely aduerſaries would fine reuolt obey counſel apeareth manifeſtly epiſtle written french king form ſafeconduit thing alſo increaſed hope opinion iudged profeſſors doctrine leaſt ſo many dead baniſhed ſpoken sweuia alſo common amonges whatſoeuer concerned religion ſhould within fewe monethes determined chief article ther remained two lordes ſupper matrimony article doctrine ready diſcuſſed father baſill attribute whole iudgement holy ſcripture wrytinges agreable ye counſel baſil purer thē trēt ſame theſe men would iudges ſelues expoundinge ſcripture neither woulde admit place decree baſill thambaſſadors reſtored chaunginge wordes decre determined alſo follow tradition thapoſtles euerye doubtfull matter whanſoeuer deſtitute ſcripture boſted ſo lefte thapoſtles deliuered hande hande diſputations deuines oft time noted cauſed alſo ambaſſadors whan receiued ſafeconduit themperors oratoures thend ianuary proteſt tradition thapoſtles vnderſtode thoſe wrytinges annexed newe teſtament ſtory foure euangeliſtes ſhewed firſt maye appoynted daye ſeſſion laſt ſeſſion yt coū ſell father remained diſpair thing aſſemble together diſcord kinges prince proroge counſell ſpace two yeares longer caſe diſſention appeaſed xxix day aprill nowe biſhop rome agreed french king day themperors ambaſſadors depart thence alſo legate frenche kinge hathe peace ye pope rome creſcētius deteined ſickneſſe abode ſtill feared viſion night ſaid fel ſicke began diſpair alſo life notwithſtanding frends alſo phiſitians comforte neither diſceiued iudgement diſeaſe increaſing died uerona thend coūſel right ſtoutly renued thought ende counſel trent verely reſtore romiſh doctrine ſhortly eſtabliſhe ſame beſides legate rome cardinall trent ther wer preſēt lxii biſhops wherof viii wer germanes fiue twenty spaniardes two sardinia four sicilie one hō gary biſhop agria reaſt italy diuines xlii xix spaniard germany flaunders death pope legate xii occaſion legate creſcentius fel ſicke purpoſed haue ſpoken ſome ſuſpicion might deuiſed mallice much frendes thoſe family went comfort whan laye ſicke thus report thought mete adde ſame xxv day march ben much occupied wryting letter biſhop rome continued trauel til night whiche time ariſing might refreſh ſelf behold ſaw greate blacke dogge going gliſtring eies eares hanging almoſt ground went ſtraightway ſlipt vnder table aſtonied amaſed whan lēgth cummen againe ſelf calleth vpon ſeruaunts vtter chamber commaunding bringe light beate dogge whan coulde found neither yet next chamber toke great thought fel ſicke ſhewed lay death bed alſo reported haue cried oute manye time ſeruantes ſhould driue dogge came vppon bed xxiiij booke sleidanes commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charies fyfte argument xxiiij booke duke moris publiſheth letter ſtates thempire hinder enterpriſes ſame doth marque albert french kinge alſo publiſheth nammge ſelf protector germany taketh metz lorayne marcheth vp straſborough thence retireth hagenaw whither came vnto ſondry ambaſſadors beſeching ſtay army king retireth armye oute germany duke moris company hauing ſtraites thalpes putteth themperor flighte little enlarged duke saxon publiſhe letter auſpurge whereb yt reſtore miniſters churche preached goſpell whileſt duke moris wente paſſaw treaty peace marque albert practiſeth great cruelty againſte nurinberge conſtraineth make theyr peace vnto meaner prince peace ſondrys thinges declared aſwell letter ambaſſadoures pleaſed certaine condition seine reuolt themperor cometh straſborough goinge beſiege metz laſte aſſemble thempire gouernment warre maidenburge common aſſente emperoure ſtates committed duke moris haue declared warre continuinge ſpace one yeare hauinge armye hys commaundemente began ſeke meanes howe deliuer lantzgraue father lawe ſeinge ſo longe time ſued themperor ſame matter vaine wherefore compelling chattes othe true makinge peace maidenburge ſendinge ambaſſadoures inſprucke former boke mentioned entreth league frenche kinge aſſuraunce made either ſide pledge geuen thoughte good wrytinges ſetforthe declare cauſe warre thentent might win therby good wils many moreouer marque albert brandenburge going priuely fraunce king withdrewe ſelf wholy ſame buſineſſe meane ſeaſon ſouldiours aſwell thoſe defended maidenburge beſeged ſame wintered mulluſie place aboutes muche hurte northuſians herfurd whan themperor demaunded cauſe therof duke moris whole war bene generall anſwered tumult want paiment wage pr •••• ded cauſe wher dede ſerued ſecreatly bounden oth might better perſwade ſelf ſame time ſente ambaſſadoures throughe inſprucke trent whiche might obtaine ſafeconduit diuines ſhould come propound certaine thinges counſel afterward commaunded diuines follow whiche goinge farre norinberge taried loking letter foreſaid ambaſſadours mentioned ſent alſo ambaſſadors emperoure chriſtopher carlebice ulrich mortiſe ſhould tary comming border bauier whoſe aduiſe counſell might vſe treaty furthermore commanded lodging prepared inſpruck ſelf toke iourney whan gone two thre day iourny waye ſending thence inſprucke moſte gentle letter alledging certain cauſe excuſe returneth home thus tracting time whan driuen day day beginning ſpring time hauing called backe men due ſeaſon began take muſters ſoldiors winter time gathered ſecreatly addreſſing letter vnto ye ſtates thempire ſaieth ther nothing world ſo deare concord wiſheth chiefly agrement religion according doctrin prophet apoſtles wherof aduerſaries haue many time put v hope priuately alſo publike decree nothing performed conſtre miſſe thoſe promiſes decree alſo abrogate ſame take cleane awaye alſo haue ſpoken vnto certen vnleſſe followe procedings let truſt greatly leane former promiſes time thoſe promiſes wer made ſtate time wiſe muſt obey el ſuch refuſe muſte puniſhed contented theſe wordes haue ſtirred vp alſo forein king againſt prince ſtate profeſſion haue inuented ſondry cauſes bring hatred whileſt blame v religion certen thing wheras thing ſelf declareth care religion haue alwaies eie throughe thoccaſion diſſention religion might aſpire gouernment theyr craft ſene men whiche vſed mighte wholly rote oute aboliſhe true religion former yeares ſetforth expounded auſpurge matter wherfore haue place exiled preacher miniſters church oute limites thempire tarye neither decree lawfull counſell yet biſhoppes rome neither begin thing execution wherfore althoughe force armes ſhoulde repulſe 〈◊〉 ſeruitude minde conſcience oughte man blame ſo much thing apperteineth god glorye alone auaunce defende worde committeth whole matter vnto pr • yeth god graunt conſtancy true knowledge vntill liues end thing wherof intendeth ſpeake cō cerning lantzgraue father law certainly v yeares ſeconde cauſe war ſince ioachim elector brandenburge put hope themperors name lantzgraue mighte perſwaded come ſubmiſſion humbly craue pardone emperor themperor ſhoulde require beſides conteined pacification conceiued would frendly let depart wheruppon ſent theyr letter geuing faith vnto ſonnes thing chaunced theyr father otherwiſe well would abide ſame fortune therefore came vppon faithe vnto hale aſked emperor pardon afterwardes ſupped duke alba til far night pleaſantly time lantzgraue deteyned priſoner againſt ſidelity would haue returned lodging beyond al men expectation deteined caried priſon wherin hath nowe remained manner fiue whole yeres without exceding great miſery although ſonnes nobilitye ſubiectes haue confirmed pacification albeit ſelf marque brandenburge wuolfgange paulſgraue became ſureties vnles perfourmed couenaunts wold deliuer cuſtody albeit according forme couenaunts mony condemned paid artilerye munition deliuered caſtels fortes raſed henrye duke brunſwicke ſonne ſette libertye letter confederacye exhibited ſo muche nothinge required yet coulde neither ſuite marque brandenburge lamentable teares wife whiche pined deathe ſorowe prayer people interceſſion prince preuaile thinge vnto daye hathe ofttimes ſpoken themperor becauſe diuers men haue ſiniſtrall opinion hath intreated moſt earneſtly haue ſome reſpect honoure eſtimation would graunt benefit elder done vnto progenitor deſerts alſo towardes king fardinando woulde ſette libertye theſe thing could moue nothinge yea conſtrained captife anſwer matter lawe priſon plead cauſe lying fatters done lawe eſpeciallye matter ſo waighty ſpeake nothing meane time ſuſpiciouſly howe raſhly handled matter ſtraunge example ſuch neuer hard germany verely vnder pretence law might little little tourn child theyr landes poſſeſſions bring ſuche diſtres ſhoulde hable maintaine theyr ſtate dignity thinge come paſſe toucheth much reaſon alliaunce hope ſucceſſion hath houſe heſſe thing dede might thought wonder theſe craftes pollicies manifeſt ſight al men whiche doubtles tende vnto ende ſame monarchye hath ben ſo many yeares framinge maye lengthe eſtabliſhed third chiefe poynt concerneth men third cauſe common natiue country germany whoſe ſtate doubtles moſt miſerable contrary lawes couenauntes forain ſouldiours brought within limit thempire whiche haue many yeres ben ſetled euery wher bothe towne country conſumeth men good exerciſe al kind filthy luſt moreouer many time ther new wais inuented get mony auncient liberty diuers way infringed neither ſtate prince electours caſe ſpared thambaſſadors foren king ſory theſe thing loue wealthe germany prohibited come anye publike aſſembles clean againſt manner thempire finally bōdage germany altogether wroughte men maye broughte ſhamefull ſtraight bondage thing doubtles poſterity ofſpring may haue moſte tuſte cauſe deteſt cowardiſe ſlouthfulnes time wherin moſte precious iewell goodly ornament liberty coūtry ſhuld loſt ſeing therefore caſe ſtandeth thus laſte awaked william lantzgraue ſonne phillip whōe iuſt ſorow father miſerye hathe raiſed makinge league french king thenemy ſeketh alſo depriue hath determined deliuerāce lātzgraue duke saxon maintaine honor recouer liberty men attempt matter force armes therfore doth exhort man diſturbe enterpriſe al men profeſſe ſame put good aſſuraunce otherwiſe man one meane aduerſary wil take ennemy iohn albert duke megelburge ſubſcribed alſo ſame letter chiefly preſeruation religion forſomuch duke moris ſaid howe warred ſame cauſe alſo marque albert brā denburge marque albert letter agaynſte emperoure publiſheth wryting manner ſame effecte complaineth liberty germany oppreſſed enē duety ought maintain auaunce ſame ſaithe ther holden counſel wherin aſſembled ſubuert truthe alſo many aſſemblies empire wherof end certaine corrupted bribe faire promiſes mony maye gotten ſome ſubtile fetche heauye burthen germany vtter vndoing germany ſame wrought chiefly cleargy conſiſtory empire ſurmounte nombre matter brought yt paſſe effect al
