counſels dependeth almoſt one mannes pleaſure neither gentleman germaine borne annexed empire great reproche aſſuredlye hinderance germaines ought ſtate weale publike much better call none aſſembles mony ſhoulde frelye franckly geuen whanſoeuer cōmaunded required ſo ſhuld ther loſſe time beſides great charge ſhoulde ſpared ſuche like craft alſo ſeale thempire commen ſtraungers hand foreiners theyr pleaſure abuſe damage germany yet ther man al dare bewail theſe thing vnleſſe wil enter high diſpleaſure nether yet germanes matter ſutes diſpatched moſt lōg delaid ſo much many men complain much ſame ſtate thing ſuch germanes nede learn lāguages caſe ſhould ſelues anye good ſame ſort wher againſt tholde cuſtome germany prohibited man may ſerue anye foreine prince warres proteſtantes reconciled ouer aboue moſt greuous penalty wer conſtramed admit vnworthy condition great ſome mony aroſe proteſtants client ſeruing theyr warres ſame burthen alſo laid vpon ſtates prince nothinge offended thoughe warre bene made common wealth commaūded pay mony recompence charge warres intent verelye yt ther ſhould ſinewes force lefte germany like ſort ciuill controuerſies moſte waighty matter committed publick iudgement thempire vnto commiſſioners may power either eſtabliſh diſplace great prince againe prohibited prince maye ſet owne image coyne newe senator made euery towne empire bondage impoſed manner vppon germanes conſtrained ſuffer forreine ſouldiors country whiche bothe verye much harme bring many men beggery alſo practiſe al kinde arrogancy lechery hath ben hard land ſpared although promiſed better fidelitye ſeruice done themperor howbeit time deteined reaſon warre maidenburge matter common wealth abſent ſoldiors wer brought country notwithſtanding officer deſired much contrary thus certainly prince whiche former war againſt proteſtants preſeruation dignity put great hazarde liues goodes haue receiued goodly recompence boke lewes auila ſetforth ſtory lewes auila proteſtants war matter done ſame war naughty lying fellow whileſt ſpeaketh germany ſo coldly ſo diſdainfullye ſtraungely though ſome barbarous vile nation whoſe originall ſkarcely knowen vnworthineſſe thing ſo much ſame boke printed ſetforth certain eſpeciall priueledge themperor verely many thinges excuſed letter ſent throughout germany ſelf ſame ſong hath ben ſongen many yeres thinges tend hitherto ſay accordinge ſtate time decree muſt altred men muſte obey preſent counſels el ſuffer puniſhment wheras certen prince haue taken armure repulſe ignominye ſeruitude hathe alſo promiſed aide fidelity yea life alſo proteſteth openlye deſireth man aid aduerſaries men woulde endeuoure fellowes defend commen cauſe although many perchaunce followe contrarye parte yet let man promiſe ſelf better thing aduerſary may vanquiſhe ſhall ſtate condition germaines common caſe anye manne beare armure againſte felowes wil perſecute ſword fire goeth brute ſaieth fellowes thoughe wold bring germany forein nation euen turk ſelfe falſe abſurd ſclaunder madneſſe procure ſo greate daunger ſelues theyr countrye vaine alſo diuers report though ſhoulde attempte warre enriche ſelfe hathe ſerued nowe manye yeares emperoure kinge ferdinando hereby hathe ſoughte gaine rather praiſe honor without great loſſe ſubſtaunce hath alſo large offer made contemned thoſe refuſed hathe fixed minde warre wherin liberty former dignity may reſtored common country warre fortune ſame ouermuch authority clergy prohibited holy scripture infringed weakned man ought blame therfore certainly chiefe biſhoppes empire haue bene occaſion al theſe euils yet intent thoſe college founded chiefly nobility ſhoulde diſtroyed vice beinge taken awaye thoſe thinges amended borne maye remaine vocation auaunced alſo wherunto furtherer ſo contente ſuffer ſelues perſwaded otherwiſe enemy king frenche kingsletters fraunce alſo letter ſetforth ſaithe hathe reſpecte chiefly religion eſtabliſhed may profite publike weale chiefly frendes therfore immediately death father reſtored scotlande former dignity renued league swiſſes recouered boloigne broughte againe old inhabiters citezens diſperſed hither thither theyr landes poſſeſſions hathe made peace alſo king england entred perfite amity whileſt occupied theſe matter emperoure ſecreat deuiſes hath imagined many thinges diſtruction oftner hath geuen occaſion warre beit common wealthes ſake priuatelye alſo relieue people would attempt nothing winckinge iniuries gaue minde whollye eſtabliſhmente realme quietneſſe afterward aduerſaries aſcribed certaine timerouſneſſe cowardlineſſe meane ſeaſon broughte vnto greuous complaint prince ſtates germany whiche ſaide occaſion ſought partly religion partlye turkiſhe warre puniſh rebellion bringe bondage craftye counſels diſſention faction mainetained germanye impoueriſhed ſo longer doubted goeth make monarchy ſelfe houſe auſtrich thing verelye conceiued inwarde ſorowe common originall either nation alſo old amity frendſhip euer continued ferme inuiolated ſo long might themperoures crafte policye ſtate ſhould haue alteration germanye loſe liberty perceiueth well damage daunger ſame realme germany fortreſſe ſtrength fraunce alſo whole chriſtian commō welth germanye ye fortreſſe chriſtendoe therfore hath deſired oft earneſt prayer wiſhing either nation force ioyned together might ſo ſtay ſelues ſhould nead afraid man hope thing appeared yet many craued healpe coulde ſee meanes mighte ſuccoure empyre ſo rente torne ſondre conſultation ſo waighey god righteous iudge hath ſhewed goodly way octauian freneſe duke placence parma whome themperour biſhop rome iuly laide waite required aide declaringe al iniuries hathe perſwaded take vppon defence countye mirandula came alſo thoſe complaintes prince ſtates germany required might enter league ſaid howe meanes onlye common wealth mighte reſtored howe iuſte waighty cauſes whiche prince attempte warre recite ſame may vnderſtande theyr owne wrytinges notwithſtanding let euery man way ſelfe whether vnſatiable couetouſneſſe oure aduerſaries dothe geue moſte iuſte occaſion griefe whiche deſtroyinge wealthe empire ſwepe theyr owne coffer treaſury burgonians nowe inuade treuers gelderland wirtemberge coūtryes oppreſſed bi emperoure make inuaſion country deſtroyeth lātzgraues dominion diuers way lyke ſorte themperor excludeth ambaſſadors thaſſemblies empire prohibiteth manne may ſerue foreine warres putteth death noble capitains worthy ſeruiceable men amonges others uogelſperge whoſe execution ſelf beheld auſpurge thintent mighte ſatiſfye bloudye minde mooſte euill example ſhoulde prouoke hyre men greate reward ſlay ſuch ſerue warres aſſuredlye fewe wordes expreſſed craftes oure ennemies vſe ſame iudgemente chamber conſiſtorye empire admitted placed ſuch meanes may bring paſſe obtaine liſte doubtles blame theſe euils imputed thys kinde menne eſpeciallye iudges chamber cauſes verely could deny ye germains requiring aid therfore hath made league yt alſo determined imploy vpon warre force royall parſon neither yet doth looke anye priuate profite gain therby minedeth thinge germany beinge reſtored ihon fridericke duke saxon lantz graue deliuered whome hathe detained priſoners longe vnworthy captiuity maye win praiſe renowne immortall time paſt flamminius deliuering grece bondage neither cauſe man ſhoulde feare anye force violence much attempteth warre liberty wholly endeuoure man hurt vndeſeruedly let truſte therefore promeſſe whiche confirmeth vnto faithfully geue creadit aduerſaries ſay purpoſe afflicte plage cleargy intendeth ſuch matter alſo receiueth al defence tuition ſo annoy yet league frendes libertye recouered put good hope many men letter concord churche ſhall may alſo reſtored lawfull meanes whan ambition priuate lucre farre remoued ſo euer may helpe hereunto gladly theſe thing wherof thought good admoniſh thend may vnderſtand purpoſe wherfore requireth ſo iuſte warre neceſſity attempted wealth germany mā would impeche hinder confederate otherwiſe man ſo cleane voide loue duety oweth country intend make reſiſtaunce wil deſtroy ſword fire albeit ſhal ſo vnwillingly yet ſuch ſhalbe ſame naughty corrupt membre muſt cut reaſt body leaſt hurt infection ſuch ſorte reſtrained harme reſt may know ambaſſador ihon fraxine biſhop bayon hath ſent vnto pleaſure vnto whome praieth geue creadit wrytinge beinge ſet forth print vulgare tonge ouer head bonnet betwene two dagger wrytten ſame badge tharmes liberty liberty vnderneath title kinge named ſelfe reuenger libertye germany prince captiue badge cognoiſaunce many ſay foūd old coynes vſed ſlue iulius ceſar ſaieth themperor aſſigned reward coulde ſlay certaine captaines thus ſtandeth caſe themperor proclamation lately ſetforthe againe wordes mooſte waighty outlawed rinegraue recrode riſeberge scherteline dede ſerued french king haue ſaid appointed foure thouſande crownes rewarde could bring forth either quicke dead furthered cauſe muche whan league made going germany preſted ſouldioures broughte fraunce scherteline dede whan ſued many yeres vaine coulde interceſſion man reconciled themperor king fernando manner conſtrained fled french king theſe letter kinge prince diſpearſed abrode germany raiſed ſome hope manye feare carefulnes duke moris wrought thinge diſſimulation firſt march holdeth aſſemble ſtates dominion amonges thinges propoundeth becauſe ſued lantzgraues ſonnes preſent ſelf may longer ſeke delay diſceine expectatiō therfore wil go vnto kepe faith promeſſe let therfore meane time obey brother auguſt whome hath made deputye abſence let gather force defend country nothing chaunce vnto vnprouided thelector brandenburge preſent treaty ſommoned appeare lantzgraues ſonnes permit ſhoulde next proceſſe appeare diſcharge bond retourneth home duke moris hauing put ordre thinges home duke moris goeth field appoynted certain counſelloures aſſiſte brother auguſte goeth ſmall company thoſe force ſaide country turing marching forth abideth lantzgraues ſonne departed frō home burggraue meyſſen call henry noble houſe plauians chauncelor boheme name king ferdinando treated diligently reconcilemēt lātzgraues ſōne leading forth armye came erlebache eightene daye marche alſo french ambaſſadour fraxine bothe requeſt franckfurt letter amonges thinges receiue garriſon emperours city beit anſwered neither plainlye purpoſelye yet ſo much muſt go forward none thing done ſixt daye ioyneth duke moris commen wyth whole armye thre dayes schwinfurt duke moris declareth vnto king fardinando woulde make interceſſion ſignified ſame plainlye letter ambaſſadoures thoughe authority emperoure treat yea touching deliuery father therfore making priuy french ambaſſador refuſeth condition requeſtes king fardinando ſhould heard thing determined march great expedition roteburge dingelſpelle norling donauerde roteburge marque albert ioyneth ſelfe hys power bothe horſe men fote men whiche waye ſo euerthey wente broughte citezens theyr ſubiection diſplacing thoſe whiche emperoure choſen ordain newe magiſtrates exact alſo mony munition becauſe auſpurge kept great garriſon becauſe ſelfe ſame day certain piece wall rampeare fallen downe marched exceading greate iourneis laſte daye marche reaſted ſo much night ſeaſon came thither firſte daye aprill midday making roades declared ſelues ennemies citye foure enſeignes fotemen ſente peroure townes men fourth day rendred city wer permitted depart ſommoned city high germany amonges alſo norinberge commaund auſpurge thend aprill alſo vrge wuolmes whiche nine mile auſpurge ſhould aide thinges come theyr ſociety aboute time prince salerne occaſion falling oute uiceroy naples reuolteth emperoure prince salerne reuolteth themperor goeth fraunce whileſt theſe thinges done germany frenche kinge marching forth huge army ſurpriſeth tullie uerdome townes thempire border fraunce inuadeth lorayne ſendeth yong prince fraunce aboute nine yeres age though lady dowager mother intreated neuer frenche ſubdueth loraine ſo much contrary promiſeth daughter mariage whileſt king ſelf occupied theſe affaire lieftenaunt conſtable anna memoraunce led uantward ſurpriſeth metz famous city thempire tenthe day aprill whan bothe garriſon within ſmall french men made fair promiſſes ſaide howe kinge made warre maintaine theyr liberty time frenche king went owne pale aboute eighte day marche ſendinge vnto letter meſſagers deſired would prepare vitaile yt might paſſe theyr country armye promiſinge benenolence vſed miniſter cardinall lenoncurt biſhop citye cardinall betraied citye metz ſetforth good zeale senate coneſtable alſo wrote vnto moſte frendlye whan came neare vnto citye force deſired let obteined next day maſter gate al fortification thither came alſo afterwardes kinge ſelfe xviii day aprill remaining four day taken thothe senate people appoynted mounſir gōnorie theyr gouernoure commanded armure deliuered caried one place citye fortified likewiſe doth townes named loraine ſending meſſagers straſburge haganawe place neare biſhoppe straſburge required aided wheate uitaile whan auſpurge taken ſaid thold senate reſtored themperoure diſplaced liberty geuinge voice reſtored alſo people prince contederated marched towarde woulmes refuſed theyr league whan came thither xii day aprill ride aboute citye whan ſhot greate piece damaunde ſatiſfied iniuries done ſumme three hondreth thouſande crownes denied becommed enemy duke moris goinge thence wente lintz towne auſtriche mighte vnderſtande kinge farnando condition peace ſaid emperoures conſent meane intreat peace afterwarde emperoure exhorted letter chiefeſt prince germanye woulde aſſaye quenche fire deuiſe ſome meanes peace whiche woulde againſte diuerſe required aide thei able nothing againſt ſo great power comforting myndes anſwereth hopeth wel treatie peace commenced ſhall haue lucky ſucceſſe neyther faile common weale whan woulmes bene beſeged ſix day prince xix day aprill remoued stocach towne hegouia receiued mony french kinges name thre monethes conuenaunted gamey marchiane frenche pledge deliuered nantoliet died waye prince pledge fraunce germanye pledge whiche gaue frenche kyng chriſtopher duke megelburg philip lantgraues ſonne laſt aprill prince retourne thonaw certen myles beneth woulmes meane ſeaſō marque albert burneth townes village belonging woulmes extorteth money taketh caſtell helfeſteyne ſituated high hill placeth therin garriſon towne giſſing nere vnto whiche thre myles frō woulmes certen village ſame condemneth paye xviii thouſand crownes whā duke maurice come lintz propoundeth deliuering lantgraue father lawe condition peace offered duke moris appeaſing diſſention religion doctrine wel ordering common wealth peace made french kyng fellowe confederate outlawes receiued agayne fauour thoſe ryngrane others named alſo erle hedecke whiche fourmer yeares gaue hym ſelfe tuition duke maurice ſayde howheit emperour appointed rewarde againſt lyfe leaſt ſhould offende duke maurice thought unto theſe demaundes ferdinando maximilian ſonne ſonne lawe albert duke bauier alſo emperours ambaſſadours maketh aunſwere howe emperour content lantgraue ſet lybertie yet ſo warre maye ceaſe immediately touchinge religion common wealth well pleaſed matter determined next conuention german emperour lothe frenche kyng ſhoulde herein compriſed neuertheleſſe duke maurice may knowe ſorte wyl accorded outlawes may alſo taken mercie caſe wyl obeye condition offered emperour moreouer ferdinādo requeſted whan peace concluded duke maurice would helpe hongary ſoldiours ſhould ſlippe away frenche kyng wherunto whan duke maurice aunſwered ſayde could determine nothing without conſent fellowes departed ſo xxvi day may ſhould mete againe paſſawe whiche towne betwene lintz regenſpurge ryuers thonawe oene mete thither ſhould come alſo prince interceſſours deputy maydaye lantgraues ſonne iohn albert duke megelburg leade armie gundelfinge lye eight whole dayes together lokyng duke maurice retourne auſtrich whan come next daye armie munſtred lawginge towne otto henry pauſgraues coūtrie oto henry recouered alſo recouered prouince poſſeſſed emperour expulſed byſhop auſpurge countrie verely otto paulſgraue ioyned hym ſelfe vnto league thence goe towarde alpes chaunced ſame tyme kyng ferdinando obteyned truce whiche beginning xxvi daye may ſhould ende eight daye iune meane tyme themperour leuied power fote alpes whiche aſſembled towne rwe hurly burly byſhop auſpurge cardinall ryche nowe ſuſteyned great loſſe ſayde went rome myght obteyne byſhop new promotion benefice wherwith might fill vp thoſe ſinkes agayne iudges chamber imperial flie away spiers iudges chamber ſlie frenche king prince forſaide wrytinges ſignified plainly diſpleaſure aſcribed thē maner blame trouble frenche king came armie ye border loraine saberne third day may foure myles straſburg town belonging biſhop requeſted straſburg ayde armie thinges neceſſary whiche cauſe ambaſſadours ſent vnto sarburg ſeuen myles straſburg whiche ſhould offer certen quantitie wheate wyne thoſe peter sturmie fridericke goteſſeme iohn sleidane coneſtable accompted nothynge whiche offered albeit ambaſſadours departed hym ſuche ſorte would aduertyſe senate make reporte vnto hym yet ſente nexte daye two gentleman ſpedy aunſwere ſpeakyng muche kynges great good wyll zeale towardes germany alſo intent kyng moued warre verely might reſtore libertie germany oppreſſed requeſt ſo much ſoldiours nede many thinges might bie ſame citie artificer might ſuffered bryng forth ware ſel within campe wherunto senate made anſwere ſuche matter weightie importaunce nothing wont determined conſent whole ſtate whan matter ſhalbe debated wyll ſende agayne ambaſſadours declare mynde whan thus ſent away next daye ye ſame ambaſſadours ſent campe saberne whan heard ſpeake offered ſome thā alſo declared cauſes ſoldiours might permitted come within citie coneſtable began ſpeake diſpleaſauntly makyng compariſon coneſtable chideth wt straſh partiall iudges kynges benefites alſo emperours iniuries gaue ſharpe language concluſion talke nexte daye ſhoulde heare kyng hym ſelfe ſpeake whiche would affirme al nowe ſayde morrowe ambaſſadours ſent kyng whome cardinal loraine duke uandome coneſtable reporte vnto hym talke haue coneſtable two ſeuerall time offer many raſers otes thei wheate alſo ſome wyne beſeching king olde amitie ye kinges fraunce haue ſtate straſburge alſo owne humanitie would take good parte offer haue great force ſoldiours within citie great nomber people alſo fled thither countrie ſo citie ſpare corne haue theyr prouiſion kyng fyrſt conferred counſell began ſelfe declare cauſe came germany ſelfe ſame effect coneſtable daye saying vitayle moſte neceſſary denied man would paye ſame vnles wer ennemy ye soldiours want wyl fynd waye howe come ſame inconuenience wold come therof euery man may eaſely perceiue thing whiche offered kyng dede refuſed would haue deliuered bread thābaſſadours corne vpon coulde agree departed matter concluded whan ambaſſadours retourned senate made decree muche parte wheate whiche citie ſpared ſhould much bread made myght place theraboutes ambaſſadours alledged coneſtable kyng alſo ſtate citie condiciō time ſuche thence nothing loked caſe thyng myght gathered countrie belonging ſame ſhould haue right gladly ye senate decre leaſt extremitie ſhuld wrought vpon plowman people countrey ſo whiche could ſodenly gotten townes village citie caried campe ſame litle whan countrey loraine citie metz taken straſburge immediatly toke vp nomber fiue thouſand ſouldiours defende citie agayne pulled many aſwel publique priuate buildinges citie cut downe tree orcherdes ſo euer let proſpecte might ſuccour ennemie moſte nede began fortifie citie ſame great diſpleaſure frenchman later communication coneſtable diſſemble ſame ambaſſadours thought howe certen hope like certen face frendſhip entred metz ſo alſo ſhould haue bene ſhut straſburg whan knewe citie exceading ſtrong ſawe moreouer thinges prouided ſo diligently defence ſame chaunging purpoſe thought tourned way remouinge campe ſeuenth day may marched towarde haganawe wiſſeburg hither came vnto ye king ambaſſadours paulſgraue electour archebyſhoppes requeſt prynces kyng mentz treuers commiſſioners duke cleaue wirtemberge whiche common wealthes ſake lately aſſembled wourmes whoſe requeſte kyng would abſteyne ſpoyling countrie ſpare poore people ſo muche proteſteth make warre lybertie germany woulde ſtaye armie ſhuld goe ſame wold great loſſe dammage empyre requyre hym geue mynde wayes peace whereof bothe haue alreadye made mention emperoure wyll doe alſo hereafter truſte ſhall well writeth entring league deſire conſider herein honour eſtimation reaſon othe faith owe empire able perfourme yet endeuour generall peace may eſtabliſhed furthermore require moſte inſtauntly would ſpare dominiōs straſburg whiche fre citie empyre mediation marque albert would intreate gently byſhop wirciburge ſelfſame tyme xi day may letter brought ye king frō duke maurice wherin wrytten maurice letter kyng done lintz duke maurice required moreouer yt kyng wold haue alſo compriſed treatie peace would declare vpon condition would accorde emperour whan theſe letter receiued kyng vnto whome thing thought haue chaunced vnloked two dayes remoueth campe leauing germany marcheth agayne towardes loraine departure aunſwereth ambaſſadours prince named hath already obteined ſame kinges anſwer ye prynces thyng whiche came army germany captiue prince ſhall deliuered cauſe warre therfore hath wonne honour enough chaunce tyme hereafter wherin germany may requyre ayde wyll ſpare neither paynes coſte perill nowe leading backe army intendeth retourne home chiefly ennemies haue inuaded fraunce concerning complaintes poore people hartely ſory howbeit ſo good order taken armie licentiouſe ſoldiours wyll alwayes ſome harme notwithſtanding taketh moſte dilligent hede bothe little harme done poſſible alſo offence moſte ſtraytely punyſhed touchyng whiche wryte emperour peace loketh certenly handes paynes force dilligence germany releaſed thoſe miſeries wherewith laye oppreſſed nowe muſt well forſee doe diſhoneſtly loſe theyr libertie hym reſtored theyr requeſt touchynge straſburge ſaye naye withſtanding tyme army ye ſoldiours citie vſed great preſumption arrogancie towardes men whan king entred germany emperours power low countreis conduict martin van roſſem ſpoyleth chāpanye marten roſſeme inuaded champaignie fraunce burning deſtroying toke towne aſteney ſtanding ryuer maſe belonging duke loraine lately ſurpryſed ye frenchemē thought one cauſe kyng retourned armie another miſliked duke maurice doinges againe hope failed hym straſburge whan remoued wiſſeburge ambaſſadours came kyng ſent ſuite swiſſes kyng swiſſes king ferdinādo hath region ioyning heluetians called sontgouia enſeme chiefeſt countrey afrayde partes intreated swiſſes aucthoritie fauour kyng would make interceſſion wherfore requeſt charge takynge iourney commended king alſo city nere vnto ſame colmar seletſtat straſburg ſaying countrie linked vnto great amitie nerenes therof alſo chiefly ſerue maner wheat ſo muche nedefull ſo diſpleaſure done whiche ſhall feele alſo unto whome kyng maketh aunſwer xx daye may beſides bipont howe doth forgeue enſem ſo wyll releaſe ſuche ſoldious haue priſoners touching reſte whome ſpake neuer ment euill albeit ſouldiours straſburg receiued men ſomwhat roughly gate put back came thither bie thinges yet wil forſake amitie therfore euen ſakes intreate meanes nowe poſſeſſeth lorayne ſhall nere neighbour wyll nothing againſt maner neighbourhead loketh ſame good wil dutie alſo saberne ambaſſadours ſent king ye senate baſill theſame matter vnto whome alſo made gentle aunſwere ſhewed duke maurice howe departed lintz kyng ferdinando alſo whan conuention done went immediatly emperour inſpruck infourme matter duke maurice retourning campe marcheth fellowes toward thalpes ſaid whan came almoſt perſwaſiō frēch ambaſſadour determined ſet vpon ſoldiours whiche emperour leuied thoſe partes ye xvii daye maye far fieſſa towne ſituated entring vp alpes ryuer leyche ſendeth forth eſpialles vnderſtande ennemie maner bryng worde howe kepe ſtraytes narrow paſſages moūtaines haue ſo fortified themſelues hurt meanes wherfore prince ſende forth certen horſemen choſen whole nomber whiche riding almoſte ennemies campe intercept diuerſe bring away prince whome vnderſtande many thynges next daye marching forewarde skirmyſhes ye prince ye eperialles fotemen hauing two hō dreth horſemē go fieſſa time thei farre rewe come vnto ſtraytes whiche kept emperours ſoldiours nomber eight hondreth two field peces upō geuing charge whan entred ye ſtraytes ouerthrowe ennemies ſlipping away flight made incā ped rwe feare tremble prince purſuing ſpede geue charge vpon thē alſo finally put flight wherof thouſand wer taken ſlayne drowned ryuer leych loſt alſo one enſeigne next morning go caſtell erenberge wherof haue ofte made mention whan fortune would taken fortreſſe ſtanding vnderneth caſtel wonne ſtraite wayes paſſages moreouer ſurpriſed diuerſe peces great ordenaūce furniſhed clyme vp ſtepe pitchell hill vnto caſtell albeit layde many erenberge take agayne weapon yet toke ſurrender caſtell xiii enſeignes fotemen wherof ix taken iiii eſcaped whiche thre germaines one italian taken thre thouſand loſt fewe owne men rebelliō moris cāp duke maurice great daunger whan woulde haue marched forewarde ſoldiours vnder riſeberge would vnleſſe might haue extraordinary paye wynning caſtell duke maurice ſayd reaſon commaunded al apprehēde ſeditious felowe clamorouſe reſt reſt make towardes pykes alſo duke morisuye ſlayne handgunnes ſo muche moſte ſpedy flighte could hardely ſaue life xxi day may two legion ſent alpes inſpruck whiche thence two dayes iourney al horſemen left one legion fotemen fieſſa rwe defende kepe paſſage next daye duke maurice felowes prince followyng ioyne army fotemen zirley whiche two great myles inſprucke emperour heard ereberge wonne departed ſodenly night awaye inſprucke brother empe ſleeth away nyght ferdinādo lately come thither perſwade peace ſayd alpes go trente tourning left hande came uillace towne carnia riuer draue whan little ſet libertie iohn friderick duke saxon bene fiue yeres priſoner leaſt ennemies ſhuld aſcribe vnto duke saxon ſet libertie glorie whiche thing dede priſoner alſo hym ſelfe woulde whā libertie followed emperour neuertheleſſe whyther ſoeuer went ſelfe ſame tyme quene marie emperours ſyſter helde aſſemblee achen lowe ducheland make league prince duke cleaue dede excuſeth matter ambaſſadours adolphe archebiſhop collon comming thither entreth league houſe burgſidy likewiſe doth byſhop luke george auſtriche whan duke maurice came inſprucke thinge ſoeuer founde empe ſtaffe ſpoiled emperours spaiardes cardinalles auſpurge ſpoyled kyng ferdinandos citezens goodes harme done ſo muche remayned thre day vnto truce whiche treatie peace taken mentioned duke maurice went thence paſſawe prince marching ſame way came ye xxviii day may retourne fieſſa afterwarde menſſengers well name alſo duke maurice publyſhe letter auſpurge effect ſorte ſaye ye ennemies truthe haue alwayes done indeuour godly preacher oppreſſed romiſhe idolle might reſtored yought brought vp thoſe errours falſe opiniōs might litle litle increaſe ſame thing ſo manifeſt nedeth demō ſtration euen ſame time whan ſticke proteſte ſought religion wrought force pure doctrine might cleane roted caſte godly preacher pryſon crueltie againſt godly preacher citie alſo compelled othe great vngentlenes ſhould departe limites empire albeit ſame othe wicked therfore grounded vpon lawe reaſon yet leaſt ſclaunder might aryſe haue called home agayne thoſe ſelfe ſame preacher ſcholemaiſters whiche aduerſaries exiled thinking dutie ſo doe wherfore ſuche ſorte banniſhed ſayd clerely releaſe bonde othe wherunto force violence contrary lawes thei bounde reſtore vnto libertie ioyning citie alſo place according vocation teache god worde ſyncerely according confeſſion tymes paſt exhibited rightly godly bring vp yougth learning truſting vnto defence tuition cōmaunde alſo man moleſte wordes iniuries though ſhould contrary faith geuen inaſmuche deſerte profeſſion truthe haue liued many monethes exile doubte good men wyll lamente chaunce accompte worthy good wyll fauour much thoſe abſence haue preached citie men ſuſpected vnconſtant inſomuch may conueniently theſe haue called agayne reaſon contrarietie teachinge require senate put ſilence ſo demeane ſelues decree may ſtande ful ſtrēgthe authoritie whan prince thus proclaimed ſeuenth day iune fift day reſtore miniſters prince reſtore ye miniſters ye churche churche place geue agayne authoritie preache great reioyſing contentation people duke maurice retourned lintz marque albert going parte armie doeth much harme ſpoyling burning wuolfgang maiſter almaigne order call hym whan exacted mony inuadeth countrie norinberge fift day may taketh compoſition lightnaw caſtell ſtandyng fiue myles citie towne ioyning ſame armie two thouſand horſemen xix enſeignes fotemen nexte daie ſending letter norinberge marq albertes armie albeit frenche king ſaieth prince cō federated haue declared wrytinge ſufficiently large thought common wealth thei bent recouer libertie germany religiō alſo vpō hope confidence good men wylling myndes woulde imbrace enterpryſe would alſo force indeuour theſame whiche many haue done dede yet haue neyther declared mynde pourpoſe heare haue ſent ambaſſadours aſſemblee appointed auſpurge prepare thinges defence plantyng ordenaunce walles bulwarkes hiring force ſoldiours make auaunt wyll perſeuer vttermoſte extremitie credible informed maketh beleue hetherto haue ſent ambaſſadours peace whiche ſome notwithſtandinge haue done bothe prince city therfore ſame wryting kyng prince confederated doth manifeſtly declare ſuche either ſhall reſiſte enterpryſe theſame ſhall taken ennemies againe ſo muche adioyned ſame warre ende bryng thoſe whoſe limites come dutie leaue behynde backe fortified place whiche force ſaleinge feared therfore haue taken whiche yet haue ſatiſfied expectation caſtell lightnaw whiche great annoyaunce campe preſeruing ſouldiours garriſon whome neuertheleſſe might haue otherwyſe vſed bycauſe chief thing yet remaineth require frenche kinges name fellowes wyll make direct aunſwer purpoſed doe defence libertie germany ſtabliſhyng religion let vnderſtande tomorrowe may knowe thyng loked ſorte ought accept howbeit tyme duke maurice fellowes schwinfurte whiche xxvi daye marche ſayde demaunded norinberge faith ſocietie munition vitayle great ſomme monie muche debating condition omitted tyme paied hondreth thouſand crownes promyſed peace well ſelues fellowes letter deuiſed moſte ample wyſe nowe therfore tyme marque albert aſſayled make complainte bycauſe duke maurice yet retourned lintz lantgraues sonne wrytynge agayne thyrde daye may gundelfynge byddeth good comforte fift day whan duke maurice retourned wryte promiſſe kepe conuenauntes ſaying acte marque cleane beſides expectation neither like indeuour may recouer wyll alſo call back immediatly ſuche ayde haue lent whan norinberge receiued letter marque albert wrote againe ſame day ſignifiyng thing duke maurice prince promiſed compoſition ſaie cauſe ſent ambaſſadours wherfore earneſtly pray beſeche hym wyll reſtore fully caſtell taken gratifie fellowes herein thre dayes wrote againe ſo muche doth know haue compounded yet concerneth frenche king muche vnto whome leſſe addicted others requireth haue ſaufeconduicte credible man whome wyll ſende citie ſe inſtrument accorde followe mynde let ſe neuertheleſſe although duke maurice fellowes meanes diligently intreated contrary xi daye may wryteth againe frenche kinges name eſpecially doeth charge within fewe houres would aunſwer playnely whether wyll obedient receiued ſuche aunſwer would towne caſtell lightnawe ſpoyleth burneth ouerthroweth maketh euen grounde whan exacted mony townes men cauſed ſweare true ſubiectes hym coſin george friderick alſo marque brandenburg beſegeth citie wherfore lantgraues ſonne calleth agayne two guidons horſemen whiche let hym haue againſt woulfgange maiſter order commaundeth come vnto wherwith ſore offended attempted therfore cruell warre whan burned ſpoyled hondreth village dominiō albertes crueltie normberg thre ſcore ten maners fermes citezens church alſo ſetteth fyre moreouer exceading great wood whiche ſerued alſo inhabiters therby tymber firewood burned therof aboue thre thouſand acre proclaymed open warre others aboutes wold obeye nobilitie others chiefly ye byſhop bamberge wirtemburg whome alſo caſe droue moſte vnreaſonable condition verely biſhop bamberge ſaue hymſelfe prouince preſent bamberge redemeth peace dearelye daunger bought peace wonderful loſſes fayne geue xx townes ſignories within iuriſdiction made hym wrytinges ſame xix daye may alſo permitteth haue wardes clientes byſhop dirtemburge payde hym two hondreth twenty thouſand crownes alſo taketh vpon hym promyſeth paye debtes whiche amounted ſumme thre hondreth fiftie thouſand crownes city sweuia hauing compaſſion vnworthie lamentable fortune norinbergians whiche lately aſſembled auſpurge ſayd nomber xxvi ambaſſadours choſen whole nomber make interceſſion eſpecially auſpurge whan come ſaufecō duicte norinberge alledging many reaſons exhorte peace tell takyng ſtrayte paſſages alpes caſtell erenberge declare ſtate hongarie italie ſuche ayde ſuccour loked man exhibite condicions propounded marque albert geue thankes good wyll paynes taken declare howe marque hath cauſe war againſt alſo treated duke maurice felowes becauſe condition ſuche partly able perfourme partly meanes excuſed emperour kyng ferdinando ſaye wyll abyde extremitie commit matter vnto god knowe ſelues ſo cleare contented iudged herein emperour prince alſo yea next frendes kinſfolkes marque ſelfe whan interceſſours reported theſe thinges agayne marque duely placed wordes termes apte conuenient relented nothing alſo threatened moſte cruell thynges fourth daye iune aduertiſe letter mynde ſet crueltie howe could bring reaſonable condition nowe marque ſhoteth ordenaunce citie much violence one night maketh batterie ouer put thē terrour burneth one ſuburbes ſame tyme came campe hym george thanberge william schacthe ſent ambaſſadours duke maurice lantgraues ſonne make peace taking ambaſſadours city whiche diſpayre matter el mynded departe long laborious treatie length perſwade partes conclude peace marque armie lately augmented iob dalbeck chriſtopher oldē burge norinberge hath peace ye mar erles duke maurice wryting letter ſenate ſignified moſte greuouſly offended marque doinge yet could remedie condicions peace theſe ſhould paye two hondreth thouſand crownes deliuer ſixe great piece artyllarie thinges furniſhed ſhould beare fauour prince confederated auſpurg hym ſelfe ſhould againe reſtore ſuche thinges taken wherfore xx day iune leuied ſiege moſte famous mightie citie maner germany beſt furniſhed thinges eſpecially moſte ſtrongly fortified marque full luſty courage reaſon thys lucky ſucceſſe xx daye iune wryteth letter albert thē wolmes woulmes campe wherin conteined howe norinbergians exceading great hinderaunce hym vanquiſhed receiued condition peace would ſo fellowes ſhall cōmaunde nowe therfore determined beſege alſo far otherwyſe muche ſtreightly late fortune fauour pourpoſe ſpare mankinde paſt ſeuen yeares olde except thei retourne time immediatly ſending ambaſſadours fully ſatiſfie league frendes alſo make purgation rebellion lately committed wyll doe herein cōmaundeth ſende playne worde brynger theſe letter unto whiche letter aunſwer briefly whyleſt ſaufe ſo longe haue lyfe wyll doe ſuche thynge demaundeth frenche king paſſing germany army deuided thre partes came laſt walderfing whiche litle towne dutchie lorayne ye riuer sare vniting armie xxv day may marching forth paſſing ouer riuer moſel tyme came ye frēche king deſtroyeth themperour coūtrie lande lutcemburg diſtroied ſpoiling burning prouoked example roſſeme thē ſelues reporte recouereth towne aſteney voyde ſoldiours defende marten roſſeme retourned home againe pitching tentes taketh little towne ſurrender called danuillers alſo iueye one ye chiefeſt fortes ſame town count manſfield erneſtus gouernour whole countrey floure youth al taken priſoners afterwarde towne ſpoyled outragious ſoldiours againſt kinges reporte let v retourne duke maurice treate peace ſaid gone paſſa repeting treatie lintz thaſſemble paſſawe firſt iune propoūdeth declareth al thinges large themperours ambaſſadours kyng ferdinando albert duke bauier byſhops saliſburge eiſtet chief prince germany ambaſſadours alſo cleaue wirtemberge many others beſides complaineth ſtate thempire whiche chiefly ought cōplain te prynces elect free gouerned ſtraungers thauthoritie prince electours deminiſhed many thing done aduiſe knowledge certē thinges alſo plucked away alienated frō thempire howe meanes deuiſed thautoritie electing thēperour may takē thē cōmon aſſemblies electours voice maner neglected priuate conuentions electours certen feare omitted liberty infringed whyleſt chamber imperiall receiueth thoſe appeale thē contrary auncient cuſtome controuerſies ſtates imperial purpoſly maynteined neuer accorded either partie haue ſuſteined loſſe dammage howe emperours courte man hardly heard ſpeake neyther matter exactly knowen chiefly vnderſtande tongue muche loſſe coſtes tyme alſo open aſſemblies matter handled nothyng frendly man propounde ought common wealth taken euyl parte germany ſore impoueryſhed beggered thoſe ofte dayly conuentions home oftentymes many thynges neglected neyther yet publique ſtate whyt amended yea made worſe intricate ſtrayghte proclamation prohibited man ſerue foreyne warres ſuche reconciled bounde ſhall warre againſt emperours countrey ſo plucked empyre proteſtaūtes warre ſuch ſerued lordes according dutie puniſhed purſe ſuch ſame war remained thēperours frendſhyp commaunded paye alſo landes goodes ſhould put ſale vnleſſe payed immediatly ambaſſadours bicauſe aſſent commaunded vnder paine death ſhuld departe court foreine ſoldiours haue bene oftentimes brought germany laſt warre beinge finiſhed diſtributed hither thither prouinces whiche haue done many thinges diſſolutely vitiouſly haue gloried conqueſt germany haue ſayde ſhould annexed 〈◊〉 emperours patrimonie head city ſhould buylded caſtelles fortes howe muche ordenaunce warlike munition mockerie caried germany foreine nation howe diuerſe men certen ambition haue cauſed armes ye prince germany ſet vpon ye gunnes made themſelues though taken thē ſet forth bokes emperours priuilege whiche ſounde great reproche infamie germany though cōquered brought bondage common aſſemblees vnder name emperours prouinces certen men placed amonges prince ſtates wrought ſecret deuiſes nō ber augmented may preuayle nomber voice howe foure yeares paſt ordeyned iudgemēt chamber imperial lawes made fewe wer publiſhed great hynderaunce many eſpecially proteſtauntes religion thoſe vtterly excluded benche wherfore thinge ſelfe requyreth thoſe lawes better ſkanned next conuention theſe ſuche lyke thynges propoundeth muche chiefly concerne emperour requyreth redreſſed hande empyre reſtored fourmer dignitie others permitted delude contempne ſame interceſſours conferring together iudged nothinge amiſſe theſe requeſtes howebeit intent emperours dignitie ſhould mainteined might ſo much eaſely perſwaded thynke many thynges whiche concerne reformation ſtate publique may ryght well differred tyll generall conuention empyre preſent french ambaſſadour fraxineus oration frenche ambaſ thyrd daye iune made oration prince betwene frenchemē germaines old time name francons knowen ſo tha •• nitie frēchmē germaines great lykenes life maners ye germains theſame people whiche romaine time paſt called brother frenchemen francons planted ſelues fraunce natiōs ſo vnited one empire one prince ſame lawes afterwarde whan alteration chaunced thempyre deuolued germains duke saxon emperours originall kinges fraunce continual amitie frenchmē ſo much philip king fraunce cauſed ye auncient league whiche could ſcant read olde antiquitie therof written goldē letter layd vp holyer place verely without iuſt cauſe league amitie cō mon wealth either nation dede moſte floriſhing certenly force germany thā ſo great preſcribed lawes hongarians bohemers poloniās deanes alſo italian ye kinges fraūce maintenaunce religion haue warred many time againſt thennemies chriſtendom saracenes turkes aſia affricke europe haue moſte noble victory chaunced time vnfortunate whan certen emperours newly entred germaines worthy ye dignitie haue forſaken amitie ye kinges fraunce haue induced great calamitie common wealth ſore plage god benefite healed noble houſe duke lutcemburg whiche haue iſſued certen emperours men great vertue linked moſte aſſuredly kinges fraunce father themperour charles fourth died battell kyng fraunce like good beare alſo prince auſtriche amongeſt others albert firſte neither promeſſe threatening hyghe byſhops could brought warre againſt fraunce theſe thynges reciteth intent may ſee howe euell certen councellours miniſters moſte puiſſaunt emperour charles fyfte prouyde common wealth whyleſt worke thys thinge plucke ſonder one theſe two moſte excellent nation alſo craft ſubtiltie haue brought paſſe longe ſynce moſte noble prince kyng fraunces iudged ennemie cauſe harde owne priuate gaine exceading great hinderaſice cōmmon wealth harde amitie two nation infringe libertie germany buylde vp kyngdome doeth hereof ſufficiently appeare libertie germany reſtored ye power fraunce nowe affrayde force fraunce ſo importune doe ſo muche vrge spanyſhe yoke bondage theſe verely whiche intreatie tribute obteyning peace turke vnder colour religion obedience haue brought diſſentions faction germany ayded power germaynes haue warred againſt germany whiche haue exacted money men made state empyre miſerable placing garriſons spanyardes vnarmyng armaries openyng waye confiſcation matter brought paſſe bothe ſeale empyre iudgement chamber alſo ryght libertie aſſemblies depende vpon pleaſure byſhop arras example equitie ſuche get liuing ſerue foreine warres ſhould therfore executed outlawed great rewardes ſet forth daūger murtheryng omit meane ſeaſon ſo many murthers lecherous actes ſpoylynges robbinges townes eſpecially handlyng religion whiche hath bene one maner diuers according tyme certenly ſo euer hath bene done theſe many yeares nowe tendeth ende contrary lawes empyre kyng ferdinando herunto eyther compelled el fayre promeſſes allured prynces alſo certen feare terrour ſubdued prince spayne might made emperour ſhuld noble courage way opened ye prynce spayne emper wyſhe death rather beholde ye lyght ye sun ſuche diſtreſſe miſeries aſſuredly man imagined ſo coward ſo barbarouſe whō theſe thyngs would moue wherfore man ought maruell ende ther ſhould arriſe ſome prince amongeſt duke maurice thelectour saxony thought part euen ye hazarde liues recouer ye libertie natife coūtrie thē ſelues able power ſufficiēt ſuſtein ſuch charge alone haue deſired ye ayde king fraūce doubtles ſetting part ye diſpleaſure former yeares hath made thē partaker al fortune hath alſo imploied ſelfe wholy ſame buſines making league wherein amongeſt thinges prouided thei may cōpounde ennemie kinges conſent howbeit duke maurice although tied ſame bonde yet ye weale countrie followe mynde kyng ferdinando requiring hereunto hath lately demaunded moſte chriſtian king could content haue peace whiche thing chaunced vnto dede ſom contrary expectation conſidering benefite ſo great ſuppoſed matter touching ſhuld haue ſent far haue deuiſed preſently neuerthe leſſe becauſe ſetteth much publique thā priuate profites would deny nothing prince confederacie wherfore woundes cōmon wealth may healed ought henceforth aſſuraunce made yt breake captine prince may releaſed vpon ſuche condition league expreſſed moreouer caſe olde league fraunce empire new confederacie alſo made late prince may ſo confirmed yt may take place euer theſe thines ſaye may brought paſſe ſo well affected towardes common wealth wyll aſſent gladly treatie peace alſo wyl giue god hartie thākes aduiſe helpe hereunto hath wanted touching priuate matter ſo much emperour deteineth many thinges force hath made warre vpon iuſt cauſe king thinketh reaſon ye hath firſt done wrong ſhould firſt ſeke alſo make ſatiſfactiō verely althoug neither diſtruſte force yet cauſe ſo demeane ſelfe yt may well perceyued deſirous peace willing alſo gratifie duke maurice hereunto prince aunſwere howe recitall antiquitie repeted fourmer memory cōcerning coniūctiō fraūce prince aunſwer oration germany right ioyfull leſſe pleaſaūt heare kyng preferreth common wealth aboue priuate cōmodities againſt prince confederate may conclude peace emperour ſhould ſo profite one nation alſo europe whiche afflicted ciuil diſcorde ten deth diſtruction ſuche condition peace kyng requyreth doubte may obteyned emperour tyme alſo trouble thinketh well common wealth wyll haue libertie germany deminiſhed good hope moreouer wyll ſhortly delyuer captiue prince olde league ſhould renewed newe confirmed king wyſdome vnderſtandeth ſame conuention ſo great matter finiſhed neuertheles wyſhe vnfainedly ſame amitie hath bene alwayes betwene bothe nation may remayne ferme vnuiolable ſuche priuate ſuites hath emperour myght appeaſed couet chiefly alſo wyll refuſe paynes trauell therin kyng affirmeth emperour deteineth diuerſe thinges ar ſignifieth plainly hath thinges lay clayme thinke againſt reaſon ſhewe thing mynded preferre controuerſie emperour meanes therin deſire much kyng would accept theſe thinges good part nowe concerning alliaunce betwene germaynes frēche men haue ſpoken eight booke whiche frenche ambaſſadour ſpeaketh houſe lutcemburge houſe lucēburg thus ſtandeth erle lutcemburge henry ſonne named henry whiche made emperour ſeuenth name ſonne called iohn whiche mariage made king boheme aided philip ualoſe frenche kyng againſt kyng englande edwarde third goyng hym ſelfe hym fielde battell battell creſſie foughten engliſhmen victory ſlayne amonges others lefte ſonne called charles whiche afterwarde made emperour fourthe name father wenceſlaus sigiſmunde whiche emperours sigiſmunde alſo kyng hongary boheme procurer counſell conſtance albert auſtriche whome ſpeaketh ſonne raffe emperour whan emperour obſerued perfit amitie albert auſtriche philip le beau kyng fraunce notwithſtanding byſhop rome boniface eight wonderfully incenſe vnto warre duke maurice beſydes deliueraunce father lawe vrged two thynges chiefly one ſuche matter annoyed libertie germany whiche hym ſelfe recited name kyng ferdinando maximiliā ſonne interceſſours themſelues ſhuld nowe forthwith examine according lawes cuſtome germany determine ſame another peace myght graunted religion man ſhould moleſted therfore tyl ſuche tyme whole cōtrouerſie fully reconciled way thinterceſſours diſcōmend themperour ambaſſadours declareth lacke findeth therin thought reaſon thoſe bene faithfull therfore chaunced extreme miſerie ſhould firſt recompēſed loſſe much debating time diuerſe pointes mittigated agreed ye length third day july emperour ſhuld anſwer directly war ſhould ceaſe meane time wherfore thinterceſſours wryting letter xvi day june exhorte themperour vnto peace whan yt caſtel ereberg taken afterwarde inſpruck ſpoyled ſhewed howe prince retorning thalpes thende may came backe fieſſa marching frō thence xix day june pitched tentes eiſtet ye byſhops town bordring vpon bauier ther whole army longed ſore duke maurice cōming without great thought carfulnes comming thither length ſheweth caſe matter ſtode laſte daye iune retourneth thence paſſaw poſt horſes might daye appointed fellowe prince remouing campe next morning fourth day came roteburg whiche towne nere vnto francony riuer duber marque albert neuertheleſſe purſued enterpriſe hauing driuen citie norinberge make marque albert warreth himſelfe peace compelled alſo nobilitie ſtates theſe party cōmaundement albeit mainteined common cauſe firſt writing ſet forth profeſſed yet ſame league whā ſiege ulmes leuied went priuate affaire whether would wynne hym ſelfe alone ſoeuer chaunce warre geuen hym myſlyked duke maurice doinge el moued frenche kynge bent otherwyſe notwithſtanding thoſe toke faith commaunded perfourme ſame fidelitie alſo felowes afterwarde inuading prouince arch • biſhop mentz ryuer meyne doeth exceading muche harme burning ſpoyling demaundeth hym wonderfull ſumme money diuers made interceſſion neither yet could thei agree vpō ſumme archebyſhop fyrſte ſynkynge hys great artylarie rhyne fyrſte daye iuly fled awaye ſaue hym ſelfe ſelfe ſame tyme alſo marque albert whiche lefte nothynge vnattempted wylleth archebyſhop treuers deliuer vnto chiefeſt caſtell dominion whiche ſituated riuers rhine moſell mete vpon hyghe hyll naturally ſtrong commodious ſayd howe required frēche kynges name conferred counſell ſent worde yt could accomplyſhe requeſt herein muche prince interceſſours latter part aunſwere made frenche ambaſſadour mentioned ſayd howe thought reaſon kyng ſhould declare required emperour ambaſſadour kyng aduertiſed whan armie beſydes eiſtet xix daye iune wryteth agayne kyng hath attempted war none cauſe double frēche kinges aunſwer thin terceſſours profit whole common wealth chiefly reſtore libertie germany ſore opreſſed tyme certen prynces long muche requeſted hym ſame aſſuredly ſought priuate gayne ſelfe therein may thing ſelfe beare witnes taken nothyng al germany bene harde haue done permitted prince alſo warre frely liſt albeit meane tyme hymſelfe laye ſtyll armie riuer rhine ennemies inuaded fraunce yet remoue tyll aduertiſed duke maurice ſuche thinges myght obteyned peaceable meanes whiche warre attempted whiche thing knowen litle glad whan ſawe thinge procede harte deſire aduiſe counſell firſt prince ſhould neglect ſo goodly occaſion neither diſceiue ſeluws others abuſed moreouer ſo muche ſhewed ſo notable token good wyl fidelitie amitie nation might aſſuredly eſtabliſhed thintent himſelf may afterwardes haue better leaſure ſe vnto cōmodities cōmon wealth becauſe duke maurice hath demaunded ſorte would accorded opinion ſayth howe ye emperour moued warre againſt without iuſt cauſe kinges fraunce wont deſire peace ennemy eſpecially ſuche one neither power thing inferiours propounde thing vnleſſe certen hope obteine yt ſame ſeeth cauſe touching ſelues ſuppoſeth wil require nothing may ſtande honour dignitie ſo loueth againe ſo eſtemeth caſe may ſe treate cōmō peace whole worlde would ſakes geue ouer great parte right contented alſo ſhall bothe heare determine requeſtes ſo emperour refuſe doe likewyſe wyſheth greatly ſame cauſe might ſome conuention ſone might may ſo ſhall men vnderſtande much loueth common wealth alſo howe farre truthe thoſe thinges whiche bruted aduerſaries cōcerning turkiſhe league theſe thinges take place conſultations referred diſcretion neither obteine league amitie germaines whiche good deſerte loked blame ought imputed chaūce trouble ariſe theſe letter red prince firſt day iuly whan duke maurice come paſſawe day morowe brought emperours aunſwere king ferdinando whan prince ſet ſayd howe emperour dede written mynde aſſente many thinges ſo muche ſo nedefull declare expreſſely thing hath aunſwered reſt neuertheleſſe thintent may appere greatly himſelfe deſireth peace howe well wyſheth vnto germany wyll go great expedition emperour doubting ſhall perſwade wherfore deſireth erneſtly duke maurice woulde content expect ſo long may goe come whiche ſhall paſſe eight day moſte whiche thing refuſed immediatly king importune vayne duke maurice calling vnto prince ambaſſadours ſaith ſelues know right well whiche haue bene preſent priuie doinges ſpace maurice weary delayes moneth hath lefte nothing vndone might eyther ſtudy trauel worke conclude peace doubted yt wolde aſſuredly witneſſe wt ſame wher fore requireth yt would ſtill beare good helpe cōmō cauſe germany may graunte reſpite long treatie ſuſpition fellowes already wherunto whan made gentle aunſwer cōmending good deſire king ferdinando themperours name would make playne determination ſuppoſe ſoeuer emperour would confirme ratifie unto ferdinando anſwered brother geuen ſuch authoritie would take ſo muche paine trauell fro might wyſe paſſe bōdes preſcribed ſhewed prince interceſſours letter wrytten xvi day iune exhorted themperour peace unto whiche letter laſt iune thempe empe letter interceſſours rour anſwereth uillace time firſt receiued crowne imperiall hath euer deſired peace yea wiſheth nothing el wherfore cauſe ſhould cōmend ſame ſo greatly vnto whiche thauthours theſe cōmotions thei wold ſo requireth thē faith owe vnto touching owne priuate affaire ſakes graunt muche concerning whole pacification hathe wrytten minde brother king ferdinando whome ſhall heare al thinges unto letter write aunſwer emperour againe fift day iuly time king ferdinando returned emperour howe thei requeſt deſire came firſt vnto treatie ſo muche rather promiſed doe thing commō wealthes ſake haue exceading great labour carefulnes diligence founde way peace wherfore beſeche eftſones moſte intierly would haue ſome reſpect cōmon countrie many chiefeſt ſtates thempire keping faith vnto haue already ſuſteined great calamitie nowe condicion thinges ſuche occaſion deliberation ſo brief prince ſtates eſpecially ſuche nere fire although would neuer ſo faine perfourme vnto al faith loialtie yet ſo conſtreined conſult meanes may ſpedely eſche preſent calamitie diſtructiō caſe refuſe peace intēding make warre wyll doubtles moſte greuouſe perillous alteration arriſe therof germany whiche afterwarde wyll redounde prouinces alſo wherfore ther nothing better would content ſelfe condition peace whiche wyth ſo great trauell haue procured eſpecially ſince ye chiefeſt pointes firſt approued lintz fourme foteſteppes whiche treatie haue followed herein againe muche ſuche thinges whiche properly concerne dignitie pourpoſly referred cō uention thempire ende may gently quietly treated ſame day wherin done duke maurice departeth thence whan come fellowes maurice retourneth fellowes xi day iuly tyme incamped mergetheme ſheweth done ſaith howe kyng ferdinando ryden poſte emperour ſuppoſeth ſhortly ſende counſellours whiche ſhal bring full determinate aunſwer doubtfull ſtate thinges leaſt ſhould ſit ſtil nothing bycauſe franckefurt garriſon emperours xvii enſeignes fotemen thouſand horſemen leading conrade hanſteyne ſo heſſebye ſmall daunder condeſcended goe thither wherfore whan done much harme woulfgange maiſter pruſſe burning ſpoiling countrie ſame time marching forwarde lande archebyſhop mentz xvii day iuly come frācfurt prince interceſſours ambaſſadours ſent immediatly duke maurice fellowes theyr campe ambaſſadours whiche might mollifie myndes perſwade thē peace whiche ſiege george duke megelburge adioyned vnto duke maurice euen firſt men moued warre againſt maydenburge ſlayne great piece tyme began firſte george du megelbu ſlayne beſiege franckfurt prince confederated deſyre great quātitie batteryng piece paulſgraue electour ſayeth nay one twyſe whan myght none otherwyſe choſe threatened come whole armie gaue eight beſt furniture kyng ferdinando retourning paſſawe daye xiii day iuly declareth interceſſours emperours mynde euery thyng uerely matter concerning empyre whiche ſayde duke maurice propounded ſhoulde condition peace offered emperour heard certen commiſſioners ſeuerally men generall whole aſſemblee empyre agayne cauſe religion ſhould quietly remayne vnto next conuention empire conuention ſhall ſeme good done therin henceforth common aduiſe ſtates ſame cōfirmed ratified themperour alſo ye xi day iuly anſwereth thinterceſſours laſt letter yt like haue letter ſo hath brother king ferdinādo treated wt diligently accept dede would gladly haue pleaſed part diuers cauſes letted whiche declareth brother lieth cōfirm approue al thing indifferētly wher thoccaſion cōmotion diuers without al deſert fallē much calamity yt ſory one man liuing yet hath ſame chanced confidence put mā hope wherunto ſhuld truſt although ſēt vnto certen chief prince yt ſhuld remedy euil growing beginning yt tumult promiſing thē al indeuor yet mindē therfor yt whatſoeuer ſhuld propoūded wold alow ye ſame ſuch thing cōcern hole empire thinketh reſō ſhuld referd publik aſſēblies time verely mā ſhal bring forth iuſt cōplaint wil fail duty verely hath omitted hitherto ſith yet hath ſuch requeſt ben brought vnto neuertheles ought haue ben done war ben attēpted could cō iecture thing ſhuld required much le geue inſtructiōs ambaſſadors ſēt paſſaw thei ſhuld anſwer euery poynt dede thoffice dignity perſon intēdeth ſelf preſētly wher therfor aloweth al thing yt many perauenture go perſwade ther cauſe mā ſhuld reprehend thoſe yt interceſſors ought rather perſwade exhort thē reſonable moderat condiciōs eſpecially ſince ſe doth hardly leaſte neceſſity cōſtraind attempt war intendeth folow nether may chuſe caſe cā deuiſe ſome reaſonable conuenient way peace ſeing caſe ſtā deth thus truſt yt wil declare fidelity rather chief magiſtrate ſhuld geue ear ſuch contrary theyr duty haue made league theyr ennemies raiſed vp cōmotions perceiueth ignoraunt euils approche neare whan army brought forth ioyn battel exceadingly moued loſſes common weale chiefly thinnocent people therfore minedeth peace hath done alwaies wil refuſe condition reaſonable aſcribed vnto mean ſeaſon whileſt conſulted condicions ſēt vnto ii ſeueral time certen ſtates ſuſteind great loſſes ther truſe al time interceſſion wheras ſame time marque albert afflicted diuers ye coulde withall euen beginning euer againſt treatye peace moreouer anſwering ſame neuer made delay perſeuered ſame way thē firſt propoūded afterward altred anſwer might haue bene much ſoner plainlye made yea ſhronke treaty lintz wherof thē ſelues make mention al thing might haue ben concluded lōg ſince wher therfor ſe minded towards ye commō welth earneſtly requireth together brother fernādo vnto whō hath opened ſelf wholy thei wold bring reſonable cōditions therin haue reſpect welth dignity thempire certenly wil vſe ſame lenity peaceable wais frō henceforth hath done hitherto yt abhorreth much al ciuil war caſe peace vpon theſe cō dicions eſtabliſhed loketh fidelity whyche bounden anſwered alſo king fardinando letter french ambaſſador red vnto prince ſaid peace french king obſerued diligently although many thing arrogantly proudly yet hath diſſembled ſame common quietnes albeit promiſed ambaſſador largely pretended ſuch thing made war againſt sea land proclaimed ſame hathe offered condition ready duke moris electoure ſhould name bring reaſonable condition peace former actes agreable wold refuſe ther certen determinate thing propounded drift wher hath laid blame breaking peace ſaith way concorde muſte ſet open alſo moreouer ſeketh purge ſelf turkiſh confederacy though wrong done al wholy forged ye caſe ſhal ſo require may brought light ſhewed cōmentaries aremont frēch ambaſſador wrytten cō ſtantinople thambaſſadors commē taries intercepted memorial ſent king one coſte cē turion ther forth comming alſo ſene letter turkes lieuetenant hongary ſent time prince confederated others intercepted wherby appeareth euidētly yt cauſer hurt turkiſhe nauye laſt yere motioned alſo like might haue ben done ſame yere right ſory ther harm brief intente purpoſe emperours turkes alſo vtterly vndoe brother ferdinando thintent may afterward bring whole common wealth chiefly germany extreme danger diſtres wel theſe thinges agre fair promeſſes care taketh wealth germany man may eaſilye perceiue thinge ſelfe declareth minde chiefeſt ſtates thempire wer yere ſore vexed afflicted vtterly diſtroid many others wer moſt pearil danger yt help germains linketh thē ſelues certain place thempire wer brought tirannical power nowe alſo fortified whole blame aſcribed vnto ſeing therfore caſe ſtandeth thus cannot ſee credit may geuen ambaſſadors letter vtterly forged fained dede opiniō ben much better haue reiected ſame haue receiued ſuch kinde anſwer conſider al thing diligently douteth ſhal perceiue ambaſſador intendeth goeth forſomuch ſame wryting maketh preſēt treaty thinketh nothing nedeful anſwer ſame xiiii iuly king ferdinando ſente henrye noble houſe plauians burgraue meiſſen chancelor boheme vnto camp frankfurt cōming duke moris xxiiii iuly matter wer debated duke moris admitteth peace laſt parſwadeth peace wherfore laſt day iuly cōtrary many men expectation concluded whole matter hereafter ye ſhal heare amonges reaſons perſwade one alſo let conſider ſelf vnles receiue condition danger ſtandeth bothe emperor hath puiſſant army alſo duke saxon ihon fridericke whome themperor hauinge inlarged incontinently ſend home let lantzgraues ſonne alſo cō ſider pearill ſhall bring father priſonner alſo whole prouince gunnes paulſgraue elector conſtrained lend ſaide whan peace made wer receiued towne leaſt ſhould come hand marque albert monthe iuly french king hauing taken certen townes duchie lucemburge ſaid brought armye artois french king diſchargeth army without notable exploict done end might relieue army trauel infection diſchargeth power ſelf returneth home hauing fortified ſuch place taken garriſons fortification ouer al thing made gouernor duke guiſe prince great authority fraunce commaunded duches loraine widow depart country neare themperor ſiſter xii iuly came straſburge ther remained certen dais huſbands ſiſter alſo cōmaunded yt french king depart straſburge came alſo driuē frō coū try ye forenamed wuolfgange maſter thorder knighthode germany conſiſtory thempire hath next place tharchbiſhops marque albert ioyned ſelf way felowes marque albert ſcourge prieſts going franckfort leauing ſiege goeth rhine ſubdueth wuormes spiers exacting mony alſo munition way ſomeuer went prieſts either wer fled away el chaunged apparell diſſembled theyr profeſſion order time army came neare vnto frankonie biſhops ther abouts thother prelate ſame ordre ſought ſaue ſelues flight tharchbiſhop mentz fear marque gon longe xxv day iuly came fleing straſburge lodgyng ther one night paſſed ouer rhine biſhop spiers aged man fled saberne wher died long biſhop wuormes mediatiō paulſgraue returned home paid xii thouſand crownes whan taken theſe city ſaid marque albert xxviii iuly ſending letter senate strauſburge requireth fellowes may requeſts straſbo haue acceſſe theyr city al time ther place garriſon whan neade ſhalbe ſhew fidelity well hys alſo french king name war ſaith moued reuenge al germany nether ſhal honeſt profitable reſiſt enterpriſe intent maye bring paſſe therfore hath fellowes ioyned together anſwer strauſbo al theyr power senate two dais wryteth theſe many yeres haue wiſhed thing true religion chriſt alſo thanciēt ſiberty might floriſh throughout al germany end haue bent doinges counſels alſo haue alwais imploid hitherto mony good ye ſame mind alſo nether wil time fail either wealth dignity cōmon country ſo much able time performe know moreouer thys theyr bounden duty ſame oth fidelity bounden yt emperor ſeing ſo nedeth declaration theyr wil king fraunce alſo time alſatia demaunded ſuch thing wryting wherof maketh mention ſetforthe prince confederated ſent ſhewed vnto wherfore deſire accept ſatiſfaction work violence coūtry ſelf ſame inſtant marque albert aduertiſed duke moris intended make peace leuing spiers garriſon returneth army franckfurt renueth ſiege duke moris hauing made peace forſaken pitching tent thother ſide town ſide riuer meyne vppon higher ground ſomwhat whence might commodiouſly beat town ordinaunce pacification toke moſt diſpleaſantly ſpake euil word duke moris would compriſed therein condition peace theſe prince confederated ſhal leaue theyr armure xii day auguſt ſo diſcharge army may ſerue king farnando ſo neither annoye themperoure germany ſame day alſo lantzgraue ſet liberty condition peace ſhalbe deliuered caſtel rinfelſe hath vpō rhine putting firſt ſurety obſerue couenaunts geuen emperor hale saxony alſo whiche ſame time became ſureties duke moris thelector brandenburge wuolfgange duke sainebricke renuing obligation entre bondes ſuit lantzgraue hath earle naſſow lordſhip chat ſhall examined prince elector ſuche alſo bothe plaintife alſo defendaunt ſhal aſſign ſame matter whiche afterward themperor ſhall chuſe ſixe ſhall determin caſe yet ſo matter diſcuſſed within two yeres ſpace within ſixe monethes emperoure ſhall holde aſſemble empire conſult chiefly howe meaue diſſention religion may beſt appeaſed meane time men ſhall obſerue peace man ſhall moleſted religion ſo euer ſhall decreed concerning manner appeaſing religion common aſſent ſtates authority emperor wit controuerſy may quieted godly rightfull way ſame firme ſtable unto iudiciall place chamber empire ſhall admitted alſo thoſe whyche proteſtantes religion thinges proprely concerne dignity libertye germany ought intreated conuention thempire otto henry paulſgraue alſo permitted frely enioye lande dominion warre ſo many geuing faith prince confederated haue boūden ſelues vnto ſhall free bondes theyr owne men haue ſuſtained domage warly tumulte ſhall commence none action therfore againſt thoſe haue done yet ſhal part themperor ſtates nexte aſſemble deuiſe ſome meane whereby maye receiue ſome recompence loſſes haue receiued concerning french king ſo much matter thempire concern nothing ſhalbe lawful declare vnto duke moris ſuch priuate action hath againſt themperor yt maye related themperor outlawes receiued mercy ſo attempt nothing hereafter againſt themperor thother ſtates ſo alſo ſerue french kinges warres retourne againe germanye within three moneths cleane forſaking ſeruice ſhal breake peace ſhall iudged ennemye unto theſe thinges prince wer ther preſent chiefeſt dignity deputy others ſubſcribed pacificatiō deuided paſſaw whiche ſigned alſo themperor whan peace concluded fraxineus frenche kinges ambaſſador retourneth home certenly king toke compoſition greuouſly hearing lantzgraue ſhould great daunger excepte compact made aſſented ſent againe pledge ſafe germany third day auguſt duke moris ye lantzgraues ſonne departinge frankfurt go two ſeuerall way man heſſe thother leadeth army donauerde ſendeth downe riuer thonawe hongary againſt turke inuading legion vnder leding riſeberge paſſing ouer riuer moene went marque albert withoute greate care prynces feared leaſt themperor woulde take occaſion hereby dimiſſe lantzgraue marque albert liyng frankfurt might haue bene compriſed peace would marque albert refuſeth peace ix day auguſt departeth thēce trāſporting army ouer rhine ineampeth beſides mentz broughte citezens ſubiection thend iuly themperor returning uillace inſprucke eight day departing thence marchinge throughe bauier almaignes bohemers italian spaniardes beginning iuly arriued gene conduit duke alba xx day auguſt came auſpurge tharchbiſhop mentz whā wandred certain day swenia ſo ſone vnderſtode emperor comming taketh iourney thither preſent time sene procurement aid french king caſt garriſon spaniard pull downe caſtell begon ther builded themperors commaundemēt recouer theyr former libertye meane ſeaſon marque albert impoſeth great ſome mony theccleſiaſticall perſons eſpecially mentz spiers whan ſame could leuied reaſon many wer fled ſpoyleth church either city began take lead cathedrall church spier requeſt senate ſurceaſed mentz burneth biſhops caſtell ſtandinge rhine owne lodging fiue church moreouer ſhippes yea thoſe laden wine wheat calling away thoſe ſouldiours ther placed garriſon marcheth towards border treuers xiii day auguſt herman archbiſhop collon pure aged man ended life natiue coū try deathe herman archebiſhop colon wiſh ſuch end deſired many time wiſhed either might ſetforth doctrin goſpel put good order church prouince liue priuate life ſometime frendes admoniſhed much enuye ſhoulde procure vnto ſelf alteration religion wonte make anſwer could chaunce nothing vnto vnloked minde eſtabliſhed againſte might fortune came noble houſe earles weden lantzgraue ſet liberty couenaunte taking iourney homeward whan commen utrecht towne ſtanding maſe commaundemente quene mary regent flaunders preſente attached againe committed cuſtodye ſame spaniardes kept theſe v yeres cauſe hereof riſeberge ſerued lantzgraues ſonne went force vnto marque albert ſaid wherin quene ſaid peace brokē therfore might ſhe let depart ſhe knewe themperors pleaſure therein duke moris ſaid comminge water thonawe xxii day auguſt ſendeth army footemen downe riuer horſmen lande ſelfe priuate affaire rideth home poſte mineding ſhortly return againe whan marque albert came frontier treuers george holie captain themperors brought ten enſeigns fotemen defend citye kepte oute townes men refuſed haue garriſon bringeth men lucemburge marque xxvii auguſt ſommoneth towne rendred vnto next day receiued marque albert entreth treuers beſtoweth ſoldiors city place aboutes biſhop meane ſeaſon caſtel ſaid ſituated rhine moſelle mete neither prelate ſame ordre themperor remaininge certaine day auſpurge diſplaceth senate whiche prince lately ordeined abrogateth tribe reſtoreth ſame ſtate common weale senate eſtabliſhed miniſters churche remoueth thre reaſte permitteth teach miniſter according fourm order confeſſion auſpurge thinge declared pulpit made many mēright glad xxv day yt mōth auguſt wheras yeare manner ſame day exiled haue xxii boke declared departing thence firſt day septembre leauing behind garriſon vi enſeignes fotemen two day came wuolmes army wente waye till came border wirtemberge done ſakes wuolmes leaſt theyr country ſhewed themperor ſo greate fidelity ſhould ſuſtain new domage ſame day themperor departed auſpurge ſente awaye ihon fridericke duke saxon goth home hys owne houſe duke saxon moſt gentle wordes promiſed largely beneuolence towardes next day toke hys iourney homeward lātzgraue alſo releaſed fourth septembre retourneth home ſixt day ſame time came forth fourth tome luther worckes whiche melanchthon making preface reioyſeth much duke returne highly commendeth conſtancy vſed time moſt aduerſity meane time marque albert treuers church ſhut vp remaining viii day whan burned certen abbaies caſtel biſhops far towne leaueth city garriſon xii enſeignes afterward marching towards sircke towne duchie loraine midway betwixt metz treuers xiii day septēbre paſſeth ther army ouer riuer moſelle inuadeth land lucemburge thence retourneth loraine euery wher doth much harme attending ſe manner condition french king would offer ſore afflicted biſhops franctonie recited whan themperor approched neare ſued biſhops dothe diſcharge thoſe compactes chargeth ſtand ſeke recouer theyr owne ſame doth permit alſo norinberge exhorteth defence theyr country would make league ſame thinge wryteth sweuia inhabiters rhine others aſwell prince city wherfore theſe foreſaide biſhops ſtate norinberge fortify ſelues afterwarde league time marque albert emperor comming went loraine biſhop bamberge aboute end auguſt septembre recouered townes forcheme diuers others themperor paſſing land wirtemberge held way toward spiers whan came bret themperor goeth wyth army toward lorain town prince palatine altering purpoſe tourned lefthand marched towards straſburge coming vi mile frō city came vnto ambaſſadors iames sturmie friderick gotteſſeme lewes grempre intreat ambaſſadors straſburge emperor would ſpare country lead army another way neither ſelf would enter city wt great power alter thing cōmon wealth right gently receiued ſaith knoweth rightwell worthely valiauntly city hath lately ſhewed ſelfe benefit haue done whole empire thing wil beare perpetuall memory dede wil declare occaſion ſerueth much bounden ſame afterward excuſeth diligently ſodain cōming reaſon ſhips brēt marque albert newes came frenchman inuade alſatia alſo time yt yere requireth expedition may come thenemy ſo ſone poſſible wherfore wil lead army long citye wherinto ſelf wil enter owne family taking dinner wil tary ther one night whan therfore xv day september cummen certaine village mile without city whole army deſtowed country abouts remaind ther v dais time themperor entreth straſburge cariage conueied rhine wherin ſmall difficulty aſſone day commaūding army march forth ſelf great company none came city neuer ſene louingly honorably receiued senate chance paſſe headchurch whan came thither alighted led prieſtes making ther ſmall abode went ſtraight dinner senate preſenteth gift cuſtome city praying accept good part anſwereth right acceptable whiche ſpoken certaine dais paſt cōcerning good wil towards theyr ſtout gouerning theyr ſtate moſt doubtfull pearillous time repeteth townes men haue hurt done without city ſoldiors orchardes heritage ſaith right ſory ſomuch vnpoſſible ſaue al vpright amonges ſo great multitude praieth take patiently chiefly warre made thempire afterward toward euening entring way hagenaw tourned next village ther reaſted al night time straſburge going metz commaunded thambaſſadors forain prince followed court go spier remain time ſir richard moriſine knight sir richard moriſine ambaſſadour england marque antonius ambaſſadour ueniſe ſpoil ſoldiors ambaſſador edward vi king england amongs mē learned hath worthy name ſtate ueniſe marcke anthony amulie alſo ſelf well learned great fauorer learning thoſe dais themperor ſtaid city man would beleue hurt ſouldiours ye country heauy ſight ſe pore huſband mē wiues child come running citye ſpoyled euer matter complained vppon duke alua senate ſaide ſory would ſe like ſhuld done henceforthe yet preuail nothing way ſo euer wēt manner ſpoyled thinges duke alua lieftenant generall whole armye manner complaintes brought vnto neither might man ſuffred ſpeke themperor thought haue ſuch thing ſai meane ſeaſon frenchman conduit duke guiſe fortify chiefly metz nancey alſo conuey thither al wheat forage country ther ſerued themperor thō marque brandenburge alphonſe duke holſt brother king denmarke philiberte ſonne duke sauoy outlawes refuſinge condition peace remained ſtill fraunce ducheſſe lorayne expulſed oute country deathe caſpar hedio andrew oſiander ſpake themperor vncle straſburge went brabant xvii daye monthe october died caſpar hedio chief miniſter church straſburge ſame day alſo died andrew oſiander coningſperge town pruſe ſea coaſt themperor remoueth hagenaw landaw ther making abode xvi dais faire weather without great wonder many length taketh way metz xxii day octobre beſiegeth city uery many citezens senator permiſſion frenche themperor beſegeth metz men went way ſome loraine ſome straſburge marque albert border lorayne towne pontamoſſe l enſeſgnes fotemen ſmal power horſmen wher french king could agre vpon wage aſwell time paſt alſo time come mediation certaine reconciled themperor marque albert reconciled themperor pardoned offence prohibiteth action ſhould commēced againſt enterpriſes warre ratifieth compact made biſhops bamberge wirciburge releaſeth warfare hongary ſake pardoneth earle oetinge father ſonne whoſe miſfortune mentioned likewiſe albert earle manſfeld ſonnes thing known duke danmalle brother duke guiſe ſent lorayne great power horſmen king leaſt yt marque ſtode doubt ſhould worke miſchiefe purpoſed ſet vppon nowe french men ſecreatly plucked one legion fote men conduit riſeberge reuolted frēch king afterward attempted reaſt army alſo purpoſe want mony made naked deſtitute men thei mighte put flighte ſhame duke danmalle counſell ihon fraxine biſhop baion whan exhorted likewiſe gaue charge whole force fotemen want paye refuſed fighte wherefore whole truſt horſmen whome marque ſpeaking frendly exhorting valeaunte ſet vpon fortune albert ouerthroweth french men fauored bold enterpriſe breaking throughe maigne battell ouerthroweth putteth flighte far mo nombre ſlayinge many euen nobilitye fraxine biſhop eſcaped away flight duke danmalle receiuing thre woundes taken fourth day nouembre duke de anmalle taken priſoner whan marque albert obteined victorye came metz duke danmalle priſoner pitcheth tent riuer moſelle time healed priſoner woū de ſent germany kept lieuetenāt alſo proteſtants war george noble houſe lichteberges adnertiſeth biſhop bamberge compactes confirmed themperor admoniſheth kepe promeſſe reſtore vnto townes commaundeth captain alſo vnles ſo recouer force armes ſelf ſame time themperors army low country inuadeth fraunce taketh heſdine ſtrongeſt caſtell thoſe party certaine time french king recouereth ſending letter germany taunteth emperor bitterly exhorteth kepe amitye mindful benefit receiued theyr liberty reſtored time iudges chamber imperiall whoſe fleinge haue ſpoken retourne spiers emperoure yet remained dedehoue whiche towne riuer moſelle foure mile beneath metz twenty day nouembre came campe chiefly city maruelouſlye beaten ſhot violence wherof ſo great noiſe thondering thereof greate battery metz hard straſburge alſo iiii dutche mile beyond rhine straſburge metz xviii great dutch mile duke moris ſaid went army hongary king fardinando time retourneth home time uolrate ſonne albert earle manſfeld made duke brunſwicke driuen country warre againſt henry duke brunſwicke maner driuen whole countrye duke henry therefore commeth emperor metz complaining miſfortune deſireth aid time counte manſfelde ſerued vnder marque albert whileſt yet frēch party whileſt themperor beſiegeth metz wuolfgange maiſter almaigne order taketh towne eluange ritch promotion eccleſiaſticall whiche ſued manye moneths fellowes prebend colledge haue authority chuſe prouoſt commonly call whan therfore choſen one noble houſe ſory paſſed vpon ſoden ſurpriſeth place known duke wirtemberge whome fellowes colledge beſought defend righte leuieth men immediatly ſetting forth cold winter ſeaſon recouereth eaſely beſides winneth town two till recompenced charge ſoldiors french men wer beſieged make many ſales oute eſpecially mar albert camp amongs others lichteberge lieftenaunt ſore wounded winter ſharpe froſt ſnow althoughe themperor exceadinge great army yet abſtaine aſſault attempted thing mine vain whan time ye yere let therunto thenemy alſo knew eſpial ther defēded city moſt choſen captaine commen noble houſes ye chief duke guiſe defended metz gouernor duke guiſe time lieuetenauntes marque albert hired ſouldiours commaundemente biſhop bamberge complaininge therof thimperiall chamber xxix day decembre obtaineth letter wherby albertines wer cōmaunded lay away armor wuolmes recouering caſtell helſeſteine expulſinge garriſon marque albert lefte raſed downe harde ground themperor enforced thextremity cold winter thend decembre diſpaire thinge leuied ſiege remouing thēce dedehouie ſo returning flanders cōmaundeth certen legion remain countrye treuers amonges whiche alſo marque albert cold ſickneſſe themperor leſt third part army french men xxii day ianuary go proceſſion church metz geuing god thankes theyr good fortune 1553 next day ſearched al lutherian bokes citezens houſes hangman brente openlye duke guiſſe leauing ther deputie returneth frāce ſame moneth captain marque albert wone many thing biſhop bamberge ſiege metz leuied whan marque albert wintred treuers til themperor paied wage moneth february returning germany biſhop bamberge xvii day ſame moneth obteyneth newe letter chā ber wherof one commaunded agayne theſame thother inioyned nobilite franckeconie norinberge paulſgraue electour iohn friderick duke saxon next neighboures helpe thende moneth february french king puft vp pride metz ſo defended ſetteth forth wryting printe french kinges wryting againſt themperor vnto ſtates empire verye ſtinginge hatefull emperoure goeth aboute bringe hatred
