contempt alſo verely nowe feared whoſe power readye fringed craft many yeares detected whiche alſo ſo ſicke diſeaſed hardlye kepe life doubtles wil alwais one mind towards thē wit frendly liberall diuers thē whiche haue receiued greate benefites haue ſhewed thē ſelues verye thanckefull yet wyll therefore renounce frendſhip reaſt marque albert aduertiſed commaundement chamber imperiall wryteth manye letter biſhop arras duke alua emperoure ſelfe ſignifyinge biſhops go aboute howe breake couenauntes ſo muche hathe ratified thoſe compactes made requyreth ther maye penaltye appoynted vnleſſe obey ſame afterwarde ſendinge meſſager chamber spier declareth biſhoppes haue broken couenauntes themperors commaundemente alſo wherefore requireth woulde ſuffer none action commenced againſte woulde aboliſhe letter whiche aduerſaries obtained wherunto make anſwer theyr partes duety miniſter law vnto men coulde denie biſhoppes alſo requiring ſame longe confutation requireth ſame el caſe ſuſtain loſſe ſhal haue good cauſe require amendes recompence hand themperor xiii march wryteth anſwer letter emperours letter aunſwere marque albert marque albert ratified compacte deny paied alſo men theyr wage moſt liberallye owne greate hinderaunce gaue reſidue nothinge woulde haue bene righte glad biſhoppes woulde haue ſtirred matter ſame cauſe ſent ambaſſadoure perſwade ſince haue refuſed haue appealed alſo prince elector chamber imperiall ſeeth well inoughe denied eſpecially conſideringe howe diuers ſtates haue conceiued ſuſpition ſpreade diuers brute caſe ſhould accompliſhe requeſt cō maunde kepe couenauntes woulde ſaide wronge ſhoulde increaſe ſuſpicion office miniſter iuſtice indifferently vnto men prohibite wronge violence therefore way matter maye frendly taken vp doubteth ſelf ponder matter diligently wil take ſame way intent matter may eaſely purpoſelye broughte paſſe appoynt owne kinſmen duke bauier wirtemberge ſhall meanes matter biſhops verely diuers ſondry letter haue complained greuouſly neuertheleſſe truſteth refuſe treaty controuerſy betwene duke brunſwicke nobility hath committed hearinge ye matter ihon marque brādenburge hath appoynted alſo duke bauier wirtemberge end matter betwene therles deting father ſonnes manner time tharmy counte manſfeld ſhrank away thambaſſadors ihon friderick duke moris met together accord thē two letter coyne ſtamped vſed ſtil name elector ii ſwords croſſe tharmes tharmes electorſhyp electorſhip themperors permiſſiō fortified caſtel goth thing duke moris toke greuouſly cōplaineth therof ſtates opiniō al thē deuiſe meanes peace wherfore ſaid ambaſſadors wer ſēt yet vain cardinall lenoncourtes ambition time alſo robert biſhop metz cardinal lenōcurt moſt addict french king came metz chalengeth ſelfe hole iuriſdictiō ſaith belōgeth prince themand ordeineth newe senate placeth nombre diuers cleargy fortifieth marſey little towne ſtandinge frontier germany fortificatiōs garriſon french men letter wer intercepted wherein deſired king would permit haue iuriſdiction whiche biſhoppes predeceſſors haue intent ordain new senate receiue none ſame ſhall wholly addicted el come paſſe ſuch emperor part ſhall remaine others ſhall depart thence doubtleſſe woulde great hinderaunce vnleſſe ſuſpected perſonnes cleane remoued let loke kepe city quiet poſſeſſion deſireth declare hart good wlil towardes euen ſame cauſe chiefly came theſe party receiued biſhoppricke might ſome notable ſeruice marque albert hedelberge paulſgraue elector ſente thoſe foreſaid letter iudges chamber time came alſo hedelberge themperors commaundement duke bauier wirtemberge pacification thither came alſo duke cleaue matter longe debated whan biſhoppes offred wonderfull ſumme mony eſpecially bamberge might haue townes quiet interceſſors alſo approued condition marque would haue couenauntes obſerued themperor alſo confirmed wheras ſame time captaines leuied horſmen saxony aſſured certen mennes aid departeth nothing done interceſſors ſore offended bendeth ſelfe war publiſhing wrying xxvii march repeteth whole matter order complaining mooſte greuouſlye aduerſaries breaking theyr promeſſe confuteth reaſon whereby biſhoppes alledge maye alienate nothing church goodes ſheweth driuen neceſſitye defende hys righte force armes biſhop wirciburge ther ſelf bamberge ſente deputy grudge controuerſy betwene duke wirtemberge maiſter almaigne order mediation prince appeaſed man recouer townes paid xxx thouſand crownes ſecond day aprill whyche eaſter daye duke moris came alſo vnto prince hedelberge vſing greate expedition thre dais returneth home againe poſte theſe prynces interceſſoures make league maye defende ſelues iniurie therin cōpriſed alſo archbiſhops mentz treuers whan marque albert refuſing condicions wente hedelberge gather armye biſhoppes bamberge wirciburge procure letter chā ber archbiſhoppe mentz paulſgraue duke moris maiſter pruiſſe duke saxon duke wirtemberge lantzgraue norinbergians theyr neyghboures commaunded aſſiſt ſecond day may duke moris ſuſpected marque albert ſuppoſed alſo pricked ſame owne aſſuraunce maketh league duke brunſwicke promiſeth aid biſhoppes norinbergians meane ſeaſon marque ſpoylinges burninges marque albert albert hauinge leuied power marcheth forewarde country biſhoppes ſtate norinberge deſtroyeth burninge ſpoylinge taketh citye bamberge head towne countrye threatneth warre nobilitye frankonie vnleſſe obey ſurpriſeth schuinfurt towne imperiall fortifieth garriſon norinbergians becauſe hold certain townes caſtels benefite realme boheme intreated king farnando might leuy certaine horſmen hys dominion defend thoſe place king content permitted gather fiue hondreth marque comminge intercepteth taketh alſo certaine foreſaide townes caſtels againe ſide henrye duke brunſwicke drawen vnto greate parte counte manſfeldes army phillip ſonne moueth warre againſte neighboures inuadinge border country biſhoppes munſter minden coſin alſo duke erike brunſwicke ſtate breme extorteth maruelous great ſome monye aboute tune controuerſy duke cleaue archbiſhop collon certaine iuriſdiction mediation paulſgraue biſhoppe treuers whiche met bacheracke throughly appeaſed little beginning monthe iune paulſgraue tharchbiſhop mentz thambaſſadors duke bauier wirtemberge themperors cōmaundement mete franckfurt aboute warre franckonie emperoure ambaſſadors ther coūte conigſten therle solmen hēry haſie king ferdinando theralſo diuers wher biſhops brged emperours abrogation marque cōfirmatiō thelectors admoniſh ambaſſadors ſignify vnto thintent may aduertiſe whether wil haue take place themperor xvii day iune maketh anſwer wheras laſt yeare paſt hard compoſition marque albert biſhops ſute requeſt certen aboliſhed ſame cōmaunding biſhops kepe matter euil preſident compell man ſuche ſubiection duety thempire afterwarde whan marque albert would none otherwiſe accord excepte thoſe former compoſitions ratified eſchue conuenience like inſue vpon germany ſerued time preſent ſo much armye readye counte manſfeld alſo name gatheringe newe power saxonie ſelf troubled french warres could ſuppreſſe neither ther al germany hable one day abide force made peace hope verely ſhuld quiet afterward eſpecially prince kinſmen ſhould trauell thing certē ly god ſente good ſucceſſe metz deuiſed meanes wherby ſhuld haue ben ſatiſfied muche good ſeruice ſame warre ſo much deſirous gratify ſiege toke place aſſaid howe make concord hedelberge wher marque refuſed condition ther propounded hath moued war diſpleaſaunte therfore aſſigne thys conuention franckfurt reported vnto attempteth warre againſte biſhoppes againſt certen others alſo thing greueth exceadinglye done alſo contrarye compactes time receiued fauoure promiſed faithfull ſeruice hereafter bothe thempire yet would leaſt obey coulde contente forget thinges paſt ſelfe alſo ſuſpicion diuers wrongfullye done wherfore let indeuoure wyth theyr force make pacification require declaration matter ſame ſhall mooſte acceptable matter concerninge empyre nothinge henceforth theyr aduiſe counſell lengthe departed frō frāckfurte wythoute matter ended aboute ſame time alſo themperors commaundemente duke bauier wirtemberge others aſſemble lawginge might pacifye father ſōnes cō tend inheritaunce earles detinge father sonnes euer ſince proteſtantes warre vnto ſiege metz lewes father eldeſt ſonne ſame name haue wandred vp moſt vncertenty warred againſt themperor landes poſſeſſions themperors permiſſion ſonnes fridericke wuolfgange whiche contrarye religion whan came treaty father accuſeth moſte ingratitude prynces laboured matter diligently yet coulde nothing determined xxv booke sledaines commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charles fyfte argument xxv booke warre beginning piedmount duke moris marque albert deſiaunce loyne battell wherin duke moris ſlaine marque loſt field auguſtus brother ſuccedeth duke moris iohn fridericke maketh reclaime hys landes time nine martirs executed lion good king edward englād dead ſiſter mary proclaimed quene popiſh biſhops reſtored dignity marque albert hauing loſt field againſt henry duke brunſwicke ſurpriſeth towne holſe baniſhed diſputation england sacramente thaultare lady iane proclaimed quene beheaded greate execution done england bleſſed death duke saxon wife alberte exiled worketh greate crueltye marye quene englande maried kinge phillip cardinall poole geueth full abſolution england aſſemble auſpurge many excellente parſonages condemned englande wholy reconqueſted pope intent ſome remeady might founde theſe trouble tumult germany emperour month may calleth aſſembly thempire xiii day auguſt whan beſieged citye terwen dominion fraunce end aprill xx day iune taketh terwen raſed aſſaulte ſpoyleth burneth raſeth ground conſtable ſonne taken ſame king englande ſendinge honorable ambaſſade ſpace certaine monthes intreated peace ſame biſhop rome vain month may ihon duke northumberlād death lord protector kinges uncle ye chief lady iane suffolke maried buylford dudley gouernment ſaide marieth one sonnes lady iane suffolke daughter lady fraunces whiche nece kinge henrye eighte siſter frenche quene time kinge edwarde greuouſlye ſicke warre alſo piedmont hither partes italy kinge edward ſore ſicke war italye emperour purpoſed recouer sene ſendinge thither power naples vnder conduit uiceroy peter toletane wheras died turkiſh nauy whiche prince salerne going fraunce ioyned ſelf ſailing sea grece italy ſoldiors retourned home repulſe neare domeſticall daunger marque albert kepinge warre franconie duke moris fellowes ſend army thither marque therfore leauing garriſon schuinfurt place whan euerye exacted monye haſted greate expedition saxony leading away many pledge oute dominion norinberge bamberge captiues whan cō men aruſtet ambaſſadors ihon fridericke duke saxon intreat would hurte country promiſed right gently kept marching limites erfurde ſpoyleth manye village duke moris amaſed ſoden comming ſente armye franckonie ſaide commaundeth nobility alſo thother ſtates put armure hyreth many coulde mar maketh war saxonye marque paſſing countrye oute doinge anye hurte whan came halberſtat taketh gate impoſeth cleargye greate ſumme monye burneth deſtroyeth countrye henrye duke brunſwicke beinge aided duke ericke nobilitye brunſwicke duke brunſwickes armye whiche ſaide gone franckonie conduit phillip sonne whan attempted schuinfurte vaine ſaw ther pearill home retourne saxonie likewiſe souldioures duke moris whereof earle hedecke leading ioyn wt duke moris northuſe ſo much ye marque tourned downe prouince minden duke moris thinckinge woulde haue gone throughe heſſe againe made inuaſion franconie northuſe marcheth embecke mighte preuente ende ioyninge force together incampeth countrye hildeſſeme oſterode firſt day iuly alſo chaū celour boheme henrye plauie kinge fardinandoes name king fernādo proclameth warre agaynſte albert proclaime warre againſte ſending abrode theyr letter themperor ſay theſe former yeares hath common aſſent conſent prince ſtates eſtabliſhed peace throughe empire gaue commaundement action ſome euer man ſhould try law worcke force violence certainly ſtate germany hath bene nowe certaine yeares nowe ſore afflicted ciuill warres doth much require peace quietneſſe wherfore time aroſe warre lately within limit empire kinge ferdinando healpe others indeuoured toke paine warre appeaſed lengthe prince conſentes chiefe captain warre finally emperoures permiſſion concluded peace wherin prouided amongs thinges nothing done contrary ſuche alſo dāger ſhuld aided aſſiſted ſame peace marque albert refuſe alſo wryte openly certen renowmed prince ſame tēded great reproche dommage germany worthye called treaſon peace making wordes declare ſufficiently minde beare natiue country whā ſpoyling burning diſtroied countrye lieth rhine wheras good ſucceſſe fraunce themperor army prepared throughe interceſſion reconciled vpon reſpect would confirme youre compoſition biſhops bamberge wirciburge ſtraightwaies abuſinge confirmation themperor permitted ſhew violence haue youre miniſters manye time put feare either prelate moſt terrible threatninges ſaying would inforce tharmies earles manſfeld oldenburge obſerue couenauntes men letter proued alſo mighte bring paſſe ſoldiors diſcharged ye ſiege metz leuied commaunded retourne againe beginning aprill put matter arbitrement themperor king ferdinando prince cl referred controuerſy iudges chamber lawes thempire namely hedelberge offered ſuche condition prince interceſſors alſo themperor letter approued ſame yet refuſinge theſe offer haue inuaded prouinces ſurpriſing certain place haue ſpared ſpoile gentle woman ſo practiſing ſpoilinge exaction mony haue fired many caſtels townes uillages ſpoylinges al buildinges burning cruelly men ſome place aſwell theyrs ſtate norinberge publicke law empire league alſo lately made aſſiſt haue taken oute ſondrye place townes men citezens greate yeares age vnweldie pledge mony impoſed haue caried aboute lower partes saxony cruelly tirannically way ſoeuer went moreouer againſt righte haue proclaimed warre agauiſt nobility franckonie taken sthuinfurt town imperiall fortified garriſon whyche thynges doubtleſſe haue raiſed vp wonderfull trouble terrour place furthermore haue ſpared king fardinando bounden wardſhip league inheritaunce yet throughe certaine deſperate raſhneſſe haue made rhoades border boheme alſo haue ſore afflicted poſſeſſions kingdom graunted time paſte compoſition norinberge diuers honeſt men alſo ſame iuriſdiction haue partlye ſlaine partly brought extreame pouerty miſery ſame guidons horſmen king licenced norinbergians leuy defence theyr country wrong man haue ſet vppon taken ſpoyling horſe armure haue compelled retourne home furthermore kepe certaine traitoures ſuch kinge hathe outlawed rebellion ſpeake wordes reported full threatninges againſt kinge bohemers yet hathe king geuen none occaſion ſo hath euer auanced commodity meanes coulde entred country one yeare paſt full like ennemy yet ignoraunt frendly wrote vnto ſhuld amend fault alſo beware henceforth part ſaith duke moris life complaint moris vpon marque al neuer gaue occaſion diſpleaſure haue rather beſtowed vpon many benefit yet laſt yeare whan peace concluded departing franckfurt common welthes ſake king ferdinandos led army hongary againſt turke remember meanes ſoughte allure men opprobrious wordes gaue ſoldioures others time ſpeaking pacification paſſawe called betraying germanye meaning frend henrye plauie moreouer ignoraunt thing attempted laſte winter whan hongary deſtruction country army earle manſfeld duchy brū ſwicke whan wer reconciled themperor manner wordes ſtinginge bitinge alſo howe threatning contumelious ye ſpake againſte prouince ſiege metz know werethan campe whan retourned home ſiege leuied demaunded letter ſame matter mind towards anſwered proudlye yt whatſoeuer haue ſpoken others remembre deny ſame thother made ſuch anſwer gether certaintainty therof wryting ſame matter hedelberge alledged certain thinges great parſonages intent ſuppoſe might cauſe ſuſpect diſtruſt wheras gaue great regard ſuch matter aduiſed counſelled bothe letter intermeſſagers ſhould obſerue peace alſo deſyred know ſelf ſhould loke hand wryting letter thelector brandenburge ſpake ſomwhat temperatly yet wher come pacification paſſaw ſignified plainly enough howe affected towards long declared alſo dede certen laſt letter required woulde call backe army tentes confederate franckonie intent verely vnleſſe ſo mighte haue occaſion war againſt againe ſhortly led army country brother auguſtus wher geuen v knowledge ther cleane contrary thaunciente cuſtome germany make boaſt hurte went men report far otherwiſe ſo yet ſo much aſcribe neceſſity knowen faſt marched weary souldiours wer knew rightwel caſe attempted force ſhewed violence ben harde haue reſiſted army ſo faint weried traueling haue called home thoſe franckonie doubtleſſe purpoſe haue ſet return haue souldiors let ſaye moreouer paſſyng country thuring ſpoiled certen village city erfurd vnder tuition denye owne letter wrytten brunſwicke ſoldiors alſo haue ſlaine diuers brother country neare vnto bichlinge toke two gentleman whan appealed vnto bette whippes caſt priſon yet could broughte attempte warre required ſame letter exhorting peace wherof treaty franckfurt inquyred minde towardes fellowes bitterly angerly anſwered appereth letter neither woulde vtter minde yet accuſed treaty franckfurt ſuſpected whereof could gether none otherwiſe determined continue warre frankonie yea occaſion ſerued ſpare neither fellowes alſo denounced erfurde immediatly declared alſo others beſides many others diſpleaſures biſhoppricke halberſtat themperor knowe hathe committed protection impoſed great ſome monye ſpoyled theyr colledges country neuertheleſſe ſame alſo archbiſhoppricke maidenburge likewiſe compriſed vnder tuition haue exacted monye northuſians mulluſians henrye duke brunſwicke whome haue made league righte honeſt dede duke mor league duke brūſwicke repugnant treatye paſſawe haue perſecuted ſword fire ſo ſone aduertiſed letter league reaſt fellowes theſe thinges doubtles correſpondent certain former letter therfore although king ferdinando fellowes greatly deſire peace eſpeciallye germany euer ſence pacification paſſaw indeuor al thinges may quiet eſpecially theſe party thing alſo manye nobility brunſwicke ſerue camp teſtify yet ſo much haue remoued war theſe party declare manifeſtly whan inuade fellowes intēt moreouer ſo muche brute yt hyring greater force though others mās name hable find except permit robbe ſpoyle worke miſchief liſt ſo much frankonie prouinces alſo ſtand great danger ſelfe diſſemble whileſt ſaye brynge paſſe man el ſhall better caſe theſe cauſes ſay ſo muche leaue place vnto concorde king fernando fellowes ſeing next dāger conſtrained put armure repulſe v violence iniury end may deliuer natiue countrye recouer publike quietneſſe lawes empire permit inioyne v alſo high court chambre imperiall commaundeth v aid aſſiſt neighbor frā konye althoughe time leuye men pretend themperors name yet knowe aſſuredly ſame forged famed hath declared mind v alſo ſhortly ſhal know thincketh ſince enterpriſe attempted common wealthes ſake therfore neaded declaration mind yet thintent ſhall ignorant proteſt hereafter thinge ſelfe ſhall require diſſolute tirannicall cruelty may ſuppreſſed verelye oure owne name oure fellowes vnderſtand hear teſtify blame calamity ſhall chaunce warre wholy imputed vnto come reaſonable condition nether doubt alſo euerliuing god aſſiſte rather thoſe ſeke ſafegard countrye goeth deſtruction warreth natiue country time theſe letter deliuered campe marque albert ambaſſadoures electoure brandenburge ſente perſwade peace whan red letter cōſulteth matter captaines demaundeth whether take part affirming calleth yong gētleman brought letter tourning talke thy prince ſaith hathe thriſe broken faith hath done wickedly thys fourth fact ſame ſort let come hardly wil proue tell name mar annſwere duke moris theſe wordes geueth certaine crownes rewarde ſendeth waye ambaſſadoures interceſſors ſhall nothing ſay theyrnothing ſaith may retourne home whan therfore perceiued waight warre ſendeth duke ericke brunſwick emperor third day iuly ſignifieth vnto policy marque albert ſendeth emperor certen ther wer many aduerſaries raiſed againſte whiche indeuor couenaunts kepte alſo might expulſed al land poſſeſſions reaſon new conſpiracy able proue certen prince elector chiefeſt germanye haue conſpired chuſe newe emperour cauſe biſhoppes ſo ſore againſt long iudges chamber prayeth hym therfore would offended ſhall attempt ought againſt aduerſaries alſo bryng hym hatred allure mo vnto haue reyſed brute though hath conſpyred oppreſſe libertie germany doubtleſſe haue certen prynces obiected vnto hym letter caſte abroade germany ſent byſhop arras howe verely intent hyreth armie myght accomplyſhe wyll duke alba ſhall brynge ſonne prynce spayne germany next conuention empyre may denounced ſucceſſour empyre kyng ferdinando ſo fully perſwaded entryng league ennemies hath proclaimed warre againſte hym hath verely excuſed vnto many ryght dilligently ſuſpicion increaſeth dayly therfore ſubiecte vnto great perilles daungers maner cauſe wyll forſake frendſhyp wherfore humbly beſecheth hym wyll bothe ratifie thoſe compoſitions byſhoppes alſo defende hym wyll doe wyll brynge vnto hym whan matter ſhall agreed vpon ix thouſande horſemen hondreth enſeignes footemen meane tyme norinbergians byſhops abſence marque albert inuade dominion biſhops abſence inuade counitie publiſhyng letter blamed ſore norinberge thoſe broken fayth conuenauntes entrynge league faulſe byſhoppes imbraced agayne popiſhe doctrine wherunto afterwarde ſetting forth boke make aunſwere recite whole matter order euer ſynce yeare howe cruel warre hath kept made compacte hym howe emperours permiſſion conſente made league byſhoppes aboute howe hathe refuſed mooſte reaſonable condition offered ſame byſhoppes againe moued warre agaynſte howe tyme bothe league made alſo commaundement chamber ayded theyr fellowes inuaded agayne theyr countrie lately amongeſt others hys wycked actes recite rare example ſuche crueltie hath bene hearde hauyng taken two townes dominion altorfe lanſe ſhut townes great crueltie mar albert men alſo people could fynde countrie eattell ſet fyre ſondry place chiefly gate pourpoſing doubtleſſe burne vp fire ſay chyldrē woman chylde many ſicke perſones able breake walles eſcape miſerably brent touchinge ſaieth altering religiō declare falſe league made repulſe violence careth religion well knowen many alſo haue many thinges ſaye behalfe noble familie commeth certen prince kinſmen wyll temper ſelues fift daye iuly sigiſmunde kynge pole marieth lady katherine daughter kyng ferdinando bene wyfe duke mantua ten yeares ſynce maried ſyſter mentioned xv boke edwarde ſyxte kyng englande prynce vndoubted excellent hope ſyxt daye iuly knowen death good kyng edward abroade departed lyfe conſumyng diſeaſe beyng xvi yeares age exceadynge great grief good godly men death enſued maruelous alteration thynges englande ſhalbe declared hereafter bruted abroade poyſoned certenly europe kyng ſo great expectation theſe many yeares chyldhode excellently well brought vp inſtructed vertue learnyng vertues edward ſixt latin tongue greke frenche alſo loued doctrine goſpell exceadyngly gaue vnto learned men enterteinement ſuccour germaines italian frenchemen scottes spanyardes polonians tyme army farre ſonder saxonie battell fought betwixt duke maurice mar albert marque come ouer water weſer nynth daye iuly none ioyned battell theyr force longe fyght duke maurice whiche excelled horſemen victory hym ſelfe beyng ſtriken dagge bowel died within two dayes marque came hanobrie ſafitie ſlayne aboute foure thouſande maner al horſemen taken exceadyng many henry duke brunſwycke loſte conflicte two ſonnes charles philippe nexte daye came fiue hondreth horſemen boheme ſent kynge ferdinando duke maurice lantgraue alſo ſent duke maurice ſeuen hondreth horſemen ſame tyme therfore together one campe lantgraue duke brunſwick byſhoppes maruelous chaunge contrarietie thinges duke ericke brunſwicke maried duke maurice ſyſter ayded marque alberte many menne thought tyme lyke kinge ferdinando gaue ayde againſt marque albert ſo emperour incourage ſtrengthen marque againſt duke maurice howebeit emperours letter whiche hereafter ſhall recite importe ſuche kynde thynges frenche kyng ſayde haue treated newe deuiſes duke maurice ryght ſory death duke maurice caried tente ſame nyght wryteth letter byſhop wirtemburge fellowe warre wherein declareth whole matter ſaieth howe victory ſore wounded ſuppoſeth albert fliyng admonyſheth hym therfore commaunde wayes layde hym certen place may intercepted ſuffered paſſe ſo euer owne ſtate ende ſhal good conſcience toke hande warre myght ſuppreſſe diſturber recouer quietnes germany buried fridberge towne meiſſen fourtenth daye battell henry father yong ſonne albert xxxii yeares olde vpwarde preſence thought great cauſe victory el ſuppoſed marque ſhould haue wonne fielde maurice wan yt fielde loſt lyfe many horſemen fled taken ennemies brought vnto hym battell liiii enſeignes xiiii guidons whiche duke maurice dede ſpent owne lyfe yet ouerthrewe force power marque battell neuer able gather mayne power whan corp went lipſia ioachim camerarie made oration funerall ſpeakyng muche commendation rekened vp wonder wōders death went death droppes bloude ſtyckynge vpon leaues tree moſte importune barkynge dogges werieng one neyinge horſes hearde clatterynge clankynge harneſſe certen thynges full terrour againe owne tente ouerthrowen whirlewynde reſidue ſtanding ſtill touched certen wordes owne foreſpeaking prognoſticating death come certenly touching thoſe red droppes commonly ſene diuerſe place euen straſburge aboute beginning iune tyme fell vpō bowes graſſe tyled houſes ſtones tyme flie wonderfull number butterfly ſome ſayde howe theſe bloudy droppes came againe others iudged pourtēde ſignifie ſome thing betwene duke maurice marqes albert one age bene great frendſhip betwixt maurice marqu albert alwayes great frendſhip ſo could derer frendes thei ſerued emperour thre warres together frenche proteſtauntes warre maydenburge fourth laſte warre attempted againſt emperour diſpleaſures aryſing ſayd amitie length doulefull ſorouful ende tyme duke maurice died brother auguſtus denmarke wyfe kyng father lawe wherfore nobilitie state doe retaine parte armie defende countrie xii enſeignes fotemen fiue guidons horſemē reſidue diſcharged moſte part retourned home funerall xviii daye iuly marque albert wryteth letter nobilitie people duke maurice late marq letter yt ſtates maurice went coūtrie saxon paſſed without harme hoſtilitie mynde duke maurice hath hurt men dominion alſo intent gratifie certen wicked periured biſhops renounced yt auncient league betwene familie ye houſe saxon maner cauſe ſtraūge example made warre againſt whiche thing ſo dede ſo muche thē ſelues haue furthered enterpriſe cleane againſt emperours cōmaundement therfore muſt ſee hym ſelfe howe may recompence himſelf domage receiued therfore renounceth league amitie emperours armie turwen ouerthrowen marching thence artois moneth iuly toke caſtell heſdine aſſaute ſlayne oratius farneſe frenche kynges ſonne lawe manye nobilitie taken amonges whome death orace farneſe hyghe mareſhall fraunce marchian dwelleth foreſte arden newes battell saxonie brought empu • within fewe dayes xxii daye iuly aunſwereth duke ericke brunſwicke whome marque albert ſent ſayde howe little ſory diſpleaſure growen ſo farre muche rather controuerſie bene appeaſed vnles ſo feareth leaſt wyll come euyll paſſe empyre alſo marque albert eſpecially ſince ſo many chiefeſt state doe ſet fote herein haue made league therfore aduiſe requeſt al ſpede laye downe theyr weapon deuiſe ſome meanes concorde marque ſo content wyll deuiſe contrary parte ſhall ſurceſſe alſo diſtruſteth ſhall perſwade earneſtly deſyreth refuſe ſo doe otherwyſe caſe ſtandyng doth nowe vſe ſeruice leaſt ſhould increaſe ſuſpicion reyſed already whiche doubtleſſe vnto hym hath nothyng derer peace tranquillitie empyre ſhould greuous diſpleaſaunt begynning moneth auguſte auguſtus auguſtus brother heſre du maurice duke maurice brother commyng home denmarke fewe dayes conſultyng counſel taketh othe people amongeſt others wyttembergians true hym heyres male none remain retourne fidelitie iohn fridericke chyldren caſe obey emperour obſerue compactes fourmer yeares obedient lantgraue done ſaluted prynce electour calleth aſſemblee state appere hym xx daye auguſte xvii daye moneth marueilous great earthquake towne meſen whan aſſembled lipſia daye many duke auguſte bryngeth queſtion fyrſte whether ſhould ioyne hym ſelfe newe league kyng ferdinando prynces byſhopes proſecute brother warre againſt marque albert secondarely ſhould forſake league ought auenge brother death finally meanes may compounde iohn fridericke abſence ſendyng letter noble required dignitie electourſhyp poſſeſſions taken awaye myght wholy reſtored hym effect conſultatiō counſell ſhould obſerue peace electour brandenburg ſhould treate pacificatiō hereof order made although king ferdinando henry plauie chauncelour boheme treated earneſtly duke auguſte concerning league conuention duke saxon ſending againe ambaſſade iohn frederick demaū deth landes dignity demaundeth owne ſharpe wordes ſame state dominion vaine auguſte ſayed howe bounde ſo doe would ſticke thoſe compactes conuenauntes emperour made whan takē yet would refuſe treatie ſame aſſemblie henry duke brunſwicke deſyred ayde duke auguſte againſt marque albert whiche hyred new bandes ſoldiours death duke maurice duke saxon ſent thone ſōnes iohn william brabant emperour might reſtored maner ſame time nobilitie ſtates dominion ſent thyther ambeſſadours alſo abſence duke auguſte emperour wold accept prince commended duke saxon ſent ambaſſadours alſo kyng ferdinando kynge denmarke ſame matter meane ſeaſon biſhop wirtemburg beſegeth schninfurt kept garriſon marque albert ſayd byſhop bamberge norinbergians whan whyle beſeged collebach leading away power ioyne thē ſelues counte plauie whiche layed batterie towne hoſie belonging marque theſe monethes ix burnt lion whan diuers bene pryſon yeare article propounded nyne burnt lion al preſence chriſtes body lordes ſupper purgatory maſſe priuate auricular confeſſion ceremony praiyng virgin mary dead ſupremacie biſhop rome free wyll iuſtification workes authoritie churche byſhoppes monaſticall vowes choice meates vnction confirmatiō image aunſwered euery point conſtantly one ſorte ſeuerally alledging teſtimonies scripture whyleſt pryſon letter comforted one alſo frendes church wrote euery thing done tyme lewys marſake one pryſoners mā warre alledging many thing lewys marſake holy scripture inquiſitours preſēt demaunded whether part read bokes scripture aſked knewe theſe thinges goſpell kinges liftenaunt alſo ſayd onely two euangeliſtes matthew iohn two blaſphe yt lieftenaunt paule alſo ſowed together certen fragmentes patch doctours churche attribute paule authoritie wold ſet epiſtles eſopes fable whan marſake inferred agayne godly teſtimonies vocation office paule eſpecially chap epiſtle galathians maketh nothing matter ſaith beareth witnes ſelf unto thoſe ſuffer hym hangeman put haltar neckes maner marſake whome iudges cōmaū ded led without bande necke ſayed vnto thē cauſe better mine wil geue ſuch chaine alſo dubbe knight noble excellent order alluding ye accuſtomed maner kinges tyme wyll honour auaunce frendes make knightes owne order geue chayne golde token honour fiue ſtudied loſanna frenchemen dede borne founde fiue ſtudēts loſanna charge liberalitie lord berne whan therfore heard taken vnderſtode daū ger made diligent ſute ye king deſiring thei might geuen vayne kyng alledged might doe lawes cardinall tournon thought haue bene occaſion hereof ſpake litle death moſte noble prince edwarde ſixte kyng england conſumptiō moneth ianuary fell ſicke ſicknes increaſed carefull realme religion conferreth counſell matter inquireth vnto whome chiefly ſhould committe gouernmēt albeit king henry father whā died appointed next ſucceſſion vnto mary elizabeth ſayd yet ſo muche ſelfe lawefull yeres accoumpted lie power make heire eſpecially ſeing moſte men doubted lawful birth ſyſter mary alſo byſhop rome religion ſhe ſhould haue gouernment ſawe howe great daunger leaſt preſent religion ſhould ſubuerted realme alſo gouerned ſtraunger wherfore deliberatiō agreed choſe lady iane suffolke daughter lady fraūces nece kinge henry eight whan reſt counſell maior lady iane london lordes realme allowed archebyſhop cantorbury primate englande ſent court myght ſubſcribe whiche refuſeth doe vnleſſe maye firſt heare kyng ſpeake wherfore admitted ſpeache whan reaſoned matter familiarly laye aſſēted earneſtly required hereunto whan kyng departed whiche ſyxt daye iuly ſayd fourth daye lady iane proclaimed quene proclamation openly ſet forth howe kyng edwarde conſent noble moſte weighty cauſes diſherited lady mary lady elizabeth ſyſters lefte ſucceſſion realme lady iane nobilitie common toke moſte diſpleaſauntly ſo muche loue lady mary hatred duke northumberlande man maner doubted authour counſell intent meane myght conuey kingdome houſe whyleſt theſe thinges workyng lady mary fleeth norfolke thence caſtell framingham suffolke wryting abroade ayde taketh vpon quene knowen duke northumberlande aſſembleth power ſetting forth londō marcheth towardes conſent reſte apprehende meane ſeaſon counſellours remayned citie perceiuing harte people force norfolke suffolke reſorted quene mary chaunging myndes pourpoſe proclaimed quene mary kepe lady lady mary proclamed quene iane pryſon theſe newes came campe al mē moſte parte bycauſe ſerued againſt wylles hated duke reuolte whan letter commiſſion came frammingham thei take duke cambridge xxv daye iuly bryng agayne citie vncredible rebuke railinges ye people receiued hym whyleſt ſome cal traytour ſome parracide others murtherer moſte innocent kyng much thought haue brought ſonnes wyfe roial crowne aroſe ſuſpicion imagined theſe thynges longe layde wayte kynges lyfe apprehended ſonnes brother certē noble kynges ſcholemaiſter sir iohn cheke knight mā great vertu learning yet diſcharged afterwardes put maner lſuing came quene mary london entring holde call towre deliuereth priſon duke norfolke bene almoſte ſeuen yeares captiuitie gardiner byſhop wincheſter tunſtall biſhop dureſme certen byſhops popyſhe religion whiche bene put byſhoprikes reſtoreth fourmer place certenly yt byſhop wincheſter although bookes ſet forth defended king henry tyme diuorſed ſelfe lady katherine mother quene mary ix booke mentioned yet nowe obteined place chauncelour whiche wincheſter made chaū celour higheſt degree dignitie lady katherine alledged byſhop rome licence iuly ſecond confirmed matrimony kyng againe ſayde naught therfore ſent byſhop wincheſter byſhop rome clement might pronoūce theſame fruſtrate comming thither moneth february xxix yeare importune ſuter biſhop rome prouerbe helde woulfe eares coueted gratifie kyng alſo feared themperours diſpleaſure aunſwereth wyll wryte themperour true licence vnder ſeale might ſhewed aſſenteth dede requireth haue two monethes appointed ſame matter whan tyme ſhalbe runne gardener requireth ye licence might compted vnlawfull thought byſhop rome ſtraunge alſo vnreaſonable ſeketh gentle wordes ſatiſfie kyng ambaſſadour tolde hym playnly vnles might obteyne kynges requeſt would great hinderaunce see rome agayne emperour kyng ferdinando xxvii daye aprill ambaſſadours declare grief expoſtulate byſhop clement fauoured kyng onermuche would haue matter iudged englande alſo appointed procurer large ample commiſſion whiche ſhould treate followe cauſe name rome wherfore byſhop commaunding laſt campegius retourne home reuoketh ſuite ſelfe ſo much rather vnderſtode cardinall yorke kynges new loue ſaid duke northumberland condemned ix booke xxii daye auguſt duke northumberland cō demned treaſō beheaded whan brought scaffolde made oration amonges thinges exhorteth people perſeuer ſame religion whiche receiued forefather wer hand hande iudgeth cauſe calamitie hath come englande longe tyme nowe incōſtancie hys death chiefly ſince death king henry ſeperated reſte body chriſtianitie many yeares nowe bene contrary opinion pretended leaſte vtterly forſaken popiſh doctrine cauſe nowe ſpake thus ſaye put hope pardoned albeit reſte talke finiſhed ſayd ſpake thought yet ther ſome affirme ſory ſo ſaiyng time loking round perceiued ſuccour ſawe begiled ſuffered ſame time one ſir thomas palmer knight profeſſed doctrine goſpell thomas palmer moſte conſtancie duke condēned ſaid rebellion treaſon albeit great ſuſpiciōs ye geuen king poiſon yet nothing al examined matter ſentēce pronoūced againſt hym mētion made therof peter martyr florentine haue ſpoken whiche going england ſix yeres paſt kinges ſending reader diuinitie lecture oxforde whome many made muche excellent learning vertue wanted alſo euil willers wherfor king dead commaunded ſtyre one fote thence without pleaſure quene firſte knowen cary away thyng vnder great penaltie caſe ſhould doe otherwyſe content obeye whan ſawe longe delayed wryteth counſelours realme concerning ſtate ought offended requireth accuſer might brought forth matter examined wherupon permiſſion came london fyndeth archebyſhop cantorbury patrone frend whome popyſh preacher cōſtancie archebyſhop cantorbury reyſed brute though ſhould vnconſtant wauering though commaundement maſſe reſtored cantorbury though promyſed ſelfe ſame thing quene bragged al diſputatiō ſhould knewe immediatly ſet forth writynge pourge ſelfe ſayth terten prieſt vnknowyng hym ſayde maſſe cantorbury denieth thing alſo yea proteſteth quene wyll geue leaue proue actes kyng edwarde concernyng lordes ſupper article doctrine conſonaunt holy scripture romyſhe maſſe cleane repugnant inſtitution chriſte declaration wherof deſyreth great nomber euen fewe amonges peter martyr ayde aſſiſte hym ſo muche contrary parte adourned religion commendatiō antiquitie ſaiyng hath continued aboue thouſand fiue hondreth yeares affirmeth thei able proue ſame wil proue doctrine whiche kyng edwardes day ſet forth yet obſerued england natiue auncient religion inſtituted left v chriſt apoſtles whan publyſhed wryting london fift daye september peter martyr ſame tyme came thither oxforde ſayd aduertyſed hym whole matter commendeth ſheweth ye wyll refuſe neyther paynes peryll herein beholde whyleſt expectation archebyſhop cantorbury committed pryſon alſo archebiſhop biſhops caried priſon yorke rydley byſhop london h byſhop worceſter certen byſhops profeſſion goſpell ſermons made againſt quene mary counſelles commaundemēt ſhe atcheued crowne moreouer hughe latimer alſo apprehended whome kyng edward deliuered tower layd father doctrine meane tyme peter martyr albeit perceiued daū ger yet nothing offended againſt lawes realme truſting innocencie thought good departe obteyned leaue wherfore whan brought paſſe receiued paſſeporte ſigned quenes hande came werpe thence collon straſburge whence went firſte englande litle hym bernardine ochine health written ſignified germany emperour ſhould haue geuen coūcell auntes daughter quene mary ſhe ſhould gouerne mercy alter religion marie without realme daū ger caſe ſhe ſhould chaunge religion knewe beſt men whether ſo dede affirme ende ſelfe declareth farre otherwyſe euen doctrine goſpel ſtraungers cōmaunded departe natiue countrie men caſte pryſon romyſhe religion wholye reſtored ſhalbe declared popiſhe religion reſtored englande hereafter firſt daye october quene mary crowned longe began parliament london conuention empyre emperour called againſt xiii day auguſte ſhewed beginning boke proroged firſt october moneth ianuary ſame battel wherin duke maurice ſlayne henry duke brunſwick marque albert euery ſelfe make ſelues ſtrong gather power warres reuiued betwixt brunſw marque albert byſhoppes state norinberge fed duke henry wyth monie men moſte parte marueled marque albert whence al ſtore wherfore ſpoken commonly quene mary emperours ſiſtes ſupported mony emperours folkes denie vtterly maruell ſo fonde ſo thinke tyme mony brought duke brunſwicke ſomewhat late great daunger whan marque intelligence therof practiſed ſoldiours forſake hym abode delaye moſte impatiently luckely ſelfe ſame momente whan heate mutine began ryſe x day september brought remedy tempeſte appeaſed duke henry better aſſuraunce fel cōpoſition duke ericke coſin whiche ennemy kyng denmarke long ſince ſent ambaſſadour saxon matter duke auguſtus ſonne lawe length helpe electour brandenburges ambaſſadours reconcile hym marque albert conditiōs theſe duke auguſtus ſhould neither albert recō ciled auguſtus proſecute brother warre ayde ennemies marque albert ſame ſhall marque doe ſhall chaunce leade armie nere vnto limites duke auguſtus ſhall go forth without harme duke auguſte ſhall beware tyme diſchargeth armie thei go marque ennemies finally league inheritaunce whiche betwene houſe saxon brandenburge renewed ſo ſhortly may next day whiche xii september marque albert leadeth armie brunſwicke chaunced vpon ennemies far without citie geueth charge vanquiſhed nōber eſpecially none duke brunſwick xx enſeignes footemen diſcomfited put flight albeit left ennemy bluddy victory battel retourneth brunſwick meane ſeaſon thei great diſtreſſe whome coūte plauie companion beſieged hoffie towne ſore battered ſhot marque vanquiſhed battell reſcowe came beinge dryuen penurie want thynges render vp towne counte plauie ſweareth townes men true hym chyldren leaueth garriſon one enſeigne fotemen great ordenaunce haue ſpoken turkiſhe flete unto whome turkiſhe naute taketh iland corſica ioyned ſelues certen frenche captaines ſetting forthe marſeilles maner theſe dayes take iland corſica belonging ſtate gene fewe townes excepted howe emperour toke caſtell heſdine force ſaid ye ſame raſeth done terwen french king meane ſeaſon leuieth armie amiens attendeth tyll swyſſes whiche ſent come whan heſdine ouerthrowen emperour ende auguſte mynde attempte dorlans whan conſtable heard therof eſpiall leadeth forth great number horſemen ſome part footemen ſo ſpedely ſet vpon euer thei aware putteth flight ſlaying takyng many tyme swiſſes come beginninge september ten thouſande footemen kyng went vp water banke wherof ſtandeth amia commeth corbie thence ſending certen guidons horſemen runneth towne bappam though would beſiege ſeuenth daye september ſendyng herault armes cambraye requireth certified harte townes men beare towardes hym large towne belongyng byſhop aunciently empire ſame warre whiche frēche king attemteth cābray emperour made frenche king neuter town indifferent tyme emperous parte king therfore ſendeth worde wil nothing againſt cōuenauntes ſo wyl ſame let citie ſet open protectour thē pire ready ſerue thinges wel themperour yt gouernour yt town ſignified ye matter emperour made aunſwer ſo muche frenchmē ſpoyling burning diſtroyed al coūtrie yt ſhould take ennemies meſſage came againe emperour kynge making roades began aſſaie citie certē day wher nothing preuailed middes september rayſeth campe pitcheth tentes two myles emperours campe whiche ualencene towne henault nere vnto riuer scalde thā approcheth nerer certenly thing like haue come batell yt end king approched ſo nere yt emperours fortification loſte many men retourned army xviii day september departing diſtroyed far nere fire matter wrytten priuatly vnto frendes frenchemē dede ſaie howe emperour would fight imperial deny king retourning home diſchargeth swiſſes ſame moneth diſcharged garriſon ſixe enſeignes fotemen whiche emperours commaundement bene yeare auſpurge ſayd fourmer boke tyme alſo met hailbrune ye paulſ graue archebyſhop mentz duke bauier duke wirtemberge archebyſhop treuers duke cleaue came ambaſſadours preſent name king ferdinando byſhop paſſawe peſtilence firing paris ſommer rage yt plague made great ſlaughter paris meane time diuers burnt alſo lutheraniſme king darling whoſe huſband tyme paſt bene gouernour normandy ſame woman wydowe two ſonnes lawe ſame time priſoners duke de anmalle mareſchall marchian ſayed raunſome duke de anmalle marque albert demaundeth hondreth thouſande crownes aboue habilitie wherfore brute went ſhe might king ſhe liſt yt ende ſhe might make monie without owne hinderaunce obteined kynge ſhould geue landes goodes condemned hereſie cuſtome fraunce kynge taketh lyfe ſuche condemned goodes alſo tyme therfore praye obtayned many ſaye brought daunger wyll certenly affirme commeth paſſe many tymes fraunce place bloude innocent perſones pleaſure alſo gaigne many bloud innocētes gaynfull many marque albert ouerthrowe battell retourneth brunſwicke little haue ſayed vnderſtode eſpiall duke would beſege citie making longe aboade gathered vp horſemen could commaundeth abide comming turingia ſending kinſfolkes ally ayde whan holpen haſteth turinge fifth daye october vſing great expedition beyond al men expectation came weymer ryght gently receiued iohn fridericke remayning two nightes myght refreſhe ſouldiours trauaile laye ſcattered broade coūtrie marcheth towardes franckony tyme erle plauie fellowes beſeged towne named birnt hearing comming leuied ſiege gote bamberge accompanied great bande horſemen goeth forthe xi day october eſpie done hoſie town lately loſte ſoldiours garriſon chaunced ſome vn warely without gate pleaſure altogether careleſſe wherfore fynding occaſion exhorting men valiaunt ryding vpon ſpurre ſetteth vpō quickely putting flight followeth entring gate whan town men reioyſing ſight preſence came running ſlewe moſte parte founde great piece artillerie certen others whiche call field piece without cariage furniture enemy caried awaye furniſhed make batterie birnte leauing ther enſeigne fotemē goeth blaſſeburg chief caſtell came awaye brunſwick duke henry beſeged citie battered ſore ſhot brunſwick beſeged byſhoppes norinberge whiche ſupported armie ſendyng hym worde ſhould repayre duke henry demaundeth citezens foure thouſande crownes whan refuſed souldiours vnleſſe payde wage woulde beare none enſeignes afrayde owne daunger promyſe geue hym ſo muche lengthe leuieng ſiege whan appoynted soldiours daye whan ſhoulde payed taketh iourney turinge knowen duke saxon iohn friderick yet made one goeth ſelfe thre ſonnes gothe leauing wife weymer ſhe wel health duke henry furniſhed duke brunſwletters saxon take iourney ſending vnto letter albeit ſayeth haue iuſt cauſe good occaſion alſo theſe certen yeares paſt reuenge iniuries fourmer time done vnto yet ſo muche emperours cuſtody haue attempted nothing againſt either ſubiectes child haue permitted thing lawe iudgement contented fourmer iniuries haue holpen late alſo ayde counſel albert brandenburg diſturber germany vttermoſte ennemy whiche knowe certentie although wrought ſecretly wherfore caſe army ſhal doe hurte countrie cauſe cōplaine therof yt beginning ſelfe duke henry determined haue playd vtter ennemy albert uolrate erles manſfeld laſt yeres war howbeit thinterceſſiō duke auguſt whō ſought vpon matter appeaſed iohn fridericke receiuing duke brunſwickes letter began treate wt ambaſſadours mitigate minde ſo ſhuld come weymer two guidons horſemen fiue enſeignes fotemen reſidue armie placed ye coūtrie therabout hither came prince minquice chaūcelour declaring cōmiſſiō perſwaded throughly du brunſwick reconciled duke saxon quietnes required great ſōme monie ſame doth partly remit remaining two day without hurt departeth frendly xviii day october began diſputation londō quenes cōmaundement preſence chriſt sacrament altar terme matter reaſoned ſix day diſputatiō england without opprobrious wordes one romſh dictrine doctor weſtō proloqutour demeaned himſelfe diſorderly decreed ſame thend parliament wyll declare end october michael serueto spaniarde executed geneua many yeares ſince ſet forth diuerſe bookes amongeſt serueto spanyarde burnt geneua thinges trinitie vtterly repugnaunt yt cōmon conſent church whan length came yeare geneua ye senate certified cōmaū deth aprehended appointeth caluine wrytten againſt miniſters yt churche haue conference wherfore great bitter diſputation amongſt would many tymes tell caluine lied immodeſtly senate leaſt thing ſhould done ſo weightie matter raſhely aſketh counſell touching ſame opinion doctours berne zurick baſill schafuſians make aunſwer ſame thinges redounde god high contumelie wold forſake opiniō alſo opprobrious wordes curſed ſpeakinges defende ſame condēned die whan came yt place execution william farell exhorte hym would call vpon chriſte eternall ſonne god ſhe wed token repentaūce yet defend cauſe vnto people many men aſcribed blame death caluine ſetting forth booke reciteth opinion matter declareth heretikes may puniſhed death laſte ſauing one october iames sturmie man moſte iuſte wittie beaultie nobilitie germany excellent gyftes mynde notable lerning departeth life straſburg whā layne ſicke quartaine ſpace two moneths paſt thre ſcore thre yeares olde theſe dayes reynold poole engliſheman borne cardinal comming rome goeth germany emperour reynold poole cardinall whan come frontier paulſgraues countrie receiuing newes emperour ſent vnto hym mendoza retourneth dilling whiche towne byſhops auſpurge water thonawe attendeth till ſhal heare emperour duke brunſwicke departing weymer ſeuenth daye nouember came fellowes campe whiche lichtefelſe towne belongyng bamberge whiche towne placed soldiours marque albert ix enſeignes fotemen ſelfe ſame bene little birnthe counte plauie fellowes beſeged tyme great piece artillerie came norinberge wherwith towne myght battered makyng ſurrendrie tenth nouember yelde ſelues ennemies hādes taking certen captaines let goe reſte without armure enſeignes done go colembach towne marque albertes batter ſore towneſmen perceiuing able defende ennemie carie goodes houſhold ſtuffe caſtel blaſſe burge ſetting houſes fire flie thether ſelues alſo thus fine ennemy entreth towne kylling diuerſe founde quencheth fire ſpoyleth reſte lefte afterwardes whan coūte plauie taken ſurrendrie caſtell lichteberge townes biruth hofie raſed walles beſegeth caſtell blaſſeburge chiefeſt forte marque kept great garriſon tyme frenche men going priuely piedmount vpon ſoden take uercelles uercelles ſurpriſed towne turin whiche spanyardes kept thought ſelues hardly able defend ſame ſo nere millan gonzago emperours lieftenaunt approched alſo power ſpoyled towne retourned home due ſeaſon laden boties long ſignified written ueniſe place solyman emperour turkes hanged eldeſt ſonne muſtapha ſuſpicion treaſon reporte turck hanged ſonne muſtapha murther committed procurement ſeconde wyfe whiche coueted haue ſonne auaunced ſuccede father haue ſpoken archebyſhop cantorbury quene iane thre ſonnes duke northumberlande brought barre archbyſhop cantorbury others condemned moneth nouember cōdemned ſuffer treaſon according cuſtome realme thei caried pryſon interceſſiō certen reſerued sebaſtian scherteline whome ofte mention made whoſe death emperour appointed great rewarde laſt boke declared tyme reconciled emperour king ferdinando recouered goodes ſuite byſhoppes conſortes iudges chamber imperiall ſolemne ceremonie fyrſte december outlawe marque albert brandenburg diſturber publique quiet empire diſpatching marque albert outlawed abroade letter hither thether ſame ſet vp openly permitted lyfe goodes ſpoiled al mē duke henry brunſwicke leauing counte plauie ye ſiege blaſſeburg ſixt day december goeth power schuinfurte whiche towne dede ſituated banke riuer moene marque kept ſtrong garriſon duke ayde soldiours came norinberge forcheme marque albert ſuſpectinge matter firſte vitaile ſo euer place thereaboutes brought towne burnte buildinges intent might take away occaſion beſieging ennemie tyme yeare wherfore duke henry without exploicte done hauinge loſt alſo many men tyme marque ſaleed fought retourneth home great company paſſing countrie iohn fridericke without harme whan marque albert vnderſtode outlawed chāber ſueth emperour would reuerſe iudgement ſayeth howe may let execution lawe refuſeth iudgement corrupted bribe rewardes maketh proteſtation wryting ſet forth ſame iudges commaūd next prouinces empire ſe thinge executed tyme holden englande parliament al godly lawes good edward repealed state realme ſo muche kyng edwardes tyme actes made lordes ſupper ceremony miniſtration sacramentes mariage prieſtes election byſhoppes ordeining miniſters churche fourme praying ſuch like thinges parliamēt enacted thoſe ſtatutes ſhould take place men ſhould followe ſame religion whiche obſerued death kyng hē ry moreouer man ſhould moleſte diſquiet ſuche prieſtes miniſtrs churche ſhalbe ordeined hereafter furthermore diuorcement quene katherine quenes mother pronoūced haue bene onlawfull finally debated amonges noble concerning quenes quene mary affiaūced emperours ſonne mariage greed ſhe ſhould eſpouſed emperours ſonne king philippe whome went report ſhould marie coſin daughter emanuell king portugale aunte elenore whan agreed vpon emperour ſendeth cardinall poole cauſe emperour would haue hym ſtaie germany many ſuppoſed leaſt bloud roiall well beloued countrie ſhould haue bene ſome let mariage ſtede thoſe byſhoppes whiche ſayd thruſt priſon created others tyme full confirmation matrimony emperour ſent moſte honorable ambaſſade englāde might affiaunce quene mary kyng philippe abſent 1554 chief ambaſſadour counte de egmonde arriuinge london beginning ianuary treated matter fewe dayes bryng paſſe common realme toke matter moſte greuouſly diuerſe alſo nobilitie laiyng heades together commotion kent rebelle chiefe authour rynge leader hereof ſyr thomas wiat reyſing rebellion kente made greuous bitter oration againſt quene counſell mariage ſtraunger wyll procure realme englande perpetuall moſte miſerable bō dage ſeke alſo true religion extinguiſhed may agayne eſtabliſhe papiſtrie kente countie ſea coaſte nexte vnto fraunce reaſon citie cantorbury right famouſe brute commotion brought london xxv daye ianuary long heard alſo henry duke suffolke reyſed vp men leceſter ſhyre wherfore quene aſſembleth power ſhe coulde ouer whome ſhe maketh generall thomas duke norfolke lately deliuered priſon ende ſame moneth meting enemy rocheſter bridge forſaken ſoldiours faine duke norfolke forſaken men ſaue himſelfe flight much payne came london wherfore amongeſt theſe tumultes emperours ambaſſadours mitigate rebellion daunger together firſt day february take ſhipping depart ſame daie came quene citie london making oration greuous complaint againſt wiat declareth intent loue ſhe beareth vnto quenes oration yt common yelde hall ſayeth howe ſhe hath determined nothing mariage without conſent counſell ſhe hath liued good part tyme mayden doteth ſo mariage ſhe would remayne ſame kynde lyfe ſtyll caſe noble common iudged mete ſhoulde ſo bee realme ſhould daunger bycauſe mariage ſhould ful ſlaughter ſhould moſte greuous wherfore let perſeuer doinge theyr dutie aſſiſte reuenging treaſon wicked perſons dutie doe whiche haue commaunded lawefull heyre father common aſſente bee quene whan ſhe thys wyſe pacified ſhe appointed certen defende citie aſſigneth erle penbroke haue charge abroade nowe wiat proclaimed heraulte armes rebell traytour realme bryng hym greater hatred read requeſtes ſent vnto quene wherof fyrſte ſaye would haue quene cuſtody ſhould lawfull determine concerning mariage either reteine diſplace counſellours pleaſure third daye proclaimed pardon cōmon people ſo would forſake captaines authours rebellion would bring wiat pryſoner appointed great rewarde duke suffolke alſo accompted nūber traitours wheras ſame daye conſpiratours came nere vnto citie quene cutteth two london bridge ouer ryuer temſe leaſt ſhould go next day thei come southwarke ſuppoſing citezēs would haue ioyned holden garriſon meane ſeaſon duke suffolke taken parte realme erle huntington whome duke suffolke quene ſent horſemen whan confederate ſpent two day citie traueled ſyde vayne taking way paſſe ouer temſe king ſtone ten mile aboue london ſo marche towardes citie laſte wiat felowes intercepted power whiche quene ſent erle wiat taken committed priſō penbroke committed pryſon next daye whiche ſeuenth daye ſame moneth proclamation made vnder payne death ſo euer receiued theſe rebelles houſe ſhould brynge forthe preſent immediatly fewe dayes duke suffolke brought pryſoner london xii daye february duke northumberlandes ſonne guilford dudley lady iane wyfe duke suffolkes daughter lady iane huſband beheaded kyng edwarde ſayde admitted quene beheaded contrary lawfull ſucceſſion aſpired crowne lady ianes miſhappe maner men lamented ſo vertuouſe lady ſo wel brought vp ſo learned ſhould chaunce ſo great calamitie none cauſe verely thā ſhe refuſed kingdome offered made oration people godly modeſte calling god mercy ieſus chriſte toke clothe one gentilwomen couered face bound eies offered hangeman necke ſtriken ſelf ſame daye corteney erle deuonſhire whome quene fewe monethes deliuered long captiuitie agayn taken vpon ſuſpicion conſpiracie made londō weſtminſter quene many caried execution nobilitie fewe alſo eſcaping amongeſt worthie knight ſyr peter carrew fled fraunce duke suffolke alſo duke suffolke beheaded xxi daye february beheaded whan bene condemned foure dayes whyleſt theſe thynges done englande sibille cleaue wyfe iohn fridericke duke saxon foreſaed xxi daye february departeth sibille duches saxō departeth weymer xi daye prynce hym ſelfe whan layen whyle ſicke died bothe true knowledge god ſuerly whan wyues tombe making churche commaunded certen place reſerued hym ſyde therof ſhould ſhortely followe neyther diſceaued opinion thyrd daye marche ten clocke noone whan heard sermon liyng bed callyng vppon god mercy commending ſpirite vnto god flitted godly end iohn friderick myſerable life heauenly countrie nowe compoſition made betwene hym duke auguſtus kyng denmarke ſendynge ambaſſadours ſayd made great interceſſion much diuerſe almoſt half yeares diſceptation tyme matter appeaſed vpon theſe condicions iohn fridericke departeth electourſhyp meiſſen townes mettell mine duke auguſtus diſceaſing without heires male theſe thinges retourne duke saxon heires male meane tyme duke saxon may vſe name armes electourſhip well ſealing letter coyninge monie duke auguſtus alſo graunteth hym ſonnes certen townes gouernementes debtes behynde certen fourmer yeares whiche duke maurice payed ſonnes payeth downe ſumme hondreth thouſand crownes redemeth alſo caſtell end made betwixt auguſtus towne conigſperge ſtanding franconie layed morgage biſhop wirtemburge xl thouſande crownes reſtoreth duke saxon ſonnes finally league inheritaunce houſe saxon theſe fourmer yeares infringed renewed eſtabliſhed agayne ſame compoſition iohn fridericke lying deth bed long ended lyfe confirmed wryting ſeale commaūded ſonnes ſhould doe likewyſe wherfore noble courage vanquiſhyng euilles miſeries wherinto chaunced died priſon cuſtody foreine ſoldiours wherūto appointed notable benefit god ſet libertie retourning home wyfe child owne religion ended lyfe moſte peaceably leauing ſonnes ſubiectes peace quietnes wyfe alſo ducheſſe hauing owne wyſhe left earthly manſion godlines wyfe often tymes ſhe ſaied ſhe coulde content dye harte ſo ſhe might firſt ſe huſband ſafe libertie ſame many time ſhe pray liuing god many teares ſighinges ſame daye ſhe ended lyfe duke auguſt ſonne borne named alexander theſe ſame dayes reſt ſtraungers englande yea many ſame natiō forſakyng countrie alteration religion quenes proclamatiōs conueye ſelues germany wherof ſome tary weſell ſome franckefurte many alſo straſburg iohn alaſcus polonian noble man borne brother hierome man excellent learning went thence wynter iohn alaſco diuerſe others dēmarke ther frendly receiued reaſon contrary opinion touching lordes ſupper theſame cauſe denied dwell lower partes saxony came length emden towne eaſt friſeland remayned fourth day marche quene england ſet forth eccleſiaſticall lawes wherin ſhe cōmaundeth biſhops officer receiue man ſuſpected hereſie holy eccleſiaſtical lawes englande order rote cleane hereſies abolyſhe al naughtie peſtiferous bokes preſcribe order scholemaiſters preacher take awaye maried prieſtes wyues benefice inioyne puniſhement condigne miſdoing yet ſo ſuche cōſent wiues wil proteſte make diuorſemēt handle gently ſuche amende alſo reſtored moreouer prayer common ſupplications ſayde latin tongue olde cuſtome holy day obſerued ceremony fourmer tyme reſtored bigge child chriſtened confirmed byſhops taught scholes howe helpe prieſt ſaye maſſe ſerue aultar tyme kyng englande henry eight baniſhed byſhop rome ſayd ix boke made lawe amongeſt others man ſhould admitted office eccleſiaſtical dignitie except would firſt proteſte ſolemne othe ſucceſſours alſo ſupreme head engliſhe churche ouer whiche byſhop rome hathe authoritie neither thinge byſhop citie rome whome wyll haue nothinge doe whiche othe quene whan ſhe publiſhed theſe thinges nowe releaſe alſo chargeth byſhoppes henceforth required man ſecretly ſorte reſtoryng ſupremacie biſhop rome ſhe ſpeaketh cō mon prayer thus kyng father commaundement proceſſion ſayde vulgare tongue wherin god prayed amonges thinges would deliuer ſedition conſpiracie tyranny byſhop rome fourme therfore ſet forth print ye quene nowe commaundeth aboliſhed long lady elizabeth quenes ſiſter lady well learned cō mitted lady elizabeth cō mitted yt tower tower ſhe thought priuie fourmer conſpiracie ende marche ennemies marque albert retourne ſiege schninfurt moneth aprill came germany england men great learning ſir richarde moriſine knight whoſe ambaſſade haue ſpoken fourmer boke ſir anthony coke ſir iohn cheke knightes kinges ſcholemaiſters went italy thither came alſo iohn pomet byſhop wincheſter whiche reaſon alteratiō religion diſplaced likewyſe diuerſe others time force duke florence byſhop rome beſieged sene peter stroſſe frenche kinges name defended citie vnderſtanding ſiege sene certen thinges eſpiall ſet vpon ſodenly ſlew great nomber notwithſtanding reſtoring ſtrength continued ſiege wherfore frenche kyng hyreth thre thouſand swiſſes ayde thoſe beſieged duke florence fiaunced daughter aſcanio byſhop rome nephewe meanes deuiſed auaunce hym mariage theſe day gouernour millan ferdinando gonzago ſent came emperour brabant thither came alſo babtiſta caſtaldus whome emperour ſayde fourmer yeares ſent ambaſſadour hongarie middes aprill sir thomas wiat executed london ſuffered excuſinge lady elizabeth death wiat erle deuonſhyre diligently affirmed priuie conſpiracie alſo archbiſhop cantorburye biſhop london hugh latimer caried firſt windſore oxford diſputed diuines vniuerſity alſo cambridge perſeueringe theyr opinion committed priſone ſame time againe quene helde parliament wherin ſhe propounded two thinges chieflye concerning owne mariage reſtoring ſupremacy biſhop parlamēt england rome wherof ſhe obteined firſt vpon certain condition nobility chiefly againſte ſhe coulde perſwade cardinal poole bene certen time themperor wente french kinge counſellor peace preuailed nothing thend aprill marque albert receiuing lx thouſand crownes ſendeth away duke danmalle priſoner wher little loſt holanſperge fortreſſe dominion long themperor ſending letter bruiſſels winter outlawed chamber outlaweth complaininge ſhould worke ſo much miſchief vnpuniſhed commaundeth wordes moſt waighty prince ſtates chiefly thoſe nexte put proclamation outlawrye execution met twiſe roteburge treate peace wheras nothinge concluded themperoure decreed againſte ſame ſtates aſſembled wuormes al ſuch belonge prouince rhine cōmon aſſemble thempire yt ſhuld holden auſpurge haue ſpoken oftner becauſe themperor impeched ſicknes alſo warres could ther king fernando requeſt taketh charge vppon prince deſired come excuſed ſelues reaſon troubleſome ſtate germany themperor ready ſent thither thaſſemble auſpurge certen counſell alſo choſen cardinall auſpurge ſame purpoſe time cauſe aboue named man came matter differred til time conueniēt marque albert written certen thinges ſpitefully bitterly againſt norinbergians though former war priuely aided french king fellowes paid mony though ſhuld haue great ſuſpitiō themperor alſo biſhops theyr fellowes ſpoken contumelious word ſhuld fauor french king themperor yt ſelues attēpted war againſt yt able yt biſhops ſhuld kepe couenants though ſhuld ſeke deſtroy al nobility though ſhoulde haue broken theyr promiſe expreſſed ſigned wryting though ſhould haue made wicked cruel warre againſt people dominion thoughe corrupted iudgemente chamber bribe called alſo traitor theyr country diſperſing abrode libel therof throughe germany knowen norinbergians whan taking holanſperge found certaine thinges lyke wrytinge city norinberge againſt marque albert ſort xviii day may make anſwer large addreſſinge theyr wryting vnto ſtates confute al thinges ordre verify moſt thinges recite vpon conditiō gaue monye duke moris fellowes declare author warre euen ſame time ſay prince interceſſoures met hedelberge vaūtcurrers leuied muche power poſſible mighte saxonye proued aſwell others alſo thoſe letter one currier william grumpache wrote vnto xxix march king ferdinando duke moris duke brū ſwicke imploid theyr force yea liues blud theyr country would doubtleſſe haue made horrible deſtruction waſte oute germany driuen byſhops franckonie condition moſt vnreaſonable cō poſition emperor made fruſtrate gaue leaue recouer againe theyr owne wherfore biſhoppe bamberge wan againe certaine townes gouernments longe receiued againe emperor fauor euen time reaſon high treaſon onlye landes poſſeſſions life alſo might haue bene taken frō lawfully afterward emperor commaundemente made league defence oure prouinces • e reconciled emperor obteined confirmation • compactes made yet vppon condition ſhould true empire emperor permitted violence time ſiege metz wrote home hys captain ſhould feare biſhops vnleſſe wold reſtore taken worke force violence monthe ianuary followinge makinge inuaſion recouered manye thinges force armes wherefore biſhop bamberge admoniſhed fellowes aide according theyr league neuertheleſſe leaſt ſhould thing raſhly ſondrye letter intermeſſagers exhorted marque albert peace anſweringe contemptuouſlye opprobriouſly ſaid amongs thinges mo ennemies honor praiſe ſhould win beginning march long began yt treatye hedelberge whan ther refuſed moſte ample large condition kinffolkes ally interceſſors exhorting vnto peace went home leuied army ſollicited moued againe biſhoppes laſt profeſſe ſelues enemy laſt yere firſt aprill wheras ſelf hath moued moſt cruell warre ſtraunge example ſuch hath bene heard germany goeth charge v crime aſſuredly vntrue neither ther euer ſuch like thinge complained vnto v ſoldiours haue omitted kind cruelty chauncing time find plowman field hanged vp father ſonnes manner oure face haue inforced woman liue haue alſo digged vp whan haue bene dead laſt yere ye moneth may certaine gentelman franconie nicholas eglofſten inforced yelde vp caſtell conrute cruell actes marque albert burne alſo fineding ther fortye country men miniſter church commaunded hā ged vp orchard adioyning caſtel caried away wife mother priſoners wente aboute dede excuſe matter letter nobility franconie nothing purpoſe alſo intreated priſonners men pledge bamberge whiche haled saxonie declare ſuch hath deteined priſone bothe demaunded vnreaſonable ſumme mony mooſte greuouſly tormented vppon racke alſo ſterued honger cold ſo many died reſidue hauing limmes ſtarke deade reaſon cold wer faine haue cut taken away wheras certain nothing either paye raunſome liue forbad ſhoulde haue meate geuen ſouldioures warde vanquiſhed lamentation pitiful cry ſomtime caſt piece bread ſo drye moulded longe kepinge cattell brute beaſtes vnleſſe extreme honger woulde haue touched died want meate yt ſom made piece mony theyr frendes yet hardly could therfore get little ſtraw water wherfore certaine ſtaruen honger thurſte onlye terrible darkneſſe alſo ſtench priſon mids thordure uermen venemous beaſtes whan thus periſhed ye coarſes wer drawn remoued frō thēce lefte aliue increaſed priſon ſtench howe gently haue intreated priſonners captaines certen centurion euen ſuche deſerued worſt v haue rendred ſelues without condition may knowen owne teſtimony howe vnwilling haue peace may well appeare two laſt treaty roteburge know moſte noble prince either wer ſelues ſente thither ambaſſadoures althoughe ſuſteined wonderfull loſſe calamity already outlawed yet former conuention made offer wold leaue warre demeane ſelfe well henceforth woulde trye matter law would alſo lay part oure weapon put matter tharbitrement prince interceſſours iudgement themperor ſtates empire ſame offer made biſhoppes aduiſe conſente ambaſſadours king ferdinando counſelloures alſo prince interceſſoures loue peace added moreouer ſtates franconie confederacy would promiſe reſtore prouince ſhoulde ceaſe warre ſides kepe peace henceforth publication behalf ſhould fruſtrate whole controuerſy committed frendly lawfull treaty contempt mockery called interceſſors enemy procurer ſaide woulde ſuffer ſelfe broughte ſuche diſtreſſe neither couet haue outlawry yet reuearſed would alſo put hazard reaſte ſpake many ſuch like thing raſhly opprobriouſly threatninges higheſt meane loweſt degree proued thoſe letter printe holanſperge nexte aſſemble althoughe offered largely yet nothing rather inclined peace yea went craftes policy neither commendable princelike requeſt interceſſors committinge whole matter emperor certen prince promiſed attempt longer warre ſame compromiſe themperor ſending letter bruiſſels fourth aprill ratifye willed ſtates frankonie ſhould leaue warre alſo cō mit cauſe care fidelity marque albert intent ful craftely appeareth ſuch thinges folowed yt might ſtaye themperor ſhuld cōmaūd certen prouinces thempire put outlawry execution ſelf alſo might haue ſpace leuy army gatheringe time place haue oppreſſed v vppon ſoden god benefit matter detected letter ſame time intercepted ſent hither thither chief captain cē turions wherin hath admitted treaty roteburge purpoſe meane ſeaſon may prepare ſelf ſet vpon enemy nowe thinterceſſors ſhal haply require forſake enſeignes let obey kepe together wiſe ſcatter abrode excuſe let alledge cauſe haue many month wage owing therfore may depart paid ſay remaine thoſe party without hurte til haue receiued theyr mony hitherto appertaine alſo thoſe letter wherin commaundeth chieftaines wyth delay ſet vpon al men whoſoeuer whan treaſon therfore brought light wheras men demaunded ambaſſadors ſent roteburge whether would ſtand compromiſe could haue certain anſwer aduiſe king ferdinandoes ambaſſadors wer conſtraind commit matter vnto god firſt themperor thempire oure letter ſent themperor ſame time declare ſeing matter thus ſo much euery man may eaſily perceiue ſuch thinges haue truelye rehearſed hitherto driuen ſo manye railinges reproches diſpleaſures repulſe fury violence haue obeied commaundement high chief magiſtrate therefore beſeche men loue vertue honeſty hate violence iniurye conſider diligently vnleſſe ſentence geuen ſhoulde put execution boldneſſe repreſſed great daunger hangeth ouer v alſo wherfore let man aid aſſiſt geue ſuccoring place refuge becommeth noble prince ſuch loue country wiſh would impeche thexecution commaundement ſelues alſo would ſe thinge executed vttermooſte theyr power woorke ſo herein others may made afraide example alſo geue creadite hys famous libel ſlaunders ſette forthe agaynſte v ſhall againe attempt anye thinge againſte v hym wyth theyr aide counſell requyre moſte earneſtlye marque albert receiuing mony duke danmalle ſaid haſteth saxony hiringe ſoldiors monthe maye goeth schuinfurt priuely tenth daye iune viii hundreth horſmen vii enſeigns fotemen dawning marque al goeth suinfort day entreth towne ſide beſieged becauſe wer great penury al thing third day whan ſpoyled towne night leadeth al ſoldiors aſwel horſmen fotemen nombre xviii enſeignes artillery leauing ward al kepe gate taketh iourny kitzing town ſtanding beneath riuer moene whan light day thenemies perceiued gate vnfurniſhed ſound trōpet prepare ſelues euery man follow purſue diuers chiefly ſoldiors duke brunſwick wer commaunded enter towne ſpoile deſtroy left wherfore chief captain gouernours field leaſt delay taryinge reaſte marque albert ſhould haue time eſcape ſet towne fire diuers ſondry place ſo driuen depart repair vnto tharmy albeit marque gon certain hour yet ſo letted hindred thordenaunce yt could make ſpeade ſtaide forewarde bickereth reaſt tharmy approching whan ſaw ſelf weake ſo great multitude exhortinge men make beſt ſhift euery mā ſelf accompanied flight horſmen goeth ſpedely ſight ſwimming ouer ye riuer kitzing eſcapeth loſing munition cariage viii day caſtell blaſſeburgh chiefeſt fortreſſe rendred vp came handes king ferdinando chauncelour boheme counte plauie beſeged ſame continually dead little thus therefore marque albert expulſed driuen dominion whileſt theſe thinges done franconie henry duke brunſwicke lower partes darony compelleth diuers aſwell prince city many nobility pay mony vnder ſubiectiō duke megelburge duke luneburge prince anhaldes earles manſfelde part alſo biſhops power hauing diſcomfited marque taken schuinfurt puniſhed right ſore roteburge towne imperiall counte henneberge amonges others thus bent except might recouer charge warre ſaid appartained men pretended worke much violence mediation matter appeaſed war ceaſed manner time charles duke sauoy depriued great part dominion tolde tenth booke departeth oute life leauinge ſonne philibert heyre death charles sauoy ſerued themperor warres many yeares king fernando ſetting forth late proclamation commaunded ſubiectes nothing ſhould altered sacramente thanckes geuing thold cuſtom ſuch receiued lordes ſupper ſhould contented thone kind terme noble gentleman city wheras diuers time ſued herein require moſt humblye theyr letter alledginge manye teaſons might permitted receiue whole supper lorde according commaundement inſtitution chriſte cuſtome primatiue churche unto theſe letter theyrs xxiii iune king auſweringe uienne full little letter king fardinando ſubiectes lord supper thought ſaith would haue called queſtion proclamation mine haue found cauillations therin mēt ſubiectes ſhould perſeuer thauncient true religion obedience catholicke church without man obtain ſaluation ſhould receiue ſacrament chiefeſt others law cuſtome church neither corrupt opinion certain curioſity pride alſo ſhould ſwarue duty owe church alſo magiſtrate verely mind effect ſame proclamation nether new thing commaunded old ordinaunce hath ben brought wer hād vnto progenitor emperor king duke auſtrich alſo whan began gouerne common wealth deduced vnto time diligently becommeth chriſten prince obſerued ſondrye time people alſo inioyned ſhoulde remayne ſame wherfore ſuppoſed would haue attempted thyng againſt proclamacion thinges contende ſhould alteraciō lawes liberty myght remaine vnto whole certenly new deuiſe lately conceaued certayne opinion alſo reaſoned large though lawful iudge commaundementes whiche chiefe ſupreme magiſtrate though ſame ought ryght permitted certen yeres diuers accord contrary lawes church haue taken vpon priuately vſurpe becauſe queſtion harde ful difficulty alſo affirme doubtles thincke therupon whan time make ſuch anſwer may well perceiued tender little ſaluation people meane time loke al obediēce truſt wil nothing againſt proclamation unto ſtates ſtates make aſwer yt kinges letter afterward anſwer wryting ſame ſay haue oft time ſpoken ſauiour chriſtes commaū dement moſt puiſſant king repete inſtitute ſupper plain manifeſt word ſame ſort ſelf preſcribeth might receiued al men nether lawfull man mortall alter hys inſtitution may proued alſo manner thauncient churche ſame vſed day haue crept little little euen counſel conſtance graunteth ye ſame ſo inſtituted chriſt wher therfore thys cōcerneth ſaluation certainly neither curioſity pride hath moued v vnto wherby truſte rather refer conſultation commaundement chriſt apoſtles conſent primatiue church conſciēce ſhuld burthened thing might pleaſe beſech honor god glorye name oure ſaluation acknowledge moſte gladlye high magiſtrate geuen v god nothing world may ought loke hāds lie v one matter deſire fauorable v byſhop wirciburges dominion ther abbay mōkes called newſtat abbot therof ihon friſe thabbot newſtat accuſed heriſye came ſuſpition lutheraniſme fift day may cited come vi day wirciburge anſwer vnto certain interrogatory queſtions theſe whether lawful ſweare whether anye man bounden othe whether lawful make vow chaſtity pouerty obediēce interrogatory miniſtred whether ſuch manner vowes binde whether becometh better miniſters church mariage ſingleneſſe whether ther one true apoſtolical church whether ſame ſpouſe chriſt continually gouerned holy ghoſt whether ſhe alwaies diſcern true holſom thyngs whether ſame reaſon head chriſtes vicar called rightly ye church rome whether bokes teſtaments cannon lawful true whether holy ſcripture ought expounded mind holy father doctor church counſels thopinion luther others lyke ſort whether beſides scripture ther nede alſo tradition thoſe apoſtles ſuch like whether ſame faith aucthority obedience oughte geuen ſame traditiōs holy ſcripture whether ought obay ye ciuill magiſtrate politick matter holy thing theccleſiaſticall ordinary whether ther vii ſacraments churche whether child oughte chriſtened whether oughte chriſten latin tounge salt oile water charactes exorciſmes whether baptiſme cleane putte awaye originall ſinne ſuch ſort concupiſcence remaineth loſeth name ſame ſinne whether breade chaunged conſecrated body wine blud chriſt vertue wordes prieſt pronounceth whether ſo remaine althoughe receiued whether sacrament ſort conſecrated worſhipped whan either borne aboute honor chriſte caried vnto ſickfolkes alſo reſerued pix whether chriſt worſhipped vnder forme bread wine whether chriſt wholly vnderneath either kinde whether confeſſion ſinnes prepare man worthy receiuing sacrament whether maſſe true continuall ſacrifice whether yt cannon maſſe reteined whether sacramēt confirming vſed whether ther iii part penaunce contrition confeſſion ſatiſfaction whether prieſt may forgeue ſinnes hath confeſſed ſame whether prieſtes onlye haue authoritye keyes whether ſoules good men loue v whether pray god v whether ought pray vnto sainctes whether ſainets holy day oughte obſerued whether relikes sainctes oughte worſhipped whether ſoules godly yet repurged relieued maſſes praiers faſtinges almoſe dedes whether place purgatory whether time lent time faſting appoynted churche oughte obſerued whether day church forboden ought abſtain frō eating fleſh whether people ought ſtirred vp vnto religion ceremony ceremony godly whiche unto theſe dothe make anſwer xxvii daye may large althoughe confirmed ſayinges teſtimonies ſcripture doctor alſo yet condemned xxv iune depriued function thend iune french king marching army chāpaigne frenchē kinge muadeth themperours country mariburge taken taketh way riuer maſe inuading emperor country ioyning tournay ſurpriſeth amonge many thinges townes bouine dinaunt ſpoyleth raſeth caſtels taking mariburg fortifieth munition garriſon themperor going bruiſſels hys army commeth namures town riuer sabie v mile beneath dinant french king appeared haue deſired battell whan time tracted tourneth henault taketh biuſe town caſtel quene mary lady regent flaunders wher ſhe houſe pleaſure ſpoileth burneth
