deſtroyeth country farre neare ſpoyling burning commeth ſiege rentie towne border artois emperor comming whoſe army wholly aſſembled ſiege leuied light conflictes ſkirmiſhing either ſide moneth auguſt wheras manner ſame time kinges armye italy conduite peter stroſſe ſet vpon themperors power wherof gouernor marque marignan receiued great ouerthrow uery many swiſſes ſlain ſaid wer ſent thither king meane time emperor ſonne phillip xix day kinge phillip arriueth england iuly arriueth england nauy oute spaine fourth day euening commeth wincheſter quene taried going cathedrall churche wyth nobility receiued biſhop wincheſter certaine others emonges prince duke alua next day goeth quene talking long much verye familiarely ſeconde daye kept holy iames patrone spain mariage ſolempniſed ther themperors ambaſſadoure affirmed openly howe themperor geuen ſonne mariage kingdom naples afterwardes departing frō thence laſt entred london head city greate pompe ſolempnitie moneth auguſt certen ſtates thempire mete wourmes themperor called vpon thexecution againſt marque albert expulſed country went firſt loraine fraunce wher king denied intertainmente becauſe feared leaſt ſhould attempt ſomething leaſt ſhoulde make roade alſatia party neare vnto prouince rhine thend septembre ſent certen guidōs horſmen border loraine kepe paſſages laſt without exploict done returne home without domage wher lay moneth octobre aſſemble frankfurt cauſes unto conuention wer broughte letter marque albert wherin complaineth enemy laſt war ſpeaking much yt biſhop arras taunteth ſpitefully amōges others biſhops treues straſburge alſo lantz frenche kinges letter graue calleth thoſe bloudy horſmen laye waite hys life letter alſo red name frenche kinge wrytten dutch tonge firſt day octobre ſpeaking thold amitie fraunce germany eunemies wholy addict ſaith infringe ſame certen yeres paſt wrought matter ſo far father declared enemy neuertheleſſe two yeres ſince ſtate thempire miſerable cleane order forgetting offence paſt declared plainly good bare following foteſteps progenitor ſoughte euer auaunce honor dignity proued euer offered wronge aduerſaries haue many way gone aboute plucke liberty goodes alſo time haue deuiſed ſondry policy exact mony haue alſo kindled faction betwene noble houſes knowe rightwell albeit caſe ſtandeth thus yet procurement heare ſay howe certaine ſtates dede neighbor verely loked ſuch thing haue moued warre againſt wher haue proclaimed ſame doubtles great maruel ſo much dede quarrell betwixt v commonly ſpoken marque albert though ſhoulde aide againſt receiue wrong inaſmuch ſhewe fauor ſame old frendſhip whiche ſaide hathe bene alwaies betwene v alſo hath bene euer cuſtome entertainment kinges fraunce prynces aduerſity eſpeciallye germaines ſhoulde haue ſafe refuge ſuccoring place much pleaſaunte ſurely ſe honor home thinges ſafe wel ſe thus diſcomfited expulſed deſtitute ſuccor would haue wiſhed alſo chaunced calamity leaſt wiſe might reconciled vpon reaſonable condition ſo much fault mine aduerſary brought diſtreſſe hathe pronounced ſame thing fruſtrate hath ratified ſhuld ſuſpition hauinge compaſſion miſfortune ſhuld geue aid againſt thempire neuer came thought neither maye aſſured ſo nothing againſt lawes amity wheras youu ought loke nothing el peaceable frendlye require againe circumuented craftes neither loue ſo either ſhould make warre ſelues aid men monye theyr endeuor maye make theyr priuate affaire common rather obſerue amity take condition offered intende herein require aduertiſe plainly bearer hereof moreouer according thauncient cuſtome pacification paſſaw ambaſſadors ſhal come next aſſemble thempire may haue ſafeconduit unto made anſwer horſmen ſente frontier loraine concerned none iniury towardes done intent caſe marque albert ſhould make anye ſodaine inuaſion enterpriſe mighte diſapoynted touching ambaſſadoures ſafeconduit ſo muche haue commiſſion hereof aduertiſe theyr prince diſtruſt herein ſhall reaſonable thend octobre themperor geueth ouer ſōne phillip thempeor geueth ſonne phyllip dukedom millan dukedome millan ſendinge meſſagers inueſt herein accuſtomed ceremony french kinge leuiynge ſiege rentie ſaid long diſcharging swiſſes placed reaſt ſoldiors garriſons themperor far heſdine yeare toke ouerthrew ſaid eſpying place conuenient began new fortification towne thintent might bringe paſſe maintaineth army whiche monthe nouembre deſtroyeth picardy ſpoyling burning farre amia wherefore whole force violence warre lighted vppon pore miſerable people either ſide afterwarde themperor diſcharging reaſt armye interteined ſtill legion two ſelf ſame time french king ſēt new power italy amonges others certaine almaignes relieue sene whome emperor force duke florence beſieged hotely xii day nouembre holden parliament england cardinall poole comming oute brabant wheras certen ambaſſadors commen england cō duit cardinall poole arriueth england amonges lord paget xxiii nouembre came london right honorably receiued place wherſoeuer came immediatly reſtored blud houſe inheritance common aſſent conſēt king henry eight diſplaced v day came parliament houſe preſence king phillip quene whā ſhewed cauſe ambaſſade exhorteth return cōmunion church reſtore moſt holy father biſhop rome due authority wil graunt vnto thē clemency gentlenes admoniſheth thē alſo geue god thankes hath geuen ſuch king quene finally wher haue reſtored houſe inheritance taketh great benefit ſaith ſo much boūden reſtore heauēly court coūtry wiſheth moſt al thing whē ſpokē effect goth part ther biſhop wincheſter chancelor repeting oration many word exhorting thē vnity concord ſaith boūden geue god great thankes vnſpeakable mercy hath raiſed vp prophet owne ſede whiche moſt honorable cardinall wholy inclined vnto ſaluation next day nobility common approued thoration requeſts cardinal poole drawne fourme petition wherin beſeche king quene would make interceſſion ſome ſupplication repented ſore ſciſme haue denied obedience apoſtolicall ſeat haue conſented decree made againſt ſame henceforth wil commaundemente quene euer ſuch lawes ſtatutes may abrogated ſame parlament wherfore mooſte humbly beſeche theyr highneſſe wold meanes bring paſſe abſolued ſinnes cenſures whith haue committed againſte lawes church may receiued england returneth vomit penitent child boſome chriſtes church henceforth may ſerue god obedience ſea biſhoppes rome glorye name increaſe theyr owne ſaluation day whan king quene cardinall poole preſent chaunceloure ſtandeth vp pronounceth openly ſtates determined concerninge requeſt biſhoppe rome legate afterwarde dothe exhibite ſupplication aforeſaide compriſed wrytinge ſubſcribed kinge quene beſeching receiue opened deliuer againe chaunceloure reade demaundeth companye whether contente herewith whiche whan hadde affirmed kinge quene arriſe deliuer cardinal whan red exhibiteth vnto letter commiſſion ſame red men mighte perceiue authority geuen biſhop rome aſſoile maketh oration declareth howe acceptable thing vnto god repentaunce much thaungels heauen reioyſe penitent ſinner alledging purpoſe manye example geueth god thanckes hath put minde deſirous amendement done arriſeth likewiſe king quene knele vpon theyr knee calling vppon high power mercy god beſecheth loke mercifully vppon people pardone offence affirming ſelf ſent therfore highe biſhop chriſtes vicar geue abſolution lifting vp ſtretching forth cardinal geueth yt lordes abſolution hand manner bleſſeth whole multitude aſſoileth go chappell geuinge thanckes vnto god playing organes ſounding trōpets token ſhewed mirth gladneſſe ſuch time accuſtomed knew cardinal poole talke manner liuing marueled much loked manner ſtuffe hand xviii day decembre themperor addreſſing letter frō bruiſſels vnto ſtates thempire upon waighty vrgēt cauſes ſaith marque emperor letter againſt marque albert albert laſt yere outlawed iudges ye chābre condemned treaſon haue certen knowledge letter ſet vp openly thoſe alſo came frō v afterward ſo muche perſeuereth obſtinatelye troubleſome ſeditious purpoſes vndoubtedly goeth miſchief thintent may vexe plage oure natiue country germany foraſmuch hath hys recourſe ſondry place ther taketh ſtarting hole refuge credily informed thought neceſſary cōmon country ſake renue ye former decree eſpecially ſince beleue none loueth countrye wold prouide ye ſafegard ſelf land ſubiects alſo wold haue thenterpriſes adherent impeched letted wherfore charge commaūd vnder ſame penalty expreſſed yt man aid felowes thing nether help counſel relief mony vitails artillery alſo yt nether fellowes permitted make power leuy ſoldiors theyr dominiōs attempt ſuch thing yt euerye man let alwaies poſſible kepe theyr people ſubiectes run oute ſuch offēders obey commaundemente puniſhe extremely theſe letter ſet vp place print xxix decembre king ferdinando becauſe coū ſel wherof haue ſpoken yt ſhuld holden auſpurge came thither fineding man two day ſendinge thimperial counſell auſpurge letter meſſagers exhorteth prince yt ſo much ſhould treat moſt waightye affaire empire would repare thither ſpede ſelf although great loſſe hindraunce leauing country commen thither yt might conſult common weale deuiſe ſuche meanes profitable neceſſary thafflicted ſtate germany wherfore let come thē ſelues thinge theyr deputy ſo waightines cauſe requireth themperor brother hath geuē ful authority treat neither wil tary longer neades muſt aboute middes ianuary breaketh vp parliament london amonges many thinges reſtoring cardinall poole enacted thactes alſo king former time concerning puniſhing 1555 heretickes authority biſhops renued chieflye ſupremacy biſhop rome wholye reſtored lawes ſtatutes ben made againſt ſea rome ſpace xx yeares condempned aboliſhed uery many ſuppoſed ſame parliament king phillip ſhuld haue ben crowned herein nothing done beginninge february fiue condemned london ſuffer becauſe would returne romiſh religion men excellent learning ihon hoper biſhop gloceſter ihon bradford laurēce fiue cōdēnd london goſpell saunders rolland tailler doctoure ciuil law ihon rogers burned london taught reaſt caried euery man home gloceſter mancheſter couentry hadley ended liues like puniſhment right conſtantly little alſo biſhoppe saint dauid condemned ſent home ſuffer wrytten englād ambaſſadoures woulde go rome name whole realme ſhuld geue biſhop thankes hys greate clemēcy hathe ſhewed towardes promiſe alſo henceforth al obedience fidelitye v daye february king ferdinando though verye fewe prince beginneth treaty auſpurge ſelues knowe howe waightye neadefull cauſes emperoure appoynted conuention firſt wuolmes citye begin middes nouember dede requeſt aduiſe brother wiſhed yt matter might haue ben cōmenced ſame time howe puttinge thinges ordre home abſence thinges mighte well gouerned neare ennemye reſiſted caſe made anye enterpriſe impeched letted notwithſtandinge xxix nouember came hither laſte conſulte common wealth thinge alſo emperoure deſireth chiefly wit ſo euer cōcerneth goddes glorye tranquillitye empire ſame might common conſente determined much hath bene alwais themperors dilligence ſtudye paine care zeale hath common country publicke quiet offence taken away religion might eſtabliſhed ſo wel tried knowen others alſo decree made two laſte aſſembles nedeth declaration ſo euer alſo promiſed ſame time perfourmed dede pernitious cō motion well ciuill foreine haue beyond al expectation chaū ced ſence thoſe ſo holſome decree onlye letted diſturbed alſo taken away greate damage common weale ſo manifeſt men nedeth reherſall herein emperour blamed gaue none occaſion offence vnto man hath alwais dealt vprightlye conſtantlye whatſoeuer ſclaunder aduerſaries hath chiefly reſpecte common profit neither doubteth alſo beleue ye ſame hold clearged behalf wher therfore remeadye theſe euils themperor hath called counſell certenly purpoſed haue ben preſent ſelf whole treatye deteined ſickneſſe affaire could yet neuertheleſſe would thing ſhould longer delaied thintent verely bothe euill increaſing might reſtrained mighte duetye country loueth aboue thinges wherfore hath made uicegerent geuen ful authoritye together maye deuiſe meanes bothe honourable alſo profitable common weale ſame purpoſe hathe ſente certen men ioyned commiſſion treat ſame chief principal matter ſhalbe concerning religion ſo long diſſention hath ben head welſpringe theſe tumultes miſeries theſe many yeares ſo manye thouſandes haue loſte oulye liues alſo ſouls eternal ſaluation altogether long ſame ſo manifeſtly known neadeth declaration doubtles lamentable heauy ſight thoſe al one baptime name empire lāguage ſhuld thus torn ſōdre profeſſiō ye ſame faith ſo many hundreth yeares haue receiued elder deliuered hand hand caſe much greuous ariſeth daily one ſect two diuers whileſt euery man wil maintain opinion whiche thinge doubtleſſe bothe reproche god breaketh bonde charity diſturbeth mennes mindes ſuch ſort vulgare people knoweth world beleue greateſt miſchief theſe ſo greate erroures many little little growe vp found diuers wel chiefeſt nobility others ſetting cocke houpe beleue nothinge neither regard reaſon honeſty thing conſciēce doth preſcribe done great hinderaunce daunger innocent youthe certainly chiefly lamented germanye hath ſo manye yeares chief praiſe religion vertue ſhuld ſo abaſed ſo far degenerate mighte compared heathen people old time neither oughte preferred daye turkes alſo barbarian thys poynte thoughte one whit better becauſe hath bene redreſſe made hitherto great enormity althoughe many conuentions haue bene therefore fewe men cared becauſe thoſe whome beſt became remeadye partlye wincked therat partly ſeruing time reſpect priuate commoditye cauſe euer liuinge god hathe longe time nowe plaged germany certaine ſtates priuately diuers calamity ſo muche ſame region time paſt nombre people excelled ſtrengthe valeauntneſſe hable eaſily repulſe foraine violence ſame rent torne diſſentions warres commotion well ciuill foreines greate daunger tendeth vtter deſtruction excepte god wonderfullye preſerue therfore neadfull euery magiſtrate indeuor part herein duetie haue eſpeciall regarde cauſe religion wherein bothe god honoure honeſtye life alſo conteined moreouer ther hath benmo way one deuiſed appeaſe religion vniuerſall free godlye counſell mighte ſemed alwaies beginning emperor alſo vnto beſt waye becauſe much matter faith apperteineth one people alſo vnto al nation chriſtendome muſt doubtleſſe called ſame yt vice ſoeuer place may reformed taken away therfore emperor duetie theyr requeſt alſo labor waye vttermoſt power length brought paſſe ſuch counſell oftner called ſometimes alſo commenced impediment ther euerye time frute ſame returned common wealth doth leaue place doubting many whiche either counſels ſelues hadde deputy know matter well inough ſo contente ſame ordre counſell maye repared take place thing verely aboue others wiſhed almighty god aſſent thervnto moſt willingly alſo apply thing ſtudy faith dilligence dede thing conſulted thoſe cauſes wer let impediment might auoided taken awaye tumultes warre tempeſt common wealthe ſhall thincke mete differred vntil time quiet content godly tollerable way debated meane ſeaſon people ſtates may liue peaceably kept vnder honeſt diſcipline glorye god alwaies ſafe conſcience former yeares dede ofttimes mention made counſell prouinciall thoughe ſame moſt fit conueniente oure purpoſe ſo much bothe name manner fourme thereof ouretime hath opinion bene much knowen accuſtomed determine nothing therof preſent third way meanes hath bene diuers time aſſaied talcke conference learned men ſame hath commen ſmall profit yet well perceiued many chiefeſt poyntes might haue bene reconciled caſe matter bene handled wyth godlye zeale reſpecte priuate commoditye either ſide thinge neuertheleſſe woulde manne ſhoulde thincke ſpoken iniurye waye therfore muſte take deliberation alſo themperors deuiſe purpoſe touchinge ſame matter together mente good faith otherwiſe taken former yeares ſmall thanke either partie yet doth againe ſhall thincke good ſo miſlike ſame party alſo treat ſincerely affection laid part obſtinacy ſet ſide haue theyr eies goddes glorye onlye common ſaluation men ſhew herein faith dilligence perceiue none way preſent conuenient caſe haue anye thing mete purpoſe ſhall lawful declare ſame part conſultation concerninge peace whan certen yeres paſt lawes made hereof themperor ſuppoſed well prouided common quiet thend declareth ſufficiently foreſene might condempne outlawe rebel ſeditious parſons vnleſſe firſt cited appere due order iudgement conuicted meane ſeaſon hauing time ſpace afflicte diuers without deſert alſo prouided former actes man ſuffred iniury force inuaded next neighbor ſhould aſſiſt vnknowen impedimentes haue chaunced therfore muſt conſult way diligently theſe two poyntes law maye amended bothe vnquiet troubleſome perſons may made feard ſuche faithfull thempire may know aſſuredly ſhal want aid againſt force violence thing may done ſo much commodiouſly foundation hereof laid late woormes frankfurt wherfore ſhal wel follow conſultation begon bring end exorteth moreouer conſult eſtabliſhing iudgemēt imperiall publicke contribution coyne politicke thinges hitherto applye deuiſes meanes theſe domeſticall euils diſſentions tumultes ſeditions force may taken awaye cleane roted oute herein conſider chiefly ſtate thempire ſe greate daunger germany ſtandeth reaſon cruell turke ennemies alſo nothing leſſe turke ſeke ye deſtruction thempire let ponder therfore commodity receiue theſe diſcordes domeſticall euils vndoutedly haue craftelye raiſed ſupported diſſention ſtates might accompliſh theyr gready luſt ſoden inuaſion might bring al men ſubiection bondage nation haue bene ſo vanquiſhed ſupplā ted ought warninge take hede thē ſelues take ſuch counſel wherby preſent tempeſt ruine country may blowen ouer empire conſiſte perſeuer full ſtrengthe authoritye foraine violence time paſte ſo nowe alſo maye manfullye valeauntly repulſed ſo euer emperoure able bothe theyr aide counſell right gladlye ſuche ſorte men maye vnderſtande intier loue beare common countrye let perſwade ſelues moſte aſſured time oration kinge fardinando publiſhed throughoute germanye wrytten ſelf time ſondry place exiled boheme two hundreth miniſters churche miniſters exiled boheme ſignified alſo bi letter cardinal morone ſhuld com frō rome counſell thempire would aſſay like germany cardinall poole already brought paſſe england thought aſſuredly recoueringe england biſhop rome client conceiued wonderful hope mindes much thing ſo lucky ſucceſſe therfore thought el neuer yt god theyr ſide maintained moſt iuſte cauſe neither theyr church could conuict error thus chiefly beleued leaſt ſo pretended whan ſend ambaſſadours germany intent acknowledge faut theyrs may helpe ſuccor ſaye mennes infirmity end february ihon albert duke megelburge ſaid league duke moris whō henry duke brunſwicke afflicted ſore yere time kept war saxonie marieth daughter albert duke pruiſſe whan proceded thus farre aduertiſed oute england thoſe fiue whome ſpake little bradford althoughe condempned reſerued priſon mindes manye conſtancy reaſte ſuffered wer wonderfully aſtonied amaſed xxvi booke sledaines commentary concerning ſtate religion common weale reigne empyre charles fyfte argument xxvj booke england brought againe ſubiection biſhop rome wrytinge ſe • te indulgence duke saxon ambaſſadoures maketh purgation ferdinando excuſeth ſelfe thaſſemble miniſters churche expulſed oute boheme comforted wrytinges godly learned men townes taken french men prince germany mete enter alſo league pope iuly dead immedidiatly mercellus choſen ſtead dieth paul fourth name founder ſectes ieſuites ſuccedeth whileſt sene yelde emperoure cardinall poole ſolliciteth themperor french kinge vnto peace vaine quene england therin meane perſecuting cruelly true chriſtians time roſe tumultes geneua lucerues senate paris indeuoureth mitigate call proclamation ſetforth french king againſt true chriſtians thinges done rome biſhop norman againſt spaniardos uulpian taken french men diſſention amonges miniſters churche concerning lordes ſupper whileſt compact made lordſhip chattes themperor going spain committeth gouernment ſonne thinges doue thaſſemble thempire concerninge religion extraordinary wryting papiſtes ſame thanſwer alſo ferdinando proteſtantes bothe decrec inſued vpon ſame parlament ſtate england auſtriche ambaſſadoures requiringe mighte permitted haue true religion denied diuers anſwers fardinando ſue baine manner ſame time bauarians ſollicite theyr duke like matter vaine lengthe truce taken betwixte emperoure frenche kinge duke pruſſe imbraſing confeſſion auſpurge therror dſiander quenched time appeared blaſinge ſtarre matter marque albert heard tharchbiſhop cantorbury openly conſtantly profeſſyng true religion burnt pope ſeketh priuelye infringe diſſeuer confeſſion auſpurge cardinall auſpurge accuſed treaſon purgeth ſelf declaring plainly nature faction ſuſpition conſpiracye englande brodeth trouble increaſeth crueltye againſte faithfull xiij burnte together ſtake fardinando alledgeth reuoltinge tranſtiuania diuers townes alſo turke ready inuade cauſes lettes come thaſſemble hitherto ſo oft differred themperor length taketh ſhipping spaine leauing ſoone gouernor lowe country sleidan departeth thys life england ſubmitted ſelf againe biſhop rome hathe bene ſhewed ioy rome england reduced yt romiſhe church former boke theſe newes wonderfull expedition broughte rome greate ioye roſe citye te deum ſong euery church chriſtmaſſe euen biſhoppe ſendeth forth wryting since lately heard ſaith england many yeares nowe ſeparated plucked body church vnmeaſurable mercye god broughte againe communion ſame church obedience ſea rome ſinguler dilligence fidelitye trauell induſtrye kinge phillip mary wife cardinall poole toke greate pleaſure minde alſo reaſon gaue thankes vnto god hartely could omitted nothing frute profit gladneſſe might redound whole city like father goſpel mentioneth hauing recouered ſonne loſt reioyſeth exceadingly priuately glad minde alſo inuiteth others feaſting making good cheare together euen ſo verely thintent al world may vnderſtand great ioy gladnes common thanckes praiers made therfore power yt indulgēces graunted pope conuerſion englande haue permit euery man generall maye chuſe prieſt liſt vnto may confeſſe ſinnes rightly geue ſame prieſt authority yt may forgeue al manner ſinnes neuer ſo greuous euen thoſe whiche reſerued power alone wonte excepted name may remit treſpaſſe paine alſo ſinnes due may impoſe ſuch ſatiſfaction behoueth may releaſe vowes except chaſtity religion ſo yet recompenſed worke yea truſting vpon god mercye interceſſion ſainctes peter paule graunt full remiſſion ſinnes wont geuen euery fifty yeare thoſe humble hart conuert god wholy confeſſing ſinnes whan ſhall vnderſtande indulgence ſetforth v twiſe thriſe weke faſt geue almoſe vſe godly exerciſes receiue sacrament thanckes geuing praiers vnto god ye light countenance would illumine thoſe walke darkneſſe would geue peace moue heartes kinges concord ſo great benefite graunt alſo hindred either reaſon age ſickneſſe ſo performe thinges ſaid intent theſe oure wrytinges may euery knowne charge commaund patriarch archbiſhops ſuche like ſo ſone ſhall haue receiued copy ſame cauſe publiſhed euery man prouince ſince gift fre ſet forth without gain laſt boke ſhewed blaſſenburge head caſtell marque albert wherin hope whole country cō ſiſted ſurrendry taken time leaſt recouered mighte geue occaſion diſpleaſure aduerſaries ſubuert raſe ground without greate diſpleaſure houſe brandenburge marque kinred ferdinando king romaine came frō home alſo commen auſpurge aſſemble meſſagers letter exhorted prince make haſte come thither parſon laſt boke hath ben ſaid chiefly ſollicited prince elector saxony come auſpurge excuſed ſelfe could come namely ſtate saxony quiet ſending ambaſſadours thither excuſeth matter againe occaſion falling mention turk ſheweth pearill germany ſtandeth time paſt mightye feared others almoſt deſtitute void ſtrength hauing receiued ſo many diſpleaſures plague euill ſo much worſe amonge ſtates ſo greate alienation mindes diſtruſt amonges ſelues emperour ſelf remeadye diſeaſe omitted kind diligence yet yt al labour hitherto hath ben taken vain mind men ſo bitterly exaſperated alwais ſo ſet open diſpleaſure vnneth hope reconcilement yeares paſt brother moris ordained certain ceremony thing indifferēt ſhould kept ſtill church dominion ſame commaundement ſo little force alſo taunted libel bitter raylings many ſo much power confirm vnles would bring ſelf daunger therfore many afraid attempted thingin behalf thother ſide contrary part impugn doctrin profeſſed auſpurge little thincke eſtabliſh godly lawfull reformation known wel inough doings former time matter attempted ether talk conference el counſels conſideringe therefore ſo much labour taken counſels holden waye concorde found god peranenture ſo willinge reuenginge oure ſinnes beſecheth earneſtlye ſame booke conteineth ſome chriſten doctrin time paſt exhibited auſpurge would take euill wicked boke know certenty pure godlye wrytinge ſhewe vnto v ſonne god authoure ſaluation whiche doctrine dothe plainly agree thauncient churche thoſe foure chiefe counſels whiche teacheth fetteth forthe true chriſten worckes exhorteth people ſhew obedience magiſtrate wherefore caſe ſure peace aſſemble maye eſtabliſhed doubte emperoure maye haue greate aide germanye againſte turke elſſe proteſtauntes religion manye theim dede borne broughte vp therein perſeuer conſtantlye ſame religion vnleſſe ſuch peace may may compriſe bothe religion alſo churche goodes matter manye time hathe bene ſhoulde differred aſſemble delaied daye daye people lefte doutfull ſtate thinges vncertaine howe pacientlye menne woulde take though prince ſhould quiet duety ſhewe obedience yet maye menne meaner baſer ſort may raiſe ſome tumulte maye pretende vncertaintye ſtate feare pearill religion eſpeciallye thoſe place whiche geue oportunitye attempte ſuche thinges since therefore caſe empire ſuche earneſtlye requireth prouide common tranquillity ſo muche hathe full authoritye emperoure determine late yeares condition propounded brother moris paſſawe caſe controuerſy religion mighte reconciled yet neuertheleſſe aſſured peace might til thing might throughli appeaſed although emperor would admit ſame condition ſaide apperteined theſtates empire yet muche ſame time reproued expreſſe woordes added compoſition woulde ſee counſell matter ſhoulde bee handeled indifferentlye neyther ſhoulde anye crafte vſed voice concerning religiō truſteth ſame cauſe moue behalfe thoſe whiche tyme paſſawe ſtates alſo ſo ſone counſel ginneth perſwade peace thambaſſadours ſpoken effect fourth daye february nexte daye king ferdinando propoundeth ſtates ſuche ſorte ſhewed ye laſt boke miniſters ye churche driuen lande boheme learned men meiſſen wittemberge amongeſt others melāchthon melancthon comforteth ye miniſters boheme comfort epiſtle ſhew craft cō trary part affirmed kept neceſſary order churche thoſe whiche either receiued order byſhops hande wynes could miniſter sacramentes cauſe expulſion fayned ſhould ſeme haue deſire oppreſſe ye true doctrine theſe men ſhewe ſtarke tyrāny maried prieſtes ſhould put holy miniſtery sathā authour prohiting matrimony euidēt ye ſcriptures ought ſeke ordeined byſhops yt open ennemies goſpell defende idol fellowſhip hath pure doctrine therfore hath keyes kingdome heauen abſurde daū gerouſe shepeheardes ſhould ordeined wolues churche haue alwayes right chouſe mete miniſters ſo decree counſell nice ſo choſen tried haue bene confirmed gouerned godly congregation ſame maner bee nowe alſo obſerued therfore ſclaunder ſaye diſturbe breake order since therfore matter ſo true profeſſing goſpell expulſed ought take calamitie ſo muche moderatly god wyll fayle tyme ready theyr next church ſhewe loue hoſpitalitie frenche men ides decēber yeare conduit briſſake taken eporedia towne towne caſſalle taken frenchman alpes water durie yeare third daye marche intercept town caſale nere vnto ye poo wherin garriſon spaniardes almaynes vpon ſodayne fewe dayes caſtell alſo afterwarde bringe many thinges ſubiection amongeſt others thei raſe make euen groūd ualence saluadore ſixt day marche auguſt duke saxony ioachim marque brandēburg prince electours ſonnes alſo aſſemble prince saxonie numburge duke iohn fridericke lantgraue certen prince theſame countrie aſſemble numburg vpon riuer sale renew league inheritaūce whiche betwixt houſes saxon brandēburg heſſia ſhewed xxiiii boke alſo determine would ſticke conſtantly ye cōfeſſion auſpurg leaſt ſhould ſuſpicion ariſe new ſecret coūſell fift day came thether ſignifie cauſe aſſemble ye emperour wryting former yeare time compact made betwene auguſtus iohn fridericke duke saxonie alſo agreed vpon y• old familiar leage letter prince saxony themp ſhould renewed witte league whiche made hondreth yeres ſince eſtabliſhed lawe therfore yt haue met ſame cauſe league profitable elder people ſo likewyſe thei truſted yt ſhuld com thē luckely paſſe ſince thei ſought nothing el peace trāquillitie ye diſpleaſure man moreouer yt maner aūceſters haue excepted highnes brother king romains intende priuatly kepe mutual amitie amongeſt thē ſelues ſo wil alſo openly doe dutie requireth may become obedient prince thempire yt religion wil procede limited confeſſion auſpurg much ſame cōteined chief article ye chriſtian doctrine wicked ſedicious opinion found therin thei wil god grace perſeuer theſame doctrine neither wil fayle alſo cō mon welth germany ſo far forth thei able trauel counſel treaſures much time moſte quiet auoiding diſcōmoditie abide home haue ſent ambaſſadours thaſſēblee thempire haue cōmaundemēt refer al counſels doings vnto peace ſo yt neither religiō ciuile cauſe force violēce ſhould feared ye peace eſtabliſhed ſhal occaſion yt cōtrouerſies may ye better appeaſed ſtate doubtles ye cōmon welth ſuch yt great nede ioine together force mindes wyder entrie ſet open ye turkes inuade v know wel enough howe greatly deſireth ſo ſone may ſufficiēt army might prepared repres thennemies violence wherfore caſe ſuch peace might eſtabliſhed ther doubt ſtates thempire wold gladly imploy ſubſtaunce vpon ſame war verely hitherto reaſon ſondry tumultes ciuile diſcordeshath bene omitted wil alwaies ready haue cōmaunded ambaſſadours offer theſe thinges name counſel theſame day write king ferdinādo maner ye ſame effect ſaid ye duke auguſt ambaſſadours vrge y• ſame cōpact paſſawe ſhew deſirous peace thei cōmend doctrine cōfeſſed auſperge exhort confirme peace alſo pray wold geue credit ſuch haply ſeke diſturbe quiet germany ides march archbyſhop mētz dieth archbiſhop mentz departed life ſaied haue bene counſel trent put flight marque albert daniel brēdel ſuccedeth viii day yt byſhop mentz ye xxiii day march death pope iuly third dieth pope iuly third bicauſe ſo eaſely beyond al expectatiō recouered england thought haue cō ceaued alſo wōderful hope germany therfor ſent thither cardinal morone next day dead came coūſell thempire auſpurg eight day hearing newes therof ye laſt day march departeth thence againe truckeſſe cardinal auſpurg ſpedeth electiō rome cardinal wer rome tarieng reſt made haſt ix day april proclaime pope marcellus ſecōd name marcellus ye ſecond choſē ſame ſent ambaſſadour cardinal farneſe ye emperour paul third ſhewed xiii boke cardinal auſpurg fewe day went rome letter ſent senate prince ambaſſadours ſheweth deſireth dede peace al meanes wiſe cōſent dignitie sea apoſtolique olde religion ſhould defaced neuer permitte meane time sene nowe ſpace eight moneths wit euen time peter stroſſe sene rendre ſelues themp receiued ouerthrowe ſhewed laſt boke beſieged ye power themperour coſmus duke florence driuen want thinges ayde appered ye xxi daye aprill yelde thēſelues thēperour ruled garriſon ſoldiours lieftenaunt themperours armie marque marignane twyſe famous policie war thre yeres ſince time thayde french king spanyardes beinge diſcomfited raſed caſtell sene ſending ambaſſadours gaue kinge harty thankes could deuiſe time forewarde cō mended tuition ſelues marcellus ſecond newly created pope xxii daye marcellus ye ſecond dieth creation night yt goeth firſt may chaū ged life death alitle wercome citie forduties ſake ſalute hercules duke farrare guy ubalde duke urbine preuēted others neuertheleſſe ſhould haue come cardinal aſſembled conclaue xxiii day may proclame cardinal theatine pope theſame iohn peter naples deane college gentleman borne noble houſe caraſtes man aunciēt yeares notably learned chaunging name called ſelf paul fourth paul third choſen nomber cardinal ſelf ſame began paule fourth certen new ſecte thoſe whiche called ieſuites haue neſtled italy alſo certen place germany lōg created nephew brother ſonne ſecte ieſuites cardinal ſame man warre chief captayne ſeruing moſte part frenche kyng ſhewed laſt boke poole thengliſh cardinal went themperour french king ſollicite moue thē trauell cardinall poole make peace betwene perour frēch king peace handled cauſe wordes writinges amongeſt thinges vſed perſwade whileſt ſaith kepe ciuile war turke doeth much inlarge dominion hauing wonne sea land two ſtrong holdes belgrade rhodes hath made way open offen hath poſſeſſion tonowa god ſtired vp king perſia aduerſary bee thought might haue already ſubdued ſelf al prouinces chriſtendom ſelfſame occaſion haue euil chriſtiās alſo increaſed ſondry place ſo much deprauation corruptiō al diſcipline aſwel eccleſiaſtical ciuile power great inough ſuppreſſe thē declare welenough ſo many rebellion ſtired vp euery duty religion neglected hereſies ſciſmes meane time ſpring vp increaſed place ye ought conſider ſaith ar prince chriſten beligion albeit god hathe permitted sathan thauthour euil altogether yt might ſift churche wynnowe like wheate ſtyre vp war amongſt two ye chiefeſt moſte noble mēbers ye church yet hath ſuffred wickednes prophane ciuile matter religion hath kept ſounde one ſame opinion annexed body churche el coulde hardly made againe concorde betwixt ſo many prince haue reuolted churche thennemy mankinde hath attempted ſo many thinges yet hath god moſte benignely loked vpon hath made enter priſes fruſtrate wherby moſte certen token goodnes clemencie towardes ſheweth wil length vſe miniſterie wil ioyne together vicar earth intent verely ſuch hurtful diſſentions may taken way well ſtate ciuile ſacred peace may reſtored al mē many ſuch like thīges brought poole threatening alſo wrath vē geaunce god vnleſſe leaue releaue miſerie ye afflicted people although preuailed nothing yet whileſt matter went forwarde englande holdeth matter lēgth brought point emperour frenche king refuſed ſende ambaſſadours treatie peace quene englande meane matter appointeth fit mete place myddes place y• treaty peace choſen quene england playne betwyxt caleis arde grauelyn townes englyſhe frenche flemiſhe dominion ſet treangle intrenchynge ſame rounde aboute wyth ditch buylded foure pauilions sommer houſes deede yet fyne fitte pourpoſe place therfore xxiii daye maye yeare ambaſſadours mete emperour amongeſt others came byſhop arras frenche kyng cardinal loraine coneſtable england came peacemaker cardinall poole biſhop wyncheſter chauncelour erle arondell lorde paget brute blowē abroade far nere ſtyred vp diuerſe expectation iudgementes men amongeſt chiefly vnto whome controuerſies vnknowen came queſtion dukedome millan burgundy sauoye piedmont corſica nauerne loraine lande luke city tully uirodone metz matter long much debated amongſt thinges laſt engliſhe interceſſours ſayde certen theſe controuerſies ought referred hearing generall counſell departed nothyng finiſhed kyng ferdinando ſtates empire ſendinge letter emperour ye fourth ides iune praied treatie peace would haue conſideratiō thoſe thinges whiche kyng fraunce taken empire therfore nothing done emperour empe letter ſtates empire wryting againe ſtates xv day duty ſaith ryght acceptable ſo moued calamity thoſe thinges whiche mine alſo publique ennemy empire hath afflicted doubtles careful ſuche thinges might reſtored fourmer eſtate epiſtle deliuered inioyned mine ambaſſadours chief counſellours ſent treate peace amongeſt thinges ſhould handle ſame moſte diligently nother ſhould herein relent thyng although wayes meanes concorde ſet open v thought becauſe cōmon quiet would haue dealte obſtinatly yet time broken without good done neuertheleſſe better ſtay chriſtendome refuſe peace vpon ſuch reaſonable condition hitherto haue bene propounded occaſiō ſhall ſerue wyll wholy indeuour thoſe thinges may reſtored empire may better ſtate hereafter emperour little ſent duke alba lumbardie might make warre ferdinando duke alba ſent millan gonzaga diſcharged ſelfe office retourning home flaunders liued priuate life many monethes bene report dede moſt certen chifly tyme ye quene englande childe nere time expectation vain alſo began burne againe englande ſame bradforde whome ende xxv booke ſayde bradforde burnt englande fewe monethes condemned caried againe pryſon laſt burnt amongeſt others ende moneth may iohn fridericke eldeſt ſonne duke iohn fridericke toke wyfe agnes iohn friderick thelect ſonne marieth lantgraues daughter whiche bene wyfe duke maurice thither came many prince whiche vpon occaſion alſo conſulted againe matter numburge maner ſame tyme lady iane emperours mother departed lyfe kyng ferdinando kept funerall auſpurge empe mother dieth certen tumult night rayſed geneua certen senatours thought bring gouernment tumult raiſed geneua citie faction chiefly hated caluine thoſe perſecutiō come thither fraunce ſought expulſe running vp downe night ſeaſon ſondry place token watche worde cried frenchemē vp harneſſe citie betrayed kept ſelues houſes matter length appeaſed certen executed many ſaued thē ſelues flight cauſe would haue expulſed french men ſtraungers amongeſt others many late choſen nomber citezens wherby ſawe owne force weakened nomber part increaſed turkes nauie certen former yeares ſo nowe alſo ſayled tuſcane ſea threatening hetruria wherfore euer went ioyned frenche nauie marque maarignane lieftenaunt emperours armie inuaded porte hercules kept frenchemen force ſouldiours wynneth caſtell putting porte hereules taken imperial plūbine beſieged turkes garriſon ye ſworde ides iune turkes afterwarde beſiege towne plumbine ouerthrowe matter would ſuccede thei attempt ilua ilande duke florence vayne alſo certen politicke lawes ſet foorth metz whiche citie frenche kyng garriſon gouernour alſo iudge execute iuſtice wrytten amongeſt thinges brother ſiſter vncle tutour gardien bawed mayde woman ſhould haue rynge iron put necke ſhall openly vſe ſuche practiſe ſubiect iniuries rebuke men let beaten roddes banniſhed father mother ſhall lyke ſhal loſe head many men marueled theſe thinges ſo ſet forth ſuch vnaccuſtomed vice euery vſed ſemed ſo muche forboden ſhewed howe corrupt maners tyme hereof may eaſely gathered ſame controuerſie hath nowe many yeares controuerſie dominion ye chattes vene betwixt lantgraue william erle naſſow lorſhip chattes haue ſpoken heretofore oftener thā wherfore intent laſt ende might made leaſt inconuenience might arriſe therof certen prince intreate matter indifferent arbitrers appointe daye wormes firſt iuly theſe paulſgraue prince electour chriſtopher duke wirtēberg william duke cleaue lātgraue ſent thither william eldeſt ſonne condition propounded certē tyme debated laſt permitted deliberatiō certen tyme appointed ſame matter ye meane ſeaſon frenchemen intent might haue victualles readines plucke downe many village countrie mountfarrate leaſt ennemie ſhould poſſeſſe caſale ſhould brought diſtreſſe thoſe partes towne uulpiane great force eſtimatiō ſame uulpian vitayled kept spaniardes newe comming duke alba great power gathered towne vitayled ſame tyme alſo frenchemen vitayled maryburge taken yeare flaunders kept emperour frenche kyng moued counſell ſet maryburg vnailed forth proclamation wherby commaunded officer ſuche eccleſiaſtical iudges inquiſitours fayth ſhould condēne ſhould greatnes fault frēche kinges proclamation againſt cō demned yt inquiſitours without delaye reſpecte appealyng put death cardinall lorayne deliuered proclamation senate paris old cuſtome thē allowed ſet forth might regiſtred common recordes ſomewhat aſtonied newnes ye thing helpe appealing takē away require time take deliberatiō ſending king ambaſſadours ſhe opinion ſhalbe declared place towne rhaetia next italy called lucarne whiche belongeth common citie heluetians citezens ſame towne required swiſſes lucernates require yt swiſſes doctrine goſpell would permitte haue doctrine goſpell muche religion diuerſe varied ſentence ſome thought mete graunte requeſte others ought permitted lyke ſome ciuile tumulte ariſe therof ende voice preuailed wherby decreed ſhould remayne religion elder ſhould lawfull thē would go dwel el founde many whiche leauing houſes went zurick whiche citie dede receiued dealt liberally time engliſh ambaſſadours ſent pope name whole realme ſhewed ende laſte booke retourne rome homewarde pope allowed well enough al thinges retourned repentaunce craued pardon churche goodes ſhould reſtored ſaide wyſe ſuffered amōgeſt ambaſſadours byſhop ely king denmarke nauie time ſailing nauie kinge dēmarke towardes north made men talke diuerſly ſome ſaid done emperours counſell mynded put kinges ſonne brother poſſeſſion scotlande others ſayde prepared vſe frenche kyng others cauſe emperour king philip ſonne whoſe power waxed great reaſon englande ſhould ſtraye might reſtrayned therfore city sea coaſte thought alſo haue borne charge ſame nauie lōg great expectation rumour vaniſhed away preparation found made againſt pirate ye ſtate rome troubleſome yt pope hauing sanſtorian camillus cardinalles led pryſon cōceiued ſuſpicion certen noble prouided garriſons placing ſoldiours citie committed sſortia cardinall sanflorian camillus houſe columnois priſon muche emperours part many men thought went greater matter ſuſpicion increaſed tyme required duke florēce emperours client wonderous great ſumme mony whiche clement ſeuenth lent alexander medices lately iuly third lent ſiege sene captiue cardinalles length putting ſuerties inlarged spaniſhe flete tyme came towardes flaunders laden kynde marchaundiſe came vpō spaniſhe flete intercepted french coaſtes normandie frenchemen whiche knewe long ſet vpon great force fight conflicte terrible ſhippes ſunke burnte either parte many loſte wherof ſome weapon others fire many ſwallowed vp billowes periſhe frenche men caried away certen ſhippes king philip came england father bruſſelles toke depe hauon whence came monthe auguſt whereas end ſame moneth kyng philip ſayling englande flaunders came emperour father bruſſelles accompanied noble englande truckeſins cardinall auſpurge vniuerſitie erected dillinge fewe yeares paſt founded uniuerſitie dillinge towne ſituated vpon riuer danubius wyll permiſſion pope iuly thirde graunted ſame publique bull exceading great fredoms priuileges wryting ſet forth print declareth hither therfore amonges came whome themperour many yeares vſed ghoſtly father confeſſour terme peter aſot spaniarde blacke freer yeare began contrary wryting impugne booke conteyning boke peter aſot againſt cō feſſion duke wirtemberge ſōme chriſten doctrine boke chriſtopher duke wirtemberge ſent ambaſſadours father counſell trent ſayde whiche alſo afrayde dedicate ſame duke iohn brentius time aunſwereth large confuteth ſophiſticall reaſons whiche boke brentius uergerius afterwarde tranſlated italian ende men owne nation might vnderſtande thing came controuerſie whether parte handled ſcriptures purely ſincerely ides september george counte mountpelicarte george erle mount pelicarte marieth yt lantgraues daughter vncle duke wirtemberge maried lady barbara lantgraues daughter arriuall duke alba lumbardie king fraunce alſo ſendeth thither new ayde many warlike captaines ioyned ſelues monſour briſſake companion peril fortune towne wherof haue ſpoken called uulpian fortified garriſon spaniard great annoyaunce frenche matter ſeing thence roades made farre taurin intent therfore let might taken away might haue victualle frenchemen towarde ende auguſt beſiege al force batter uulpian taken raſed frenchman muche harme done receiued length xxii day september take ſurrendry raſe walles towne caſtell make ſhape uillage fewe dayes take alſo towne caſtell mountcalue taken yt frenchman mountcalue betwixt aſte caſale diſſention hath bene nowe theſe xxx yeares betwixt learned men aboute lordes ſupper preſence chriſtes body began time renewed bokes ſet forth miniſters church breme hamborough namely againſte controuerſie lordes ſupper renewed yt bremers caluine iohn alaſcus caluine afterward aunſwereth ſharpely defendeth cauſe theſame doeth bullinger iohn alaſcus alſo ſetting forthe booke kyng poole complayneth bewayleth examination made talke cōference ſentences opinion condemned preiudice verely maner papiſtes whiche alſo procede argumentes ſcripture wyll violence end september auguſtus duke saxony auguſt prince electour ſonne borne ſonne borne called magnus godfather fōtſtone amongeſt others henry duke brunſwicke iohn fridericke lantgraues ſonne lawe haue ſpoken archebyſhop cantorbury ridley byſhop london hughe latimer howe caried oxforde reaſoning diuines condemned therfore kept priſon vnto tyme nowe laſt moneth october ridley olde father latimer burnt archebyſhop alſo ridley latimer burnt england brought forth place execution openly call vpon god mercy lead againe pryſon ſame moneth cardinalles lorayne tournon went rome alſo senate paris whiche cal parliament aunſwering king thanſwere parliament paris yt kinges proclamatiō lutherians whiche cardinall loraine requeſted mentioned proclamation ſay whiche came forth foure yeares ſince moſte mighty kyng reſerued ſelfe iudges examination puniſhment luther hereſie neither thinge exceptep vnleſſe time required declaration hereſie ſentence pronounced ſuche taken order proclamation ſet forth doth plainly eſtabliſh contrary ſubmitteth people realme eccleſiaſticall iudgement inquiſitours meane diminiſhed dignitie wherby excelle men geueth ſubiectes iuſt cauſe grief clerely deſtitute ar made ſubiect foreine power herein great deale inconuenience ſhalbe goodes lyfe health dignitie ſhall pleaſure helpe appealing taken away verely appellation refuge ſanctuary innocencie protectour defendour appellation alſo innocentes yea beſides note howe byſhops ſeke authoritie kinges cō demne innocentes man hath right ouer people lawe iudgement nowe committed inquiſitours byſhops officer appellation taken away ſet open wyndowe make waye euen innocentes might condemned loſe body goodes indewed ſo great power witte kinges ful authoritie forget dutie kepe meaſure tyme ſhall ſee euery degree ſubiecte common perſones alſo noble men prince ſtande hande howbeit yet meane waye may take iudges ſhuld heare cauſe geue ſentence obſcure opinion ſame determined clergie let thē alſo order iudged owne men concerning appellation let wrytyng obteined pope wherby may permitted iudges matter ſhall come iſſue iudgement muſt made ſuche haue appealed let preſent certen choſen counſellers eccleſiaſticall order ſuche wante tried fit men inquiſition let obſerued pope inquiſitour doe ſubſtitute place vnder prouinces men vpright fame good men byſhop doe beare whole charge defendaunt yet ſo matter determined coſtes required whome behoueth theſe thinges tende ende verely ſuche maner controuerſies may reſtreyned within certen boundes limites notwithſtanding muche appeareth puniſhement heretickes al though neceſſary hath hitherto bene thereby brought paſſe facte ſhould deteſted rather ſhould amended moreouer bicauſe much better remedy diſeaſe time geue ſpace whileſt may increaſe lay medicine ſhalbe law full moſte mercifull kyng herein followe maner ſteppes olde primatiue churche ſame eſtabliſhed either fyre ſworde diligence biſhops euer reſiſte heretickes whyleſt preached oftentymes god worde ſhone example good lyfe since therfore tymes paſt meane firſte confirmed may nowe ſame alſo reteyned kept ſo would execute whiche lieth rather power verely byſhoppes paſtours ſhepe ſhould ſelues gouerne church preſently let alſo inferiour miniſters ſame againe henceforth ſuche made byſhops able ſelues teache people ſubſtitute deputy ſteade rote muſt tilled vpon foū dation muſt builde ſo may hope well hereſies wyll litle litle vaniſhe away caſe waye neglected feared leaſt thei wil increaſe proclamatiōs ſo euer finally made remedy ſo euer vſed xvi daye october ſignified theſe thinges king ambaſſadours letter alſo prince vmperes controuerſie gouernemēt chattes mete againe appointed meting prince yt • ātgrauet matter firſt bacherach afterwarde ſickenes paulſgraue wormes matter dede ended certen ſomme money agreed vpon whiche lantgraue ſhoulde paye erle abyde ſtyll poſſeſſion erle vnleſſe mony payd certen time would haue compact vaine action remayne hym whole lantgraue whiche ſent ſonne thither reiected condition departed matter finiſhed ſame moneth emperour calleth emre charles geueth gouernemēt sonns philip bruſſelles ruler ſtates ſpeaking ſicknes ſheweth amongeſt thinges would goe spayne geueth ouer gouernement right power philip ſonne exhorteth dutie theſe newes ſpred abroade ouer al europe far nere nauie prepared day appointed iourney ides nouember litle litle brute waxed colde becauſe wynter hande ſayde nauigation differred next ſommer nowe muſt come counſell empire matter ſhould treate kyng ferdinando fifte daye february propounded ſayde ende laſte booke many came ſlowly began nonas marche laſte ambaſſadours prince electours doe conſulte matter ſhould firſt treate although many againſt yet doe conſente laſte treate fyrſte religion ſame alſo thought mete senate prynces city muche debatynge agreed geue peace religion thynge came chiefly controuerſie whether peace ſhould geuen religion proteſtauntes woulde haue lawefull men indifferently followe theyr doctrine aduerſaries muche contention reſiſte ſayde ſame permitted either city receiued decree auſpurge made ſeuen yeare concerning religion yet whole ſtate clergie yf byſhoppe abbot woulde chaunge hys religion woulde haue hym remoued ſubſtitute place therfore contention ſharpe proteſtauntes alledged cauſe purpoſe promeſſes god well olde newe teſtament whiche conteine ſaluation doe apperteine generally vnto men therfore lawfull include ſame within certen limites brynge reſtreinte leaſt ſhould ſhutte bothe ſelues others kyngdome heauen neither turke iewe zeale would bee glad bringe men owne religion howe muche ought doe ſame whome god hath ſo earneſtly ſtraightly charged wherfore able proue men caſe oughte haue libertie graunted bothe holy scripture alſo decree father counſelles howe thoſe whiche take vpon title olde catholique religion without great diſhonour god handle religion abuſe churche goodes neuertheleſſe eſtabliſhe peace permitte may kepe ſtyll lawes rite ceremony inioye goodes landes poſſeſſions cuſtomes rightes priuileges tyll ſuche tyme diſſention religion accorded wherfore allowe ſhoulde preſcribe condition byſhoppes ſo ſhould come paſſe ſelues ſhoulde bounde impugne approuers felowes owne religion theyr great diſhonour ſhoulde condemne owne cauſe ſaye graunte religion doctryne worthy churche goodes ſame goodes haue bene hetherto applied amiſſe church miniſteries ſhould alſo confeſſe theyr wicked doctrine miniſterie grounded vpon goddes worde churche goodes conſecrated fylthie lyfe theyrs lawes ceremony howe greate aſſence woulde thynge ingender yf ſhoulde maynteyne cauſe lyuynges whyche doe perfourme profitable neceſſary dutie churche ſhoulde betraye ſame religion oughte v bee moſte ſet aduerſaryes amonges thinges ſaide clergie ſhould permitted alter religion would come paſſe byſhoprikes ſuche like college ſhould made prophane litle litle plucked away churche ſhould come handes prince made inheritaunce affirme neuer intēt haue reſpect called olde foundation might imployed true vſes ſame goodes might annexed ſame church euer take awaye doubtes promiſe put good aſſuraunce byſhoprikes college ſoeuer religion ſhall altered part goodes alienated death reſignation byſhop free election adminiſtration ſhould permitted college muche reaſoning could agree exhibite partes kyng ferdinando reaſons compriſed wrytinge requeſte hym wold fynde ſome waye ides iune proceded ſlowly cauſe wherof many thought concluſion peace betwene emperour frenche kyng loked ſame thought make litle either parte papiſtes made extraordinary wryting wrytinge papiſtes requeſtes yt proteſtauntes vehement byting intent myght ſet forth matter firſte ſaye proteſtauntes haue propounded fiue condition firſt catholiques ſhould allowe doctrine many yeares paſt time alſo ſo ſone ſprāg vp ordinary magiſtrate hath bene alwayes condēned secondly ſacrileges ſpace theſe xxx whole yeres haue cō mitted ſhould ratified allowed neither law godly lawful meanes church may recouer yt ſame goodes wold alſo haue peace made notwithſtāding forboden haue cōpany moreouer thei might place ye college church archbiſhops prelate wicked miniſters ſet forth doteſtable condēned doctrine aboliſh true ſeruice ceremony ye church bring new wicked place may noriſh thoſe falſe preacher ye churche goodes directly againſt tholde lawes cuſtome churche ſhould lawefull perſones well eccleſiaſtical ciuile yet followe catholique religiō reuolt frō true religion come followe lore finally prince byſhops reuolt ſyde ſhall concerne ſame perſone muſt apperteine people alſo ſubiecte gouernement goodes whole eccleſiaſticall iuriſdiction nowe although theſe thinges ſtriue lawes god man albeit thei contrary othe themperour king al prelate ſo muche catholiques may conueniently receiue vnleſſe would breake fayeth promeſſe yet much ſticke obſtinatly pourpoſe threaten force alſo catholiques length contented ſo farre forth ought pacification paſſawe haue declared ſame ſufficiently senate empire ſhewyng graunt libertie chaunging religion indifferently men ſo ſhould come paſſe empire ſhoulde broughte deſolation hyghe top dignitie taken away germany dutie archebyſhops prelate office archebyſh permitte religion condemned alſo ſhould admoniſhe put feare byſhoppes ſuche others yea vnlearned ready reuolte ſuche continue errour preſent catholique romiſhe churche maner hath euer ſince tyme apoſtels bene obſerued proued ſondry teſtimonies counſelles chiefly calcedonie neyther ought man thinke ſuche reuolte ſhould left owne conſcience thinges concerne fayth euery man ought permitted haue cō ſcience free departeth commō conſent churche ought puniſhed reſtreyned caſe obeie muſt excommunicated example thoſe counſelles whiche accompted chief whiche condemned arrius macedonius neſtorius eutyches dede counſell calcedonie depoſed dioſcorides maynteyner eutyches byſhoprike ſayde euery man ought haue iudgement conſcience free neyther chriſte apoſtles euer compelle beleue yea many went awaye chriſte none holden againſt wyll ſame verely grounded vpon foundation confuted saint auguſtine large two hondreth fourth epiſtle ſhould free byſhoppes forſaking catholique religion reuolte wyll relinquiſhe theyr byſhoprike wyll ſaye nōt doe ſaufe conſcience wyll deſyre ayde proteſtaūtes wyll aſſiſte mainteining ſtate keping people religion done doubt theſe wyl take hande defende wil ſaye doe dutie end may haue gouernment alſo poſſeſſion good wher theſe men ſaye bounde admitte fellowes religiō exclude man kyngdome heauen doth excuſe one fayth whiche chriſtians ought profeſſe obſerue faith tymes paſt emperours kynges prince ruler empire people alſo confirmed othe uerely catholique faith ſelfe ſame germany beginning vnto time haue followed thoſe excepted haue reuolted ſame wherfore nothing made newe thynges ought referred fayth mynde ſubdued may obeye catholique churche doeth otherwiſe taketh ſelfe priuate religion vnleſſe obeye admoniſhementes ought byſhop excommunicated remoued function goodes alſo ought ciuile magiſtrate publiſhed neither ſuffered within limites empire ſame libertie licenciouſnes religion father haue alwayes reiected certen confuſion faith made lawe thinges ſo euer determined coūſels matter faith ſhuld reaſoned called doubt ſo lawful none ordeine propounde thing cōtrary hiſtories teache v time ualentinian themperour admitted kinde ſectes trouble aroſe ſame ſhuld receiued yt whoſoeuer diſſenteth frō ye catholique faith ſhuld excuſed conſcience ſhould anabaptiſtes zwinglians schuuenchfeldians ſuche like alſo excuſed peace cōpriſed ſaye promeſſes god wherby promiſeth v euerlaſting life apperteine men generall neither ought thē reſtreined though thoſe promeſſes apperteined thē whiche profeſſion thing far otherwyſe tyme ſhall ſwarue communion churche excluded kingdom heauē euen iudgement ſaluation churche howe ſhould kyngdome heauen belonge whiche reiecte sacramentes churche contemne ordeining prieſtes vnto whome chriſte hathe geuen power binde loſe prieſtes conſecrated amonges howe obteyne remiſſion ſynnes except ſinnes forgeuen ſhall made partaker heauenly kingdome therfore thoſe promiſes apperteine rather thought nomber whome chriſte ſayeth knoweth bragge able proue howe catholiques ſondry abuſe religion churche goodes let v ſee thing herein blamed holy scripture lawes father counſelles churche goodes ought diſtributed byſhops miniſters churche imployed vpon poore vpon reparation thing require ſo vpon raunſomyng kept pryſoners turkes barbarian uerely cuſtome hath continued thouſand thre hondreth yeares ſince ſame goodes ſhoulde bee imployed godly miniſters vſes whiche ſorte ſaye maſſe ſhewe god worde repare builde church fynde pore men alſo monkes freers nunnes putting certen byſhops make newe prophane ciuile officer vnto whome geue ſmall portion poſſible ioyne miniſters whiche bring ye ſely people errour whileſt contemne ſound doctrine miniſter people sacrament whole bread dede conſecrated witte creature place creatour vnder colour true worſhipping committe idolatrie ſaye henceforth wyll imploye churche goodes aboute none matter vſe ſcholes wyll conuert part therof ſelues well let ſo vſe catholique religion ſhould polluted vtterly oppreſſed vſe ſhall great deale worſe ſame goodes beſtowed prophane matter theſe cauſes therfore lawefull catholiques allowe condition wrytten wryting ſayed extraordinary priuatly made proteſtaūtes aduertiſed hereof write againſt anſwer proteſtauntes yt wryting papiſtes firſt ſhewe true doctrine ſame verely whiche conteined wrytinges prophetes apoſtles secondly declare muche doctrine papiſtes differeth ſame whiche haue ſo many wayes polluted lordes ſupper whiche haue brought ſo filthie errours purgatory praying dead whiche take awaye denie remiſſion ſinnes whileſt ſaye muſt alwayes doubte grace god whiche ſo muche diſhonour matrimonie inſtituted god deteſtable horrible crime defiled ſenglenes lyfe euē ſame vice saint paule rehearſeth theſe thinges may clerely appeare haue forſaken true religion ſeing ſo ſuche eccleſiaſticall perſones either haue nowe already el hereafter ſhall imbrace pure doctrine neglected touching churche goodes thinges maruelouſly defiled alſo truthe benefice geuen dutie conſidered diligently ſorte office prieſt byſhop conſideration ſcholes muſt alſo euen tyme ye prophetes maner hath euer remayned nowe prelate church ſeke chiefly ſuche thinges due miniſtrs churche teacher ſchollers ſcholes almouſe houſes hoſpitalles imploye vſes may liue al voluptuouſnes ſame thei abbey colledges doeth byſhop repreſent great prince taking firſt poſſeſſiō byſhoprike entreth citie two thouſand horſemen theſe thinges dede none doe dutie mynde conſcience theſe obiecte ſacrilege extortion others doctrine dede condemned freers wickednes yt perſwade reade wrytings pope rabble condemne deſpiſe maruell ſame maner chriſte doctrine intreated anna caiphas ſorte phariſeis byſhoppes make oft mention counſelles churche lieth power counſelles churche propounde commaunde newe doctrine beſides ſame whiche left v prophetes chriſt apoſtles ſpeake conſecrating miniſters fonde worthy laughed foliſhe hiſtrionicall annointing maketh nothing ye purpoſe finally wryting full rayling opprobrious wordes committe god would aunſwer thynge fewe wordes wryitng king ferdinando prince ſtate thinges king ferdinādo partes requeſted would ſhewe ſome waye ſayde beginning auguſte ſendeth ambaſſadours electours certen prince meſſage howe obeye emperour brother common wealth came auſpurge third kalē de ianuary without loſſe hinderaunce owne affaire againe come thither driuen tary long becauſe fewe none come could propounde thing matter differred tyll nonas february firſte declared cauſes ſommoning ſayde aſſemblee conſultations haue wonderfull delayes tenth kalendes iuly aunſwere made hym one point deliberation witte peace religion ſelfe ſame aunſwere one mynde diuerſe contrary verely fearyng longe admoniſhed diligently woulde haue bene preſent counſell ſelues followed aduiſe herein matter opinion might haue bene brought ende wyſhed upon parte whiche concerneth publique peace doe nowe conſulte becauſe thought diſpatched ſhort tyme againe bicauſe ſtate country requyred preſence muche turkes ſemed attempte new matter threaten ſore notwithſtanding treateth peace moreouer muche nothing done determined pourpoſe vnleſſe preſent ſelues therfore thinketh good counſell differred tyll tyme nowe decree made maner muche abſence prynces nothynge determined agreed treatie differed tyll nexte aſſemblee begynnynge whereof made regenſburge aboute kalendes marche yeare followyng prince ſelues bee preſent may together emperour hym determine ordeine thoſe thynges wherof haue nowe conſulted hereafter ſhall doe meane ſeaſon pacification paſſawe remayne full ſtrength muche conteyneth fyrſt counſell empyre ſhould treated whether generall prouinciall counſell germany el conferrence learned men cauſe religion ought appeaſed secondly thynge done common coū ſel al ſtates without ordinary power themperour therfore whiche loueth peace concorde hath determined next aſſemblee exhibitie certen booke compiled reconciling ſuche matter controuerſie none intrapping made ende diſcorde ſhuld growe offence might mitigated moreouer thintent ſelues may better determine whether meane declared boke diſſention may taken vp whether way muſt ſought therfore requireth take proroging good part next counſell would come ſelues example cō mon welthe ſake hath bene nowe ſo longe tyme prouinces hath choſen place regenſpurge bicauſe iminēt daūger turke may depart far owne countrie let aduertiſe therfore wil herein ende may certen matter ſhall forſlowed vaine expectation better part time paſſe away hath heretofore oftener one theſe requeſtes hearde moſt part prince thought good ſhould departe peace confirmed al germany great expectation matter ſince agree nowe better voyces euer time beſeche woulde make ende departure intent verely next aſſemblee might ſo muche expedicion take order determine turkiſhe matter yet remained touching boke wold exhibite many ſayde howe like would come chaunced boke whiche ſeuen yeares paſte wrytten alſo religion ſet forth yet freſhe memory rayling wordes taunted ſet forth priuileged emperour haue made cōcorde aroſe occaſions therof many offence diſſentions ferdinando heard theſe ambaſſadours eight kalendes september daye kalendes ſame moneth declareth opinion wrytinges partes exhibited amongeſt matter chief poinct concerneth byſhops caſe chaunge religion ſhould forgo office biſhops whiche chaunge religion ſhuld loſe promotion goodes alſo wyll many wordes moueth proteſtauntes would aſſente ſame cōdition ſayth taketh nothing doth byſhop forſaketh order departeth olde religion benefice promotiōs may neuertheleſſe remaine ſame ſtate wherin inſtituted whiche thinge agreable ciuile lawe alſo lawes empire pacification paſſawe whiche ſayeth playne wordes thoſe whiche followe olde religion well ſtate eccleſiaſticall ciuile moleſted religion ceremony goodes poſſeſſions rightes priuileges ſhould inioye theſe thinges quietly without interruption man ſe therfore condition denied whiche apperteineth ende ſpake may inioye thinges quietly whiche dede ſhould releaſe condition ſo ſhould come paſſe ſuche happely forſake relinquiſhe holy order auncient religion would kepe ſtyll neuertheleſſe office goodes poſſeſſions neyther ſhould lawefull college meane time trie lawe caſe inconuenience wil come alſo betwene byſhop wyll great good wyll reaſon according lawes foundation mete perſones ſhould gouerne rule holy office againſt thoſe lawes relinquiſhe ſtate thā collegers ſhould remoue forſee ſame reuolting hurt alone certenly demaunde ought refuſed wherfore exhorte agayne agayne contende herein amonges thinges ought conſider preſcribe vnto meane waye kept gouerning ſuche office college benefice ſelues haue vſurped yet done miniſters church dominion whiche breake lawes ſet forth neglecte dutie lyke ſhould greuouſly euyll taken caſe would haue ſuche miniſters forſake impugne religion reteyned ſhould muche greuouſe vnto thē gouernment poſſeſſion landes goodes ſhould left vnto whiche ſhould forſake impugne religiō thing myght hereof loked debate ſtrife contention foundation therfore thinge nowe hande witte peace ſelfe meane ſhould vtterly taken away eight daye aunſwere howe intent preſcribe clergie herein muche leſſe holy gouernmentes ſhould brought deſolation nature altered ſhould made ciuile prophane wear ignoraūt ſay ſome part empire conſiſteth theſe matter poſſeſſions whiche couet deminiſhe decaye al meanes mainteyne would haue pleaſed v right well queſtion neuer bene moued haue ſtande decree fourmer yeares made norinberge regenſpurg spiers whiche include peace al parteners cō feſſion auſpurge firſt dede ambaſſadours thre archebyſhops electours wittely conſider alſo doubte began moued others went vnto ſyde firſt moued queſtion peraduenture ſome cauſe ſo doe hath inſued therof nowe appereth let chaunced way al ye matter opiniō ben brought good ende ſhould admitte cōdicion wer godly weighty cauſes euery man doeth eaſely perceiue howe muche ſhould contempte hinderaunce religion ſhould permitte ſuche imbrace ſame ſhould diſplaced depriued honour dignitie accompted nomber heretikes firſt foundation college vice haue crept ſince wyl paſſe ouer ſilence ſuppoſe many ſame ſtatutes againſt religion aſſente none eccleſiaſticall ſtate ſhould religion whiche true chriſten religion profeſſe doubtles ſmal offence ſame facte ſhould cōdemne wicked vnworthy ſtate priſtes whiche ought chiefly ſet forth religion ſeing thus moſte mightie kyng beſeche waye theſe thinges mynde authoritie haue emperour would ſuffer part omitted maketh aunſwere nothynge graunted ſayeth moreouer thoſe thinges nowe permitted ſo many yeares could neuer obteined therfore let haue conſideration hereof el ſhall fayne departe without thing finiſhed whiche ſo come paſſe incōuenience ariſe therof cauſe blame ſhuld layde either ye emperour ſo quietly patiently hath handled matter hitherto hath remayned whiche nowe defer longer therfore geueth ten dayes meane time may wryte theſe thinges home prince make direct anſwer daye came theſe men omitted diligence al others prouided concerning religiō might preſcribe meaſure herein ye king emperour doe aſſent eſpecially ſince king alſo releaſed certen thinges hereafter ſhalbe ſhewed therfore ſeuenth kalendes october decree made red openly maner effect doctrine decrewher religiō frely permit men proteſtauntes faith religion emperour king ferdinando reſidue prince ſtates ſhall hurte man whole empire wyſe neither ſhall compell man forſake religion ceremony lawes whiche dominion proteſtauntes haue already ordeined hereafter ſhall ordeyne commaundemētes meane yet contemne ſame permitte religion free alſo goodes faculty cuſtomes poſſeſſion rightes ſo peaceably may inioy controuerſie alſo religion appeaſed none godly frendly quiet meanes like caſe ſhall confeſſion auſpurg demeane ſelues towardes emperour king ferdinando reſt prince ſtates addicte olde religion well ſacred ciuile towardes whole ſtate eccleſiaſtical college ſame whether ſo euer ſhal finally remoue dwel ſo miniſterie well ordered beneath ſhall ſayde theſe ſhal permitte religion lawes ceremony poſſeſſions cuſtomes rightes frely neither meane hinder may quietly inioye ſo euer diſpleaſure ſtrife ſhall ariſe determined either ſyde cuſtome lawes empire ſuche neyther religiō compryſed peace archebyſhop byſhop prelate eccleſiaſtical perſone ſhall reuolte olde religion ſhall immediatly eccleſiaſtical perſon chaungeth religion ſhalbe depriued departe byſhoprike office benefice alſo proſites receiueth therof ſhall lawfull free college thoſe whome ſame thing ſhal ryght cuſtome apperteyne choſe ſubſtitute place whiche olde religion intent ryghtes foundation election preſentation confirmation ſuch like may remayne whole quiet poſſeſſion goodes yet ſo nothinge hereby taken away foreſayde reconcilement religion ſhalbe bicauſe diuerſe ſtates empire progenitours haue taken certen eccleſiaſticall gouernementes abbey ſuche like goodes church haue diſpoſed ſame miniſters church vpō ſcholes church goodes al cō trouerſies ar taken away good vſes ſhal troubled ſame ſewed law therfore ſuch goodes wit thoſe belōg ſtates thempire others ſubiecte thempire poſſeſſion wherof clergie time pacification paſſawe alſo ſhall remayne cōpriſed peace neyther ſhall lawfull iudges chamber imperiall graunte proces decree thing againſt vſurpinge ſame goodes eccleſiaſtical iuriſdiction exerciſed take place againſt proteſtaūtes religiō faith eccleſiaſticall lawes ſhall exerciſed againſt ye proteſtauntes rightes lawes eccleſiaſticall miniſterie remayne ſuſpence ſtayed moleſte nothing tyll controuerſie throughly ended taken away al matter concerne religion ceremony lawes miniſterie let force exerciſed olde cuſtome lawe againe goodes cuſtomes rightes remaine whole ſtate eccleſiaſticall yet ſo whoſe iuriſdictiō ſuch goodes loſe part politicke law cōtention religion moreouer yt theſe ſelfſame goodes neceſſary miniſteries churche pariſhes ſcholes almouſes hoſpitalles poore ſicke people founded time paſt ye ſo alſo eſtabliſhed mainteined without reſpect religiō whoſe vſe almouſe ſuſtenaūce imployed fortune ſtrife contention ariſe reaſon ſuſtenaūce yt meaſure therof yt bi cōſent ye partes arbitrers choſen viewing ye thing within ye ſpace half yeare ſhall determine make eſtimate howe much ought decided beſtowed vpon ſuche vſes miniſteries meane ſeaſon til matter decided yt thet whoſe part geue ſuche ayde moleſted poſſeſſion loke wont geue beſtowe tymes paſt let thē geue alſo till matter determined october nouember parliament holden englande many ſuppoſed would haue treated parliamēt england coronation king philip nothing propoūided quene motioned reſtoring abbey landes muche pope vrged ſame many noble men gentleman doe poſſeſſe thē wherfore nothing could brought paſſe quene ſelfe dede whiche al ſhe coulde reſtored clergie firſt fruictes tēthes benefice tyme parliamēt certen biting libelles libelles ſtrowed london ſowen abroade london wherin ſome thinges whet people againſt spaniardes ſome yt might haue withdrawen quenes minde frō king philip inquiſition made nothing could tried end parliament byſhop wincheſter chauncelour died byſhop wincheſter dieth dropſie whoſe place ſubſtituted doctour heth archebiſhop yorke bene tymes paſt archebyſhop cantorbury germany thought rightly pure doctrine ye none nouēber wife iohn wife iohn friderick dieth friderick lantgraues daughter died whoſe mariage ſpokē fraūces uenerie duke ueniſe handled ſelfe well vytayling citie ſet france uenery diſplaced priuate profit thā publique diſplaced time themperour geuen ouer gouernmēt coūtries philip ſonne ſendeth ambaſſadours chief prince city germany ſignified thē yt ſame ambaſſad prince germany offereth thē good wil amitie ſame time alſo ye ambaſſadours king ferdinādo ſollicited prince germany much moſte preſent daūger hanged euer turke required al tranſyluania geuē coūtrie nature moſt ſtrōg fertile ful horſemē wold day appointed preſent ſelues coūſel empire conſulte common wealth helde alſo aſſemble auſtriche coūſel ſubiectes ſame cauſe yt whiche aſſemblee auſtriche required religiō might permitted thē fre king differred coūſel thempire ſhould next regenſpurg alſo toke order ſhuld uienne ides ianuary next yere marque marignane diyng millan cardinall trent ſent lumbardy emperour king philip ſonne haue gouernment duke alba made viceroy naples chriſtmas day pope maner createth newe cardinalles amongeſt others iohn gropper counſellour archebyſhop collon whome often mention made fourmer bokes alſo iohn gropper cardin reinold poole cardinall deacon made prieſt call began ſinge maſſe law full deacon pope lawe beginning moneth ianuary throughout saxonie meiſſen boheme horrible tempeſtes thondering lightening thonderboltes whiche dyd muche harme euery eſpecially church ſame moneth uirodure whiche towne swicerlande two mile zuricke night ſuppertyme fyre burſting one towres church cracked ſo men came running quēch came thither ther flame twyſe happened one tyme witte fourth daye ſame moneth xiiii daye certen men townes heluetia moued pope go afterwardes rome without great ſuſpicion many kyng philippe beginning newe gouernmēt whiche receiued father great pompe ſolemnitie xviii day ianuary entreth andwerpe chief towne coūtrey meane tyme great king philip entreth andwerpe perſecution burning englande ides ianuary thābaſſadours prouinces auſtriche aſſemble uienne appointed king oratiō graue long declareth great daū ger ſtode turke iminent therfore doth admoniſh ſo ſone may would helpe hym men mony great outragiouſe crueltie might repreſſed yt lower partes auſtriche ſaye thei cōmaunded thei ſhuld treate thambaſſadours auſtrtche require kynge ferdinando true religiō may permitted firſt religion therfore recite haue done ſelfſame cauſe ye ſpace xiiii yeares oft haue intreated put vp ſupplicatiōs maner proclamation hath ſet forth contrary expectatiō muche hitherto ſay al coūſelles againſt ye turke taken vaine yet could repreſſed alſo violence hath ſo farre proceded hauing taken hongary slauonie many townes caſtels fortes hangeth ouer yt neckes v doubtles thought manifeſt vengeaunce god whiche plageth v ſinne afflicteth v amende life ſo dede afflicteth v vnleſſe worde receiued amendement life followe loſſe lyfe goodes alſo eternall ſaluation like inſue although whole worlde toke armure againſt ennemie yet ſo long ſhall remayne ſtate lyfe hope victory rather deſtruction ſlaughter euident haue chaunced ſome tyme moſte floriſhynge kyngdomes treated ſame matter alſo laſte aſſemblee prayed myght compelled thyng againſt conſcience referred matter counſell regenſpurg may cōſider moſt mightie king howe greuouſe whiche thyrſte health ſoules differred tyme vncertē meane time mynde angwiſhe angwyſhe perplexitie many thouſandes mē ende life doubtles worde god whiche sauiour ieſus chriſte opened v ſhould rule whiche church ought followe caſe thing cōtrary god worde haue crept although grounded great antiquitie muſt reiected god wilbe honored worſhipped ſelfe preſcribeth cōmaundeth men wene fayne horrible greuous plage reuengeth neglecting cōmaundemēt obſeruation mēs tradition empire fourmer time ſhewe alſo freſhe domeſticall calamity people next v declare therfore moſte diligēt ſearche appereth v none remedy thoſe manifeſt errours deprauations brought long ſince churche caſte away pure doctrine may receiued frely preached gether ſuche adminiſtration sacramentes chriſt ſelfe inſtitute departe tourne away worde god ſo manifeſt ſo plaine may haue ofte ſhewed tymes firſte muſt ſeke kingdome god whiche done god aſſiſteth v ſpirite gouerneth counſelles doinges ende therfore would deliuer v al theſe daungers would counſeller warre enſeigne bearer may aſſiſte v battel diſcomfite thennemies force moſte humble earneſt wyſe beſeche highnes euen death chriſte ſaluation laſt iudgement ſhall abyde muche thing apperteineth perpetuall felicitie child al realme ſpotted ſecte may leaue permiſſion remaine pure ſincere religion vntyll free generall counſell may inioye ſame benefite peace whiche laſte aſſemblee empyre haue made fellowes confeſſion auſpurge ſeyng baptized chriſte beſeche state condicion worſe nother woulde denye v thynge whiche haue graunted diuerſe prouinces woulde call thoſe proclamation ſette forth concerning religion woulde delyuer v thys carefulnes wherwith bounde moreouer beſeche woulde ſet forth proclamation miniſters church teache wrytinges prophetes apoſtels ſame maner ſaid doe miniſter sacramentes moleſted yet ſuche ſchomaiſters neither impriſoned baniſhed ſhall pleade cauſe lawful iudge thus truſt wil extreame daunger doubt god rewarde ſame moſte aboundantly alſo ſtates empire ſende ayde haue done hitherto likewiſe behinde dutie moſte willing mindes beſtowe geue ſo euer ſhall apperteine cōmon defence preſeruation coūtrie wil throughly ſatiſfie demaūdes ſo muche ſhall lie power habilitie ſelfſame time ambaſſadours themperour truce takē betwene emperour kynge fraunce frenche king met controuerſie coulde finiſhed peace fift day moneth february take truce fiue yeares sea lande well flaunders thoſe partes alſo italy place euery one kepeth poſſeſſion thoſe thinges whiche hath gotten tyme war themperour excepteth exile naples scicilie compriſeth pope firſt place doth alſo frenche king afterward euery mā frendes ally maner ſame truce long king cauſed proclamed throughout fraunce metz alſo emperour ſomwhat later coū try brute went pope toke ſnuffe truce made went afterwarde perſwade frenche king breake ſame others thought cōtrariwiſe made chiefly aduiſe yt might make warre againſt lutherians touching priſoners nothinge could concluded truce amongeſt whome chiefeſt duke areſcot bourgunnion monmoraūce coneſtables eldeſt ſonne takē thre yeres terwin auſtriche ſayde wiſe anſwer king ferdinando yt ambaſſa houſe auſtriche day kalendes february put vp ſupplication king ferdinando wryting king eight day aunſwereth ſpeaking firſt good wyll towardes common wealth common calamitie miſerie time god wrath whileſt conſider ſaieth way mine owne ſtate place diligently whileſt thinke howe haue euer yought hitherto followed preceptes chriſten catholique churche maner progenitours whome haue receiued religion meaneth emper sigiſmonde burnte iohn huſſe diſcipline deliuered hand ſurely finde yt may aſſent whiche require would gladly gratifie people ſee lawful ſhould preiudiciall chriſte church ſhoulde alter lawes ſame holſome decree pleaſure muſt rather heare chriſt cōmaū deth beit much know long experiēce occaſion great euils bitter contention religion bringeth haue doubtles brother yt emperour bene theſe many yeares wholy occupied might come compoſition therfore hath matter bene attēpted many counſels empyre certein conference learned men mediation hath bene begon twyſe counſell trent treatie came good effect doubtles imputed v neither vnknowen diuiſes craftes matter hindered require pure doctrine benefite peace newly made religion may graūted like heretofore haue kept backe man frō true religion ſo alſo hereafter well compriſed ſame peace people prince meaning ſame decree people ſhall followe religion prince permitted temporall prince choſe whether religiō people ought content choiſe prince yet ſo al ſuch ſhal like religion whiche prince hath choſen may haue fre libertie ſell haue go dwell place without hinderaunce blemiſhe eſtimation whiche ſeing ſo dutie perſeuer olde catholique religion profeſſe goſpel ſhould purely taught expoſition apoſtels martyr father whiche churche hath receiued neuer againſt lordes ſupper
